From kurt at kurt-harlan.net  Sat Feb  1 08:31:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] MandrakeSoft update

Following is an update on the Mandrake situation in case some of you haven't
heard . . .

Financial Corner
----------------------------------------
On January 27th, 2003, confirmation was received from a French
Commercial Court that MandrakeSoft had been granted a six-month
observation & protection period to establish a business continuation
plan. MandrakeSoft welcomes this latest news as a positive step toward
achieving solid restructuring and profitability.

Please see the following announcement for additional details:
http://www.mandrakesoft.com/company/press/briefs?n=/mandrakesoft/news/2406&l
g=en


Kurt




From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Sat Feb  1 08:58:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Sat Feb  1 08:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
References: <mailman.1044032122.2136.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86n0lhz1yc.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Alice" == Alice Corbin <ali at axian.com> writes:

Alice> I'm thinking about getting a broadband connection to the internet
Alice> and am looking for advice.

I've been using an ATT cable modem for a couple of years now.  Works
great.  Then again, I don't need high upload speeds or a server.  (I
rent server space at a professional co-lo.)  My total downtime is less
than 8 hours in two years.

Alice> I'm thinking along the lines of a hub/firewall in the basement,
Alice> with cables running up to the first and second floors.

Alice> I'm not too thrilled with either ATT or Qwest, but they seem to be
Alice> the only games in town.  But I'm really apprehensive about the
Alice> wiring.  I live in a 1920's wood-frame house, with gobs of windows 
Alice> and blown-in insulation.

Alice> Any suggestions?

Yes, get a wireless hub.  If it's all wood frame, you should have no
problems going through the wood up two stories.  Linksys makes a nice
firewall/NAT-router/wireless unit for somewhere under $150, if I
recall.  And then you'd need wireless adaptors for each unit to be
attached... USB/802.11b can be as cheap as $60 (I'm using one on my
TiVo).

--

over a decade ago.  "late", ahem.

Please to not be dissing Perl.

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Sat Feb  1 08:58:09 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Sat Feb  1 08:58:09 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
References: <mailman.1043933000.32227.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86u1fq638t.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Felix" == Felix Lee <felix.1 at canids.net> writes:

Felix> Steven Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com>:
>> I agree, Perl is a really good choice to promote the learning of good
>> programming habits.

Felix> ummmm... no.  Perl encourages sloppy programming.  it's far
Felix> too irregular and has too much magic behavior.

Felix> simple example.  this:

Felix>     while (my $line = <IN>) { ... }

Felix> does not do the same thing as this:

Felix>     sub in { return <IN>; }
Felix>     while (my $line = in ()) { ... }

You're being pedantic.  The only difference between the two
is that the second one will stop one line early if the last
line is "0" without a newline.

That's such a rare case that Perl programmers didn't worry about it
for 11 years of Perl's existence.

Please to not be pulling up red herrings.  Thank you.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Sat Feb  1 08:58:11 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Sat Feb  1 08:58:11 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
References: <mailman.1043992762.7928.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86isw521yg.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Felix" == Felix Lee <felix.1 at canids.net> writes:

Felix> David Fleck <dcf at aracnet.com>:
>> > simple example.  this:
>> >     while (my $line = <IN>) { ... }
>> > does not do the same thing as this:
>> >     sub in { return <IN>; }
>> >     while (my $line = in ()) { ... }
>> > and there's no warning for that.
>> 
>> But I think you're wrong - the two examples above do the exact same thing.

Felix> nope.  the first loop will stop when IN hits eof or error.
Felix> the second loop can stop before that.  discovering the place
Felix> this is explained in the perl man pages is left as an
Felix> exercise to the reader.

OK, now I call your bluff.  I've said repeatedly here that
except for the case where you have a file ending in a character
zero not followed by a newline, THESE TWO LOOPS DO THE SAME THING.

And if you wrote them in the manner recommended by manpages
before the DWIMming logic was added, they'd do the *exact* same thing:

while (defined (my $line = <IN>)) { ... }

sub in { return <IN> } while (defined (my $line = in())) { ... }

There.  Those do *exactly* the same thing.  And in fact, between Perl
4 and Perl 5.004, so did the two loops you posted.  5.004 was made
smarter to insert the "defined" that everyone kept forgetting to put
in, so that's the ONLY REASON they do something different now.  To
help YOU in the common case.

Gah.

Please stop lying.  I find you with a much stronger hidden agenda now.

--

Eric> I'm a "professional" C/C++/Java programmer who dabbles in perl cgi
Eric> scripts and whose friends have been urging him to learn PHP.  In
Eric> addition, I have a close friend and a 10-year-old daughter, both very
Eric> bright but neither with any programming experience, who want to "learn
Eric> to program."

See www.squeakland.org

Learn Smalltalk, from the guys who invented it, so that you can
learn a *proper* OO language.  And there's lots of pretty moving
thingies in the first five minutes of exposure.  Keeps the kids
interested.

Smalltalk - if you say you know OO but haven't seen Smalltalk, you
don't know OO yet. :) Hint: Java, C++, Python, Perl are *not* true OO
languages... see how the granddaddy did it.

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Sat Feb  1 08:58:22 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Sat Feb  1 08:58:22 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
References: <20030129160245.E1591@tpol.peak.org> <mailman.1044047242.14803.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86wukkt233.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Mark" == Mark Roberts <mark at ecl.us> writes:

Mark> As for perl I havn't seen much in the way of IDE's either.

For all platforms, there's the integrated Emacs support in the
built-in perl debugger that puts the source code in one Emacs window,
the debug management in another, and the stdin/stdout of the process
in a third.

For Windows, Activestate has a $99 product that has lots of
clicky-tracey things going on.

Mark> Being able to set breakpoints, single step and check variables
Mark> interactively can be the quickest way to learn what your code is doing. 
Mark> Nothing like the ease of learning in an integrated edit, compile, go
Mark> environment.

Yes, this is one big problem if your only access to something like PHP
is as a web browser response.  It's tough enough getting a CGI "hello world"
app running under a server... trying to debug your PHP web app would be
10 times worse.

Especially for a beginner.

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Sat Feb  1 08:59:17 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Sat Feb  1 08:59:17 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
References: <200301301320.h0UDKFF05002@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org> <mailman.1043981961.1639.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86el6u2eoh.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "David" == David Fleck <dcf at aracnet.com> writes:

>> simple example.  this:
>> 
>> while (my $line = <IN>) { ... }
>> 
>> does not do the same thing as this:
>> 
>> sub in { return <IN>; }
>> while (my $line = in ()) { ... }
>> 
>> and there's no warning for that.

David> But I think you're wrong - the two examples above do the exact same thing.

Not exactly.  Recent Perls turn the first one into:

  while (defined (my $line = <IN>) ) { ... }

which protects against the "last line is digit 0 without a newline"
problem.  I said this already in a previous post.

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Sat Feb  1 09:49:01 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Sat Feb  1 09:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <20030131085434.C6779@zaphod.axian.com>
Message-ID: <20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com>

Alice,

I've had AT&T cable since it was @home, and I think I
was the first guy in Oregon City to have it, as I kept
calling them weekly.

I have been very happy with the service. For the two
or three years that it was @home, downtime was very
rare: I think it was down once for a half day, then
down a couple times for a couple hours, which I think
is pretty good for two or three years.

When it switched to AT&T, I was down for about a day.
Others were down for a week or more though. I was up
because I was set statically, but others I knew were
down because they were set dynamically and AT&T seemed
to be having problems with DHCP.

Since then (a year ago) I think I've had one downtime
of a couple hours.

Connection is really fast. When it was @home, it was
2.3 mbit/sec down, but sending was capped at 128k,
which was a bit slow for me.

When it switched to AT&T, now it's 1.9 mbit down, but
they bumped uploads to 256k, which was a nice
improvement.

Anyway, our service is $45/month, plus 3 or 4 dollars
tax.

Most people I know that have DSL have 256k/256k, or
possibly 384k/384k. Most of them are pretty happy with
their service too, though their download speeds are
only a fraction of cable.

One argument against cable is that it's "share" with
your neighbors. I don't know how many people my
connection is shared with, but I pretty much always
download at full speed from decent servers (190
k/sec), even during peak times, so for me this has
been a non-issue. My connection it work is a 384k/384k
DSL, and it always seems really slow, downloading
around 35k/sec max.

-Scott

Also worth noting: the Oregon Dept. of Revenue has fill-in-PDF 
versions of this year's state income tax forms:

  http://www.dor.state.or.us/formspit.html#2002

And before you go thinking that the DOR web admins have a sense of 
humor (formspit :-), note that it stands for 'FORMS: Personal Income 
Tax,' and there's also formscorp, formsdry (for dry cleaners; how 
wierd is that?), formspet (for the petroleum industry), etc.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Sat Feb  1 13:25:03 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Feb  1 13:25:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Email File Uploading
Message-ID: <1044134661.1240.38.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

I was just thinking about a project, how to improve on it, and have come
up with an idea...

The project is accepting small image files from folks, most easily via
email, then posting them on to the web.  The small image files would be
no bigger than 10 or 15KB in size....

Does such a system exist which would easily allow me to do this?  That
is, procmail would deliver the message, then this *thing* would take
just the attachment from the message and move it into another
directory?  That other folder could then be rsync'd with somebody who
has more bandwidth via a cron job or something....

But does anybody know of such a thing that will screen emails to make
sure they are under 20KB in size, then decode them, just putting the
attachment into a seperate directory?

This is all very preliminary, I'd just like to not re-invent the wheel
if at all possible... I would think such a thing should be possible with
procmail, some mime utilities, and some fancy bash scripting....

Rob




From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Feb  1 13:33:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat Feb  1 13:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Email File Uploading
In-Reply-To: <1044134661.1240.38.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
References: <1044134661.1240.38.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302011331400.30515@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 1 Feb 2003, AthlonRob wrote:
> But does anybody know of such a thing that will screen emails to make
> sure they are under 20KB in size, then decode them, just putting the
> attachment into a seperate directory?
>
> This is all very preliminary, I'd just like to not re-invent the wheel
> if at all possible... I would think such a thing should be possible with
> procmail, some mime utilities, and some fancy bash scripting....

Uh... aren't you making this kind difficult for no reason?

You could just pipe the mails to a script that runs uudecode or munpack
and puts the file in /tmp and then only moves it if the size is alright
and sends a reply mail if it's too big (or whatever you need to do).

J.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Feb  1 13:37:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Tax Preparation Software - Free Online
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302011201300.32491-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

> Tax,' and there's also formscorp, formsdry (for dry cleaners; how

  Dry cleaners need separate forms so the information doesn't evaporate too
quickly. Also, the forms cannot contain any VOCs[1] or they get in trouble
with DEQ and EPA.

> > procmail, some mime utilities, and some fancy bash scripting....
> 
> Uh... aren't you making this kind difficult for no reason?
>

easier...

will be.... heh.  :-)

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Sat Feb  1 19:49:02 2003
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Sat Feb  1 19:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rat off a Sinking Ship?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301310851050.13201-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301310851050.13201-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <200302011948.54716.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

On Friday January 31, 2003 09:01, David Mandel wrote:
> On Thu, 23 Jan 2003, Kyle Hayes wrote:
>
> ...
>
> > However, my experience with 8.1 hasn't been so good.  For reasons
> > unclear to me Mozilla insists on printing everything in A4 size. 
> > Given that I don't have any A4 paper around, this makes it a little
> > frustrating.  Other things print fine in Letter size.
>
> I wouldn't know.  I'm still using SuSE 8.0.  Need to get a copy of 8.1,
> but I'm not in a hurry.  Might wait for 8.2.

I'm not sure what the next one will be called.  The whole UnitedLinux thing 
is confusing the issue.  I don't know if 8.2 will be based on UnitedLinux 
(since that is just SuSE, there won't be much difference).

> > > SuSE includes yast and yast2 which are nice admin tools, but they
> > > are not Open Source.  SuSE owns these and seems to use them to
> > > restrict redistribution of their complete distribution.
> >
> > It happens that there's a lot of history here.   The following was
> > explained to me by one of the former SuSE Germany employees I once
> > met.
>
> I understand SuSE's position; especially after having tryed to make
> a commercial distribution for MicroSharp called Netule.  I truely wanted
> to totally Open Source everything, but they were reluctant for very
> good reasons.  The biggest problem we had was that we were spending
> significant resources building a good distribution (actually 3 special
> purpose distributions), but weren't in a good position to make money
> on auxilary goods and services.  This made it very difficult.

It is.  I suspect that Red Hat purchased companies like Cygnus to jump 
start the revenue flow from services.  Smart move if that's what they were 
doing.

> I would actually like to try doing another speciality distribution, but
> this time I would Open Source it completely from day one and combine
> it with a book so one could get it into book stores.  Altho one
> wouldn't get rich doing this, it might get the distribution enough
> attention that one could use it to sell installation and other services
> from the distros web site.

I think that building a specialty distro is getting harder than it was.  As 
packages mature and integrate, it is going to become more difficult to 
trim off what you don't want.  If you stay with binary packages at least.  
I think that the next real wave of specialty distros will probably emerge 
from the various source-based distros.

I believe that several trends support this opinion.  First, computers are 
getting faster and faster so that compile time is dropping into the realm 
of the supportable (it's still too long, but it is getting much better).  
Second, the upstream packages are getting more sophisticated about 
integrating with other software on the system.  Have GNOME? Then the Gtk 
version will be built.  Have KDE? Then the Qt version will be built.  
Third, the upstream packages are starting to standarize on use of 
autoconf, standard build arguments and behavior, and use of LSB-compatible 
defaults.

The first time I built the Linux kernel, it was on some sort of 486 machine 
and the build took many hours (8? I can't remember).  Now, I've got an 
elderly P-II system and the kernel only takes a few minutes to build.  
Another speed up of the same magnitude and the worst packages (OpenOffice 
comes to mind) will be buildable in a few minutes.  Obviously things are 
not this simple, but I think the trends hold.

Best,
Kyle




From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Feb  1 21:06:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat Feb  1 21:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ppp multi-user demand dial
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302012059530.1758@shaft.bitmine.net>

Hi.

I haven't had a ppp connection in ages and I've never had to set up PPP
for anybody who wasn't pretty savvy from the start.

So, here's my situation.

There's this box at a friends' that is used by everyone in the house.
They've got a dial-up account that they want to use through this machine.

So what (non-KDE) graphical tools are run as regular users for connecting
when they need internet?  Disconnect?

I need a tool that's simple and dockable and times out after a period of
disuse and doesn't require setup for each user (i.e., a new user can be
created in a month and it'll just work for them).

Any pointers accepted.
J.

From beattie at beattie-home.net  Sat Feb  1 22:26:02 2003
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: Sat Feb  1 22:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ppp multi-user demand dial
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302012059530.1758@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302012059530.1758@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1044167102.24327.744.camel@coyote.pdx.beattie-home.net>

On Sat, 2003-02-01 at 21:05, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> Hi.
> 
> I haven't had a ppp connection in ages and I've never had to set up PPP
> for anybody who wasn't pretty savvy from the start.
> 
> So, here's my situation.
> 
> There's this box at a friends' that is used by everyone in the house.
> They've got a dial-up account that they want to use through this machine.
> 
> So what (non-KDE) graphical tools are run as regular users for connecting
> when they need internet?  Disconnect?
> 
> I need a tool that's simple and dockable and times out after a period of
> disuse and doesn't require setup for each user (i.e., a new user can be
> created in a month and it'll just work for them).

You should be able to set it up so it dials on demans, i.e. when you try
to use the internet, it will dial out and if the link is idle for a
specific amount of time it will drop it.  How you do thi will depend on
what distro you use

> 
> Any pointers accepted.
> J.

From krisa at subtend.net  Sat Feb  1 23:34:02 2003
From: krisa at subtend.net (Kris)
Date: Sat Feb  1 23:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <20030202070004.A8185C5CF@max.seansdomain.org>
References: <20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com> <20030202070004.A8185C5CF@max.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <20030202073318.GA27181@subtend.net>

On Sat, Feb 01, 2003 at 10:59:57PM -0800, Sean Whitney wrote:
> This is a marketing myth.  Cable you share with your neighbor before
> the router, DSL you share with your neighbor after the DSLAM, what's
> the difference?

There are a couple things DSL has over cable (and vice versa).  Security
is a bit less on a cable network.

The primary reason I prefer DSL is freedom of ISP.  This is very
important for competition and keeping service reliable and cheap
(regardless of the failure of the LEC's to cooperate in some
situations).

Comparing the options, in the last couple years Qwest has seemed to pull
ahead of Verizon with bandwidth choices and ease of moving ISP's.  They
did screw their customers by moving everyone to MSN a while back.

When cable will allow me to say "your IP service sucks, please move my
traffic to <x> local ISP", then I will consider them a competitor for my
business, even if they are faster than DSL in some cases (downstream).

Additionally, though they all suck, DSL user agreements seem to play a
bit nicer than those with AT&T.  I do not want to be thrown in jail for
putting up a PTP node.

-- 
I'm just a packet pusher.

> The primary reason I prefer DSL is freedom of ISP.  This is very
> important for competition and keeping service reliable and cheap
> (regardless of the failure of the LEC's to cooperate in some

Exactly, at least with the Internet connection you can choose your
provider. Competition is the very core of effective markets.

I would never in a million years get cable access. Hell, I don't even have
cable television and will not get it unless a competitive system develops.
As it stands I will not be overcharged by monopolies.

Everyone knows about Tacoma? http://www.click-network.com/welcome.htm

http://www.click-network.com/news/PR_M.HTM
December 1, 1999

Click! Network and local Internet service provider make history

Tacoma Power?s Click! Network will make history December 1 as the first
telecommunications company in the United States that will give multiple
Internet service providers (ISPs) the ability to provide high- speed Internet
cable modem access to customers over a cable network.


January 1, 1999

Click! Network connects customers in the east area of Tacoma to cable TV!
Customers in the east area of Tacoma are the next lucky citizens to have a
choice in their cable TV provider. 


July 17, 1998

Tacoma residents may soon have another choice when it comes to choosing who
will provide cable television services to their homes and businesses. The
Tacoma City Council on July 21 will consider a 10- year agreement that allows
Tacoma Power?s Click! Network to offer cable television services to city
residents.  


Thank you
Russell

Feb  1 23:48:26 localhost kernel: ide-floppy driver 0.99.newide
then;
Feb  1 23:48:02 localhost updfstab: unexpected file type for /dev/fd0
Feb  1 23:48:02 localhost kudzu: Updating /etc/fstab failed

and if I try; 
 mount /dev/fd0
mount: /dev/fd0 is not a block device (maybe try `-o loop'?)

and /etc/fstab is;
defaults        0 0
/dev/cdrom1             /mnt/cdrom1            
iso9660noauto,owner,kudzu,ro 0 0
/dev/fd0                /mnt/floppy             auto   
noauto,owner,kudzu 0 0
 and the floppy works in another machine, what does it all mean? Is life
complicated and I'm not meant to understand or is life simple and I
don't have the capacity to comprhend?

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Sun Feb  2 08:25:02 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sun Feb  2 08:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] floppy problem
In-Reply-To: <1044201704.1377.14.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1044201704.1377.14.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <E18fMvL-0000yP-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

If it is an LS-120 then the /dev/fd0 isn't correct. Depending where on the IDE
bus the drive is, it will be /dev/hdX. My guess, if you have an IDE hard drive
based box; the hard drive will be hda, the CDR will be hdc, and the ide-loppy
will be hdd. 

If you can, you should move the ide-floppy to its own channel because it is a
slow device. Any faster drive, 66, 100, 133 MHz device on the same channel,
will have to run at 33MHz.

Thank you
Russell

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Sun Feb  2 09:05:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Sun Feb  2 09:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0302012336340.2887-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20030202170416.59256.qmail@web40809.mail.yahoo.com>

I understand your sentiment, I too believe competition
is very important to good service and price. In the
case of AT&T's cable modems, it is true that they are
the only choice for cable, but they do have
competition: DSL. Right now I am staying with AT&T
because they are several times faster for downloads
than DSL, and it's cheaper. Also, I have been very
happy with the product: very little downtime, always
fast and stable, etc.

They are not a broadband monopoly, because if they
decide to raise their prices too high, or if their
quality diminishes, I can switch to DSL.

One other reason that I would switch to DSL: at the
moment, my IP address is technically dynamic, but they
could change my IP address if they wanted to. They
have only done this once in a year, but if it began
happening often, I would switch to DSL because I like
to run a web server, and to log in remotely through
ssh, etc, and would want a static IP.

-Scott

From sean at fork.com  Sun Feb  2 10:03:02 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Sun Feb  2 10:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <20030202073318.GA27181@subtend.net>
References: <20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com> <20030202070004.A8185C5CF@max.seansdomain.org> <20030202073318.GA27181@subtend.net>
Message-ID: <20030202180252.C314FC5CF@max.seansdomain.org>

I work for a cable company (but have DSL, because of the AUP and upstream 
speed) and I have seen some interesting developments recently.  We're moving 
to a new IP provisioning system and inplementing subinterfaces on the Cable 
Routers.  This will allow us to have other ISP as providers.  I don't know 
what are company management decision is on this, however our engineering 
group is plannig for this possibility.

As to cable being less secure than DSL, who ever claimed that one was more 
secure than another.  Depend on ISP protecting themselves, not their 
customers.  If they start getting in the protection business, they've just 
add a whole slew of management issues they really don't want or need to deal 
with.
The only security that we provide is to protect our equipment and services, 
the customers are on their own.  We recommend virus scanners/firewall for all 
our customers.



Sean

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Feb  2 14:12:02 2003

Date: Sun Feb  2 14:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <20030202073318.GA27181@subtend.net>
References: <20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com> <20030202070004.A8185C5CF@max.seansdomain.org> <20030202073318.GA27181@subtend.net>
Message-ID: <200302021410.46566.aschlemm@attbi.com>

It is my understanding that the data going to/from a cable modem within 
the cable network is encrypted. Once the data leaves the cable network 
and enters other public networks it's as vulnerable as any other 
network traffic. What does DSL have that makes it more secure? My guess 
is that once the data enters other public networks is no more secure 
than any other data unless the data is already encrypted just like data 
from a cable network.

Also in someways a cable network may be a bit more secure since 
vulnerable SMB ports are automatically blocked so people using Windows 
systems can't have any shared filesystems and/or printers accessed by 
others. This is a good thing since most users don't have a clue on how 
to properly secure their systems. I've not heard of DSL blocking access 
to SMB ports.

Still without any port filtering or firewalling a system running 
vulnerable services will be just as vulnerable on a cable network as it 
is on a DSL network. Certainly I know people with DSL connections that 
can do some filtering and other functionality with their DSL router 
that can help make things more secure but you have to understand how to 
access and configure the router properly. I've read that my cable modem 
may have some port filtering capabilities and other stuff but I don't 
have any documentation on how to access my cable modem or anything 
since the modem was supplied by AT&T and the user documentation is very 
minimal. 

We have our house networked and with multiple email addresses included 
we've found cable modem access to be a very good and cheap way of 
achieving high speed internet connectivity for multiple users at home. 
I know DSL is available to me as well but in looking at what is 
available the downlink speeds don't seem to come close to what I get 
with my cable modem connection. Also the price difference isn't worth 
it to take such a big hit in the down link speed. 

Tony

On Saturday 01 February 2003 23:33 pm, Kris wrote:
> On Sat, Feb 01, 2003 at 10:59:57PM -0800, Sean Whitney wrote:
> > This is a marketing myth.  Cable you share with your neighbor
> > before the router, DSL you share with your neighbor after the
> > DSLAM, what's the difference?
>
> There are a couple things DSL has over cable (and vice versa). 
> Security is a bit less on a cable network.
>
> The primary reason I prefer DSL is freedom of ISP.  This is very
> important for competition and keeping service reliable and cheap
> (regardless of the failure of the LEC's to cooperate in some
> situations).
>
> Comparing the options, in the last couple years Qwest has seemed to
> pull ahead of Verizon with bandwidth choices and ease of moving
> ISP's.  They did screw their customers by moving everyone to MSN a
> while back.
>
> When cable will allow me to say "your IP service sucks, please move
> my traffic to <x> local ISP", then I will consider them a competitor
> for my business, even if they are faster than DSL in some cases
> (downstream).
>
> Additionally, though they all suck, DSL user agreements seem to play
> a bit nicer than those with AT&T.  I do not want to be thrown in jail
> for putting up a PTP node.

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com




From sean at fork.com  Sun Feb  2 15:30:02 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Sun Feb  2 15:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0302021028170.20325-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
References: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0302021028170.20325-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20030202232910.B044DC5CC@max.seansdomain.org>

I never implied that this was something we are actively pursuing, only that 
engineering is building it into our new model.

The way it would work would be that the cable company would provide layer's 
1-3 and all other services (except DHCP) would be provided by the ISP.  The 
ISP would have to buy a circuit into our core and traffic on their 
sub-interfaces on the ubr's would be routed to them.  They would provide tier 
1&2 troubleshooting, mail, news etc.  We would provide 
installer/troubleshooters in each market as well, that could be billed back 
to the ISP.



Sean

> Generally, I think this is good news as it provides for more competition

From sean at fork.com  Sun Feb  2 15:34:01 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Sun Feb  2 15:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <200302021410.46566.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com> <20030202073318.GA27181@subtend.net> <200302021410.46566.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20030202233323.1F38CC5CC@max.seansdomain.org>

On Sunday 02 February 2003 14:10, you wrote:
> It is my understanding that the data going to/from a cable modem within
> the cable network is encrypted. 
Not so the data is only "encrypted" within the DOCSIS spec.  It's not "real" 
ethernet that can be intercepted with traditional ethernet tools, however the 
same broadcast and transmissions are still seen on the ethernet side of all 
cable modems.

 Once the data leaves the cable network
> and enters other public networks it's as vulnerable as any other
> network traffic. What does DSL have that makes it more secure? My guess
> is that once the data enters other public networks is no more secure
> than any other data unless the data is already encrypted just like data
> from a cable network.
>
> Also in someways a cable network may be a bit more secure since
> vulnerable SMB ports are automatically blocked so people using Windows
> systems can't have any shared filesystems and/or printers accessed by
> others. This is a good thing since most users don't have a clue on how
> to properly secure their systems. I've not heard of DSL blocking access
> to SMB ports.
This also isn't true in all senses.  ATT might do this (I don't know) we have 
discussed block SMB/NFS/XPWin/Appletalk ports at the cable modem to provide 
basic security to our customer, to protect them from our customers, however 
we having implemented this yet.


Sean

  I ran /usr/sbin/chkfontpath and discovered that the 100dpi font directory
is down quite a way in the list, but I don't recall how to modify the paths
now that they're not all listed in /etc/X11/XF86Config-4.

From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Feb  2 20:08:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun Feb  2 20:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <20030202070004.A8185C5CF@max.seansdomain.org>
References: <20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com>
 <20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <5.2.0.9.0.20030202200509.01ba1d70@192.168.0.2>

At 10:59 PM 2/1/2003 -0800, you wrote:
>This is a marketing myth.  Cable you share with your neighbor before
>the router, DSL you share with your neighbor after the DSLAM, what's
>the difference?

The difference is that usually, if it's configured properly, your neighbors 
can't see your SMB shares over DSL, ever. On Cable, your neighbors can see 
your SMB shares.

Of course, this assumes that you DON'T run a firewall, and that you DO have 
things shared.


Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online

From kens at cad2cam.com  Sun Feb  2 20:42:02 2003
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Sun Feb  2 20:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030202200509.01ba1d70@192.168.0.2>
References: <20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com>
	<20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com> 
	<5.2.0.9.0.20030202200509.01ba1d70@192.168.0.2>
Message-ID: <1044247519.3988.14.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>

On Sun, 2003-02-02 at 20:07, Russ Johnson wrote:
> At 10:59 PM 2/1/2003 -0800, you wrote:
> >This is a marketing myth.  Cable you share with your neighbor before
> >the router, DSL you share with your neighbor after the DSLAM, what's
> >the difference?
> 
> The difference is that usually, if it's configured properly, your neighbors 
> can't see your SMB shares over DSL, ever. On Cable, your neighbors can see 
> your SMB shares.
> 
> Of course, this assumes that you DON'T run a firewall, and that you DO have 
> things shared

Oh contrar.  Neighbors can see anything you put on the net with DSL.  If
you have a fixed IP, even better.  This is why all the chatter about
firewalls.  Cable, DSL, phone lines via PPP.  All connect to the
internet.  All are vulnerable.  All need some kind of firewall.

Ken
 





From athlonrob at axpr.net  Sun Feb  2 21:30:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sun Feb  2 21:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <1044247519.3988.14.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
References: <20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com>
	 <20030201174744.384.qmail@web40805.mail.yahoo.com>
	 <5.2.0.9.0.20030202200509.01ba1d70@192.168.0.2>
	 <1044247519.3988.14.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
Message-ID: <1044250148.11732.13.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sun, 2003-02-02 at 20:45, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:

> Oh contrar.  Neighbors can see anything you put on the net with DSL.  If
> you have a fixed IP, even better.  This is why all the chatter about
> firewalls.  Cable, DSL, phone lines via PPP.  All connect to the
> internet.  All are vulnerable.  All need some kind of firewall.

I think what people were trying to do is compare the level of security
between the two - if cable encrypts information going from the modem to
the ISP, then they are a level ahead of where they used to be, where it
was like each cable user was plugged in to a hub, everybody getting
every packet, essentially... at least, that is how I understood it.

My DSL allows broadcast packets through on the local subnet - as such, I
get hit by 10.0.0.1 a lot on DHCP and bootp ports and from actual IPs
for Windoze share stuff.

Most DSL isn't like this, though....

Rob

        support that was!

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Mon Feb  3 10:21:01 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Mon Feb  3 10:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rat off a Sinking Ship?
In-Reply-To: <200302011948.54716.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302030934190.1945-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

I tend to agree.  Building speciality distributions may become much more
difficult, and in the future one may want to build more and more from
source code.  This is unfortunate, because I think it is faster and
easier to build as much as possible from binaries.  Why, you ask?
Well, the build times are a minor consideration.  However, I prefer using
binaries whenever practical, because the parent distribution has
already done a good deal of quality assurance that is relevant to the
new distribution.   I always feel the need to do more testing when I
compile from source code; and testing is very very time consumming.
Indeed, testing is time consumming even when working from "well tested"
binaries from an established distribution.

Fortunately for distribution builders, I think Debian will remain a
good distribution for distribution builders to start from.  I'm less
confident of RedHat, SuSE, and the others.

I also tend to think speciality distributions will become
more and more important in the future, but I'm absolutely sure
of this.  If the general distributions become more better and more
flexible than I expect, or if consummers demand major brand names
in their distributions then this may not happen.  Moreover,
speciality distributions won't become more important until we
geeks learn more about market research and the value of applications.

                                                     Dave

P.S.  I haven't compiled anything on a 486 in a while, but I thought it
only took me 2-4 hours to compile a kernel on my 486/33, and it wasn't
very painful because it usually compiled right.  Other Linux components
like X took a lot longer, and the ones you were actively working on
could be a real pain since you were always fixing something and
recompiling the mess.

On Sat, 1 Feb 2003, Kyle Hayes wrote:

> .........
> I think that building a specialty distro is getting harder than it was.  As
> packages mature and integrate, it is going to become more difficult to
> trim off what you don't want.  If you stay with binary packages at least.
> I think that the next real wave of specialty distros will probably emerge
> from the various source-based distros.
>
> I believe that several trends support this opinion.  First, computers are
> getting faster and faster so that compile time is dropping into the realm
> of the supportable (it's still too long, but it is getting much better).
> Second, the upstream packages are getting more sophisticated about
> integrating with other software on the system.  Have GNOME? Then the Gtk
> version will be built.  Have KDE? Then the Qt version will be built.
> Third, the upstream packages are starting to standarize on use of
> autoconf, standard build arguments and behavior, and use of LSB-compatible
> defaults.
>
> The first time I built the Linux kernel, it was on some sort of 486 machine
> and the build took many hours (8? I can't remember).  Now, I've got an
> elderly P-II system and the kernel only takes a few minutes to build.
> Another speed up of the same magnitude and the worst packages (OpenOffice
> comes to mind) will be buildable in a few minutes.  Obviously things are
> not this simple, but I think the trends hold.
>
> Best,
> Kyle
>


                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213
                                          (360) 260-2066 at work
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell

Piet,

    I don't know much about individual programs at any of the schools in
this area, but I grew up in Sherwood so I have some general impressions
of the schools.

    I like all the schools in the area (Western Oregon, Linfield, George
Fox, and Willamette).  In general, I like Willamette the best.  I have
employed Willamette graduates.  The two that come to mind were both
Computer Science majors and they were both very good before turning to
the dark side (At least one of them works for MicroSoft.).  I was also
a finalist for a job at Willmette University many years ago.  What
impressed me most about them, was how much the faculty seemed to like
working there.

    Many of my teachers at Sherwood came from George Fox, Linfield, or
Western Oregon.  All of these schools seem reasonable to me.  I suppose,
in general I like Linfield a bit better than Western Oregon and Western
Oregon a bit better than George Fox; but I don't have any good reason
for this.  Also, I think George Fox has grown and improved a lot in
the last 30 years and they were are quite acceptable 30 years ago.

    Of course, what really counts is the quality of the individual
programs and I can't help you in this area.

                                               Good luck,
                                               Dave

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Feb  3 10:43:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Feb  3 10:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030203101458.018aa790@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302031040090.11936-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 3 Feb 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:

> They can't see smb, as it won't travel through a router. It's a
> limitation of the protocol.

I think it's more correct to say that it won't broadcast correctly 
through a router; otherwise, a router is no obstacle. The broadcast 
limitation will decrease a share's visibility via SMB browsing; it 
won't prevent someone from mounting the C$ share...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From ed at alcpress.com  Mon Feb  3 12:20:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Mon Feb  3 12:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
Message-ID: <1044303546.4262.331.camel@red>

I was asked by two people recently about Linux virus
scanning. One asked why there doesn't seem to be many
or any virus scanning software for Linux that a business
can use. The other wondered why Linux was less susceptible
than Windows.

The first was referring to Linux viruses - not a Linux box
scanning email for Windows clients. I explained that
most Linux deployments in business are as servers
presently and a Linux server managed by an administrator
reasonably well-versed in security is not going to fall
victim to viruses or other form of attack easily.

I explained to both the concepts of daemons running as
root versus a lesser privileged user, not having daemons
running as the same user, restricting a daemon to a
portion of a file system by chrooting it, choosing to
use daemons that don't have a history of security issues,
etc. I said that by using common sense security
precautions, virus attacks are unlikely to succeed and,
if they do, cleanup would be relatively simple.

This was the wrong answer. The first fellow insists that
Linux is equally as vulnerable to virus attack as
Windows. He dismissed my explanation as the rantings
of a "rabid Linux user" - his words. I suspect he thinks
that Linux is not as secure as Windows because there are
no virus scanners available - no other facts matter. I
wonder what he'll think when he finds out that there is no
disk defragger for Linux.

The other didn't accept my explanation because "there are
more security alerts for Linux that there are for Windows.'
and "if Linux was as popular as Windows it would have just
as many security problems" and "wasn't there a Linux
slammer attack?".

Clearly, there's a lot of people out there who don't get it
and technical explanations are lost on them. As Linux is
deployed by more and more people who don't have the
necessary skills and security awareness, Linux is going to
be perceived as a platform just as problematic as Windows.
These people need simpler concepts they can grasp.

I'm thinking that the solution is to shift the emphasis
away from Linux as a secure operating system to the
administrator. It's the administrator who makes a system
secure - not an operating system. When security problems
occur, we should not complain about Windows, we should
complain about administration. If company management puts
the pressure on their administrators to solve security
problems, more secure solutions, like Linux, should
eventually bubble to the top.
 

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

Gang: 

I am investigating an emerging connector spec called HDMI (www.hdmi.org)
which is supposedly the "High Definition Multimedia Interface" slated to take 
over where S-Video and DVI connectors leave off.

Obviously, there may be something of interst to Linux programmers regarding 
writing new drivers, etc.

http://www.hdmi.org/faq/faq.asp

But by the verbiage in the FAQ portion of the page (and besides, just 'who' 
is an "educated digital video consumer" **) it seems that the unstated point 
behind NOT having to switch to "clumsy analog signals" (their words) is more 
like trying to retain 'content control' all the way through to the picture 
tube.

"...enabling new functionality..." Right.

GLL

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Feb  3 14:18:01 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Feb  3 14:18:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <1044303546.4262.331.camel@red>
References: <1044303546.4262.331.camel@red>
Message-ID: <1044310651.30448.67.camel@rheingold>

On Mon, 2003-02-03 at 12:19, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> I was asked by two people recently about Linux virus
> scanning. One asked why there doesn't seem to be many
> or any virus scanning software for Linux that a business
> can use. The other wondered why Linux was less susceptible
> than Windows.

For one thing, there are almost as many virus-scanners for Linux as
there are for Windows.  All of the "store brands" have Linux versions of
their scanners:  McAfee, Symantec, etc., as do most of the more focused
brands like Sophos, F-PROT, etc.

He's also right that in many ways, a Linux workstation is as susceptible
as a Windows workstation.  Sure, we do have privileges, chroot jails and
whatnot--but a user-level virus (say, from downloading a binary or
trojaned source) which did nasty things would be equally as devastating
from a user's standpoint--it could delete all your (user-owned) data
files and/or send porn web sites to your entire addressbook, including
your grandmother and customers.  It would no doubt be less effective
because of the heterogeneity of our systems and lack of standardization
and sharing among applications.  (E.g., every mail application has its
own addressbook.)

And let's face it, there's a lot of crappy code out there, particularly
in user-level applications.  And with StarOffice being so compatible
with MS Office, it wouldn't surprise if some of the same Word macro
viruses would work.

We like to think we're safer, but the fact is once we've become
comfortable with that and cease vigilance--we too will fall prey.

The arguments about popularity hold some water, but like most
unqualified generalisations, are not necessarily true.  Using a
rarely-used distro, OS, application means most of the time the
proof-of-concept or skript-kiddie exploits won't work.  It doesn't mean
you're not vulnerable to the flaw in general, but there may not be
active exploits on the net for it.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *

From guy1656 at ados.com  Mon Feb  3 14:28:02 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Mon Feb  3 14:28:02 2003
Subject: Fwd: Re: [PLUG] New Connector - OT
Message-ID: <20030203221428.29C113698D@ados.com>

"educated digital video consumer"
:^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
:
: Isn't this an oxymoron? Most of us read books.
: Rich

Two Points! But here we have 'education' = PHB-speak for 'persuasion.' When
video 'pirates' of the Far East defeat copy protections it's because they
haven't been 'educated' to understand and accept that a DVD of a 110-min.
movie should 'logically' cost $34.99.  Locally, some would say that Measure
28 failed because the rural populations weren't 'educated' correctly.

Unfortunately, I'm not a programmer, but I'd think that the first step would
be to find a D/A->A/D converter which interposes itself somewhere along the
path, to preserve the anonymity of WHERE the signal goes thereafter - like to
my TV (when? how many times this month? That's "important marketing
information") or to another recording device which, although it remains
within Fair Use, is also 'off their radar screen.'

GLL

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Mon Feb  3 14:48:01 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon Feb  3 14:48:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <200302031211.01041.tjg@craigelachie.org>
References: <20030202170416.59256.qmail@web40809.mail.yahoo.com> <200302031211.01041.tjg@craigelachie.org>
Message-ID: <200302031447.24298.aschlemm@attbi.com>

FWIW,

I know a few people that have done this and as far as I know they 
haven't been nailed by AT&T for violating their EULA which forbids the 
running of a server. These people aren't getting very many hits at all 
but having their own website has proved useful for posting a few 
pictures and other stuff online. If you were running a high traffic 
site on your system you might be detected but given that the up link 
speeds on AT&T aren't that great IMHO, I can't imagine anyone running a 
high traffic web or FTP site through their cable modem service.

I don't run any public servers but I do have sendmail set up on my 
gateway system which accessible to systems on my internal network. I 
have sendmail setup to relay any of my network's own outgoing email 
through AT&T's mail servers. This works fine since my system resides on 
AT&T's network so their email server readily accept email from my 
system.

I did have to do a little configuration work with sendmail so it uses my 
"attbi.com" email address rather than my local userid and bogus domain 
name which I use on my internal network.

Tony

On Monday 03 February 2003 12:11 pm, Timothy Grant wrote:
> On Sunday 02 February 2003 09:04 am, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
> > happening often, I would switch to DSL because I like
> > to run a web server, and to log in remotely through
> > ssh, etc, and would want a static IP.
>
> Scott,
>
> I'm an AT&T customer, and I run my own mail server (using the
> rationale that the bandwidth is the same to AT&T whether I host my
> mail in my basement, or go out to another mail-server somewhere to
> get it).
>
> However, I haven't had the nerve to put up a webserver, as I can't
> rationalize that violation of the TOS (that's not a moral
> determination, it's just a lame defense if I should ever be asked
> about it).
>
> That said, I desperately want to run my own website on my own server
> in my own basement. Have you ever been questioned or had any flags
> raised over this technical violation of the AT&T TOS?

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon Feb  3 14:56:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon Feb  3 14:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Desperate situation-> Quick time videos in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <1044312255.975.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <200302032151.h13Lp6318553@gate.daniloff.com> <1044311335.29833.78.camel@rheingold> <1044312255.975.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20030203225511.GB9005@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

Disclaimer: this is a debian-centric solution. but it may work if you
have alien and another distro (sorry, I dont know of a
distribution-generic solution like this.)

If you are using debian, then this apt-source line will allow you to
apt-get install mplayer with much less pain.

deb http://marillat.free.fr unstable main

(apt-get update after adding it to your sources.list of course.)


-Rogan

From ed at alcpress.com  Mon Feb  3 15:20:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)

Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security

In this case, the discussion was about Linux servers.



On Mon, 2003-02-03 at 14:17, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On Mon, 2003-02-03 at 12:19, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> > I was asked by two people recently about Linux virus
> > scanning. One asked why there doesn't seem to be many
> > or any virus scanning software for Linux that a business
> > can use. The other wondered why Linux was less susceptible
> > than Windows.
> 
> For one thing, there are almost as many virus-scanners for Linux as
> there are for Windows.  All of the "store brands" have Linux versions of
> their scanners:  McAfee, Symantec, etc., as do most of the more focused
> brands like Sophos, F-PROT, etc.
> 
> He's also right that in many ways, a Linux workstation is as susceptible
> as a Windows workstation.  Sure, we do have privileges, chroot jails and
> whatnot--but a user-level virus (say, from downloading a binary or
> trojaned source) which did nasty things would be equally as devastating
> from a user's standpoint--it could delete all your (user-owned) data
> files and/or send porn web sites to your entire addressbook, including
> your grandmother and customers.  It would no doubt be less effective
> because of the heterogeneity of our systems and lack of standardization
> and sharing among applications.  (E.g., every mail application has its
> own addressbook.)
> 
> And let's face it, there's a lot of crappy code out there, particularly
> in user-level applications.  And with StarOffice being so compatible
> with MS Office, it wouldn't surprise if some of the same Word macro
> viruses would work.
> 
> We like to think we're safer, but the fact is once we've become
> comfortable with that and cease vigilance--we too will fall prey.
> 
> The arguments about popularity hold some water, but like most
> unqualified generalisations, are not necessarily true.  Using a
> rarely-used distro, OS, application means most of the time the
> proof-of-concept or skript-kiddie exploits won't work.  It doesn't mean
> you're not vulnerable to the flaw in general, but there may not be
> active exploits on the net for it.
> 
> Wil
-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

pull the code from CVS and compile with the correct flags.  It does not 
happen by default.

mplayer is a bitch to get working right.  I have done it, but it took some 
serious voodoo.  (Since broken now that I am running Rawhide on my home 
machine and an even more experimental OS on my laptop.)





From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Mon Feb  3 15:22:02 2003

I download the tarball, edit the RPM spec to change the version, then
do rpm --ba with the options I want, and install new mplayer RPMs.
Doesn't seem all that hard to me. And it can play more formats than any
other player for Linux, especially after you install the win32 codecs.

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Feb  3 15:29:01 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)

In-Reply-To: <1044314346.3835.344.camel@red>

On 3 Feb 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> In this case, the discussion was about Linux servers.
> 
> 
> 
> On Mon, 2003-02-03 at 14:17, Wil Cooley wrote:
> > On Mon, 2003-02-03 at 12:19, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> > > I was asked by two people recently about Linux virus
> > > scanning. One asked why there doesn't seem to be many
> > > or any virus scanning software for Linux that a business
> > > can use. The other wondered why Linux was less susceptible
> > > than Windows.
> > 
> > For one thing, there are almost as many virus-scanners for Linux as
> > there are for Windows.  All of the "store brands" have Linux versions of
> > their scanners:  McAfee, Symantec, etc., as do most of the more focused
> > brands like Sophos, F-PROT, etc.

And you need them for scanning Windows files and documents.  (FTP servers 
and SMB shares used by marketing people are a prime target for this sort 
of scanning need.)

I have found that the Linux versions are usually more expensive because 
they assume that if you are using Linux, you will be doing "corporate 
work", therefore they can suck more money out of you.

> > He's also right that in many ways, a Linux workstation is as susceptible
> > as a Windows workstation.  Sure, we do have privileges, chroot jails and
> > whatnot--but a user-level virus (say, from downloading a binary or
> > trojaned source) which did nasty things would be equally as devastating
> > from a user's standpoint--it could delete all your (user-owned) data
> > files and/or send porn web sites to your entire addressbook, including
> > your grandmother and customers.  It would no doubt be less effective
> > because of the heterogeneity of our systems and lack of standardization
> > and sharing among applications.  (E.g., every mail application has its
> > own addressbook.)

But Linux does not have anything as wide-open as Outlook.  (Where the 
features have been pushed through by the S&M department, without reguard 
to common sense.)

> > And let's face it, there's a lot of crappy code out there, particularly
> > in user-level applications.  And with StarOffice being so compatible
> > with MS Office, it wouldn't surprise if some of the same Word macro
> > viruses would work.

Actually we are starting to see some of the same things working, but not 
from OpenOffice as much as Wine.  (Wine is set to run .exe files by 
default with some configurations.)

> > We like to think we're safer, but the fact is once we've become
> > comfortable with that and cease vigilance--we too will fall prey.
> > 
> > The arguments about popularity hold some water, but like most
> > unqualified generalisations, are not necessarily true.  Using a
> > rarely-used distro, OS, application means most of the time the
> > proof-of-concept or skript-kiddie exploits won't work.  It doesn't mean
> > you're not vulnerable to the flaw in general, but there may not be
> > active exploits on the net for it.

Actually we are much less vulnerable now.  The question is if we can stay 
that way.

>From what i have seen, the answer is "yes".  The question of if anyone 
will use it is still to be determined...




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Feb  3 15:54:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Feb  3 15:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To:

On Mon, 2003-02-03 at 06:52, alan wrote:
 
> And you need them for scanning Windows files and documents.  (FTP servers 
> and SMB shares used by marketing people are a prime target for this sort 
> of scanning need.)

Not to mention e-mail.
 
> I have found that the Linux versions are usually more expensive because 
> they assume that if you are using Linux, you will be doing "corporate 
> work", therefore they can suck more money out of you.

Not with Sophos, but then, Sophos is marketed only towards enterprise
environments, so I guess it doesn't have cheap home-user editions to
begin with.  (Although their license permits employees to use it at home
for no extra charge.)
 
> But Linux does not have anything as wide-open as Outlook.  (Where the 
> features have been pushed through by the S&M department, without reguard 
> to common sense.)

True, but there have been vulnerabilities in the MIME handling of e-mail
applications under Linux.  There's nothing inherent in the system that
makes user-level applications more secure (unless, of course employing
special tools, like Stack/FormatGuard).
 
> Actually we are starting to see some of the same things working, but not 
> from OpenOffice as much as Wine.  (Wine is set to run .exe files by 
> default with some configurations.)

We discussed the OOo possibility at the last AT meething; I think you
were still out working on that paper.
 
> Actually we are much less vulnerable now.  The question is if we can stay 
> that way.
> 
> From what i have seen, the answer is "yes".  The question of if anyone 
> will use it is still to be determined...

I agree that there is a good deal more attention being given to security
issues these days.

Wil

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Feb  3 16:57:01 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Mon Feb  3 16:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <1044316401.30448.105.camel@rheingold>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302030804520.28615-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On 3 Feb 2003, Wil Cooley wrote:

> On Mon, 2003-02-03 at 06:52, alan wrote:
>  
> > And you need them for scanning Windows files and documents.  (FTP servers 
> > and SMB shares used by marketing people are a prime target for this sort 
> > of scanning need.)
> 
> Not to mention e-mail.

Yes.  I tend to forget that since the current mail servers do not feed 
mail to Windows clients.  (Saving copies for later is important, 
however...)

> > I have found that the Linux versions are usually more expensive because 
> > they assume that if you are using Linux, you will be doing "corporate 
> > work", therefore they can suck more money out of you.
> 
> Not with Sophos, but then, Sophos is marketed only towards enterprise
> environments, so I guess it doesn't have cheap home-user editions to
> begin with.  (Although their license permits employees to use it at home
> for no extra charge.)

I am trying to remember if Sophos was the one that wanted to charge me 
$2,000 a year per server.  

When i was testing virus scanners about three years back, the Linux 
versions had some serious problems.  The McAfee versions would either core 
or not detect some viruses. (Mostly macro viruses, which is what I 
needed the most.)  There was not much else available.

I need to test against my collection and see how well the new versions 
work.

> > But Linux does not have anything as wide-open as Outlook.  (Where the 
> > features have been pushed through by the S&M department, without reguard 
> > to common sense.)
> 
> True, but there have been vulnerabilities in the MIME handling of e-mail
> applications under Linux.  There's nothing inherent in the system that
> makes user-level applications more secure (unless, of course employing
> special tools, like Stack/FormatGuard).

Just keeping users from being able to alter system binaries stops 
many of the attacks that Windows exploits like to use.  (Many of the 
windows viruses replace the winsock dll(s) with their own trojaned 
version.) That protection helps a great deal.  (Especially in a multi-user 
environment.)  To get MS Office to work with Multi-user NT, you have to 
give it write access to the system directory.  One infection infects the 
entire userbase all at once.

Special tools help as well, but having proper permissions set helps keep 
the infection limited to a single user, if it happens at all.  (And with 
things like SubDomain, you can nail the process down to the point where, 
even if they can gain a foothold on the machine, it does not help a whole 
lot.)

> > Actually we are starting to see some of the same things working, but not 
> > from OpenOffice as much as Wine.  (Wine is set to run .exe files by 
> > default with some configurations.)
> 
> We discussed the OOo possibility at the last AT meething; I think you
> were still out working on that paper.

Yep.  Oh well...

> > Actually we are much less vulnerable now.  The question is if we can stay 
> > that way.
> > 
> > From what i have seen, the answer is "yes".  The question of if anyone 
> > will use it is still to be determined...
> 
> I agree that there is a good deal more attention being given to security
> issues these days.

Unfortunatly, in many places it is just lipservice or DRM masquerading as 
security.  (Security for Microsoft is whether your check clears.)

: not-too-distant future about what's been lost because too few of us gave a

I recently heard about an emerging group of folks calling themselves "Amish 
2.0 - Still Living in the 20th Century."

They are enthusiasts of neat, mostly mechanical and electrical (or early 
electronic) devices, tricks, work-arounds, war stories etc. Folks who 
remember how to hook up Nixie tubes.

GLL,

also -NOT- part of the 'if it breaks, 
buy a new one for cheap at Wal-Mart' crowd.



From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Mon Feb  3 17:15:06 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Mon Feb  3 17:15:06 2003
Subject: [PLUG] up2date not updating
Message-ID: <20030204011339.GA2260@dalsemi.com>

I'm pretty frustrated, so this may not be my most clear email.

I thought I'd sign up for Red Hat's free up2date service to try it out.
So first I ran the configurator, then I ran up2date, which produced a
bunch of output saying it was checking header files and then it
reported that it would not update the kernel because I had asked it not
to.

However, it didn't do or say anything about the other RPMs that need
updating.

Next I tried the RHN website, with similar results.  I selected
the system that I wanted to update.  The website reports back
that the system was scheduled to be updated in two hours.  So,
two hours later I check back and there's no activity on the server,
no RPMs have been updated, and the RHN website reports that it
had no problems updating my machine.

I've tried running up2date on the command line with -v for more
verbose output, which it doesn't produce.  I've also tried
just downloading RPMs, which it won't download.

Has anyone out there tried this and succeeded?  

Colin

> I've tried running up2date on the command line with -v for more
> verbose output, which it doesn't produce.  I've also tried
> just downloading RPMs, which it won't download.

One annoying aspect is that when running up2date from CLI, you must pass
it a switch, -u in order for it to actually follow through with the
updating of your system.
I assume you've already learned the --nox switch, which doesn't fire up
the gui front end?  Try up2date --help for more examples.  The --configure
switch should let you specify which packages to skip (kernel is by default
skipped).

> Has anyone out there tried this and succeeded?

Yes, up2date works great for me.

Hope this helps!

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon Feb  3 17:54:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Mon Feb  3 17:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <1044303546.4262.331.camel@red>
References: <1044303546.4262.331.camel@red>
Message-ID: <1044323552.1008.27.camel@main>

On Mon, 2003-02-03 at 12:19, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> I was asked by two people recently about Linux virus
> scanning. One asked why there doesn't seem to be many
> or any virus scanning software for Linux that a business
> can use. The other wondered why Linux was less susceptible
> than Windows.
> 
> The first was referring to Linux viruses - not a Linux box
> scanning email for Windows clients. I explained that
> most Linux deployments in business are as servers
> presently and a Linux server managed by an administrator
> reasonably well-versed in security is not going to fall
> victim to viruses or other form of attack easily.
> 
> I explained to both the concepts of daemons running as
> root versus a lesser privileged user, not having daemons
> running as the same user, restricting a daemon to a
> portion of a file system by chrooting it, choosing to
> use daemons that don't have a history of security issues,
> etc. I said that by using common sense security
> precautions, virus attacks are unlikely to succeed and,
> if they do, cleanup would be relatively simple.

All very good answers in my opinion. Any reasonable person would accept
this and do the appropriate research if questions remain.
 
> This was the wrong answer. The first fellow insists that
> Linux is equally as vulnerable to virus attack as
> Windows. He dismissed my explanation as the rantings
> of a "rabid Linux user" - his words. I suspect he thinks
> that Linux is not as secure as Windows because there are
> no virus scanners available - no other facts matter. I
> wonder what he'll think when he finds out that there is no
> disk defragger for Linux.

See above (emphasis on REASONABLE)
 
> The other didn't accept my explanation because "there are
> more security alerts for Linux that there are for Windows.'
> and "if Linux was as popular as Windows it would have just
> as many security problems" and "wasn't there a Linux
> slammer attack?".

See above
 
> Clearly, there's a lot of people out there who don't get it
> and technical explanations are lost on them. As Linux is
> deployed by more and more people who don't have the
> necessary skills and security awareness, Linux is going to
> be perceived as a platform just as problematic as Windows.
> These people need simpler concepts they can grasp.
> 
> I'm thinking that the solution is to shift the emphasis
> away from Linux as a secure operating system to the
> administrator. It's the administrator who makes a system
> secure - not an operating system. When security problems
> occur, we should not complain about Windows, we should
> complain about administration. If company management puts
> the pressure on their administrators to solve security
> problems, more secure solutions, like Linux, should
> eventually bubble to the top.
 
But Ed, the administrator can not force Microsoft to produce any
security fixes. In fact, even discussing vulnerabilities in that OS
could force one to fall prey to DMCA heart-ache, head-ache and possible
prosecution. Just as a vague example of the attitude that those
unfortunate individuals have to deal with, read the EULA (quite the
fancy acronym for End-User License Agreement) for the Microsoft .NET
Framework - it clearly states that by accepting this License Agreement
you will NOT discuss any benchmark findings with .NET to anyone without
the express written consent of Microsoft (I ran into that one over the
weekend while setting up my dual boot workstation). With an arrogant,
publish only the good, attitude like this, would it be possible that the
opinion of an administrator is going to make a difference when the CFOs
of the world just keep signing checks for more Windows? I'm sorry, I
think not.

In theory I really do agree with you, a lame Linux admin can create a
security nightmare much larger than one likely to come from a well cared
for Windows box. However, until Balmer and his marketing machine start
hearing it from the money source there will be no change in the product.

Just my opinion, and like Mr. Miller, I could be wrong.

From smathews at pcez.com  Mon Feb  3 19:58:01 2003
From: smathews at pcez.com (stuart mathews)
Date: Mon Feb  3 19:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] C compiler question
Message-ID: <3e3f3a3c.f2f.0@pcez.com>

While learning C, I ran this exercise designed to demonstrate floating point
rounding errors. You run a program that adds two float numbers. The book said
the output would be one of the following, depending on your system;

1. gcc / Linux  =    0.00000
2. Turbo C 1.5  =    -13584010575872.000000
3. CodeWarrior 5.0, MSVC++ 6.0  =  4008175468544.000000

On my system, (Compaq PII, Redhat 8.0, gcc version 3.2), the out put was exactly
that for the "CodeWarrior" listed above.  Questions is, why that output instead
of the gcc / Linux output?

-------------------
http://www.pcez.com

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Feb  4 03:02:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Feb  4 03:02:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Desperate situation-> Quick time videos in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <1044312255.975.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <200302032151.h13Lp6318553@gate.daniloff.com> 
 <1044311335.29833.78.camel@rheingold> <1044312255.975.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302040251270.32636@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 3 Feb 2003, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> mplayer is a bear to install.  I tried on several occasions and got
> thoroughly confused by the poor installation documentation and had to
> give up.  I've been lucky enough not to need any QT or WMV file support.
> I've heard good things about CodeWeavers crossover software.

I read comments like this (mostly on this list) all the time and I have to
wonder if there is some OTHER software called MPlayer that is "a bear to
install".

I remember some early version that had a build error in some video output
function or other, but that was like two years ago.

I built a new MPlayer just after New Year's Day and it was just a matter
of ./configure --help, picking out the options I needed, running
configure, then make, then make install.  I also downloaded some big fancy
new set of (unfortunately binary) codecs and added them to the group in
/usr/lib/win32/ and now I can play just about anything.

Oh, I also put in the mga_vid kernel module they distribute because it
makes things so fast and pretty with my G400 (though it's a pain that the
backend scaler isn't available on the second head).

But anyway, MPlayer builds cleanly and just works.  You kinda gotta watch
the configure output to make sure all the options you want are going to be
compiled in based on the libraries you have available and everything, but
it's not like it asks for anything unreasonable.

Oppose this with, say, ogg vorbis which I've NEVER had build cleanly on
any system without serious tweaking and hacking.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From smathews at pcez.com  Tue Feb  4 06:29:01 2003
From: smathews at pcez.com (stuart mathews)
Date: Tue Feb  4 06:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] C compiler question
Message-ID: <3e3fce06.318f.0@pcez.com>

>
>This might prove to be a fascinating conversation. There is not really
>enough information to make even an educated guess on the subject so lets
>start with the revisions of the compilers (gcc / linux 2.xx??) and the
>processor architecture (is this 64 bit precision math on an ix86 vs. 64
>bit precision on a SPARC or Alpha etc...)?  Some detail please.
>

Here is more info on the situation.

Compiler; gcc version 3.2 20020903
Kernel;   2.4.18-14 (Redhat 8.0)
Hardware; P4 (Thinkpad, NOT the Compaq box)
Preprocessor architecture; I don't know for sure if what I am attempting to
do is 64-bit precision math or not - remember, I'm the perpetual newbie here.


Code;
#include <stdio.h>
int main(void)
{
   float a, b;
   
   b = 2.0e20 + 1.0;
   a = b - 2.0e20;
   printf("%f \n", a);
   return 0;
}

The output is supposed to reflect the fact that the computer doesn't keep track
of enough decimal places to do the operation correctly. That's all well and
good, but then the book goes on to say that the output will be one of the following,
and my output matches exactly that of the "CodeWarrior;

gcc, Linux;   0.000000
Turbo C 1.5;  -13584010575872.000000
CodeWarrior;  4008175468544.000000

Incidentally, when I try to open vi to view the source file I get the following
message;

E325: ATTENTION
Found a swap file by the name ".floaterr.c.swap" while opening file "floaterr.c"


1. Another program may be editing the same file.....
2. An edit session for this file crashed. If this is the case, use ":recover"
or............"


-------------------
http://www.pcez.com



From russell-evans at uswest.net  Tue Feb  4 06:48:02 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Tue Feb  4 06:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] C compiler question
In-Reply-To: <3e3fce06.318f.0@pcez.com>
References: <3e3fce06.318f.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <E18g4Lv-0006hL-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

#include <stdio.h>

int main(void)
{
   double a, b;

   b = 2.0e20 + 1.0;
   a = b - 2.0e20;
   printf("%f \n", a);
   return 0;
}

Gives the result you're looking for.

Thank you
Russell

> I read comments like this (mostly on this list) all the time and I have to
> wonder if there is some OTHER software called MPlayer that is "a bear to
> install".

I searched on rpmfind and pulled the src RPM backwith.  (Advise on the 
mplayer site and friends suggested there could be problems with library 
version unless compiled on the machine it was going to run on.)  Between 
14-16 hour days and a lack of attention I missed the real problem with the 
rebuild - the /usr/local/man/man1 directory didn't exist - but a few days 
later I took the time to look at the output.  5-10 minutes later I had 
mplayer installed.

> I built a new MPlayer just after New Year's Day and it was just a matter
> of ./configure --help, picking out the options I needed, running
> configure, then make, then make install.  I also downloaded some big fancy
> new set of (unfortunately binary) codecs and added them to the group in
> /usr/lib/win32/ and now I can play just about anything.

Made the mistake of placing them in the mplayer library directory.  A
quick link and I was watching everything I could find and wanted to
download for free.

> But anyway, MPlayer builds cleanly and just works.  You kinda gotta watch
> the configure output to make sure all the options you want are going to be
> compiled in based on the libraries you have available and everything, but
> it's not like it asks for anything unreasonable.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

Me too - now.

I started out in the Linux world with RedHat 6.0... then 6.2... then
Mandrake 7.0... then 7.2... and I could hardly ever get anything to
compile.  I was *sure* compiling things in Linux required you go in and
mess with the source code - way far over my head... I thought only true
Gurus and Developers compiled their own programs in Linux.

Then kernel 2.4.x wouldn't work for me on my hardware - it crashed and
burned the way it was compiled with everybody.  So I ended up trying
Slackware... I can't think of anything I was unable to get to compile
under Slackware 8.0 or 8.1 or my now 9.0-early-beta.  I also tried
Debian to build an LFS box - it also worked well at compiling
everything.  Now I'm playing around with Gentoo - it also compiles
everything.

Read into that what you will - it seems to me RH and Mandrake's setups
lead to problems building things from scratch.

Rob

I would have to interject that *nix has been running for 30 years in a 
networked enviornment.  As such it has been looked at from a security 
point of veiw from the get go.  Microsoft on the other hand is a johnny 
come lately to networking and had no clue when designing the OS.  As 
such, they just now are finding out what security is.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Feb  4 10:08:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
