In-Reply-To: <1044380021.12677.75.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On 4 Feb 2003, AthlonRob wrote:

> Read into that what you will - it seems to me RH and Mandrake's setups
> lead to problems building things from scratch.
 
Rob,

  FWIW, I've run only Red Hat since 4.0 or 4.1 (I forget which one) and have
compiled every kernel version but one (when I used the rpm to install it)
without a single problem. A couple of times I didn't have necessary
libraries when I tried building an end-user application from the source
tarball, but that was easily fixed. Once I remembered to run ldconfig again,
of course. :-) If it matters, I'm running on "antique" hardware: PII/333MHz
cpu with 328M RAM and an 8M vRAM nVidia 128 video card on one box and a
PII/500MHz with 128M RAM on the other, plus a new video card because the old
one died.

  My Slackware-8.1 disk set arrived yesterday and I'll be installing that on
my notebook Real Soon Now. This Toshiba Portege CT-3025 has a
Pentium-MMX/300 MHz cpu and 96M RAM. It's been running RH 6.2 and xfce just
fine.

  I'm not suggesting that your problems were not real, just that my
experience with Red Hat and building from source has been much more
favorable than trying to install some packages. As a matter of fact, when I
enter Dependency Hell with the rpms I'll often grab the tarball and run
'configure; make; make install' while I go work on something else.

Rich

From guy1656 at ados.com  Tue Feb  4 10:15:02 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Tue Feb  4 10:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Desperate situation-> Quick time videos in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302040251270.32636@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <200302032151.h13Lp6318553@gate.daniloff.com> <1044312255.975.9.camel@localhost.localdomain> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302040251270.32636@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20030204175424.0DA6B36EE4@ados.com>

Reply regarding Re: [PLUG] Desperate situation-> Quick time videos in Linux? 
from Jeme A Brelin:
: On Mon, 3 Feb 2003, Robbert van Andel wrote:
: > mplayer is a bear to install. 

When this message first posted, I almost fired back a VERY capitalized 
'Amen!' 

: I read comments like this (mostly on this list) all the time and I have to
: wonder if there is some OTHER software called MPlayer that is "a bear to
: install"

No, your setting for 'EZ install - just plop-n-go' is out of calibration.

A) But anyway, MPlayer builds cleanly and just works.
B) You kinda gotta watch the configure output to make sure all the options 
you want are going to be compiled in based on the libraries you have 
available and everything, but it's not like it asks for anything unreasonable.

Umm, statements (A) and (B) contradict each other.

Software that 'just works' installs with a single and simple action (a 
'familiar' word in a command shell, or a single action like a mouse-click) 
runs with a similarly simple one-hit. That's what the 'just' part means.

Let's say a user wants an 'AM Radio' program. First get a grip on the 
complexity of the task of operating a radio you can buy at Freddy's. Pretty 
much, not more than two controls: tuning and volume. Anything else starts 
getting geeky-tweeky, and isn't really necessary (timed auto-shutoffs, 
radio-on alarm mode, etc.)

So, you buy the radio, insert batteries, click 'On,' slide the volume to the 
middle, (because you didn't read the directions or look at the knob to know 
which way is LOUD - you select a mid-point expressly to avoid all these 
steps) and slide the tuner around. At this point, based on what you hear, you 
will make a decision about whether the device 'just works' or not.

Very few people buy a radio in order to learn about how amplitude modulation 
works They buy it to hear what the radio stations are playing. Same thing 
goes for the initial user in this thread. She need to learn about medicine, 
and doesn't have the bandwith to learn about that AND scalable 
back-whatchamacallits simultaneously.

So if you have a radio program, if it installs with a double-click on an RPM, 
and no other configurations are necessary, and it runs on my system and 
yours, THEN it's a 'normal, easy, simple install.' If you have to go to 
another website and figure out what else to install and where to put it, AND 
if you don't get it right then NOTHING happens, well, that's called 'a bear 
to install.' Or worse.

Remember, "builds cleanly and just works" contradicts "You kinda gotta watch."

-GLL

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Feb  4 10:52:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Feb  4 10:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Desperate situation-> Quick time videos in  Linux?
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030204103138.00bccde8@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302041046070.13893-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 4 Feb 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:

> >Remember, "builds cleanly and just works" contradicts "You kinda
> >gotta watch."
> 
> And Jeme will now tell you that anyone that doesn't grok the output
> of make after compiling shouldn't be using a computer. They should
> be using a single purpose appliance.... :/

Does anyone besides me think that building software and using software 
are two **completely different** things?

It's one thing to buy a radio from a retail outlet, and something else 
entirely to buy one from HeathKit.

The minute we start complaining that developers need to make sure 
their Makefiles are completely user friendly is the day that 
developers will flip us all the finger and go underground.

The minute you decide to build software from scratch, you toss "just 
works" out the window.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Tue Feb  4 10:56:01 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue Feb  4 10:56:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <3E3FAB4E.8040007@linuxlink.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302040302450.32636@shaft.bitmine.net> <5.2.0.9.0.20030204085848.017a2940@localhost> <3E3FAB4E.8040007@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <200302041054.44329.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I'm not that ancient yet and even some 20 years ago I didn't see Unix 
systems in a networked environment that much. We mostly had 1200 bps 
serial connections to dumb terminals. Most of the Unix systems I used 
didn't even have ethernet and so we copied files and executed programs 
remotely between systems using UUCP with a modem. In some cases if the 
system's were in the same room we'd make our own NULL modem cables to 
connect the systems together. 

Anyone have a good history of Unix reference? I thought TCP/IP 
networking didn't show up in Unix until BSD 4.x in the early 80s. 
Certainly the work that went on through DARPA that led to TCP/IP goes 
way back though. I have an old "BSD 4.3 Unix" textbook and that's about 
the only reference I see to networking in the "History of Unix" 
chapter.

Tony

On Tuesday 04 February 2003 04:00 am, mike wrote:
> I would have to interject that *nix has been running for 30 years in
> a networked environment.  As such it has been looked at from a
> security point of veiw from the get go.  Microsoft on the other hand
> is a johnny come lately to networking and had no clue when designing
> the OS.  As such, they just now are finding out what security is.
>

> >> > are
> >>
> >> on as
> >>
> >> > many machines as Windows?

> >> things are

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Feb  4 11:10:03 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Feb  4 11:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Desperate situation-> Quick time videos in  Linux?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302041053510.11806-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302041105190.13893-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 4 Feb 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

> > The minute you decide to build software from scratch, you toss
> > "just works" out the window.
> 
>   .src.rpm's too?

That's really a different issue. A source rpm has been packaged by 
someone who thinks s/he has been able to script the build process 
cleanly enough for it to "just work" elsewhere.

Even then, however, I'm not going to hold the package maintainer
completely responsible for dealing with someone who wants to build his
source rpm on a system that has none of the -devel packages installed.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From mike at linuxlink.com  Tue Feb  4 11:42:02 2003

TCP or serial doesn't matter.  the fact that multiple users had access 
makes it multi user/networked.  If one had a terminal one was trying to 
hack something.  Ask Richard Stallman.  Remember when they passworded 
his logins and he hacked his way around that?


Microsoft was made for a single user.  And even the users often  hack 
their own machines to death.


Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> I'm not that ancient yet and even some 20 years ago I didn't see Unix 
> systems in a networked environment that much. We mostly had 1200 bps 
> serial connections to dumb terminals. Most of the Unix systems I used 
> didn't even have ethernet and so we copied files and executed programs 
> remotely between systems using UUCP with a modem. In some cases if the 
> system's were in the same room we'd make our own NULL modem cables to 
> connect the systems together. 
> 
> Anyone have a good history of Unix reference? I thought TCP/IP 
> networking didn't show up in Unix until BSD 4.x in the early 80s. 
> Certainly the work that went on through DARPA that led to TCP/IP goes 
> way back though. I have an old "BSD 4.3 Unix" textbook and that's about 
> the only reference I see to networking in the "History of Unix" 
> chapter.

From ed at alcpress.com  Tue Feb  4 13:26:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Tue Feb  4 13:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <200302041054.44329.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302040302450.32636@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <5.2.0.9.0.20030204085848.017a2940@localhost>
	 <3E3FAB4E.8040007@linuxlink.com>  <200302041054.44329.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1044393914.2726.405.camel@red>

On Tue, 2003-02-04 at 10:54, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> Anyone have a good history of Unix reference? I thought TCP/IP 
> networking didn't show up in Unix until BSD 4.x in the early 80s. 
> Certainly the work that went on through DARPA that led to TCP/IP goes 
> way back though. I have an old "BSD 4.3 Unix" textbook and that's about 
> the only reference I see to networking in the "History of Unix" 
> chapter.

Yes, work that went on before TCP/IP helped contribute to it.
I recall a class that I taught in the late 1970s, where some
students and I were discussing the IP protocol. An associate
of mine worked on Internet protocols as far back as the fall
of 1969. It wasn't IP back then but lessons learned from
these ancient protocols, especially routing protocols,
influenced the design of IP and modern day routing protocols.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

From alan at clueserver.org  Tue Feb  4 13:36:02 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Tue Feb  4 13:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030204132555.017c86d8@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302040453240.1564-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Tue, 4 Feb 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:

> At 10:54 AM 2/4/2003 -0800, you wrote:
> >I'm not that ancient yet and even some 20 years ago I didn't see Unix
> >systems in a networked environment that much. We mostly had 1200 bps
> >serial connections to dumb terminals.
> 
> 
> Um, what did the dumb terminals connect to, and what OS was THAT computer 
> running?
> 
> I'd bet it was some form of Unix.

In my case you would lose the bet.

The PICK os ran on dumb terminals at 9600 baud (or slower) using 
unshielded lines in most cases.  They did not move to Unix until the early 
90s.

The first dumb terminals I used were on a Honeywell mainframe at the 
University of Alaska.  That system was running a Honeywell proprietary OS. 
(Back in the mid 70s.)  They started on cards and moved to DecWriters and 
VT-102s.
  




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Tue Feb  4 13:39:02 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue Feb  4 13:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030204132555.017c86d8@localhost>
References: <3E3FAB4E.8040007@linuxlink.com> <5.2.0.9.0.20030204132555.017c86d8@localhost>
Message-ID: <200302041338.19887.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Yes it was Unix but the terminals were hardwired to the system. Later on 
I saw things like terminal servers that we dialed into and that let us 
go to whatever system we specified. That was done with a network in 
place since many of the systems were in different buildings etc.

Tony

From ed at alcpress.com  Tue Feb  4 13:39:07 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Tue Feb  4 13:39:07 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <1044323552.1008.27.camel@main>
References: <1044303546.4262.331.camel@red>  <1044323552.1008.27.camel@main>
Message-ID: <1044394686.3835.413.camel@red>

On Mon, 2003-02-03 at 17:52, Steven A. Adams wrote:

> > I'm thinking that the solution is to shift the emphasis
> > away from Linux as a secure operating system to the
> > administrator. It's the administrator who makes a system
> > secure - not an operating system. When security problems
> > occur, we should not complain about Windows, we should
> > complain about administration. If company management puts
> > the pressure on their administrators to solve security
> > problems, more secure solutions, like Linux, should
> > eventually bubble to the top.
>  
> But Ed, the administrator can not force Microsoft to produce any
> security fixes. In fact, even discussing vulnerabilities in that OS
> could force one to fall prey to DMCA heart-ache, head-ache and possible
> prosecution. Just as a vague example of the attitude that those
> unfortunate individuals have to deal with, read the EULA (quite the
> fancy acronym for End-User License Agreement) for the Microsoft .NET
> Framework - it clearly states that by accepting this License Agreement
> you will NOT discuss any benchmark findings with .NET to anyone without
> the express written consent of Microsoft (I ran into that one over the
> weekend while setting up my dual boot workstation).

But that's the point. Windows administrators can't solve many
of the security problems. It's beyond their control.If company
management insists that they do, they'll be forced to search
for better solutions and tell management that changes must occur
if their demands are to be met. As it is now, most Windows
administrators are silent co-conspirators.


>  With an arrogant,
> publish only the good, attitude like this, would it be possible that the
> opinion of an administrator is going to make a difference when the CFOs
> of the world just keep signing checks for more Windows? I'm sorry, I
> think not.

Than what's the solution?

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

>

It should not make a difference, but try:

up2date -u --nox

Does the machine give you any grief about being registered with RHN?  I
know that can be a pain.  Try deleting the machine profile from RHN's
web-based interface and perhaps it will re-register and kick things into
gear.

the sound is rippled.

with a very high pitch and frequency.

From ed at alcpress.com  Tue Feb  4 14:16:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Tue Feb  4 14:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rippled Sound --> QuickTime in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <200302042155.h14LtEf21214@gate.daniloff.com>

don't know the Quick Time protocol, but is there a
way to capture the stream so it can be played off-line?

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Feb  4 14:28:06 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Feb  4 14:28:06 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Desperate situation-> Quick time videos in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <20030204175424.0DA6B36EE4@ados.com>
References: <200302032151.h13Lp6318553@gate.daniloff.com>
 <1044312255.975.9.camel@localhost.localdomain> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302040251270.32636@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <20030204175424.0DA6B36EE4@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302041407390.7954@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 4 Feb 2003, guy1656 wrote:
> No, your setting for 'EZ install - just plop-n-go' is out of calibration.

I don't think "not in line with Guy" means "out of calibration".

> A) But anyway, MPlayer builds cleanly and just works.
> B) You kinda gotta watch the configure output to make sure all the
> options you want are going to be compiled in based on the libraries you
> have available and everything, but it's not like it asks for anything
> unreasonable.
>
> Umm, statements (A) and (B) contradict each other.

I don't.  Let me (briefly) explain why.

The configure portion of the install process is not the same as the build
portion.  Once the Makefiles have been generated, the software builds
cleanly and just works.  However, making sure you're building the software
with the right options to do what you want to do requires ATTENTION.
It's not hard work.  You just watch the configure output go by and when it
says "DVD Navigation Disabled" you go "whoops!" and run ./configure --help
again and see that you should have appended --enable-dvdnav.  It's really
not rocket science or anything.  And when you actually run make, it just
works.  That's not the case with everything.

Now, I also think it's a GOOD THING that MPlayer doesn't enable everything
by default.  It's a big piece of software with lots of components and some
people may not want all that crud on their system (I wouldn't compile in
the DVD features if I didn't have a DVD ROM, for example).  So it makes
sense that you have to find the right options and enable them.  And I
don't see a functional difference between clicking a checkbox and typing
"--enable-foo".

> Software that 'just works' installs with a single and simple action (a
> 'familiar' word in a command shell, or a single action like a
> mouse-click)  runs with a similarly simple one-hit. That's what the
> 'just' part means.

I think `make all install` is pretty simple and familiar.  The
configuration takes a bit of attention, but if you're not going to pay
attention to what your software is doing, you're openning yourself up to
every kind of trojan and bug on Earth.

> So, you buy the radio, insert batteries, click 'On,' slide the volume to
> the middle, (because you didn't read the directions or look at the knob
> to know which way is LOUD - you select a mid-point expressly to avoid
> all these steps) and slide the tuner around. At this point, based on
> what you hear, you will make a decision about whether the device 'just
> works' or not.

You had to LEARN all of this at some point.  It's deeply ingrained now and
something of a cultural feature.  One might also make some argument about
the "collective unconscious".  You know how it was a running joke for most
of the eighties and nineties that you had to get your kid to program your
VCR?  The difference is the cultural queues and development rates.  Now,
most people have it figured out and the people that don't have given up or
gotten too old to care.

> Very few people buy a radio in order to learn about how amplitude
> modulation works They buy it to hear what the radio stations are
> playing. Same thing goes for the initial user in this thread. She need
> to learn about medicine, and doesn't have the bandwith to learn about
> that AND scalable back-whatchamacallits simultaneously.

You don't need to know anything about backend scalers to watch videos or
even to make MPlayer do whatever you want it to do.  Just like you don't
need to know everything about the endocrine system to know what happens
when you snort cocaine.

I mean, I don't know how HOW MPlayer works.  I don't have that level of
knowledge.  I mean, I know more than many and less than many.  I WISH I
knew more because it interests me, but that's one of the things that makes
me a geek; I have interest in details.

> So if you have a radio program, if it installs with a double-click on an
> RPM, and no other configurations are necessary, and it runs on my system
> and yours, THEN it's a 'normal, easy, simple install.'

"Normal" is relative.  Hopefully you understand that.  (Or you end up like
George W. Bush preaching about Isaiah and going "home" with "the creator"
in a eulogy for a group that included at least one hindu and one
buddhist.)

For me, a "normal, easy, simple install" is `make all install`.  The
"./configure" part is part of figuring what software I'd like installed,
what I would like it to do, and how I would like to use it.  When you use
binary installations with preconfigured options (both compile-time and
run-time options like config files), you are submitting yourself to the
decisions of other people and taking a very passive role in the way you go
about doing the things you want to do.

> If you have to go to another website and figure out what else to install
> and where to put it, AND if you don't get it right then NOTHING happens,
> well, that's called 'a bear to install.' Or worse.

You are trying to impose your ignorance on me and I won't have it.  We
have a different concept of what "a bear to install" means and you just
want to tell me that you're right and I'm wrong.  I reject that method of
thinking outright.

I do have an idea of what "a bear to install" means and it's related to
things that generate improper Makefiles, do not provide enough information
in their configure scripts or documentation to enable all of the options,
or require legal entanglements that prevent me from doing everything I can
to improve the lives of others.  So that doesn't jive with your
definition.  So what?

If you want to avoid "bears", I'm showing you another way to approach the
problem where the bears rarely come up.

> Remember, "builds cleanly and just works" contradicts "You kinda gotta
> watch."

Not if you're watching something other than the build, silly.


-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org



From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Feb  4 14:40:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Feb  4 14:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Desperate situation-> Quick time videos in  Linux?
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030204103138.00bccde8@localhost>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302040251270.32636@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <200302032151.h13Lp6318553@gate.daniloff.com> <1044312255.975.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302040251270.32636@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <5.2.0.9.0.20030204103138.00bccde8@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302041428000.7954@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 4 Feb 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> At 10:05 AM 2/4/2003 -0800, you wrote:
> > Remember, "builds cleanly and just works" contradicts "You kinda gotta
> > watch."
>
> And Jeme will now tell you that anyone that doesn't grok the output of
> make after compiling shouldn't be using a computer. They should be using
> a single purpose appliance.... :/

How many layers of misconception can you find in the above sentences?

I was writing about the output of a configure script, not make.  Those are
two totally different things that require two different (but not mutually
exclusive) knowledge sets.

> Or, at least, that's what he told me when I told him about users and how
> they don't want to know how to compile.

Again, you're mistaken and simply carried your misconception through the
discussion while ignoring the actual argument.

I tried to express to you the idea that people who didn't have a fair
understanding of how software works (which is all you need to build
software) shouldn't be MANAGING computers.  You don't need more than very
basic knowledge to USE a computer.  And if your computer doesn't have an
administrator to manage the system, then you should probably ditch it and
get an appliance.

Your radio doesn't require an administrator because it IS an appliance.  A
PC is not an appliance.  It's a multi-functioning general purpose
computing device.  You can turn it into an appliance by installing some
kind of kiosk software, but the whole thing would be faster if you just
got a device with the kiosk software in ROM and only had the hardware
supported by the kiosk functionality.

Ignorant people shouldn't administer PCs just as ignorant people shouldn't
go mucking around inside their televisions, radios or even toasters.

And every system should be devised to protect itself from ignorant USERS.
Unix does this with file permissions.  Some devices do this with
tamper-proof seals and others do it with warning labels.  When we become
educated, we figure out how to alter our file permissions, open
tamper-proof seals and recognize the true dangers expressed in warning
labels.

A user doesn't configure and install system software just as a user
doesn't convert a VCR from NTSC to PAL.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org



From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Feb  4 14:43:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Feb  4 14:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Desperate situation-> Quick time videos in  Linux?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302041046070.13893-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302041046070.13893-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302041440460.7954@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 4 Feb 2003, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> Does anyone besides me think that building software and using software
> are two **completely different** things?
[snip]
> The minute we start complaining that developers need to make sure their
> Makefiles are completely user friendly is the day that developers will
> flip us all the finger and go underground.

I agree completely.  That's why we need to encourage people either become
or find competent administrators for their general purpose computer
systems.

> The minute you decide to build software from scratch, you toss "just
> works" out the window.

No, you just change your definition of "just works".

Social norms (which "easy" and "just works" really are) are defined by the
group with which you identify.  When you decide to build software from
scratch, you move from "user" to "administrator" and the definitions
change.

J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Feb  4 14:53:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Feb  4 14:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <200302041054.44329.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302040302450.32636@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <5.2.0.9.0.20030204085848.017a2940@localhost> <3E3FAB4E.8040007@linuxlink.com>
 <200302041054.44329.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302041443540.7954@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 4 Feb 2003, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> I'm not that ancient yet and even some 20 years ago I didn't see Unix
> systems in a networked environment that much. We mostly had 1200 bps
> serial connections to dumb terminals. Most of the Unix systems I used
> didn't even have ethernet and so we copied files and executed programs
> remotely between systems using UUCP with a modem. In some cases if the
> system's were in the same room we'd make our own NULL modem cables to
> connect the systems together.

I think someone else brought this up, but if you didn't have to get up and
go over to the computer to use it, it was networked.

More (correctly and) to the point, it isn't really the network that adds
the security risks, but the multi-user expectations and capabilities of
the system.  Unix was designed for many people to use and processes run by
different users or by the "services" provided therein.  Windows was
designed <*cough*> to be used by one person sitting at the console running
every single process for local output.

This is a crucial difference when considering security.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

 http://www.openlaw.org



From felix.1 at canids.net  Tue Feb  4 15:10:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Tue Feb  4 15:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <86u1fq638t.fsf@red.stonehenge.com> on 30 Jan 2003 07:56:02 PST.
Message-ID: <200302042309.h14N98R29145@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz):
> You're being pedantic.  The only difference between the two
> is that the second one will stop one line early if the last
> line is "0" without a newline.
> 
> That's such a rare case that Perl programmers didn't worry about it
> for 11 years of Perl's existence.

yes, that's not the point.  the point is the difference
between undef and '' and '0' and 0 is important.  if someone
doesn't know why the two loops are not identical, then I'd
be wary of their understanding of Perl booleans in general.
there are way too many cargo-cult programmers out there.

yes, I'm being pedantic.  there's a normal tension between
programming as mathematics and programming as engineering.
this is not going to go away anytime soon.
--

> It's been said that if you can play solitaire you're a Windows Network Admin.
> 
> It seems that Unix/Linux admins are more capable and do a better job of 
> managing security.
> 
> How much is due to the admin's skills and how much is due to the operating 
> system?

It's a synergy. Linux (and Unix) provides the security
mechanisms but it's up to an administrator to intelligently
use them. It was/is the same way with NetWare. There's little
benefit unless administrator intelligence is applied.

From felix.1 at canids.net  Tue Feb  4 16:15:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Tue Feb  4 16:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302041443540.7954@shaft.bitmine.net> on Tue, 04 Feb 2003 14:53:09 PST.
Message-ID: <200302050014.h150E6t29268@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

pre-Internet, there were still email and online chat
programs on Unix systems, with their own security problems.
one I remember: many terminals are "smart", and with the
right escape sequences you can a) change the terminal's
"answerback" string, b) tell the terminal to send the
answerback string.  so someone using a naive email program
could read an email message that would cause their terminal
to execute, say, "rm -rf *".  this bug was killed a couple
decades ago, though it might have modern versions.
--



From stevea at nwtechops.com  Tue Feb  4 17:52:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Tue Feb  4 17:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security

	<1044323552.1008.27.camel@main>  <1044394686.3835.413.camel@red>
Message-ID: <1044409874.1003.38.camel@main>

On Tue, 2003-02-04 at 13:38, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> Than what's the solution?

I have seen management actually tell the MS reps that they intended to
spend IT dollars elsewhere, citing the fact that the product was not
worth the price anymore. That strategy sent a very clear signal to MS,
once that they realized we were serious, and the negotiation started
followed by a genuine effort to fix any existing problems that we had.

Microsoft's development teams actually have the ability to deliver
quality, I don't think that anyone would dispute that, unfortunately
their management and marketing machine lacks the motivation to allow the
basic fundamental changes necessary to implement quality and security.
This situation corrects itself a little more with every customer that
tells MS that they intend to move to a competitor.

All in all, it's really not complaints that Microsoft lacks (threads
like this one happen daily and globally). I feel that the solution rests
firmly on the shoulders of IT decision makers - when they make a
conscious decision to use non-MS products, thus stopping the constant
flow of cash, Microsoft will solve the problem very quickly.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Feb  4 20:15:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)

Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <1044409874.1003.38.camel@main>

On Tue, 4 Feb 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> On Tue, 2003-02-04 at 13:38, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> > Than what's the solution?
>
> I have seen management actually tell the MS reps that they intended to
> spend IT dollars elsewhere, citing the fact that the product was not
> worth the price anymore.
[snip]
> I feel that the solution rests firmly on the shoulders of IT decision
> makers - when they make a conscious decision to use non-MS products,
> thus stopping the constant flow of cash, Microsoft will solve the
> problem very quickly.

I don't think the question was "What is the solution to Microsoft's
security problems?", but rather, "What is the solution to showing people
that Linux-based and other Unix-like systems are less susceptible to virii
and usually more secure?"

Maybe I misread, but I don't think the problem of Microsoft's security
methods are all that relevant to most of us (except insofar as protocols
get broken and become unusable due to something Microsoft botched either
on purpose or by blunder).

J.

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Tue Feb  4 20:45:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Tue Feb  4 20:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with security
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302042012050.12504@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <1044303546.4262.331.camel@red>

Message-ID: <1044420248.3686.81.camel@main>

On Tue, 2003-02-04 at 20:15, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
 
> I don't think the question was "What is the solution to Microsoft's
> security problems?", but rather, "What is the solution to showing people
> that Linux-based and other Unix-like systems are less susceptible to virii
> and usually more secure?"
> 
> Maybe I misread, but I don't think the problem of Microsoft's security
> methods are all that relevant to most of us (except insofar as protocols
> get broken and become unusable due to something Microsoft botched either
> on purpose or by blunder).
> 
I don't think that you misread the question at all. I interpreted the
thread to be a discussion on what is the solution to putting pressure on
MS to correct some of the problems that their plague their OSes. Was
that the wrong impression?

I really don't believe that the Engineers at MS intentionally produce
code that breaks. Not sure if you remember or not but every MS OS from
Win95 and to current had a hard-coded release date that was set by MS
Marketing (we all know that this normally happens with a dart board and
not through feasibility study). Perhaps this little snip from RFC1925
would help them in the future.

  (2)  No matter how hard you push and no matter what the priority,
       you can't increase the speed of light.

       (2a) (corollary). No matter how hard you try, you can't make a
            baby in much less than 9 months. Trying to speed this up
            *might* make it slower, but it won't make it happen any
            quicker.

is solved by replacing Microsoft's products with those that
were designed to be secure from the start. Why reward

computing and for breaking the law. Jeme can argue the latter
point.

From mikedela at ipns.com  Tue Feb  4 23:15:02 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue Feb  4 23:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] egrep help please
Message-ID: <ZY1ZNLPMGCAHG2B8NHF53U1YQOZX.3e40b9db@miked>

My son is selling his game boay advance on ebay. I'm hosting the picures on my server, because I'm cheap and 
nothing sells like photographs. (except touch, bu apache doesn't do that yet)

I'm wanting to do a little specialized analysis of my log files. I want to know how many looks at the files 
with "/gba/" AND "_small.jpg" and how many looked at the files that were only "/gba/" this will tell me how 
many clicked on the link for a much larger image to really check out his item. Part of the problem is that 
there are other entries in the log that have "_small.jpg" in them.

I'm using egrep like this:
egrep -c "/gba/" /var/log/httpd/access_log
THis gives me half of what I want.

I've tried:
egrep -c "/gba/|_small" /var/log/httpd/access_log
but it gives me an EITHER search, not what I wanted. I cannot find an AND in the man page, maybe because it's 
too simple to specify.

Is there a character for this, or will egrep even do this?



Mike De La Mater
Small business networks and technology consulting
503-702-6749
mikedela at ipns.com 






From brucek at kingkon.com  Tue Feb  4 23:16:02 2003
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Tue Feb  4 23:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] bandwidth limiter?
Message-ID: <20030204231529.G19357@defiant.ncplus.net>

I share a dialup connection with another non-linux user. The modem is
on one of my linux boxen, but the other user is connected on the local
ethernet. I'd like a way to limit his use of the available bandwidth
when I'm trying to do work. He tends to do wget sequences while he's
sleeping, which is when I'm up. His equipment is not handy to me, so I
can't simply pause the process on his desktop. I'd like some toggle
that I can set on my system that limits his thruput so that I can get
useful thruput of my own. The honor system doesn't seem to be working
these days.

Any ideas on where to start?

Thanx!
-bk
-- 
Bruce Kingsland
Kingsland Konsulting
brucek at kingkon.com
360-531-3730

From mikedela at ipns.com  Tue Feb  4 23:27:01 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue Feb  4 23:27:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] more about specialized reports
Message-ID: <GF5YLHQL953274GDUQ51NHA031W5ZPN.3e40bc8c@miked>

If I use this, I get the actual lines, but I only care about the counts. Should I 
just egrep -c the result files?

Mike De La Mater
Small business networks and technology consulting
503-702-6749
mikedela at ipns.com 


#!/bin/sh

MATCH="gba"
LOGFILE="/var/log/httpd/access_log"

grep $MATCH $LOGFILE > /root/Desktop/gba.txt


MATCH="small\|132\"
LOGFILE="/root/Desktop/gba.txt"

grep -v $MATCH $LOGFILE > /root/Desktop/gba-1.txt








From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Tue Feb  4 23:34:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue Feb  4 23:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] egrep help please
In-Reply-To: <ZY1ZNLPMGCAHG2B8NHF53U1YQOZX.3e40b9db@miked>
References: <ZY1ZNLPMGCAHG2B8NHF53U1YQOZX.3e40b9db@miked>
Message-ID: <20030205073358.GB10240@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

egrep -c "/gba/.*_small.jpg" /var/log/httpd/access_log 

should work, but I'm no grep master. The idea is that you are grepping
for /gba/ followed by some set of characters (.* the "." usually means
any one char. the "*" means any number of times) followed by the
string _small.jpg.

This did what I expected on a test example I had laying arround, if
you wanted to do a true AND, you would need something more
complex.. but I'm guessing the /gba/ always comes before the
_small.jpg

-Rogan

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Tue Feb  4 23:44:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue Feb  4 23:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] more about specialized reports
In-Reply-To: <GF5YLHQL953274GDUQ51NHA031W5ZPN.3e40bc8c@miked>
References: <GF5YLHQL953274GDUQ51NHA031W5ZPN.3e40bc8c@miked>
Message-ID: <20030205074316.GD10240@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

I think hte post above is a cleaner solution, but the code below can
be condensed:

grep gba /var/log/httpd/access_log | grep _small.jpg | wc

The first # output by wc is the line count (the number of lines that
matched both greps)

pipeing grep to grep is an invaluable tool for searching code, btw. 

find . -name "*.lisp" | xargs grep -in <function_name> 

if that floods your screen,

!! | grep -i "def"

and you have the file, line # and function prototype..

-Rogan

From mikedela at ipns.com  Tue Feb  4 23:53:02 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue Feb  4 23:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] more about specialized reports
In-Reply-To: <20030205074316.GD10240@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <ZWD0ZYIDPIGLGRL2ZIDIEHCLK75B6L.3e40c2c0@miked>

So, would this find gba and eliminate the small and 132 lines?

grep gba /var/log/httpd/access_log | grep  -v _small.jpg | -v grep 132 | wc


Mike

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Wed Feb  5 01:46:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Wed Feb  5 01:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] more about specialized reports
In-Reply-To: <ZWD0ZYIDPIGLGRL2ZIDIEHCLK75B6L.3e40c2c0@miked>
References: <20030205074316.GD10240@silver.CS.ORST.EDU> <ZWD0ZYIDPIGLGRL2ZIDIEHCLK75B6L.3e40c2c0@miked>
Message-ID: <20030205094500.GF10240@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

> So, would this find gba and eliminate the small and 132 lines?
> 
> grep gba /var/log/httpd/access_log | grep  -v _small.jpg | -v grep 132 | wc

Yep. or you could probably combine the lat two greps into 

egrep -v "_small.jpg|132"

(use deMorgan's Law) 

-Rogan

>box, the bottom three are from my Slack 8.1 system.  They are all Athlon
>boxes, but that shouldn't make any difference compiler-wise as there are

all levels of Government will use Linux citing the problems that MS has
dealing with security issues.

From ali at axian.com  Wed Feb  5 07:30:02 2003
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Wed Feb  5 07:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] egrep help please
In-Reply-To: <ZY1ZNLPMGCAHG2B8NHF53U1YQOZX.3e40b9db@miked>; from mikedela@ipns.com on Tue, Feb 04, 2003 at 11:14:35PM -0800
References: <ZY1ZNLPMGCAHG2B8NHF53U1YQOZX.3e40b9db@miked>
Message-ID: <20030205072926.A23601@zaphod.axian.com>

You can use a couple of simple greps piped together.
For both:

grep "/gba/" /var/log/httpd/access_log | grep "_small.jpg" | wc

And for the other case:

grep "/gba/" /var/log/httpd/access_log | grep -v "_small.jpg" | wc

Ali

From fixin at peak.org  Wed Feb  5 12:34:02 2003
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Wed Feb  5 12:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] configuring mutt for html mail
Message-ID: <20030205123324.A31512@tpol.peak.org>

I'm trying to switch from pine to mutt, but can't get mutt to handle
incomming html mail the way pine does -- which is basically to display
it as if it were plain text.  I've set up my .mailcap file with this line:

text/html;lynx %s; copiousoutput

and in .muttrc have 

auto_view text/html

but when I try to open mail that's text/html I see a permanent message
at the bottom of mutt's display like this:

Invoking autoview command: lynx '/tmp/mutt4534'

I have to ^C to get out of that state, and then get a screen full of
raw html.

Does anybody have this working?  Any tips?  I've found plenty of sites
via google that claim it does work but none with info beyond what I've
set up in my .muttrc and .mailcap.

Versions: mutt: 1.2.5i; lynx 2.8.4dev16

Thanks,

--Eric House
-- 
******************************************************************************
* From the desktop of: Eric House, fixin at peak.org                            *
*    Crosswords 4.0 for PalmOS is out!: <http://www.peak.org/~fixin/xwords>  *
******************************************************************************

From ali at axian.com  Wed Feb  5 13:13:01 2003
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Wed Feb  5 13:13:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] configuring mutt for html mail
In-Reply-To: <20030205123324.A31512@tpol.peak.org>; from fixin@peak.org on Wed, Feb 05, 2003 at 12:33:24PM -0800
References: <20030205123324.A31512@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <20030205131245.A430@zaphod.axian.com>

I've put this in my .mailcap:

text/html; lynx -force_html %s; needsterminal;

and didn't change my .muttrc.
It works, in that I can read the html, but I have to view the 
attachments in order to see it.

Mutt 1.2.5.1i 
Lynx Version 2.8.4dev.7

Ali

From steve at wirex.net  Wed Feb  5 13:42:01 2003
From: steve at wirex.net (Steve Beattie)
Date: Wed Feb  5 13:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] configuring mutt for html mail
In-Reply-To: <20030205123324.A31512@tpol.peak.org>
References: <20030205123324.A31512@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <20030205214131.GA8648@wirex.net>

On Wed, Feb 05, 2003 at 12:33:24PM -0800, Eric House wrote:
> I'm trying to switch from pine to mutt, but can't get mutt to handle
> incomming html mail the way pine does -- which is basically to display
> it as if it were plain text.  I've set up my .mailcap file with this line:
> 
> text/html;lynx %s; copiousoutput
> 
> and in .muttrc have 
> 
> auto_view text/html

I have the same auto_view line and I'm using this in my mailcap:

text/html; links -dump %s; nametemplate=%s.html; copiousoutput

as suggested by the mutt manual at mutt.org, and it works fine in mutt
1.4. I don't have mutt 1.2.5.1 anywhere to test with.

-- 
Steve Beattie                               Don't trust programmers?
<steve at wirex.net>                         Complete StackGuard distro at
http://NxNW.org/~steve/                            immunix.org
http://www.personaltelco.net -- overthrowing QWest, one block at a time.

2/5/03 1:45:00 AM, Rogan Creswick <creswick at cs.orst.edu> 
wrote:

>> So, would this find gba and eliminate the small and 132 
lines?
>> 
>> grep gba /var/log/httpd/access_log | grep  -v _small.jpg | 
-v grep 132 | wc
>
>Yep. or you could probably combine the lat two greps into 
>
>egrep -v "_small.jpg|132"
>
>(use deMorgan's Law) 
>
>-Rogan
>
>On Tue, Feb 04, 2003 at 11:52:32PM -0800, Mike De La Mater 
wrote:
>> So, would this find gba and eliminate the small and 132 
lines?
>> 
>> grep gba /var/log/httpd/access_log | grep  -v _small.jpg | 
-v grep 132 | wc
>> 
>> 
>> Mike
>> 
>> 2/4/03 11:43:16 PM, Rogan Creswick <creswick at cs.orst.edu> 
wrote:
>> 
>> >I think hte post above is a cleaner solution, but the 
code below can
>> >be condensed:
>> >
>> >grep gba /var/log/httpd/access_log | grep _small.jpg | wc
>> >
>> >The first # output by wc is the line count (the number of 
lines that
>> >matched both greps)
>> >
>> >pipeing grep to grep is an invaluable tool for searching 
code, btw. 
>> >
>> >find . -name "*.lisp" | xargs grep -in <function_name> 
>> >
>> >if that floods your screen,
>> >
>> >!! | grep -i "def"
>> >
>> >and you have the file, line # and function prototype..
>> >
>> >-Rogan
>> >
>> >
>> >On Tue, Feb 04, 2003 at 11:26:04PM -0800, Mike De La 
Mater wrote:
>> >> If I use this, I get the actual lines, but I only care 
about the counts. 
>> Should I 
>> >> just egrep -c the result files?
>> >> 
>> >> Mike De La Mater
>> >> Small business networks and technology consulting
>> >> 503-702-6749
>> >> mikedela at ipns.com 
>> >> 
>> >> 
>> >> #!/bin/sh
>> >> 
>> >> MATCH="gba"
>> >> LOGFILE="/var/log/httpd/access_log"
>> >> 
>> >> grep $MATCH $LOGFILE > /root/Desktop/gba.txt
>> >> 
>> >> 
>> >> MATCH="small\|132\"
>> >> LOGFILE="/root/Desktop/gba.txt"
>> >> 
>> >> grep -v $MATCH $LOGFILE > /root/Desktop/gba-1.txt
>> >> 
>> >> 
>> >> 
>> >> 
>> >>

> life)
> 
> Any pointers to a new Xconfigurator or netcfg type tool (they're gone, too)?? 
> There's no man squirrelmail, no redhat-config-squirrelmail, nothing, nada that I can 
> find. The required google searches leave me wanting.

It didn't seem particularly redhat-ized when I was working with it on a
friend's computer yesterday.... although there is always a chance he
dropped the RPM version in favor of just downloading it from the SM
webpage (as I would suggest you do, if you have problems).

There was a configure script in the main squirrelmail directory that
handled most of the setup.

It authenticates with your main system as far as I know, so if you want
to add users, just add them to your system and you should be good to go.

Rob




From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Wed Feb  5 17:10:02 2003
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Wed Feb  5 17:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] managing squirrelmail under RH8
In-Reply-To: <KHZXC8E3105E942ONPKYVA5FAA5YSM.3e41b2e8@mike>
References: <KHZXC8E3105E942ONPKYVA5FAA5YSM.3e41b2e8@mike>
Message-ID: <3E41B5E2.7050500@parkrose.k12.or.us>

Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I don't knowhow to tweak configurations or set up users under the new redhat-ized 
> version of squirrelmail.
> 
> There was a script in the old version you could run to do lots of cool stuff, but 
> it's gone and I can't find out how to do it without the old way (the story of my 
> life)
> 
> Any pointers to a new Xconfigurator or netcfg type tool (they're gone, too)?? 
> There's no man squirrelmail, no redhat-config-squirrelmail, nothing, nada that I can 
> find. The required google searches leave me wanting.

I'd be looking at:

/etc/httpd/conf.d/squirrelmail.conf
/etc/squirrelmail/config.php
/usr/share/squirrelmail/config/conf.pl

I think the last one is the missing configure script you are looking for.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

   .nr a 5819013056
   .af a a 
   \na
   <standard input>:1: numeric overflow
   0

On Tue, 2003-02-04 at 23:33, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> 
> egrep -c "/gba/.*_small.jpg" /var/log/httpd/access_log 
> 
> should work, but I'm no grep master. The idea is that you are grepping
> for /gba/ followed by some set of characters (.* the "." usually means
> any one char. the "*" means any number of times) followed by the
> string _small.jpg.
> 
> This did what I expected on a test example I had laying arround, if
> you wanted to do a true AND, you would need something more
> complex.. but I'm guessing the /gba/ always comes before the
> _small.jpg
> 
> -Rogan
> 
>

> > with "/gba/" AND "_small.jpg" and how many looked at the files that were only "/gba/" this will tell me how 
> > many clicked on the link for a much larger image to really check out his item. Part of the problem is that 
> > there are other entries in the log that have "_small.jpg" in them.
> > 
> > I'm using egrep like this:
> > egrep -c "/gba/" /var/log/httpd/access_log
> > THis gives me half of what I want.
> > 
> > I've tried:
> > egrep -c "/gba/|_small" /var/log/httpd/access_log
> > but it gives me an EITHER search, not what I wanted. I cannot find an AND in the man page, maybe because it's 
> > too simple to specify.
> > 
> > Is there a character for this, or will egrep even do this?

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Wed Feb  5 21:46:07 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Wed Feb  5 21:46:07 2003
Subject: [PLUG] managing squirrelmail under RH8
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302051825110.23122-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302051825110.23122-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <E18geqq-0007yv-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

rpm -qd , very nice. This is my attempt to make this easy for me to use. Any
ideas on  how to make the menu more managable when the script finds a lot of
documents? 


#!/bin/sh

if [ $1 ] ; then
	WTHIT=$1
else
	echo "usage: $0 pattern"
	exit 1
fi
let x=0
for i in `rpm -qa | grep $WTHIT` ; do
	DOC=`rpm -qd $i`
	if [ x = 0 ] ; then
		DOCS="$DOC"
		let x=1
	else
		DOCS="$DOCS $DOC"
	fi  
done
PS3="Please select the menu number for the resource you wish to view #"
select RESOURCE in $DOCS ; do
	if [ $RESOURCE ] ; then 
		if [ `echo $RESOURCE | grep man` ] ; then
			man $RESOURCE
			exit 0
		elif [ `echo $RESOURCE | tr [:upper:] [:lower:] | grep html` ]
; then
			links -g $RESOURCE
			exit 0	
		elif [ $RESOURCE ] ; then
			less $RESOURCE
			exit 0
		fi
	else	
		echo "Invalid Selection"
	fi
done
exit 0


I like links 2.1 instead of lynx but either should work. 


Thank you
Russell


On Wed, 5 Feb 2003 18:28:14 -0800 (PST), Paul Heinlein said:

>  rpm lets you query for documentation (assuming the packager designated 
>  it with a %doc macro):
>  
>    rpm -qd squirrelmail

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Thu Feb  6 09:19:01 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Thu Feb  6 09:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] managing squirrelmail under RH8
In-Reply-To: <3E41B5E2.7050500@parkrose.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <20030206171739.18640.qmail@web40804.mail.yahoo.com>

> > Any pointers to a new Xconfigurator or netcfg type
> tool (they're gone, too)?? 
> > There's no man squirrelmail, no
> redhat-config-squirrelmail, nothing, nada that I can

Not sure about Squirrelmail, but the replacement for
Xconfigurator is twofold:

  redhat-config-xfree86

This will set up X, but the catch is, it needs a
rudimentary X to run.

To set up a basix X configuration so you can run
redhat-config-xfree86:

  xf86config

I hope in 8.1 they smooth out this process.

-Scott

From siobhan at sdf.lonestar.org  Thu Feb  6 11:11:01 2003
From: siobhan at sdf.lonestar.org (Siobhan Elliott)
Date: Thu Feb  6 11:11:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] configuring mutt for html mail
In-Reply-To: <20030205123324.A31512@tpol.peak.org>
References: <20030205123324.A31512@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <20030206191027.GA13485@sdf.lonestar.org>

> I'm trying to switch from pine to mutt, but can't get mutt to handle
> incomming html mail the way pine does -- which is basically to display
> it as if it were plain text.  I've set up my .mailcap file with this line:
> 
> text/html;lynx %s; copiousoutput
> 
> and in .muttrc have 
> 
> auto_view text/html

<SNIP>

> Does anybody have this working?  Any tips?  I've found plenty of sites
> via google that claim it does work but none with info beyond what I've
> set up in my .muttrc and .mailcap.

Yep, put this in your .mailcap instead:

text/html; lynx -dump -force-html %s; copiousoutput nametemplate=%s.html

Kind regards,
-- 
Siobhan Elliott
Mail: siobhan at sdf.lonestar.org
AIM: chordchemist999



From barryb at proaxis.com  Thu Feb  6 12:15:02 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Thu Feb  6 12:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] configuring mutt for html mail
In-Reply-To: <20030205123324.A31512@tpol.peak.org>
References: <20030205123324.A31512@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <20030206201413.GA3093@edge.edge>

I like to use the links browser instead of lynx. It
does a better job with tables and layout. So in
.mailcap I have

text/html;      links %s; nametemplate=%s.html

Bill Barry

On Wed, Feb 05, 2003 at 12:33:24PM -0800, Eric House wrote:

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Feb  6 13:05:03 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Feb  6 13:05:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Intel Linux compiler
In-Reply-To: <3e42ad28.63ba.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302061255290.20354-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 6 Feb 2003, stuart mathews wrote:

> I've heard talk about an "Intel C++ Compiler for Linux"; do they
> have a separate Linux compiler for C, or is it all bundled together?  
> Also, anybody know how I might be able to get one?

icc, the Intel compiler (at least ver. 6.0; I haven't used 7.0) will
indeed compile C code.

You can get a free noncommercial-use license just by asking Intel.  
There are some restrictions that come with the free license, e.g.,

  If you are using the Materials under the control of a
  Noncommercial-Use license, you as an individual may use the 
  Materials for only personal, noncommercial and research purposes.  
  The Materials may not be used fo r any other purpose, whether "for
  profit" or "not for profit."  Any work perform ed or produced as a
  result of use of the Materials cannot be performed or produc ed for
  the benefit of other parties for a fee, compensation or any other
  reimbur sement or remuneration.

I've never done any performance testing of the binaries it produces,
though they seem to behave well. Assuming your output is dynamically
linked, it will have a dependency on one or more of the Intel runtime
libaries.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> linked, it will have a dependency on one or more of the Intel runtime
> libaries.

Does this means that if I wrote a dynamically-linked GPL program
with Intel's compiler I'd be able to distribute the libraries?

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC




From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Feb  6 15:51:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Feb  6 15:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Intel Linux compiler
In-Reply-To: <1044569367.3835.893.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302061547090.20354-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 6 Feb 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> On Thu, 2003-02-06 at 13:04, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> 
> > I've never done any performance testing of the binaries it
> > produces, though they seem to behave well. Assuming your output is
> > dynamically linked, it will have a dependency on one or more of
> > the Intel runtime libaries.
> 
> Does this means that if I wrote a dynamically-linked GPL program
> with Intel's compiler I'd be able to distribute the libraries?

Yep. You may redistribute the libraries, unless you're using the
'Evaluation License,' in which case you can't do much of anything
besides evaluate the product. Here's the legalese:

    Redistributables: include header, library, and dynamically 
    linkable library files. You may copy and distribute (except under
    an Evaluation License) the Redistributables, or any portions
    thereof, as part of the product you developed using the Developer
    Tools.

    ...

    The Materials defined as Redistributables are the following files: 

    libcprts.so.1
    libcprts.so
    libcxa.so.1
    libcxa.so
    libguide.so
    libunwind.so.1
    libunwind.so.2
    libunwind.so

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From ed at alcpress.com  Thu Feb  6 16:12:01 2003

References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302061547090.20354-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <1044576670.4262.902.camel@red>

Thanks, Paul. I find their 30% speed improvement interesting.
I'm also wondering whether statically-linking with their
compiler produces executables that are as large as with
gcc and GNU libraries.

Ed

Date: Thu Feb  6 17:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Tools for reading Prime Magsav/Magrst or other strange data tapes
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302061721570.7788-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

data from strange internal formatted tapes?  I wrote some tools for
this at one time, but they were very specific and limited in their
abilities.  I also used a great (and very complex) tool called Forms in
the 1970s that ran on CDC Cybers; but haven't seen anything like it since.

I need to read a tape or part of a tape that was created on a Prime
computer using Magsav/Magrst.  I think they created the tape in about
1990.  I would hate to use dd and write C programs to convert the data,
but if need be ...

From daniel_petcher at yahoo.com  Thu Feb  6 22:09:01 2003
From: daniel_petcher at yahoo.com (Daniel Petcher)
Date: Thu Feb  6 22:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Anyone know where one could find a 9 track tape drive?
Message-ID: <20030207060856.58300.qmail@web20107.mail.yahoo.com>

There's a dead-tree type magazine called "The Processor" with a website
http://www.processor.com that somewhat resembles Computer Shopper from
a decade ago: it's got no articles -- just classified and
non-classified advertising. Fortunately, a subscription is free. The
ads they publish are mostly for midrange (ie. rackmount,
enterprise-class stuff) equipment, with some of it new and some used
stuff available. I think their website might also have a search engine.
I'll bet they have someone who will sell you a 9-track drive.

Words could not express my joy a few years ago when my manager decided
to migrate our tape library from 9-track to DAT! Those were the
days....


David asked:
Where could I get a 9 track tape drive in install on my Linux
workstation?
Should be SCSI rather than Pertec interface.  Prefer cheap.  I'm poor
at
the moment.  Needs to read 2400' reel to reel 9 track tapes recorded at
6250 bpi.

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Thu Feb  6 22:43:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Thu Feb  6 22:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Intel Linux compiler
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302061656480.20354-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0302062240450.27876-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

Be warned that the compiler's quality is suboptimal at best. We have
several bug reports open with Intel against this compiler. With
optimization enabled, it can generate bad code very easilly, and it's damn
hard to find.

From daniel_petcher at yahoo.com  Fri Feb  7 05:40:02 2003
From: daniel_petcher at yahoo.com (Daniel Petcher)
Date: Fri Feb  7 05:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] a Samba PDC - has it actually been done?
Message-ID: <20030207133945.10185.qmail@web20102.mail.yahoo.com>

I've heard that it can be done, and I've got five different
(conflicting) sets of instructions regarding HOW to do it, but I just
want to know....

Has anybody set-up Samba to act as an NT4 primary domain controller to
authenticate logins from Win98SE boxes _AND_ joined a Windows2000
server to this Samba-controlled domain? Before I invest any more time
and effort in this project that's momentarily beyond my skills, I want
to know if anyone else has successfully done it before. I've heard it's
possible, I've gathered documentation, and I've seen ads for embedded
appliances that claim to have this feature, but I want to know whether
or not some mere mortal has done it before.

I've got plenty of systems experience and a worthless paper
certification on the Windows side of the planet, and I've been using
mostly-GUI applications in Linux. I've hacked at this in my spare time
for a few weeks with limited success. This is my first real
system-level project in Linux and I'm just drowning in obsolete and
incompletely debugged information.

I found an excellent tutorial from IBM, but just because it's
well-written, that doesn't mean it's necessarily accurate from the
technical standpoint. I've read HowTo documents from Samba.org, but
they haven't been updated in a timely fashion. I spoke to David last
night at the meeting and he recommended some dead-tree references I
might find at Powell's Technical annex.

From daniel_petcher at yahoo.com  Fri Feb  7 05:53:01 2003

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Feb  7 07:15:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Feb  7 07:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RH8 Installation (anaconda?) question
In-Reply-To: <20030207135248.40763.qmail@web20109.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302070655420.8864-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Fri, 7 Feb 2003, Daniel Petcher wrote:

> I then proceded to screw around with settings and install programs
> that I don't really want to have around in the long run. I have
> copied my install.log and anaconda-ks.cfg files to a floppy disk. Is
> there some way to use these as a script to reinstall the OS and my
> selected tools without walking through twenty minutes worth of
> check-boxes?

I see from your follow-up message that you've got this straightened 
out, but since PLUG can never let a simple "it's working" statement go 
without comment...

Take a peek at the base/comps.xml file in your installation tree (on 
the CD or wherever). It's a big file, but you'll get the hang of it 
pretty quickly.

It'll tell you exactly what individual RPMs are associated with each
package group and whether those RPMs must be installed, are usually 
installed, or are optional (not usually installed). Here, for 
instance, is the package list for the 'Web Server' group:

  <packagelist>
    <packagereq type="mandatory">httpd</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="mandatory">httpd-manual</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="default">hwcrypto</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="default">mod_python</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="default">mod_perl</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="default">mod_ssl</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="default">php</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="default">php-imap</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="default">php-ldap</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="optional">php-pgsql</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="optional">mod_auth_pgsql</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="default">squid</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="default">tux</packagereq>
    <packagereq type="default">webalizer</packagereq>
  </packagelist>

The only packages you need to install are httpd (Apache) and its 
documentation. The ones marked 'default' are typically installed 
unless you say otherwise. The ones marked 'optional' are typically 
*not* installed unless you specify them.

If you're doing network installation of Red Hat, you can easily 
customize any existing group. If you don't think the Apache manual is 
all that necessary, then edit its entry:

  <packagereq type="optional">httpd-manual</packagereq>

Or you can create your own groups that contain non-default packages 
you want installed on all your systems. Here's a group I created for 
use at work:

  <group>
    <id>cfst-required</id>
    <uservisible>true</uservisible>
    <name>CFST Required</name>
    <description>
      A grouping of CFST-built packages and some Red Hat packages we 
      install by default on all Linux hosts.
    </description>
    <packagelist>
      <!-- required locally built rpms -->
      <packagereq type="default">cfengine</packagereq>
      <packagereq type="default">qr</packagereq>
      <!-- required red hat packages -->
      <packagereq type="default">chkconfig</packagereq>
      <packagereq type="default">mysql</packagereq>
      <packagereq type="default">ntp</packagereq>
      <packagereq type="default">perl-CGI</packagereq>
      <packagereq type="default">perl-DBD-MySQL</packagereq>
      <packagereq type="default">perl-DBI</packagereq>
      <packagereq type="default">perl-RPM2</packagereq>
      <packagereq type="default">perl-TermReadKey</packagereq>
      <packagereq type="default">rcs</packagereq>
    </packagelist>
  </group>

The 'CFST Required' package group shows up during the install process 
(if you're doing a manual installation) and can also be invoked during 
a kickstart installation. It installs some Red Hat packages that might 
not get installed otherwise, plus some locally built packages on 
which we rely[1].

I'm sure this is more than you wanted to know... :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

[1] Actually, some more trickery is involved before a locally built 
    package can be grafted into the Red Hat installer, but it's not 
    that difficult.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Fri Feb  7 11:04:01 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Feb  7 11:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] a Samba PDC - has it actually been done?
In-Reply-To: <20030207133945.10185.qmail@web20102.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030207133945.10185.qmail@web20102.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1044644612.8760.23.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Fri, 2003-02-07 at 05:39, Daniel Petcher wrote:
> I've heard that it can be done, and I've got five different
> (conflicting) sets of instructions regarding HOW to do it, but I just
> want to know....
> 
> Has anybody set-up Samba to act as an NT4 primary domain controller to
> authenticate logins from Win98SE boxes _AND_ joined a Windows2000
> server to this Samba-controlled domain? Before I invest any more time
> and effort in this project that's momentarily beyond my skills, I want
> to know if anyone else has successfully done it before. I've heard it's
> possible, I've gathered documentation, and I've seen ads for embedded
> appliances that claim to have this feature, but I want to know whether
> or not some mere mortal has done it before.

I set up a Samba PDC on my little server-in-the-closet system a month or
two back Just Because I Could.  It seems to work as designed, although
I've never had the pleasure of playing with domains before.

It was all very very easy to set up.  I had Windows 98 and Windows 2000
boxes as members of the domain, and was able to authenticate with it on
a more temporary basis from XP Home... and also from XP Pro, although XP
Pro can be joined to the domain like all other versions of Windows
except XP Home.

Anyway, it works well.

But, I haven't tried to join a Windows 2000 *server* to the domain
before.  Did you want it to act as a backup PDC or something?  Samba is
limited in regards to how well it works with other domain controllers,
if I remember correctly.

Anyway... if you like, I can post my smb.conf file... I know how
daunting it can seem to try and write one from scratch.  Mine is
modified from one a friend gave me, so it's only fair I pass it along. 
:-)

Rob

> to migrate our tape library from 9-track to DAT! Those were the

We purchased our 9-track drive about 15 years ago because the mail
list houses would only accept 9-track media. We could fit our data
on a floppy but that was too cutting edge for them at the time.
Tapes were expensive compared to floppies so I purchased about 100
used tapes from a company in Boston. The tapes came complete with
company accounting data.

From guy1656 at ados.com  Fri Feb  7 17:03:01 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Fri Feb  7 17:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Helping MPlayer install to -not- suck ...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302041407390.7954@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <200302032151.h13Lp6318553@gate.daniloff.com> <20030204175424.0DA6B36EE4@ados.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302041407390.7954@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20030208005007.2C21B365DE@ados.com>

:  You just watch the configure output go by and when it
: says "DVD Navigation Disabled" you go "whoops!" and run ./configure --help
: again and see that you should have appended --enable-dvdnav. 

How easy is it to know that, (in your case) you should have 'appended' 
"--enable dvdnav"? This is where good feedback (telling the operator what's 
happenig in a language he can understand) is critical to usability. 

: Now, I also think it's a GOOD THING that MPlayer doesn't enable everything
: by default.  It's a big piece of software with lots of components and some
: people may not want all that crud on their system (I wouldn't compile in
: the DVD features if I didn't have a DVD ROM, for example).  So it makes
: sense that you have to find the right options and enable them. 

After reading this part, (and to offer something constructive to the whole 
list) 

: I think `make all install` is pretty simple and familiar. 

I never heard of 'make all install.' (I'm not setting myself up a s'the' 
reference standard, but it's also NOT in the indices of my:

Mandrake 8.0 "Installation and User Guide"
Mandrake 8.0 "Reference Manual"
Siever, "Linux in a Nutshell" (O'Reilly)
Cornes, "Linux A-Z" (Prentice Hall)
Welsh, Kaufmann "Runnin Linux" (O'Reilly)

This indicates that 'make all install' is far less well-known and certainly 
not explained in a quickly accessable fashion. (Remember we're -still- trying 
to wacth the movie, not read 5 books.)

OK - on to the constructive suggestions:

It occurs to me that, since (a) I'm not alone, and (b) WAL-MART has been 
selling Lindows machines for $199, that there will be a GROWING (read: 
"profitable?") market for simple CD's that implement simple 'appliance' 
programs FOR you.

How big is MPlayer when uncompressed and installed? A couple of megs?)
Next question: How much is the space for -all- the required dependent 
libraries for -all- the available functions? 100M tops? (I don't know - if my 
guesses are wrong please feel free to tweak the numbers.)

What I'm driving at is this: If the process of interrogating a machine and 
finding out what's there and what's not, PLUS writing a GUI to ask the user 
what he* wants and don't want (DVD? etc.) is -sooo- easy:

Then could a company be formed to prodice and market an 'MPLayer installer 
CD?' I'd pay $12 - $22 bux for it. 

The CD has - what - 650MB or more available? So, we should be able to write 
(in 400MB?) a program to help the user find and fix what's wrong.

What do you think? Can we do this? Does anybody want to? Gather seed money 
and do a website or product launch? I already have a company and a rented 
mailbox. Anyone interested?

-GLL

*he/she - My copy of Strunk & White, 5th ed, says 'he' is usable here.



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Feb  7 17:22:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri Feb  7 17:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Helping MPlayer install to -not- suck ...
In-Reply-To: <20030208005007.2C21B365DE@ados.com>
References: <200302032151.h13Lp6318553@gate.daniloff.com>
	<20030204175424.0DA6B36EE4@ados.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0302041407390.7954@shaft.bitmine.net> 
	<20030208005007.2C21B365DE@ados.com>
Message-ID: <1044667265.15970.77.camel@rheingold>

On Fri, 2003-02-07 at 17:01, guy1656 wrote:
 
> : I think `make all install` is pretty simple and familiar. 
> 
> I never heard of 'make all install.' (I'm not setting myself up a s'the' 
> reference standard, but it's also NOT in the indices of my:

Usually it's given as 
$ make
$ make install

in the 'INSTALL' doc from autoconf, often proceeded by './configure'. 
'all' is usually the default target by convention, but you probably
wouldn't get that from a beginner's book (or possibly by anything other
than looking at Makefiles...)

Wil

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Feb  7 17:35:02 2003
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Fri Feb  7 17:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to indentify a computer on the network
Message-ID: <1517.134.244.174.42.1044668013.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>

Hello all,

I'm sure some of you have had this problem and can give me a nice trick to
find the computer.

I have a computer on the network doing NTP broadcast yet I can not find it.

I know the IP and I know that windows nbtstat doesn't respond.  This makes
me think that maybe it is some sort of linux box.  But I could be wrong.

Does anyone know how I would go about testing to see what type of machine
it is and how to find it?  I have no idea where it is in the building
either.

Thanks,

Josh





From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Feb  7 17:43:01 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri Feb  7 17:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to indentify a computer on the network
In-Reply-To: <1517.134.244.174.42.1044668013.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
References: <1517.134.244.174.42.1044668013.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <1044668531.15970.82.camel@rheingold>

On Fri, 2003-02-07 at 17:33, Josh Orchard wrote:
> Hello all,
> 
> I'm sure some of you have had this problem and can give me a nice trick to
> find the computer.
> 
> I have a computer on the network doing NTP broadcast yet I can not find it.
> 
> I know the IP and I know that windows nbtstat doesn't respond.  This makes
> me think that maybe it is some sort of linux box.  But I could be wrong.
> 
> Does anyone know how I would go about testing to see what type of machine
> it is and how to find it?  I have no idea where it is in the building
> either.

If you've got the IP address, you've also got the MAC address.  From
that, you can find a) The NIC manufacturer and b) The switch port
(assuming you're using switched Ethernet).

Wil
--

It varies by vendor and I assume you have a managed switch.  I've done
it with 3Com and Cisco switches, but it's been so long I don't remember
exactly.

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Fri Feb  7 19:41:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Fri Feb  7 19:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Helping MPlayer install to -not- suck ...
In-Reply-To: <20030208005007.2C21B365DE@ados.com>
References: <200302032151.h13Lp6318553@gate.daniloff.com>
	<20030204175424.0DA6B36EE4@ados.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0302041407390.7954@shaft.bitmine.net> 
	<20030208005007.2C21B365DE@ados.com>
Message-ID: <1044675628.1004.95.camel@main>

On Fri, 2003-02-07 at 17:01, guy1656 wrote:
> What do you think? Can we do this? Does anybody want to? Gather seed money 
> and do a website or product launch? I already have a company and a rented 
> mailbox. Anyone interested?

I'm not too sure that you'll get favorable market study results on this.
The reason that I say this is because most source tarballs, and I have
not seen any that don't, come with at least a README or INSTALL document
in the source root. If you look in the source root of the latest MPlayer
tarball you'll find a README text file that includes step by step
installation procedures.

Yes, configure/make/make install  is more difficult than insert CD/click
Setup but I would encourage you to ask around and see if you can get a
feel for how many folks really hate to read an INSTALL document
(something that will have to be done regardless of the installation
method).




From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Feb  7 19:52:01 2003

Yes it is a coorporate place.  I don't have control over the switches but
I have access to them.  I can get the login into them I believe on Monday.
 That guy is in another office.  But if I do this over the weekend I can
even goes so far as to figure out who it is.  But Since our sub-office is
pretty small I doubt it will effect anyone that much.  I have since left
the office so I can't tell you what type of switches.

If I did have access to them I still would only be able to find out which
port the computer is pulled into.  Then I would still have to go all
around the office checking every cube/room for a computer connected to
that port number provided that the labeling is correct. One of the reasons
I thought just unplugging it would be faster.  OH, and I'm lazy.  I'm sure
it is not an old exchange server or any "real" server.  We don't have
anything that important in our office anymore.  They moved those all very
far away.

If I had a way to tell what type of machine it was I could really narrow
down the problem really fast.  I can't seem to find a tool that would scan
all ports and give me a report on what type of machine.  I know it doesn't
have a web server running.  So that option is out.

Josh

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Fri Feb  7 19:56:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Fri Feb  7 19:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to indentify a computer on the network
References: <1517.134.244.174.42.1044668013.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org> <3E446760.20408@pacifier.com> <mailman.1044670746.17332.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86vfzvxwe4.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Josh" == Josh Orchard <josh at emediatedesigns.com> writes:

Josh> It seems that there are place holders in the DNS and folks have used IP's
Josh> that they were not suppose to use.  HMM.  Anywho, I'll just go to the
Josh> switch and start pulling cables until my laptop stops responding to the
Josh> ping.  Then I'll waiting until the user of the computer complains.  That
Josh> way I'll know. :-)

If it's running buggy enough software, you can probably find a few O/S
exploits from the known sources, and then take it over and start
making it beep loudly. :)

On a more practical note, "sudo nmap -O i.p.ad.dr" will at least give
you an idea of O/S it's running.

From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Fri Feb  7 20:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to indentify a computer on the network
In-Reply-To: <1517.134.244.174.42.1044668013.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
References: <1517.134.244.174.42.1044668013.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <200302072004.29266.griffint@pobox.com>

To determine the OS try:

      nmap -O [ipaddress]

On Friday 07 February 2003 05:33 pm, Josh Orchard wrote:
> Hello all,
>
> I'm sure some of you have had this problem and can give me a nice trick to
> find the computer.
>
> I have a computer on the network doing NTP broadcast yet I can not find it.
>
> I know the IP and I know that windows nbtstat doesn't respond.  This makes
> me think that maybe it is some sort of linux box.  But I could be wrong.
>
