From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Feb  7 20:06:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Feb  7 20:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Helping MPlayer install to -not- suck ...
In-Reply-To: <20030208005007.2C21B365DE@ados.com>
References: <200302032151.h13Lp6318553@gate.daniloff.com>
 <20030204175424.0DA6B36EE4@ados.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302041407390.7954@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <20030208005007.2C21B365DE@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302071941520.27644@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 7 Feb 2003, guy1656 wrote:
> How easy is it to know that, (in your case) you should have 'appended'
> "--enable dvdnav"? This is where good feedback (telling the operator
> what's happenig in a language he can understand) is critical to
> usability.

And I think most configure scripts are pretty straightforward and usable
in that respect.  You get something like:
checking for dvd navigation.... No.

And when you run ./configure --help, you get some output line like
--enable-dvdnav        Enable dvd menu navigation

It's pretty straightforward.

> : Now, I also think it's a GOOD THING that MPlayer doesn't enable everything
> : by default.  It's a big piece of software with lots of components and some
> : people may not want all that crud on their system (I wouldn't compile in
> : the DVD features if I didn't have a DVD ROM, for example).  So it makes
> : sense that you have to find the right options and enable them.
>
> After reading this part, (and to offer something constructive to the
> whole list)

Was there to be more here?

> : I think `make all install` is pretty simple and familiar.
>
> I never heard of 'make all install.' (I'm not setting myself up a s'the'
> reference standard, but it's also NOT in the indices of my:
>
> Mandrake 8.0 "Installation and User Guide"
> Mandrake 8.0 "Reference Manual"
> Siever, "Linux in a Nutshell" (O'Reilly)
> Cornes, "Linux A-Z" (Prentice Hall)
> Welsh, Kaufmann "Runnin Linux" (O'Reilly)
>
> This indicates that 'make all install' is far less well-known and
> certainly not explained in a quickly accessable fashion. (Remember we're
> -still- trying to wacth the movie, not read 5 books.)

As with most unix commands, there's lots of ways to phrase the same thing.
You might see it as `make; make install`, `make && make install` or merely
`make install`.

Also note that those references are for USERS rather than administrators
(and I don't think Mandrake probably goes through a lot of trouble to
distinguish between the two).

I think you'll find lots of information if you just look at make(1).
You'll see that "all" is the default paramter and parameters passed in
sequence are processed in the sequence they were passed.

> OK - on to the constructive suggestions:
>
> It occurs to me that, since (a) I'm not alone, and (b) WAL-MART has been
> selling Lindows machines for $199, that there will be a GROWING (read:
> "profitable?") market for simple CD's that implement simple 'appliance'
> programs FOR you.

Right.  As I wrote before, it is possible to turn a general purpose PC
into an appliance by installing some kind of kiosk software... preferably
on read-only media.

However, if you want a general purpose computer to remain a general
purpose computer, you're going to need an administrator to keep it running
smoothly and securely.

> How big is MPlayer when uncompressed and installed? A couple of megs?)
> Next question: How much is the space for -all- the required dependent
> libraries for -all- the available functions? 100M tops? (I don't know -
> if my guesses are wrong please feel free to tweak the numbers.)

100MB is absurd.  See the following:
jbrelin at person:~$ du -m /usr/bin/mplayer
3       /usr/bin/mplayer
jbrelin at person:~$ ldd /usr/bin/mplayer | sed -e 's/.*=> \([^
]*\).*/\1/'|xargs du -mDc
1       /usr/lib/libdvdnav.so.1
1       /usr/lib/libdvdread.so.2
1       /lib/libpthread.so.0
1       /usr/lib/libmad-0.13.0b.so
1       /usr/lib/libvorbis.so.0
1       /usr/lib/libogg.so.0
1       /usr/lib/libdivxdecore.so.0
1       /usr/lib/libpng.so.2
1       /usr/lib/libz.so.1
1       /usr/lib/libjpeg.so.62
1       /usr/lib/libcdda_interface.so.0
1       /usr/lib/libcdda_paranoia.so.0
1       /lib/libnsl.so.1
3       /usr/lib/libgtk-1.2.so.0
1       /usr/lib/libgdk-1.2.so.0
1       /usr/lib/libgmodule-1.2.so.0
1       /usr/lib/libglib-1.2.so.0
1       /lib/libdl.so.2
1       /usr/X11R6/lib/libXext.so.6
1       /usr/X11R6/lib/libX11.so.6
1       /lib/libm.so.6
1       /usr/lib/libaa.so.1
1       /usr/X11R6/lib/libGL.so.1
2       /usr/lib/libSDL-1.2.so.0
1       /usr/lib/libungif.so.4
1       /usr/lib/libiconv.so.2
5       /lib/libc.so.6
1       /lib/libncurses.so.5
1       /usr/lib/libslang.so.1
1       /usr/lib/libgpm.so.1
1       /usr/lib/libesd.so.0
1       /usr/lib/libaudiofile.so.0
1       /lib/ld-linux.so.2
17      total

So we're looking at 20MB for the binary and all the dynamic libraries,
many of which are shared with dozens or hundreds of other executables.

> What I'm driving at is this: If the process of interrogating a machine
> and finding out what's there and what's not, PLUS writing a GUI to ask
> the user what he* wants and don't want (DVD? etc.) is -sooo- easy:

It only interrogates for things that are either on by default or
specifically requested.  The default setting for each optional capability
is really up to the maintainer.  I prefer that optional things be turned
off until I enable them.  Some prefer the opposite.  There are good
arguments for both sides and you end up with, in practice, a mix.

> Then could a company be formed to prodice and market an 'MPLayer
> installer CD?' I'd pay $12 - $22 bux for it.

I suppose people COULD do that, if they wanted to keep secrets for a
living.  After all, the entire business model here is to keep information
from people who do not pay and restrict those who do pay from sharing
information with others.  I find that entire concept unsavory.

> The CD has - what - 650MB or more available? So, we should be able to
> write (in 400MB?) a program to help the user find and fix what's wrong.
>
> What do you think? Can we do this? Does anybody want to? Gather seed
> money and do a website or product launch? I already have a company and a
> rented mailbox. Anyone interested?

I think you're trying to solve a problem that doesn't exist.

I think the real business opportunity is home system administration.
Show people that making a computer system work smoothly and securely
requires a trained individual that isn't present in most households.  I
think such a service could probably be provided to most households for
$20/month for the first pc and $10 for each thereafter with the
requirement that the household have a broadband connection and run some
remote administration software (sshd should be fine).

> *he/she - My copy of Strunk & White, 5th ed, says 'he' is usable here.

I personally believe that english has no male pronouns or, indeed,
specifically male words.  There are general words and feminine words.
Unfortunately, usage has made a mess of the whole thing and there are fine
literary examples of "they" in the singular for these occassions as well
as the argument (again, from example, but language is only "correct"
insofar as we understand each other) that either neutral or feminine
pronoun is usable in a hypothetical because the gender is also
hypothetical and the relevance of the gender is up to the reader to
deduce.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org



From kgoins at aracnet.com  Fri Feb  7 20:11:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] SuSE 64bit Power PC help needed.
Message-ID: <3E44834F.6070007@aracnet.com>

First of all no throwing things at me. I admit I don't eat, sleep and drink 
Linux. But, I've played with and have a Mandrake 8.1 system running here at 
home. I generally navigate/config via MidnightCommander, X or Webmin.

I have been asked to do some work on SuSE 64bit PowerPC setup remotely. Best I 
can tell the system is not much more than a default install with some small 
changes. I want to be able to use X remotely via both my linux box and a windows 
system. I've seen this done in the past but never needed to do it. Ialso will 
need some help getting sendmail to relay to and rcv mail from another server via 
smtp.

I did a quick browse of the SuSE install man but it's mainly just that. It 
assumes that you want to run X on a phyically attached monitor, mouse etc which 
I am not.

Thoughts? Comments? Hints on were to go ? (careful what you say, little ones may 
be reading this)

thanks

says it is a VxWorks 5.3.x based System.  usually an ethernet hub or
switch or BayNetworks MicroAnnex XL Term Server.

send an email.  That would make sense.  I'll make the guy complaining fix
it.  Thanks for the help.

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Fri Feb  7 21:33:01 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Fri Feb  7 21:33:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to indentify a computer on the network
In-Reply-To: <1877.216.99.218.67.1044676259.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
References: <1517.134.244.174.42.1044668013.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org><3E446760.20408@pacifier.com><1878.134.244.174.42.1044670635.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org><1044672933.1005.66.camel@main>
    <1877.216.99.218.67.1044676259.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <E18hNar-0000YW-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

nmap -vv -P0 -O -p 1-1024 IP_ADDRESS

http://www.insecure.org/nmap/

The -O is OS finger printing.

Thank you
Russell

On Fri, 7 Feb 2003 19:50:59 -0800 (PST), Josh Orchard said:

>  If I had a way to tell what type of machine it was I could really narrow
>  down the problem really fast.  I can't seem to find a tool that would scan





From russell-evans at uswest.net  Fri Feb  7 22:04:01 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Fri Feb  7 22:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to indentify a computer on the network
In-Reply-To: <2663.216.99.218.67.1044678701.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
References: <1517.134.244.174.42.1044668013.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org><200302072004.29266.griffint@pobox.com>
    <2663.216.99.218.67.1044678701.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <E18hO5P-0001IH-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Try to telnet from a box on the same local network segment as the suspect box
if you aren't on it, i.e. from another switch. To have a switch listening to
port 80 means the switch isn't that old. I'm not sure when web based management
became common, maybe after 1997, but it wasn't too long ago when a CLI and SNMP
were the only tools available. 

Thank you
Russell

On Fri, 7 Feb 2003 20:31:41 -0800 (PST), Josh Orchard said:

>  
>  Still odd. because I would have thought that 23 or 80 would respond. 
>  Maybe open but not running a service.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Feb  8 10:54:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sat Feb  8 10:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] anybody using this?
Message-ID: <86smuyk3iz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

With the recent degradation of effectiveness of SpamAssassin that
I've been experiencing, I set off to investigate some ideas I'd seen
earlier, including the Paul Graham's Bayesian scheme (see "A Plan for
Spam", <http://www.paulgraham.com/spam.html>).  At the bottom, there
are links to other information and projects, including one that gets
points _at least_ for naming cleverness:

  <http://crm114.sourceforge.net/>

"P-O-E, O-P-E, 'Peace on Earth', 'Purity of Essence", it's one of those!"

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Sat Feb  8 11:10:02 2003

On 8 Feb 2003, Russell Senior wrote:

>
> With the recent degradation of effectiveness of SpamAssassin that
> I've been experiencing, I set off to investigate some ideas I'd seen
> earlier, including the Paul Graham's Bayesian scheme (see "A Plan for
> Spam", <http://www.paulgraham.com/spam.html>).  At the bottom, there
> are links to other information and projects, including one that gets
> points _at least_ for naming cleverness:
>

Haven't used it, but it's mentioned in an article in the March 2003 Linux
Journal about the basis of Bayesian filtering techniques.  crm114 is
phrase-based instead of word based - this would seem to be a plus.

BTW: there's also an article in there about SpamBayes another Bayesian
spam filter.

Phil

Subject: [PLUG] anybody using this?
In-Reply-To: <86smuyk3iz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86smuyk3iz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <33181.207.173.0.68.1044733676.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

Russell Senior said:
>
> With the recent degradation of effectiveness of SpamAssassin that
> I've been experiencing, I set off to investigate some ideas I'd seen
> earlier, including the Paul Graham's Bayesian scheme (see "A Plan for

Hmmm, that makes a question occur to me; has everyone (who runs their own
mail server) tried Postfix's built-in anti-spam measures?
Since I switched to Postfix and turned on most (all?) of the features in
main.cf, I receive fewer than 1 spam per week.  I take that back, last
week I received two (down from 10-15 per day before Postfix).

Reviewing my nightly Postfix log summary, so far this week it's received
497 emails, and rejected 161 or 32% blocked for spam.  Of the options,
Spamcop's blacklist seems to block about 70% of the total rejects.

Because of these what I consider excellent results, I have not endeavored
at all to look at SpamAssassin.  My satisfaction is particularly keen in
knowing that the spam is not even received by my Postfix, even if later to
be zapped by SA or some other tool.

So my questions are- why aren't the blacklists used by Postfix & it's
other tools used more commonly?  Or is it simply the fact that my measly
497 messages per week volume is much smaller than most folk's (including
less spam)?  Is it simply that most people don't run their own mail
server?

That reminds me of another SpamCop question.  I paid their $25 for a
"reporting" account, which gives me 25MB of spams for them to process (I
report the few spams I still get dutifully).  It isn't clear to me if/how
this contributes to the blacklist.  Do they take the combined complaints
against a mail server, and after a threshold add it to the blacklist?  Or
did that just get me only the "reporting" service?  Quite frankly, I don't
much care if the network admins get notified about their spammers, I'm
quite sure they don't care.  I just want to help feed the blacklist.  It
seems that querying their blacklist server via Postfix is free.  That's
where I would like my money to go- perhaps it did when I sent the $25.

Interested to hear other's results in blocking spam.

From cmize at goiter.com  Sat Feb  8 12:05:02 2003
From: cmize at goiter.com (Chuck Mize)
Date: Sat Feb  8 12:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] anybody using this?
In-Reply-To: <33181.207.173.0.68.1044733676.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <86smuyk3iz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <33181.207.173.0.68.1044733676.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <200302081204.17629.cmize@goiter.com>

On Saturday 08 February 2003 11:47, Steven Raymond wrote:

> That reminds me of another SpamCop question.  I paid their $25 for a
> "reporting" account, which gives me 25MB of spams for them to process (I
> report the few spams I still get dutifully).  It isn't clear to me if/how
> this contributes to the blacklist.  Do they take the combined complaints
> against a mail server, and after a threshold add it to the blacklist?  Or
> did that just get me only the "reporting" service?  Quite frankly, I don't
> much care if the network admins get notified about their spammers, I'm
> quite sure they don't care.  I just want to help feed the blacklist.  It
> seems that querying their blacklist server via Postfix is free.  That's
> where I would like my money to go- perhaps it did when I sent the $25.
>
> Interested to hear other's results in blocking spam.

Whenever you report spam to Spamcop the IP addresses from the spam are used to 
make up the Spamcop DNSBL. After a certain number complaints about a 
particular IP it's added to the list and then drops off in something like 
seven days unless there are more complaints.

I'm getting about the same results as you--the Spamcop list is responsible for 
70-80 percent of my spam rejects.



From russell-evans at uswest.net  Sat Feb  8 12:17:01 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sat Feb  8 12:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] rpm document finder
Message-ID: <E18hbOa-0005LN-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

I'm pretty happy about this in that I will be able to use it in other scripts.
The fact it pulls up the docs is pretty tame but pulling the documents out of
rpms is what started me working on it.

Thank you
Russell


#!/bin/sh
#
# rpm document finder
#

declare -a LIST_ARRAY
declare -i HOW_MANY

CHOOSE_FUNC1 () {
	DOCS=`rpm -qd $CHOOSE`
	break 2
}

CHOOSE_FUNC2 () {
	if [ `echo $CHOOSE | grep man` ] ; then
		man $CHOOSE
		exit 0
	elif [ `echo $CHOOSE | tr [:upper:] [:lower:] | grep html` ] ; then
		links -g $CHOOSE
		exit 0
	elif [ $CHOOSE ] ; then
		echo ""
		echo $CHOOSE
		echo ""
		less $CHOOSE
		exit 0
	fi
} 

MENU_FUNCTION () {
	LIST_ARRAY=(`echo $LIST`)
	COUNT=`echo ${#LIST_ARRAY[@]}`
	let y=0
	while [ $y -lt $COUNT ] ; do
		let z=0 ; let a=0
		while [ $z -lt $HOW_MANY ] ; do
			let b=$y+$z
			if [ $a = 0 ] ; then
				SMALL_LIST="${LIST_ARRAY[$b]}" 
				let a=1
			elif [ $b -lt $COUNT ] ; then
				SMALL_LIST="$SMALL_LIST ${LIST_ARRAY[$b]}"
			elif [ $b = $COUNT ] ; then
				break
			fi
			let z=$z+1
		done
		if [ $b -lt $COUNT ] && [ $y = 0 ]; then
			SMALL_LIST="$SMALL_LIST next"
			echo ""
		elif [ $b -lt $COUNT ] && [ $y != 0 ] ; then
			SMALL_LIST="$SMALL_LIST previous  next"
			echo ""
		elif [ $b = $COUNT ] ; then
			SMALL_LIST="$SMALL_LIST previous"
		fi 
		PS3="$PROMPT"
		select CHOOSE in $SMALL_LIST ; do
			if [ $CHOOSE ] ; then	
				if [ $CHOOSE = next ] ; then
					let y=$y+$HOW_MANY
					break
				elif [ $CHOOSE = previous ] ; then
					let y=$y-$HOW_MANY
					break
				fi
				$LIST_FUNCTION
			else	
				echo "" ; echo "Invalid Selection" ; echo "" 
			fi
		done
		echo ""
		echo "Next Selection"
	done
}


if [ $1 ] ; then
	WTHIT=$1
else
	echo "usage: $0 pattern"
	exit 1
fi

#
# Get matches on pattern
#

HOW_MANY=15
PROMPT="Please select the menu number for the resource you wish to view #"
LIST=`rpm -qa | grep $WTHIT`
LIST_FUNCTION="CHOOSE_FUNC1"
MENU_FUNCTION

#
# Get document from match selected
#

HOW_MANY=15
PROMPT="Please select the menu number for the resource you wish to view #"
LIST=$DOCS
LIST_FUNCTION="CHOOSE_FUNC2"
MENU_FUNCTION

exit 0

From cmize at goiter.com  Sat Feb  8 12:37:02 2003
From: cmize at goiter.com (Chuck Mize)
Date: Sat Feb  8 12:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] anybody using this?
In-Reply-To: <E18hbRZ-0005Tc-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <86smuyk3iz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <200302081204.17629.cmize@goiter.com> <E18hbRZ-0005Tc-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200302081236.32299.cmize@goiter.com>

Nope. A lot of spammers forge their mail as being from hotmail, yahoo or AOL 
but Spamcop only looks at the actual IP address that connected to your mail 
server. Whatever spammers use as a return address or forged HELO or whatever 
isn't taken into account--only the connecting IP address.

On Saturday 08 February 2003 12:19, Russell Evans wrote:

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Sat Feb  8 12:50:03 2003
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)

Message-ID: <33233.207.173.0.68.1044737348.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

Chuck Mize said:
> Nope. A lot of spammers forge their mail as being from hotmail, yahoo or
> AOL  but Spamcop only looks at the actual IP address that connected to
> your mail  server. Whatever spammers use as a return address or forged
> HELO or whatever  isn't taken into account--only the connecting IP
> address.

I might add- most of my extended family uses AOL, and I've never had
Postfix incorrectly reject an email from them.  The only thing it
sometimes rejects is fqdn and other DNS-related problems, and it is easy
to configure PF to not reject that.  Sometimes public mail adminstrators
assign a RFC1918 address to the "public" hostname of their mx record or
some such nonsense.  When there is an inconsistency Postfix will reject-
but it's relatively easy to see in the logs when it happens.

On Sat, 2003-02-08 at 11:47, Steven Raymond wrote:

> So my questions are- why aren't the blacklists used by Postfix & it's
> other tools used more commonly?  Or is it simply the fact that my measly
> 497 messages per week volume is much smaller than most folk's (including

My results are a little interesting, although similar. I too was getting
20+ spams daily before I turned on the blacklists on my mail server. My
server is processing roughly 700 messages a day, about 2 get through a
month and the last 2 day report was 1428 processed and 38 blocked - and
I received no spam in my inboxes. What makes these numbers interesting
is that the number of messages processed has increased 2 fold within
that year and the number of spam messages are slowly decreasing. It's
near impossible to tell if the ineffectiveness of spam on this domain is
making an impact on the amount of attempts - it quite possible may be
coincidental or a picture of that industry as a whole.

I'm using rblsmtpd with Spamcop, dsbl.org and ordb.org. I have used
rblsmtpd in sendmail and qmail with good results.

From ed at alcpress.com  Sat Feb  8 13:19:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sat Feb  8 13:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] anybody using this?
In-Reply-To: <33181.207.173.0.68.1044733676.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <86smuyk3iz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	 <33181.207.173.0.68.1044733676.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <1044739084.1157.48.camel@red>

On Sat, 2003-02-08 at 11:47, Steven Raymond wrote:

> Hmmm, that makes a question occur to me; has everyone (who runs their own
> mail server) tried Postfix's built-in anti-spam measures?

Yes, I do that currently for my mail and for customers.


> Since I switched to Postfix and turned on most (all?) of the features in
> main.cf, I receive fewer than 1 spam per week.  I take that back, last
> week I received two (down from 10-15 per day before Postfix).

My mail servers turn away about 10,000 spam messages a week. That's
for me and all my customers combined. The number is deceptive because
much of the software that spammers use doesn't understand error codes
and continues trying to deliver their message even when given the
SMTP error code to go away. So, the number may be high. However, when
that happens, I either block these ill-behaved servers at the
firewall, or lie to them when they do their DNS query, so the number
may be low.

The nice thing about Postfix for my customers is the white list
capability. I can be aggressive when suppressing spam but allow
white mail to get through.


> So my questions are- why aren't the blacklists used by Postfix & it's
> other tools used more commonly?

Because you'd have to take the time to understand them and
configure them. In particular, you need to understand when
one of these features has a high probability of turning away
white mail.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

list and relays.osirusoft.com catch about 95% of all my spam and then I use a 
couple of the lists from blackholes.us to block all mail from China and 
Korea. Just about everything else gets filtered by SpamAssassin.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Feb  8 14:59:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sat Feb  8 14:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] anybody using this?
In-Reply-To: <33181.207.173.0.68.1044733676.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <86smuyk3iz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	 <33181.207.173.0.68.1044733676.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <1044745079.30967.13.camel@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On Sat, 2003-02-08 at 11:47, Steven Raymond wrote:

> Hmmm, that makes a question occur to me; has everyone (who runs their own
> mail server) tried Postfix's built-in anti-spam measures?
> Since I switched to Postfix and turned on most (all?) of the features in
> main.cf, I receive fewer than 1 spam per week.  I take that back, last
> week I received two (down from 10-15 per day before Postfix).
> 
> Reviewing my nightly Postfix log summary, so far this week it's received
> 497 emails, and rejected 161 or 32% blocked for spam.  Of the options,
> Spamcop's blacklist seems to block about 70% of the total rejects.

I use Postfix' RBL checks with some of the more conservative lists and
that's about it; I run amavisd-new with SpamAssassin and Razor through
postfix' 'content_filter' mechanism, and that catches almost all of my
spam.  I prefer the weighted heuristic method over boolean reject/deny
checks--it's mostly maintenance-free and I don't have to muck with
complex regexps.

I've done this setup with a number of customers, also plugging in Sophos
Anti-Virus and it is effective and preforms very well.

Wil

From griffint at pobox.com  Sat Feb  8 15:05:03 2003

On Sat, Feb 08, 2003 at 10:53:24AM -0800, Russell Senior wrote:
> 
> With the recent degradation of effectiveness of SpamAssassin that
> I've been experiencing, I set off to investigate some ideas I'd seen
> earlier, including the Paul Graham's Bayesian scheme (see "A Plan for
> Spam", <http://www.paulgraham.com/spam.html>).  At the bottom, there
> are links to other information and projects, including one that gets
> points _at least_ for naming cleverness:

I've been using Eric Raymond's bogofilter, which was inspired by
Paul Graham's paper. I've found it to be *very* effective, once the
data bases had been sufficiently populated with samples of spam
and non-spam.

    http://bogofilter.sourceforge.net/

From daniel_petcher at yahoo.com  Sat Feb  8 15:20:03 2003

information. I've also been frustrated by the HowTo documentation telling 
me how to implement extra features (such as printer support or roaming 
profiles) that I don't want or need.

My particular question would be: how can I discover which parts of the 
sample smb.conf file are irrelevant to my application and therefore safe to 
omit?

All I really want is a computer to centralize passwords on a current 
peer-based network so that I don't have to fix all six machines when I 
change one user account's password.

>
>But, I haven't tried to join a Windows 2000 *server* to the domain
>before.  Did you want it to act as a backup PDC or something?  Samba is
>limited in regards to how well it works with other domain controllers,
>if I remember correctly.

I'm not trying to make the W2k server a BDC; I've read already that Samba 
doesn't do that. Besides, I only have six clients in one LAN with no WAN 
links anywhere. There isn't enough authentication traffic to require a BDC. 
I just want to make it a member server in the domain so that it will 
consult with the PDC when a network resource request of some sort arrives.

>Anyway... if you like, I can post my smb.conf file... I know how
>daunting it can seem to try and write one from scratch.  Mine is
>modified from one a friend gave me, so it's only fair I pass it along.
>:-)

I'd certainly like to see the file, but there are dozens of other PLUG 
subscribers who probably don't care. Would you consider Emailing it 
directly to me? I'll certainly "pay it forward" if anyone ever asks me how 
I succeeded in this endeavor.
-djp

1 2

1 2

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Feb  8 17:05:03 2003

Hi gang,

Another chance at fame and glory. I want to collect True Tales of Sysadmins on 
New Jobs, or, Inheriting A Big Mess and Surviving.

How do you deal with taking over a new job, or new customer, and their 
computing infrastructure is a complete mess? Every version of windows, 
various *nixes and BSDs, weirdo no-name routers, switches, and other 
components, and nothing is documented. Printers are shared through user's 
PCs. Domains and groups are higgledy-piggledy. Cables are snarled, circuits 
are overloaded, passwords are lost. What's your plan of attack? How do you 
explain it to your boss or client? 

The best true tales will be published in an article in crossnodes.com, with 
your name and everything. Successes only, please. Keep it around 2-3 
paragraphs. I wish I had room for long gory tales with happy endings, but I 
only get 1000 words.

Reply off-list, of course. Thanks!

Michael Luevane wrote:

information. I've also been frustrated by the HowTo documentation telling
me how to implement extra features (such as printer support or roaming
profiles) that I don't want or need.

My particular question would be: how can I discover which parts of the
sample smb.conf file are irrelevant to my application and therefore safe to
omit?

All I really want is a computer to centralize passwords on a current
peer-based network so that I don't have to fix all six machines when I
change one user account's password.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Sat Feb  8 17:24:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Feb  8 17:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] a Samba PDC - has it actually been done?
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030208113038.00a69768@mail.dsl-only.net>
References: <5.2.0.9.0.20030208113038.00a69768@mail.dsl-only.net>
Message-ID: <1044753812.8760.67.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sat, 2003-02-08 at 11:36, Daniel Petcher wrote:

> I'm not trying to make the W2k server a BDC; I've read already that Samba 
> doesn't do that. Besides, I only have six clients in one LAN with no WAN 
> links anywhere. There isn't enough authentication traffic to require a BDC. 
> I just want to make it a member server in the domain so that it will 
> consult with the PDC when a network resource request of some sort arrives.

Backup PDC.. heh... yes... BDC... I don't have much reason for running a
PDC, really, it's just one of those 'because I can' things I have set up
on the slackware server.

> >Anyway... if you like, I can post my smb.conf file... I know how
> >daunting it can seem to try and write one from scratch.  Mine is
> >modified from one a friend gave me, so it's only fair I pass it along.
> >:-)
> 
> I'd certainly like to see the file, but there are dozens of other PLUG 
> subscribers who probably don't care. Would you consider Emailing it 
> directly to me? I'll certainly "pay it forward" if anyone ever asks me how 
> I succeeded in this endeavor.

Well, it is really pretty short and to the point.  Take it with that
webpage Carla posted and you should be able to easily modify it to meet
your needs.

[global]
        workgroup = WORKGROUP
        server string = SLACKWARE
        interfaces = 192.168.1.1/24 127.0.0.1
        bind interfaces only = Yes
        encrypt passwords = Yes
        passwd program = /usr/bin/passwd %u
        passwd chat debug = Yes
        unix password sync = Yes
        log file = /usr/local/samba/var/log.%m
        max log size = 50
        logon script = system.bat
        logon path = \\%N\Profiles\%u
        logon drive = H:
        logon home = \\linuxbox\%u
        domain logons = Yes
        os level = 64
        preferred master = True
        domain master = True
        dns proxy = No
        add user script = /usr/sbin/useradd -d /dev/null -g 100 -s /bin/false -M %u

[homes]
        comment = Home Directories
        valid users = %S
        read only = No
        browseable = No

[netlogon]
        path = /usr/local/samba/lib/netlogon
        read only = yes
        write list = rob
        browsable = No

[profiles]
        path = /usr/local/samba/lib/profiles
        read only = no
        create mask = 0600
        directory mask = 0700
        browsable = No

I'm sure the added 1.1K won't cause anybody any grief.

Rob




From athlonrob at axpr.net  Sat Feb  8 17:28:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Feb  8 17:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] a Samba PDC - has it actually been done?
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOCEJANAAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOCEJANAAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <1044754007.8777.71.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sat, 2003-02-08 at 17:14, Michael Luevane wrote:
> Ah. One issue that I had was that I couldn't figure out how to have
> automatically expiring passwords or how to have users change their passwords
> from their machines. Additionally, there are *two* passwords that need to be
> changed (as far as *I* can figure out) - the Samba password and the *nix
> password. I'm not a guru by any stretch of the imagination...

I don't know how to get the passwords expire, but sync'ing them up isn't
difficult.  You must manually sync them the first time, if I understand
things properly... but from then out you just use proper 'passwd
program' and 'unix passowrd sync' lines and as long as all password
changes are made via SMB, it all stays sync'd up.  What it does,
essentially, is takes that password you entered for samba and runs
passwd, inputting that password for your account.

See the example I just posted for how it works for me...

Rob

to the new computer.  Harddrive 1 has a windows XP installation and

unable to boot into Windows and I'm most likely going to need to
reinstall it.

MBR that the reinstall is going to overwrite?

From lamsokvr at xprt.net  Sun Feb  9 17:47:02 2003
From: lamsokvr at xprt.net (Marvin J. Kosmal)
Date: Sun Feb  9 17:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MBR Question
In-Reply-To: <1044888178.1421.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1044888178.1421.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1044841634.670.26.camel@libranet>

One method would be to have grub make a boot floppy.


Install XP..

Boot off the floppy..

Run Grub to install itself in MBR.

HTH

Marvin

From marcm at dsl-only.net  Sun Feb  9 23:56:01 2003
From: marcm at dsl-only.net (Marc)
Date: Sun Feb  9 23:56:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux supported TV card
In-Reply-To: <F95twa6QFaktM65cLgw0000d970@hotmail.com>; from v_yau2@hotmail.com on Sun, Feb 09, 2003 at 09:34:17PM -0800
References: <F95twa6QFaktM65cLgw0000d970@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <20030209235501.A10162@mentorg.com>

Hi Vincent,

> I am looking for a TV card for my linux box?  I have cable TV and want to be
> able to watch them on my linux box.  I found a lot of TV cards (that have
> coaxial input) for Windows but have not been able to find one that supports
> linux.

I have an AverMedia Stereo from Fryes (about $50) that works fine.  I run
'xawtv' to see the picture, and I'm using the coax input.  

You should be fine with a capture card that uses one of the chips from
Brooktree.  Here is my '/sbin/lspci' output in case you find it useful:

    00:09.0 Multimedia video controller: Brooktree Corporation Bt878 Video Capture (rev 11)
    00:09.1 Multimedia controller: Brooktree Corporation Bt878 Audio Capture (rev 11)

Good luck,

Marc

From marcm at dsl-only.net  Mon Feb 10 00:47:01 2003
From: marcm at dsl-only.net (Marc)
Date: Mon Feb 10 00:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux supported TV card
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302100023260.3406-100000@serpentor.cobrala>; from me@prestoncrawford.com on Mon, Feb 10, 2003 at 12:24:44AM -0800
References: <20030209235501.A10162@mentorg.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302100023260.3406-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
Message-ID: <20030210004600.B10162@mentorg.com>

On Mon 02/10/03  0:24, me at prestoncrawford.com wrote:
> 
> On Sun, 9 Feb 2003, Marc wrote:
> 
> > Hi Vincent,
> >
> > > I am looking for a TV card for my linux box?  I have cable TV and want to
> > > be able to watch them on my linux box.  I found a lot of TV cards (that
> > > have coaxial input) for Windows but have not been able to find one that
> > > supports linux.
> >
> > I have an AverMedia Stereo from Fryes (about $50) that works fine.  I run
> > 'xawtv' to see the picture, and I'm using the coax input.
> >
> > You should be fine with a capture card that uses one of the chips from
> > Brooktree.  Here is my '/sbin/lspci' output in case you find it useful:
> 
> Wait, you get this to work without having to recompile the kernel or did you
> have to do that? I bought this exact same card this weekend and it wasn't
> recognized  as the right card, so the audio is messed up. I get the SAP audio
> on many channels or no audio at all using kwintv.
> 
No kernel recompile was necessary, but you may need to mess with your
/etc/modules.conf file a bit to get rid of the SAP problem:

    options bttv gpiomask=0x0f audiomux=14,0,0,0,0

The values in "audiomux" were derived experimentally; I just kept trying
numbers from 1 on up until I got the right sound for the video.  I learned what
(little) I know of this from a Google hit and some browsing of the "bttv"
module's source code in the kernel tree.

> Have you tried using it as a PVR? What are the hardware requirements for
> that?

I have tried using MythTV (http://www.mythtv.org/) with some success.  I am
waiting for this application to develop a little further before I jump back in.
I don't have a good sense for the hardware requirements yet.

> 
> Preston
> 

Have fun,

Marc

>

> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From shahms at shahms.com  Mon Feb 10 08:03:01 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Mon Feb 10 08:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Radeon 9000 pro
In-Reply-To: <20030210144915.54936.qmail@web20203.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030210144915.54936.qmail@web20203.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1044892935.14998.1.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Mon, 2003-02-10 at 06:49, Gerardo Arnaez wrote:
> hi all, I decided to get a radeon 9000 pro instead of
> Nvidia having read that the linux support is better,
> but lo and behold, I start really looking and can find
> nothing comparable to getting the radeon's working
> under linux
> Any pointers?
> thanks

You can download drivers from the ATI website, they are the same drivers
as for the "FireGL" card.  Or, if you don't want 3D, you can use the
XFree86 RPMS from the latest RedHat beta (assuming you run RedHat, of
course)

Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

"Accept images that come from the originating server only"?
On the page in question, the images are served from a different 
server than the page is.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Mon Feb 10 10:29:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Feb 10 10:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] UDF
In-Reply-To: <20030210175542.65062.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030210175542.65062.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1044901656.17920.6.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Mon, 2003-02-10 at 09:55, Robert Kopp wrote:
> I haven't yet attempted to play DVD's on this
> computer, but I am about to make the attempt. I
> downloaded and installed xine.
> 
> However, although my DVD-ROM drive will play CD's,
> will it be recognized as a DVD drive? I downloaded a
> package to patch the kernel for UDF. Will I need to
> take this step? How do I know?

Ummm... if I remember correctly, UDF is a way to write data to CDRs and
DVD-Rs.  The former only in Windows, the latter also in Linux.

If what you want to do is play DVDs... Xine will only play un-encrypted
DVDs without some hacking.  I would suggest using Ogle for playing
DVDs.  It does a good job as far as I'm concerned.  It is also pretty
darned simple to use.  :-)

As for patching the kernel for UDF... I really don't see why you would
need to do that to play DVDs.

Rob




From susan_strayer at yahoo.com  Mon Feb 10 10:54:02 2003

Date: Mon Feb 10 10:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles

but it's not booting.  When I've pulled the hard drive from my laptop,
to make sure that it's not booting Windows from the hard drive, my
laptop seems to see the CD, but reports "Operating System not found".
I've read all the FAQ's I can from the Knoppix site, but can't see what
I'm doing wrong.  

 

Any suggestions?

Susan

From shahms at shahms.com  Mon Feb 10 10:58:01 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Mon Feb 10 10:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles
In-Reply-To: <000b01c2d135$c612fc00$f500a8c0@susanka8qvbt4p>
References: <000b01c2d135$c612fc00$f500a8c0@susanka8qvbt4p>
Message-ID: <1044903461.15010.5.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Mon, 2003-02-10 at 10:52, Susan Strayer wrote:
> I have a copy of KNOPPIX_V3.1-2003-01-20-EN.iso that I copied onto a
> CD, but it?s not booting. 

By "copied onto a CD" what do you mean? The iso should be a bootable
image (all the Knoppix isos I've installed have been) and all that's
required to put them on cd is 
"cdrecord dev=<bus,id,lun> KNOPPIX_V3.1-2003-01-20-EN.iso"

-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

> essential. 

I'm sorry, what do you mean by that? Essential? 

I'm just asking (since I understood make dep to be part of a larger process) what doing make dep on its own would do. 

Preston




From susan_strayer at yahoo.com  Mon Feb 10 11:29:02 2003
From: susan_strayer at yahoo.com (Susan Strayer)
Date: Mon Feb 10 11:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles
In-Reply-To: <1044903461.15010.5.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <001401c2d13a$a7a10050$f500a8c0@susanka8qvbt4p>

"copied onto CD" means that we used HP RecordNow in Windows and hit the
"Make a Data Disc" button to copy the .iso file onto a CD.  It seemed to
compare well with the "how to burn a CD in Windows" I saw in one of the
Knoppix FAQs.  I think it's the Windows equivalent of the "cdrecord"
command you gave me.  I also checked the file size of the .iso file
against the original mirror on the source site, and it matched.  

Thanks for the question - it was a good one.  

Susan Strayer
susan_strayer at yahoo.com
 

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Shahms King
Sent: Monday, February 10, 2003 10:58 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles

On Mon, 2003-02-10 at 10:52, Susan Strayer wrote:
> I have a copy of KNOPPIX_V3.1-2003-01-20-EN.iso that I copied onto a
> CD, but it?s not booting. 

By "copied onto a CD" what do you mean? The iso should be a bootable
image (all the Knoppix isos I've installed have been) and all that's
required to put them on cd is 
"cdrecord dev=<bus,id,lun> KNOPPIX_V3.1-2003-01-20-EN.iso"

-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Mon Feb 10 11:34:02 2003
From: John.Hampton at gijoes.com (John Hampton)
Date: Mon Feb 10 11:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles
Message-ID: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014DA2@gilligan.gijoes.com>

Susan Strayer said:
>"copied onto CD" means that we used HP RecordNow in Windows and hit the
>"Make a Data Disc" button to copy the .iso file onto a CD.  It seemed to
>compare well with the "how to burn a CD in Windows" I saw in one of the
>Knoppix FAQs.  I think it's the Windows equivalent of the "cdrecord"
>command you gave me.  I also checked the file size of the .iso file
>against the original mirror on the source site, and it matched.  

I've never used HP RecordNow, but I'm guessing that "Make a Data Disc" is not the option that you wanted.  Usually the option that you want is something like, "Create CD from disk image".  The difference being that "Make a Data Disk" probably just copies the ISO onto the CD as one file.  Where as the "Create CD from disk image" creates the file system on the CD as described in the ISO image.  HTH.

John Hampton
Programmer Analyst
G.I. Joe's, Inc.
john.hampton at gijoes.com




From athlonrob at axpr.net  Mon Feb 10 11:37:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Feb 10 11:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles
In-Reply-To: <001401c2d13a$a7a10050$f500a8c0@susanka8qvbt4p>
References: <001401c2d13a$a7a10050$f500a8c0@susanka8qvbt4p>
Message-ID: <1044905746.19370.9.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Mon, 2003-02-10 at 11:28, Susan Strayer wrote:
> "copied onto CD" means that we used HP RecordNow in Windows and hit the
> "Make a Data Disc" button to copy the .iso file onto a CD.  It seemed to
> compare well with the "how to burn a CD in Windows" I saw in one of the
> Knoppix FAQs.  I think it's the Windows equivalent of the "cdrecord"
> command you gave me.  I also checked the file size of the .iso file
> against the original mirror on the source site, and it matched.  

Does the CD have files on it or does it have one giant knoppix.iso file
on it?

If the former, we can look in to other stuff ... if the latter, you
burned it wrong.  Can the HP software burn a file as a track, maybe?  I
think B's Recorder Gold (cheap software we have here) has to burn ISO
images as tracks...

Just putting an ISO image into an iso9660 filesystem isn't going to do
it - the .iso file *is* the iso9660 filesystem.  :-)

Rob




From bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us  Mon Feb 10 11:46:02 2003
From: bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us (Ben Mabbott)
Date: Mon Feb 10 11:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles
References: <001401c2d13a$a7a10050$f500a8c0@susanka8qvbt4p>
Message-ID: <016401c2d13c$fd473360$fa0dab0a@admin>

Unfortunately that isn't going to work. ISO makes it easier to move around
the contents of a CD by rolling it all into one file. For the image to work,
it needs to be reverted back into it's component files when it is burned.

The HP software does not have the ability to do this. What it does is simply
burn the ISO file itself to CD, which is not the same thing. Rather than
just a CD with whatever.ISO on it, you should have multiple files. You're
going to need another burning program. I know that Nuro and CDRWin will do
the job. AFAIK there is no free app. for windows that will do it.

-Ben

======================================================================
Ben Mabbott - bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us
Technology Coordinator, Riverdale Grade School
(503) 636-4511 - http://riverdale.k12.or.us/gs.html

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon Feb 10 11:55:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon Feb 10 11:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Make menuconfig and make dep on their own?
In-Reply-To: <20030210175951.65768.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302100847390.4352-100000@serpentor.cobrala> <20030210175951.65768.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030210195413.GD16716@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

There are some things that need a current kernel source tree to
compile correctly, I'm no expert either, but I'm betting that make
menuconfig & make dep make symlinks or something similar that
determines which specific (possibly processor dependant?) headers are
used, and this could certianly affect compilation of other things.

-Rogan

From bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us  Mon Feb 10 12:07:02 2003
From: bmabbott at riverdale.k12.or.us (Ben Mabbott)
Date: Mon Feb 10 12:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles
References: <001401c2d13a$a7a10050$f500a8c0@susanka8qvbt4p> <016401c2d13c$fd473360$fa0dab0a@admin>
Message-ID: <017c01c2d13f$ed6ec680$fa0dab0a@admin>

Oops, looks like the newest version of the HP software will in fact burn ISO
images. It's about time ;)

In HP RecordNow, goto help, about, and check the version number. If it's 3.5
you should be able to do it. If it's not, you can download the 3.5 update
from HP's site. I'd post the exact link, but it's pretty long. Just goto the
support page for your particular burner.

-Ben

From mike at linuxlink.com  Mon Feb 10 12:36:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] UDF
In-Reply-To: <1044901656.17920.6.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

link /dev/dvd to /dev/hdc or wherever yours is.  Then install ogle and 
you will have all the dvd menuses and all.  it plays encrypteds
too.

have fun

> Ummm... if I remember correctly, UDF is a way to write data to CDRs and
> DVD-Rs.  The former only in Windows, the latter also in Linux.
> 
> If what you want to do is play DVDs... Xine will only play un-encrypted
> DVDs without some hacking.  I would suggest using Ogle for playing
> DVDs.  It does a good job as far as I'm concerned.  It is also pretty
> darned simple to use.  :-)
> 
> As for patching the kernel for UDF... I really don't see why you would
> need to do that to play DVDs.
>

From richard at freegeek.org  Mon Feb 10 12:38:01 2003
From: richard at freegeek.org (Richard Seymour)
Date: Mon Feb 10 12:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles
References: <000b01c2d135$c612fc00$f500a8c0@susanka8qvbt4p>
Message-ID: <3E480D82.304@freegeek.org>

There's also BIOS issues on the computer to explore. Most newer 
computers with standard settings probably boot from a CD if it's there, 
but an older computer, or one with not so standard settings might not 
boot from a CD. Easy enough to check, even though it's probably not your 
problem.

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Feb 10 12:48:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Feb 10 12:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] UDF
In-Reply-To: <20030210175542.65062.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030210175542.65062.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302101239470.18148@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 10 Feb 2003, Robert Kopp wrote:
> I haven't yet attempted to play DVD's on this computer, but I am about
> to make the attempt. I downloaded and installed xine.
>
> However, although my DVD-ROM drive will play CD's, will it be recognized
> as a DVD drive? I downloaded a package to patch the kernel for UDF. Will
> I need to take this step? How do I know?

You don't need UDF to play DVD video.  You need UDF support to mount a UDF
filesystem.  Playing DVD video is like playing CD audio in that you don't
mount the device when you access the media.

MPlayer will play DVD video with direct access to all the titles and
chapters and various audio channels and angles.  I've never had it fail
and it's very fast and clean.  (I've gotten it to display menus, but
haven't bothered to see if I can navigate them or not... I usually just
play the titles directly.)

Ogle will allow you to navigate the menus, but my experience is that it's
rather unstable.

I've used Xine for playing DVDs, but I found the chapter access weak.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org



From beattie at beattie-home.net  Mon Feb 10 13:18:02 2003

On Mon, 2003-02-10 at 12:37, Richard Seymour wrote:
> There's also BIOS issues on the computer to explore. Most newer 
> computers with standard settings probably boot from a CD if it's there,

One thing I've done on my laptop is to install btmgr on the harddrive,
btmgr will boot from a CD.  This could probably be done with a floppy as
well.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Feb 10 13:31:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Feb 10 13:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATC - February 6 (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302101327130.8660-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
                        Aspire to Crudeness -- Issue 33

  February 6, 2003

  by Don Marti, Editor in Chief of Linux Journal
     _________________________________________________________________

                         This Week's Sponsor: Emac

                 Embedded Linux Starter Kit from Emac Inc.

   Imagine running embedded Linux on a single-board computer! Get all you
   need in this 2.4 kernel compatible single-board computer starter kit
   from Emac. Emac has been offering an impressive line-up of products
   for the embedded systems market since 1985. Kits start from as low
   $399.00 US. Call now at 618-529-4525 or visit us on-line:
   http://www.emacinc.com.
     _________________________________________________________________

   Infoworld sent out a survey asking, "Do you think tech spending will
   improve in 2003 from last year?"

   Improve? As far as I'm concerned, "improve" is having to spend less.
   Last I heard, half of the capital investments US businesses were
   making was in information technology, and even if you call it
   Information Technology it's still just a bunch of sand and poetry. I'd
   like to see more of you people get jobs, but realistically those are
   going to come on the customer side--actually making information
   technology work in a business--rather than at some hot new vendor. If
   I were a betting man I would bet on Doc Searls' prediction that
   information technology is going to look more and more like the
   construction industry.

   Speaking of Doc, he's Mr. Controversy over at the Linux Journal web
   site, with one article offering some advance speculation about the
   Lindows conference:
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article/6611 and another article calling
   for comments on how Linux is changing the way company IT departments
   work:
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article/6601.

   Now that vendors are sending you the source and allowing you to have a
   clue without violating the EULA, are you getting that clue and using
   it to help business? Tell Doc:
   mailto:doc at ssc.com. He's looking for people who are using Linux and
   related technologies to get smarter and to make their companies
   smarter.

   Way over on the other side of the "smart/not smart" line, those wacky
   venture capitalists are at it again:
   http://www.bayarea.com/mld/mercurynews/business/5100882.htm: "San
   Jose's Rackable Systems, a provider of rack-mounted high-density
   computer server and storage systems, said it has raised $21 million
   from Parthenon Capital."

   Remember that scene in Time Bandits where the kid yells, "Mum! Dad!
   Don't touch it! It's evil!", and they touch it anyway? Is $21 million
   worth putting venture capitalists on your company's board?

   From the devoted FCC-watchers and ham radio spectrum defenders at the
   American Radio Relay League comes some FCC news:

     The FCC has launched ECFS Express, an updated electronic system
     that the Commission says will make it easier for some members of
     the public to file comments on FCC proceedings. ECFS Express is a
     simplified version of the popular Electronic Comment Filing System
     (ECFS), but it is not available for all FCC proceedings.

     ECFS Express focuses on topics rather than docket numbers, and [it]
     requires minimal input by consumers seeking to participate in the
     Commission's public rule-making process. ECFS Express is accessible
     from the FCC home page at www.fcc.gov:
     http://www.fcc.gov. Users click on the "File Comments" logo. Anyone
     who wants to comment just has to click on a topic, fill in their
     personal information, write their comments and hit "SEND."

   I checked this out, and it really is easy. So now there's no excuse
   for not saying exactly how you feel about the Broadcast Flag Mandate
   and other anti-freedom, pro-monopoly proposals before the FCC.

   Also in the "easy ways to complain about the government" department,
   my Representative in Congress, Anna Eshoo, now has a stock paragraph
   about one of the DMCA reform bills. So I'm still getting form letters
   back about DMCA reform, but the good news is she now has a stock reply
   paragraph about the DMCA.

   Unfortunately the stock paragraph doesn't yet address the point I made
   in my first letter, so it's time to send another one. Feel free to
   make fair use of any of the text here. If you need a quick way to send
   letters, I recommend either Abiword (a point-and-click word processor)
   or for real power, your favorite editor, LaTeX. There's a LaTeX letter
   tutorial:
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article/3387 on the LJ site.

     Dear Representative Eshoo:

     Thank you for your reply to my letter regarding H.R. 5522, the
     Digital Choice and Freedom Act of 2002. While it is true that if
     reintroduced and passed, this bill would, as you say, help in
     "protecting consumers' ability to enjoy digital copyrighted
     material", there is another important issue at stake.

     The Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) needs reform not only
     to protect fair use rights, but also to ensure that information
     technology research can continue. Under the DMCA, copyright holders
     and established consumer electronics vendors can lock out
     competition by preventing the development of new technologies.

     The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM), which is the leading
     scientific society for computer science, filed an amicus brief in
     Eric Corley v. Universal City Studios et al., a civil case in which
     a group of movie studios used the DMCA to suppress the first
     DVD-playing software for the Linux operating system. The
     association wrote,

     "The concern of the ACM is that the DMCA prohibits scientific
     analysis and discourse on the cutting edge of research and
     development in encryption technologies, including research and
     development of copyright protection tools and expertise."

     Because new technologies are essential to the economy of the 14th
     district, DMCA reform to allow research and fair use is especially
     critical for our area. It is for this reason that it is important
     for you to co-sponsor either the Digital Choice and Freedom Act of
     2002 or H.R. 107, the Digital Media Consumer's Rights Act. Thank
     you for your consideration.

   Answers to Questions

   One of the most common questions on user group mailing lists is "Which
   is the best distribution?" Here's a slightly revised version of what
   is becoming my standard answer.

   "The most important part of picking a distribution is thinking about
   where you will go for help, and what distribution that source of help
   understands. That's true if your source of help is a vendor, a
   consultant or a users group.

   "As a home user, you'll probably be asking your local Linux users
   group for help when you need it. So get on the mailing list and just
   "lurk" for a while. See what the most helpful people on the list use
   and install that. That way if you have a question, you'll be more
   likely to reach someone who has already dealt with it."

   Security

   If anybody is turning the recent Microsoft worm outbreak into an
   excuse for Microsoft-bashing, stop it. There's a real security lesson
   here, and if you can stop with the "neener, neener, hey Bill Gates,
   where's your security initiative now", you can learn something. And,
   hey! No mooning! That's just unprofessional.

   1. The best way to connect a computer to the Internet is not to
   connect it to the Internet. Use application-level proxies. If your
   database server needs to get a software upgrade, make it use a proxy.
   Same for desktop machines--it's a matter of minutes to set up a web
   proxy. And you should, of course, be using an internal name server.

   2. If you use a packet-filtering firewall, which you should almost
   certainly be doing, set it up totally closed, and open up as little as
   possible to get your job done. None of this "look out, there's a worm,
   block port whatever".

   3. Run as little software as you can, and run the simplest software
   you can. Most of the worm-infected systems weren't even servers--they
   merely had a vulnerable software component that the users didn't know
   was there.

   End of security lessons. They were kind of obvious, and you probably
   already knew them, but if one person doesn't have to reinstall and
   thereby gains an hour to BUG YOUR REPRESENTATIVE IN CONGRESS FOR DMCA
   REFORM it will all be worthwhile.

   --
   Don Marti:
   mailto:dmarti at ssc.com
     _________________________________________________________________

   To remove yourself from this list, see www.ssc.com/mailing-lists:
   http://www.ssc.com/mailing-lists.
     _________________________________________________________________

From ed at alcpress.com  Mon Feb 10 14:14:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Mon Feb 10 14:14:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Beyond .COM - The Alternate Roots
Message-ID: <1044915147.1157.205.camel@red>

This month, the PANUG user group is having a presentation
at its monthly meeting that has wide appeal to all
Internet users:

 BEYOND .COM - THE ALTERNATE ROOTS

 Most users of the Internet are locked in to Web and
 email addresses that end in names like COM, NET, and
 ORG. These are called Top Level Domain names or TLDs.
 TLDs are tightly controlled by a non-government
 organization that operates as a government-sanctioned
 monopoly. It takes years for this organization to allow
 new TLDs, such as BIZ. Why so long?

 The excuse is that technical issues have to be worked
 out but the real reason is money and politics. The same
 organization controls our DNS so there's little we can
 do. Or is there?

 Numerous people and companies have created an
 alternative to this monopoly. They offer lots of TLDs
 - many are free and some are not. These alternate TLDs
 are supported by an alternate DNS. We call these the
 "alternate roots". Some articles and white papers on
 the subject claim that, if we use the alternate roots,
 we put the health of the Internet in jeopardy. But
 remember - it's not technical - it's about money and
 politics. Truth seldom flourishes in that environment.

 This presentation will bring you up to speed on the
 issues, and DEMONSTRATES LIVE that we can easily use
 the "standard roots" and the "alternate roots'
 together to access any of the TLDs - without affecting
 the health of the Internet.  

Normally, PANUG meetings are members-only but non-members
can attend this meeting for $5.00, which includes pizza
and refreshments. The meeting is held at Novell's office
near Washington Square. Directions are on the PANUG web
site at http://www.panug.org. You must RSVP to attend.
Send your RSVP to info at panug.org. Space is limited and
PANUG members have preference.




From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Feb 10 14:30:02 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Mon Feb 10 14:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] UDF
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302101239470.18148@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302100549410.11905-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Mon, 10 Feb 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> 
> On Mon, 10 Feb 2003, Robert Kopp wrote:
> > I haven't yet attempted to play DVD's on this computer, but I am about
> > to make the attempt. I downloaded and installed xine.
> >
> > However, although my DVD-ROM drive will play CD's, will it be recognized
> > as a DVD drive? I downloaded a package to patch the kernel for UDF. Will
> > I need to take this step? How do I know?
> 
> You don't need UDF to play DVD video.  You need UDF support to mount a UDF
> filesystem.  Playing DVD video is like playing CD audio in that you don't
> mount the device when you access the media.
> 
> MPlayer will play DVD video with direct access to all the titles and
> chapters and various audio channels and angles.  I've never had it fail
> and it's very fast and clean.  (I've gotten it to display menus, but
> haven't bothered to see if I can navigate them or not... I usually just
> play the titles directly.)
> 
> Ogle will allow you to navigate the menus, but my experience is that it's
> rather unstable.
> 
> I've used Xine for playing DVDs, but I found the chapter access weak.

For those people using an RPM based system, check out 
http://www.freshrpms.net/.  It includes the libraries needed to get Xine 
to work "correctly", with the exception of the win32 codecs.  (Which may 
not be enabled with that build.  I need to check.)






From savages at mozapps.org  Mon Feb 10 14:41:01 2003

The talk will be on embedded Linux and CBD (Compressed Block Device).

What is an embedded system?
Why use Linux for embedded system?
Embedded Design Concepts.
Linux filesystem overview.
How buffers and block device work.
Compressed Block Device   CBD
     1/3  the size
     Grub boot support
     uses cache
     secure
     on demand decompression
     build time compression
     GPL kernel block device driver


Shaun Savage

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Mon Feb 10 17:17:02 2003
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Mon Feb 10 17:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: Start X
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCOEMCCFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCOEMCCFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <3E484ED4.60704@parkrose.k12.or.us>

BMDimaculangan wrote:
> I'm using RH8.0, how do i quit X and go to the command prompt. Anyone?

http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/linux/RHL-8.0-Manual/getting-started-guide/s1-q-and-a-runlevels.html

Just reverse the directions. Change "id:5:initdefault:" to 
"id:3:initdefault:" in /etc/inittab.

Log out and log back in.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District




From ali at axian.com  Mon Feb 10 17:23:01 2003
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Mon Feb 10 17:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: Start X
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCOEMCCFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>; from bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph on Tue, Feb 11, 2003 at 08:50:18AM +0800
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCOEMCCFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20030210172233.A17730@zaphod.axian.com>

If you set it up with a text-based login, then you can press
Ctrl-Alt-Backspace to kill X and kick yourself back to the 
command line.

Or you can press Ctrl-Alt-F2 (or F3, etc) to leave X running and
switch to a text login console.  If you have a graphical login
set up, then this is your best bet.  (Ctrl-Alt-F9 will take you
back to X.)

Ali

This statement is simply not true. You'll have to attend
the presentation to find out why.

> Ain't gonna happen.

There's already over 1.7 million second level domains registered
in the inclusive (alternate) name space and roughly 20 percent of
the people on the Internet, worldwide, have access to them. This
is not my statistic, so it could be inaccurate.

> Much better to work with the IANA,

I think you mean ICANN and the IETF and their working groups.
IANA? You're out of date by a few years.

>  as corrupt as the system is.  New
> domain TLDs *are* being created.  Be patient.

They are being created only when ICANN can find people who
are willing to buy them for a few million dollars. Corrupt
is an understatement.

> asking for money to register your pet domain name in the "new"
> altroots.

Sure, just like any of the Perl alternatives are snake oil.
Just like Linux is snake oil.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Mon Feb 10 20:03:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Feb 10 20:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] VPN Suggestions?
Message-ID: <1044932801.19370.77.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

Hey everybody-

I'm going to be gone for several months... unfortunately, I'm going to
be using AOL for my ISP.  I can't say why, but it is by far a better
deal than anything else.

I would really like to be able to connect to my local network here at
home from away, though.  I was looking at OpenVPN at first as it didn't
require any additional firewall rules on my firewall (and I'd like to
run the VPN server behind the firewall, ideally).

But... there doesn't seem to be a way to connect to an OpenVPN server
with Windoze.  Bummer.

So what kind of VPN solutions would you guys suggest I look in to?  I'd
just like a quick (ie; compressed) and secure connection to the systems
behind my firewall.  While I could always tunnel SSH connections through
the server, I'd rather have something a bit more robust and
native-looking to the remote side.

The firewall server is running Slackware 8.1.  The to-be VPN server is
running a hodgepodge type old pre-release slackware 9.0 install with
virtually everything recompiled from scratch.  The system that will be
connecting remotely (ideally, anyway) is running a dual-boot betweem
Gentoo (which likely will be unable to connect to the Internet) and
Windows XP Home Edition.

I'd appreciate any ideas.  :-)

Rob

> This statement is simply not true. You'll have to attend
> the presentation to find out why.
> 
> > Ain't gonna happen.
> 
> There's already over 1.7 million second level domains registered
> in the inclusive (alternate) name space and roughly 20 percent of
> the people on the Internet, worldwide, have access to them. This
> is not my statistic, so it could be inaccurate.
> 
> > Much better to work with the IANA,
> 
> I think you mean ICANN and the IETF and their working groups.
> IANA? You're out of date by a few years.
> 
> >  as corrupt as the system is.  New
> > domain TLDs *are* being created.  Be patient.
> 
> They are being created only when ICANN can find people who
> are willing to buy them for a few million dollars. Corrupt
> is an understatement.
> 
> > Don't sign any checks at the meeting.  Don't visit any web pages
> > asking for money to register your pet domain name in the "new"
> > altroots.
> >

> 
> Sure, just like any of the Perl alternatives are snake oil.
> Just like Linux is snake oil. 

Hey Ed,
This looked like it might be an interesting discussion so I went out to
new.net to take a look around. They're featured site is www.level9.mp3
and in following that link, my browser failed to resolve that name. I
run a cache name server that uses root-servers.net and I suspect that
the mp3 TLD is not included here. To verify that the problem was on my
end I reset my resolv.conf to my ISP's primary name server and got the
same result. Looking at the error, it's really unable to resolve the
name and not attempting to load a page and timing out. So here's my
question: If all DNS sites are going to need to add "alternet
root-servers" to their configs to see the "alternet TLDs" than would
that not validate Randal's (only one L this time) argument?

Steve




From ed at alcpress.com  Mon Feb 10 21:08:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Mon Feb 10 21:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Beyond .COM - The Alternate Roots
In-Reply-To: <1044939086.1945.18.camel@main>
References: <mailman.1044915248.4924.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
	 <86fzqvpo1d.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>  <1044935650.1155.273.camel@red>
	 <1044939086.1945.18.camel@main>
Message-ID: <1044940037.13861.283.camel@red>

On Mon, 2003-02-10 at 20:51, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> Hey Ed,
> This looked like it might be an interesting discussion so I went out to
> new.net to take a look around. They're featured site is www.level9.mp3
> and in following that link, my browser failed to resolve that name. I
> run a cache name server that uses root-servers.net and I suspect that
> the mp3 TLD is not included here. To verify that the problem was on my
> end I reset my resolv.conf to my ISP's primary name server and got the
> same result. Looking at the error, it's really unable to resolve the
> name and not attempting to load a page and timing out. So here's my
> question: If all DNS sites are going to need to add "alternet
> root-servers" to their configs to see the "alternet TLDs" than would
> that not validate Randal's (only one L this time) argument?
> 
> Steve

You can't resolve the names because your DNS cache and your ISP's
cache/name server/whatever only look to the ICANN roots to
resolve names. For the inclusive name space to work for you,
you'll need access to a cache/name server/whatever that looks
to the alternate roots OR non-ICANN TLD servers instead of or
in addition to the ICANN roots. The possibilities for doing this
will be presented at the PANUG meeting.
 
-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

On Mon, 2003-02-10 at 21:26, Terry Layne wrote:

> What's wrong with ssh when you just need a shell and vnc when you want a
> desktop?  The Windows VNC viewer works well enough.  You'd just need to open
> 22 and 580n, 590n, on your firewall (assuming you start vnc with vncserver :n.)

Well, that isn't encrypted at all, for one thing.  To encrypt VNC you
have to forward ports over SSH and, IMHO, that is a kludge.

Besides, getting this to work would be very interesting... I've never
played with VPNs before.  :-)

From marcm at dsl-only.net  Mon Feb 10 23:49:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Make menuconfig and make dep on their own?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302100847390.4352-100000@serpentor.cobrala>; from me@prestoncrawford.com on Mon, Feb 10, 2003 at 08:47:58AM -0800
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302100847390.4352-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
Message-ID: <20030210234807.C10162@mentorg.com>

On Mon 02/10/03  8:47, me at prestoncrawford.com wrote:
> 
> I'm having trouble getting my TV Card working properly. Only another list,
> someone told me the following.

So did the modules option mentioned in an earlier thread (*) not work for you?

Marc

(*) Add to /etc/modules.conf:

    options bttv gpiomask=0x0f audiomux=14,0,0,0,0

It is likely you would need to reload the module with

    # rmmod bttv
    # insmod bttv gpiomask=0x0f audiomux=14,0,0,0,0
        Using /lib/modules/2.4.18-3/kernel/drivers/media/video/bttv.o

> --------------------------------------
> things like upgrading V4L/V4L2. If you want to upgrade bttv, you also
> need the kernel sources. IIRC, a kernel recompile is not necessary. Just
> "make menuconfig" and "make dep" should be enough.
> --------------------------------------
> 
> Now I may be ignorant to Linux, but aren't those commands part of the
> process of recompiling the kernel? Can they be run on their own?
> 
> Preston
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
---end quoted text---

-- 
No sig here



From DVHoward at teleport.com  Mon Feb 10 23:53:02 2003
From: DVHoward at teleport.com (Douglas Howard)
Date: Mon Feb 10 23:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles
References: <000b01c2d135$c612fc00$f500a8c0@susanka8qvbt4p>
Message-ID: <024c01c2d1a2$a28a1260$7f031ad8@k61800DVH>

Verify that the CD is good by booting it on another system.
I downloaded the ISO a while back and it didn't work.
So I ran the checksum on it and it was bad.
Had to download it all over again.

If the bios won't support booting from the CD, you can make 
a boot floppy.  But some CD drives may not be supported.

If you get part way into the boot process and it freezes, press F2
for other boot options.
On one Dell laptop I need to use "knoppix noscsi"







From amunk at pdx.edu  Tue Feb 11 00:33:02 2003
From: amunk at pdx.edu (Andrew Munkres)
Date: Tue Feb 11 00:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Make menuconfig and make dep on their own?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302100847390.4352-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302100847390.4352-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
Message-ID: <20030211001947.1abbe1b4.amunk@pdx.edu>

On Mon, 10 Feb 2003 08:47:58 -0800 (PST)
me at prestoncrawford.com wrote:

> 
> I'm having trouble getting my TV Card working properly. Only another list,
> someone told me the following.
> 
> --------------------------------------
> things like upgrading V4L/V4L2. If you want to upgrade bttv, you also
> need the kernel sources. IIRC, a kernel recompile is not necessary. Just
> "make menuconfig" and "make dep" should be enough.
> --------------------------------------
> 
> Now I may be ignorant to Linux, but aren't those commands part of the
> process of recompiling the kernel? Can they be run on their own?

The kernel sources include the source for many modules. You "make
(menu|x|)config" to choose which modules to compile, and then "make dep" and
"make modules". To compile the kernel itself, "make all".

I guess that by "upgrade bttv", the other respondant meant getting a newer
version of the bttv module? If so, I would think that you need to "make modules"
as well as what they said to do.

From garnaez at yahoo.com  Tue Feb 11 07:34:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Email Admin Help: Clarification
Message-ID: <20030211153305.84547.qmail@web20210.mail.yahoo.com>

Thanks to everyone that responded.
I need to be more clear on what is needed and
expected.
I am helping a non-profit web/education hosting
company out here in astorias,  raintree.org.
1. They provide internet access to the community and
also are teaching computer skills to help people
improve their job skills.

2. They have at least two NT email servers that are
constantly dying, and need to be replaced by something
stable (at this point, we are going with debian).

3. Talking to the head guy, they can not offer any
pay. Everyone working their right now is voluntering.
This may change if a grant is approved.

4.  I/We dont expect a full-time admin.  We would want
someone to help setup the email servers and then hand
over the maintenance to me or someone here. We can
learn and have done a pretty good job of it, but feel
very uncomfortable about setting up email servers with
no prior experience, and these are production servers,
ie people rely on them.

5. The issue of which email server to install has not
been decided and if you decide to help, you would be
involved in this discussion. right now postfix or
qmail seems to be the alternatives.

6. I will be contacting everyone who has contacted me,
but I have to go to work. :)

Thanks for your time,
G

From mikel at quantecllc.com  Tue Feb 11 08:53:02 2003
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael Luevane)
Date: Tue Feb 11 08:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: Start X
In-Reply-To: <1044926498.1156.240.camel@red>
Message-ID: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOMECGNBAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

This will kill the X server, but if you boot to a graphical login, it'll
take you right back to it.

If you want a pure terminal screen (not an xterm window) then change to
runlevel 3 and reboot.

---- Original Message ----
From: ed at alcpress.com
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: RE: [PLUG] Beyond .COM - The Alternate Roots
Date: 10 Feb 2003 14:12:28 -0800

>This month, the PANUG user group is having a presentation
>at its monthly meeting that has wide appeal to all
>Internet users:
>
> BEYOND .COM - THE ALTERNATE ROOTS
>
> Most users of the Internet are locked in to Web and
> email addresses that end in names like COM, NET, and
> ORG. These are called Top Level Domain names or TLDs.
> TLDs are tightly controlled by a non-government
> organization that operates as a government-sanctioned
> monopoly. It takes years for this organization to allow
> new TLDs, such as BIZ. Why so long?
>
> The excuse is that technical issues have to be worked
> out but the real reason is money and politics. The same
> organization controls our DNS so there's little we can
> do. Or is there?
>
> Numerous people and companies have created an
> alternative to this monopoly. They offer lots of TLDs
> - many are free and some are not. These alternate TLDs
> are supported by an alternate DNS. We call these the
> "alternate roots". Some articles and white papers on
> the subject claim that, if we use the alternate roots,
> we put the health of the Internet in jeopardy. But
> remember - it's not technical - it's about money and
> politics. Truth seldom flourishes in that environment.
>
> This presentation will bring you up to speed on the
> issues, and DEMONSTRATES LIVE that we can easily use
> the "standard roots" and the "alternate roots'
> together to access any of the TLDs - without affecting
> the health of the Internet.  
>
>Normally, PANUG meetings are members-only but non-members
>can attend this meeting for $5.00, which includes pizza
>and refreshments. The meeting is held at Novell's office
>near Washington Square. Directions are on the PANUG web
>site at http://www.panug.org. You must RSVP to attend.
>Send your RSVP to info at panug.org. Space is limited and
>PANUG members have preference.
>
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
