From derek at infotects.com  Tue Feb 11 12:15:02 2003
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Feb 11 12:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] VPN Suggestions?
In-Reply-To: <20030211052633.M51456@laynesoftware.com>
References: <1044932801.19370.77.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
	 <20030211052633.M51456@laynesoftware.com>
Message-ID: <1044994485.19504.89.camel@dereklinux>

On Mon, 2003-02-10 at 21:26, Terry Layne wrote:
> On 10 Feb 2003 19:06:41 -0800, AthlonRob wrote
> > Hey everybody-
> > 
> > I'm going to be gone for several months... unfortunately, I'm going 
> > to be using AOL for my ISP.  I can't say why, but it is by far a better
> > deal than anything else.
> > 
> > I would really like to be able to connect to my local network here at
> > home from away, though.  I was looking at OpenVPN at first as it didn't
> > require any additional firewall rules on my firewall (and I'd like to
> > run the VPN server behind the firewall, ideally).
> > 
> > But... there doesn't seem to be a way to connect to an OpenVPN server
> > with Windoze.  Bummer.
> > 
> > So what kind of VPN solutions would you guys suggest I look in to?
> 
> What's wrong with ssh when you just need a shell and vnc when you want a
> desktop?  The Windows VNC viewer works well enough.  You'd just need to open
> 22 and 580n, 590n, on your firewall (assuming you start vnc with vncserver :n.)

For me, it was about the namespace and browser compatibility.  

There is a certain web application that is served up by apache on a
virtual host that is available only to the private LAN.  Unfortunately,
this application only runs in IE (ActiveX).  So, I needed the internal
DNS server to correctly resolve the host name, so that apache would
serve up the right application.  NETBIOS works too, which gives me easy
file transfers between the windows box and the linux server.

To solve it, I used PopTop and the native windows PPTP protocol.  It
uses "mppe" as the encryption protocol, and an IP protocol called "GRE",
though this is not to be confused with the Cisco version of "GRE", this
is the PPTP version of "GRE".  This protocol is also know as 47.  

Over the weekend I was able to modify my lrp firewall to forward a GRE
tunnel (of the PPTP variety) to the specified windows box.  This means
that my home network is not attached to my work network, only one
windows box inside my home network is attached to my work network.

It's not entirely stable, but was up for about 3 days before
mysteriously closing.  The windows network browser is having a hard time
(I transplanted the windows box into my home network, then hooked it
back up to the work network -- I think it is very confused), however,
searching for computers by ip address will almost always work, searching
by name will start to work as time goes by.  Another problem was that
windows pays no attention to the search order of the DNS; I had to
specify only the work DNS for IE to resolve the virtual host correctly. 
If any other DNS server was listed, IE would fail to resolve it.

I realize that there are more secure options out there, IPSEC comes to
mind, but this one has a major advantage -- I actually got it to work! 
I can't say the same about IPSEC, though it wasn't for lack of trying.

As much as I like ssh and vnc, VPN's do have a purpose.

Derek Loree

access via my satellite phone from anywhere to anywhere. It's limited to
9600 bps, and the air time charge is $1.50 per minute, but it works.

of the Cascades I've found cellular telephone dead zones. The satellite
phone works like a charm in those locations.

Running debian stable.  What is the quickest way to cap my eth0 to 2mb?
I'm getting some free rack space and I've been showing up on radar a
couple times so I just want to cap it, no firewalling or fancy
filtering.

From deathfox at moochercrew.org  Tue Feb 11 14:36:01 2003
From: deathfox at moochercrew.org (Chris Emery)
Date: Tue Feb 11 14:36:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] quick bandwidth cap
In-Reply-To: <20030211222607.GA27054@subtend.net>
References: <20030211222607.GA27054@subtend.net>
Message-ID: <1045002911.14498.4.camel@paleblueeyes.moochercrew.org>

Unfortunately, I belive the only way to cap an ethernet controler is by
using packet flow control found in the kernel.  Either the Trafic
Shaper, or the CBQ/fair queueing.  This is the only way I know how to do
it.

Chris (vrs K-Ris)

On Tue, 2003-02-11 at 14:26, Kris wrote:
> Running debian stable.  What is the quickest way to cap my eth0 to 2mb?
> I'm getting some free rack space and I've been showing up on radar a
> couple times so I just want to cap it, no firewalling or fancy
> filtering.




From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue Feb 11 14:50:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue Feb 11 14:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CanoScan N670U installation
References: <20030211200003.99538.qmail@web9608.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <3E497DE8.5060800@pacifier.com>

Robert Kopp wrote:
> I may almost have a scanner set up, but something
> isn't quite right. It's a USB scanner, as are most
> scanners sold today. 
> 
> The module was loaded manually with modprobe scanner
> 
> According to cat /proc/bus/usb/devices, the kernel
> recognizes it (below).


Check /var/log/messages for more info
mine spits out this

kernel: hub.c: USB new device connect on bus1/2, assigned device number 3
kernel: usb.c: USB device 3 (vend/prod 0x4b8/0x110) is not claimed by any 
active driver.
/etc/hotplug/usb.agent: Setup scanner for USB product 4b8/110/302
kernel: usb.c: registered new driver usbscanner
kernel: scanner.c: probe_scanner: User specified USB scanner -- 
Vendor:Product - 4b8:110
kernel: scanner.c: 0.4.6:USB Scanner Driver

When I launch xsane, I get a lot of warnings

kernel: scanner.c: open_scanner(1): Unable to access minor data

dunno why, but it seems to work anyway.

So make sure the kernel is happy.  Also, according to your /proc, there is 
no driver associated

P:  Vendor=04a9 ProdID=220d Rev= 1.00
S:  Manufacturer=Canon
S:  Product=CanoScan
C:* #Ifs= 1 Cfg#= 1 Atr=a0 MxPwr=500mA
I:  If#= 0 Alt= 0 #EPs= 3 Cls=ff(vend.) Sub=00 Prot=ff Driver=(none)
                                                                ^^^^
whereas mine says
P:  Vendor=04b8 ProdID=0110 Rev= 3.02
S:  Manufacturer=EPSON
S:  Product=EPSON Scanner
C:* #Ifs= 1 Cfg#= 1 Atr=c0 MxPwr=  2mA
I:  If#= 0 Alt= 0 #EPs= 2 Cls=ff(vend.) Sub=ff Prot=ff Driver=usbscanner

I have a line in /etc/modules.conf
options scanner product=0x0110 vendor=0x04b8

so you might check that your says something like
options scanner product=0x220d vendor=0x04a9

Also, see if `lsmod` shows that usbcore is loaded

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Tue Feb 11 15:35:02 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Tue Feb 11 15:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CanoScan N670U installation
Message-ID: <20030211233458.28656.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com>

Here's where I am now: by giving a parameter with
modprobe scanner, I was able to get sane-find-scanner
to recognize the device as /dev/usb/scanner0.It still
could not be mounted as a block device, however.

Using cat /proc/bus/usb/devices, I found that the
driver was SUPPOSED to be usbscanner, wheich is
probably the source of the trouble. My /lib/modules
does not contain such a module; modprobe will not load
it. 

Any ideas about how to fix that? My version of
sane-backends (1.0.8-5) is not the most recent.It is
an rpm, so if I upgrade it will have to be removed
with the nodeps option.Anyhow, I hate to give up when
things are starting to look promising.

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Feb 12 00:07:01 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Wed Feb 12 00:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix (Linux on CD) troubles
In-Reply-To: <1044911870.17099.293.camel@coyote.pdx.beattie-home.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302112358330.10152-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

I was going to say something, but people have covered things pretty well.
The two major issues are:

     -  Burn Knoppix ISO image to CD as a raw burn using something like
        cdrecord.  The image has already been mastered as a bootable
        CD, so the complex part already done.  One simply has to burn
        it to the CD as a raw burn.  I'm afraid I don't know how this
        works with most non Unix CD burning software.

     -  Make sure the BIOS is set to try booting from CDROM before
        booting from disk.
        I'm assuming that both the CDROM and the hard disk are IDE.
        I have booted Knoppix on SCSI based systems, but as I recall
        there are a number of quirks.  However, I was successful with
        Knoppix.  I have not always been so successful booting
        DEMO Linux on systems with SCSI components.

                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213
                                          (360) 260-2066 at work
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Feb 12 07:00:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Feb 12 07:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Journal Weekly Newsletter - February 12 (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302120655230.15013-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
  Feature Links of the Week

   Bridge the Gap Between Physical and Virtual Networking with netstat:
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=6613 -- Sean Conway looks
   at the open systems interconnect (OSI) model and how netstat can help
   those used to the physical side of the system understand what's going
   on in the network.

   Tale of Two Stories:
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=6616 -- Scandal and bad
   news aren't the terrain of only the checkout-line newspapers. The tech
   industry also loves a good "star on the skids" story--even if it's not
   true.

  Tech Tip

   If you want to train a Bayesian spam filter on your mail, don't delete
   non-spam mail that you're done with. Put it in a "non-spam trash"
   folder and let the filter train on it. Then, delete only the mail
   that's been used for training. Do the same thing with spam.

   It's especially important to train your filter on mail that it
   misclassified the first time. Be sure to move spam from your index to
   your spam folder instead of merely deleting it.

   To do the training, edit your crontab with crontab -e and add lines
   like this:

6 1 * * * /bin/mv -fv $HOME/Maildir/nonspam-trash/new/* $HOME/Maildir/nonspam-t
rash/cur/ && /usr/local/bin/mboxtrain.py -d $HOME/.hammiedb -g $HOME/Maildir/no
nspam-trash

6 1 * * * /bin/mv -fv $HOME/Maildir/spam/new/* $HOME/Maildir/spam/cur/ && /usr/
local/bin/mboxtrain.py -d $HOME/.hammiedb -s $HOME/Maildir/spam

   Finally, you can remove mail in a trash mailbox that the Bayesian
   filter has already seen:

2 2 * * * grep -rl X-Spambayes-Trained $HOME/Maildir/nonspam-trash | xargs rm -
v

2 2 * * * grep -rl X-Spambayes-Trained $HOME/Maildir/spam | xargs rm -v

   Look for more information on Spambayes and the math behind spam
   filtering in the March issue of Linux Journal.




From bspears at easystreet.com  Wed Feb 12 09:43:02 2003
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Wed Feb 12 09:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of X
In-Reply-To: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0302120617590.7407-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References:

From bspears at easystreet.com  Wed Feb 12 09:51:02 2003
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Wed Feb 12 09:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sound on the motherboard
Message-ID: <1045072231.1078.12.camel@apollo.spears.org>

I have a motherboard with built in sound and finally decided to hook up
some speakers and see if it works. It doesn't.

I used both sndconfig and the new version included with RH 8.0 and when
it played a test sound nothing happened.

Context:
	motherboard: Ampton ddr 266
	sound stuff from boot up:

Intel 810 + AC97 Audio, version 0.22, 12:24:02 Sep  4 2002
PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:02.7
i810: SiS 7012 found at IO 0xd400 and 0xdc00, IRQ 11
i810_audio: Audio Controller supports 2 channels.
i810_audio: Defaulting to base 2 channel mode.
ac97_codec: AC97 Audio codec, id: 0x414c:0x4326 (Unknown)
i810_audio: only 48Khz playback available.
i810_audio: AC'97 codec 0 supports AMAP, total channels = 2

	speakers: plugged in to blue connector which I believe is line out.


Willing to entertain all possibilities.




From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Wed Feb 12 09:51:11 2003

Subject: [PLUG] CanoScan N670U
Message-ID: <20030212175016.88428.qmail@web9608.mail.yahoo.com>

From plug at laynesoftware.com  Wed Feb 12 10:01:02 2003
From: plug at laynesoftware.com (Terry Layne)
Date: Wed Feb 12 10:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sound on the motherboard
In-Reply-To: <1045072231.1078.12.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1045072231.1078.12.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <20030212180017.M76682@laynesoftware.com>

On 13 Feb 2003 01:50:31 +0800, Bill Spears wrote
> I have a motherboard with built in sound and finally decided to hook 
> up some speakers and see if it works. It doesn't.
> 
> I used both sndconfig and the new version included with RH 8.0 and when
> it played a test sound nothing happened.

Just to cover all the obvious stuff, check the permissions on /dev/audio. 
Sometimes they install as 600 and you need to change it to 666 so that
non-root users can listen to sounds.


Terry Layne



From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Feb 12 10:04:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Feb 12 10:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of X
In-Reply-To: <1045071767.1071.3.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302120956290.7407-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 13 Feb 2003, Bill Spears wrote:

> Well, it was interesting to look at, in that X is really intricate
> and I couldn't even begin to understand most of the start up
> messages. It said I have two "mouses" defined, one of which I have:
> PS2 and one I don't IMPS.

That's probably not a problem. The IMPS mouse definition works with MS 
IntelliMouse devices on the PS/2 port; it also works with USB devices.

If you're using a wheel mouse or a USB mouse, then you'll want to use 
the IMPS protocol.

Can you provide

* a description of the mouse you're using (no. of buttons, type of 
  connector, wheel/no-wheel, ...)

* from your /etc/X11/XF86Config file
  - any ServerLayout sections
  - any InputDevice sections that define the mouse Driver

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed Feb 12 10:34:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Wed Feb 12 10:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sound on the motherboard
References: <1045072231.1078.12.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <3E4A9362.7030306@pacifier.com>

Bill Spears wrote:
> I have a motherboard with built in sound and finally decided to hook up
> some speakers and see if it works. It doesn't.


One more obvious thing: are the speakers powered or not?  If not, the 
internal amp may be disabled and you won't hear anything--try headphones.

Also, at least on my soundblaster, blue is an input.  (I think.  It was hard 
to see without moving the box.)



> Intel 810 + AC97 Audio, version 0.22, 12:24:02 Sep  4 2002
> PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:02.7
> i810: SiS 7012 found at IO 0xd400 and 0xdc00, IRQ 11
> i810_audio: Audio Controller supports 2 channels.
> i810_audio: Defaulting to base 2 channel mode.
> ac97_codec: AC97 Audio codec, id: 0x414c:0x4326 (Unknown)
> i810_audio: only 48Khz playback available.
> i810_audio: AC'97 codec 0 supports AMAP, total channels = 2


 > I did note in /var/log/messages: modprobe: "Couldn't locate
 > sound-service-0-3"

Do you have an entry in /etc/modules.conf?  I'm not an expert on the new 
sound mechanisms (ALSA), and sound-service is different from sound-slot, but 
if it helps, I have

alias sound-slot-0 emu10k1

you'd change emu10k1 to i810 (or whatever it's called).

--
Kyle Accardi









From bspears at easystreet.com  Wed Feb 12 10:37:01 2003
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Wed Feb 12 10:37:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of X
In-Reply-To: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0302120956290.7407-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0302120956290.7407-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <1045075013.1078.23.camel@apollo.spears.org>

On Thu, 2003-02-13 at 02:03, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On 13 Feb 2003, Bill Spears wrote:
> 
> > Well, it was interesting to look at, in that X is really intricate
> > and I couldn't even begin to understand most of the start up
> > messages. It said I have two "mouses" defined, one of which I have:
> > PS2 and one I don't IMPS.
> 
> That's probably not a problem. The IMPS mouse definition works with MS 
> IntelliMouse devices on the PS/2 port; it also works with USB devices.
> 
> If you're using a wheel mouse or a USB mouse, then you'll want to use 
> the IMPS protocol.
> 
> Can you provide
> 
> * a description of the mouse you're using (no. of buttons, type of 
>   connector, wheel/no-wheel, ...)
> 
> * from your /etc/X11/XF86Config file
>   - any ServerLayout sections
>   - any InputDevice sections that define the mouse Driver
> 
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
> 
Mouse: Microsoft optical wheel mouse usb, plugged into a PS/2 adapter

Section "ServerLayout"
        Identifier     "Anaconda Configured"
        Screen      0  "Screen0" 0 0
        InputDevice    "Mouse0" "CorePointer"
        InputDevice     "Mouse1" "SendCoreEvents"
        InputDevice    "Keyboard0" "CoreKeyboard"
EndSection

Section "InputDevice"
        Identifier  "Mouse0"
        Driver      "mouse"
        Option      "Protocol" "PS/2"
        Option      "Device" "/dev/psaux"
        Option      "ZAxisMapping" "4 5"
        Option      "Emulate3Buttons" "yes"
EndSection


Section "InputDevice"
        Identifier      "Mouse1"
        Driver          "mouse"
        Option          "Device"                "/dev/input/mice"
        Option          "Protocol"              "IMPS/2"
        Option          "Emulate3Buttons"       "no"
        Option          "ZAxisMapping"          "4 5"
EndSection





From ed at alcpress.com  Wed Feb 12 10:38:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Wed Feb 12 10:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] rackspace.com
Message-ID: <1045075033.16190.161.camel@red>

For those of you maintaining your own email black lists
or RBLs, my customers and I have been getting a lot of
spam from IP addresses allocated to rackspace.com in Texas.
I recall discussion here of using rackspace as a
co-location facility. rackspace has no database available
to the outside world to identify the IP blocks of their
individual customers (the spammers) and they don't return
phone calls about the matter.

As a result, we just blocked their 65.61.128.0/18
allocation entirely. They have other allocations and we'll
block them as well as we receive spam from them. If you use
IP addresses from their allocation, let me know what they
are and I'll white list them.

Ed  





From mikel at quantecllc.com  Wed Feb 12 10:43:02 2003
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael Luevane)
Date: Wed Feb 12 10:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Website issues
Message-ID: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOMEJINBAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

Hello, all.

I'm hoping some of you web server/network gurus out there can point me in
the right direction.

Issue:

Our test website (hosted internally) is behind a firewall/router (Hawking
D945F).
We are running Windows 2000 Server. Active Directory, DNS - all set up.
The website is hosted on a Dell PowerEdge 1600 running Mandrake Linux 8.2,
using the Apache server.
>From inside the company: I can always get to the test site by typing the
internal IP address.

On the router, I set a DMZ entry to our existing website, also running on a
Linux system, Apache webserver. Works fine.
On the router, I set a DMZ entry to our test website. Nothing.

I look in the auth_log, error_log. Nothing. Looks like the request isn't
even getting to the web server.

Change the DMZ entry back to the old site - works fine.

So, it looks like the request is not being passed to the test server.

Any suggestions on where to look?

BTW, the router is not set up for DHCP. That's handled by our W2K server, as
is our DNS.

Thanks in advance!

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Feb 12 10:51:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Feb 12 10:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of X
In-Reply-To: <1045075013.1078.23.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302121042400.7407-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 13 Feb 2003, Bill Spears wrote:

> > Can you provide
> > 
> > * a description of the mouse you're using (no. of buttons, type of 
> >   connector, wheel/no-wheel, ...)
> > 
> > * from your /etc/X11/XF86Config file
> >   - any ServerLayout sections
> >   - any InputDevice sections that define the mouse Driver
> > 

> Mouse: Microsoft optical wheel mouse usb, plugged into a PS/2 adapter

Ah, that's interesting. So Linux and X think you've got a PS/2 mouse, 
not a USB mouse. I think you'll need to do some editing of your 
XF86Config file.

First, make a safe copy of your current /etc/X11/XF86Config file.

Then,

> Section "ServerLayout"
>         Identifier     "Anaconda Configured"
>         Screen      0  "Screen0" 0 0
>         InputDevice    "Mouse0" "CorePointer"
>         InputDevice     "Mouse1" "SendCoreEvents"
>         InputDevice    "Keyboard0" "CoreKeyboard"
> EndSection

Comment out the Mouse0 and Mouse1 lines in the ServerLayout section. 
Add a new line just below Mouse1:

  InputDevice  "MouseLocal" "CorePointer"

Create a new InputDevice Section:

  Section "InputDevice"
    Identifier "MouseLocal"
    Driver     "mouse"
    Option     "Device"          "/dev/psaux"
    Option     "Protocol"        "IMPS/2"
    Option     "Emulate3Buttons" "off"
    Option     "ZAxisMapping"    "4 5"
  EndSection

You can leave the Mouse0 and Mouse1 InputDevice sections alone.

Restart X and see if it flies. :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From robby at planetargon.com  Wed Feb 12 11:18:01 2003
From: robby at planetargon.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Wed Feb 12 11:18:01 2003

conference is
Embracing and Extending Proprietary Software.

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Feb 12 12:20:03 2003
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed Feb 12 12:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sound on the motherboard
In-Reply-To: <1045072231.1078.12.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1045072231.1078.12.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1045081198.5559.188.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Bill,


On Wed, 2003-02-12 at 09:50, Bill Spears wrote:
> I have a motherboard with built in sound and finally decided to hook up
> some speakers and see if it works. It doesn't.
> 
> I used both sndconfig and the new version included with RH 8.0 and when
> it played a test sound nothing happened.
> 
> Context:
> 	motherboard: Ampton ddr 266
> 	sound stuff from boot up:
> 
> Intel 810 + AC97 Audio, version 0.22, 12:24:02 Sep  4 2002
> PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:02.7
> i810: SiS 7012 found at IO 0xd400 and 0xdc00, IRQ 11
> i810_audio: Audio Controller supports 2 channels.
> i810_audio: Defaulting to base 2 channel mode.
> ac97_codec: AC97 Audio codec, id: 0x414c:0x4326 (Unknown)
> i810_audio: only 48Khz playback available.
> i810_audio: AC'97 codec 0 supports AMAP, total channels = 2

It looks like the sound card was found by the kernel, that is good.
> 
> 	speakers: plugged in to blue connector which I believe is line out.

Try plugging into the green, sometimes the line out is muted, but the
speaker out is probably set to half volume.

To see if the sound card is functioning at some level, try playing an
audio cd.  This won't test your sound server, but will at least make
noise for you.  If this works, you need to open up a mixer program, and
see what has been muted and what hasn't.

Now, with the mixer open try a couple of different programs that are
supposed to make noise.

Report back with your findings.

Derek Loree

From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Wed Feb 12 13:19:02 2003
From: John.Hampton at gijoes.com (John Hampton)
Date: Wed Feb 12 13:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of X
Message-ID: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014DA6@gilligan.gijoes.com>

Bill Spears said:
<much snippage of good stuff>
>After a few false starts, due to typos on my part, it is working. Is
>there some reason for turning Emulate3Buttons off? What's the difference
>between /dev/psaux and /dev/input/mice? 
>
>I had thought that since the physical connector was PS/2 that the port
>would also be. Doh!

All of the scroll mice that I have seen are actually 3 button mice.  The 3rd button being when you press down on the scroll wheel.  Because the scroll wheel is considered the 3rd button, you don't want to emulate it.  Also, my understanding of the "ZAxisMapping" line is that you are mapping buttons 4 and 5 to the Z axis.  Buttons 4 and 5 corresponding to a scroll up and scroll down of the scroll wheel.  so, in essence, X sees your mouse as being a 5 button mouse.

John Hampton
Programmer Analyst
G.I. Joe's, Inc.
john.hampton at gijoes.com

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Feb 12 13:39:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Feb 12 13:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking of X
In-Reply-To: <1045084334.1557.13.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302121331380.7407-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 13 Feb 2003, Bill Spears wrote:

> After a few false starts, due to typos on my part, it is working. Is
> there some reason for turning Emulate3Buttons off? What's the
> difference between /dev/psaux and /dev/input/mice?

John H. answered the question about Emulate3Buttons.

As for the /dev entries, /dev/psaux is the PS/2 port while
/dev/input/mice is part of the USB "human interface device" (HID)
support. If you've got a kernel tree lying around, take a peek at 
the CONFIG_USB_HID section of Documentation/Configure.help.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From gilmanhunt at attbi.com  Wed Feb 12 15:00:04 2003
From: gilmanhunt at attbi.com (gilmanhunt at attbi.com)
Date: Wed Feb 12 15:00:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] naive question about the internet, etc.
Message-ID: <E18j5qw-0000dg-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Bear with me, it's been probably about 12 months or more since I've used the
tool "mtr." It's "Matt's TraceRoute" and what it does is do a traceroute and
then sit back and ping each host returned, and shows you over time what the ping
counts are. It can be used as a tool to test network reliability.

Work has a website at (www.craftpizazz.com) Not a plug, just a point of
reference. We (web guys) have been having an issue with FTPing to and from the
site, and I've installed Snort and seen some interesting results, but need more
quantification before I make a determination. Anyway, on to my question.

I've got a (relatively new) firewall located at the server location, and I
installed MTR and ran the MTR back to our firewall here at the company: 
I get back about 12 rows of hosts, each with between 1 and 5 percent packet loss.

If I go to another server I have access to, and do MTR from it to the webserver,
I have similar numbers with different servers in the list.

If I stay on that other server and go from there to a friend's server at
RackSpace, I get 0s and 1s.

Twelve to Eighteen months ago, 0s and 1s were acceptable; but up to 5% was not,
really, and I'd be calling the ISP. 

Naive question of the day?
Has the Internet been mangled enough that the 5% is an acceptable number, or
should I keep looking for a problem with the network layer? 

-Russ



From srau at rauhaus.org  Wed Feb 12 15:17:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Wed Feb 12 15:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] naive question about the internet, etc.
In-Reply-To: <E18j5qw-0000dg-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <E18j5qw-0000dg-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20030212231622.GA18887@rauhaus.org>

* gilmanhunt at attbi.com <gilmanhunt at attbi.com> [030212 15:00]:
> 
> I've got a (relatively new) firewall located at the server location, and I
> installed MTR and ran the MTR back to our firewall here at the company: 
> I get back about 12 rows of hosts, each with between 1 and 5 percent packet loss.

You may in fact have a network problem, but do keep in mind that sending
back the ICMP "Time to live exceeded in transit" messages that tools
like mtr and traceroute rely on is about last in the order of priorities
that a busy router in the middle has to keep up on.

You can see higher latency and/or dropped packets from an intermediate
router when there is no problem with your end to end performance, simply
because the intermediate hops are too busy passing traffic to interrupt
their processors to create the ICMP reply to send back.

If your performance from wherever you're testing to your ftp server is
good, then you don't have a problem. If you are seeing problems end to
end, then tools like mtr, pchar, and others can help you isolate where
the problem is exactly happening.

Speaking of which, the "nanog" version of traceroute has some nice
options like showing the ASN & contact info for the networks through which
you're transitting.

--Stafford



From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Feb 12 15:25:03 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Feb 12 15:25:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] naive question about the internet, etc.
In-Reply-To: <E18j5qw-0000dg-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302121520510.7407-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 12 Feb 2003 gilmanhunt at attbi.com wrote:

> Naive question of the day?
>
> Has the Internet been mangled enough that the 5% is an acceptable
> number, or should I keep looking for a problem with the network
> layer?

If I saw 5% packet loss between any two hosts in any two well-wired
countries (US, Europe, East Asia, Australia), I'd be looking for a
problem.

My first hunch is that some router along the way is being asked to 
manage too much traffic. It might be a flood worm like the recent 
Sapphire, a DoS attack, or perhaps just poor capital spending :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Rich> intelligence modeling code (in C) from Windows to linux. I'm

It depends on the modeling code.  Common Lisp is good for lots of
different kind of programming, not just AI stuff.  There is some stuff
it isn't particularly good for.

Rich>   Has anyone here had experience with CL? 

Yes.

Rich> Can applications written in it be linked to data stored in, for
Rich> example, a postgres database?

Yes.  E.g.:

and its cousins.

Rich> What UI tools are avaialable for it?

Yes, but I don't have any direct experience with them.

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Wed Feb 12 16:34:02 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Wed Feb 12 16:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] External Firewire Drive
Message-ID: <20030213003355.1741.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>

By now I have only one device I haven't used with
Linux, an IDE hard drive in an external FireWire case.
The system knows about it, for when it is hot-plugged
in, a stanza instantly appears in cat /proc/scsi/scsi:

Host: scsi2 Channel: 00 Id: 00 Lun: 00
  Vendor: WDC WD20 Model: 0BB-00CFC0       Rev:
  Type:   Direct-Access                    ANSI SCSI
revision: 06

It might be convenient to use it. What would really be
helpful is if someone could tell me what the name of
this device was likely to be, so I could mount it. 

mount /dev/1394 /mnt/1394. Well, sort of...

Otherwise, is there a good source of information on
the subject?

At the moment, I have the contents of my Windows
partition on it, although I haven't accessed that
partition in a long time. I had been thinking about
backing that data up to CD's, and using the FireWire
drive to back up Linux data.

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

"SAMBA--opening Windows to a wider world."

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Feb 12 18:07:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Feb 12 18:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] External Firewire Drive
In-Reply-To: <20030213003355.1741.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302121804260.802-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 12 Feb 2003, Robert Kopp wrote:

> By now I have only one device I haven't used with Linux, an IDE hard
> drive in an external FireWire case. The system knows about it, for
> when it is hot-plugged in, a stanza instantly appears in cat
> /proc/scsi/scsi:

This should do it:

  dmesg | grep 'SCSI device'

Chances are, however, it'll just show up in order: if you've got no 
SCSI devices, it'll be /dev/sda; if you've got sda, it'll be sdb; ...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Wed Feb 12 18:34:02 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Wed Feb 12 18:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FireWire hard drive
Message-ID: <20030213023345.30394.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>

It turns out that the FireWire drive wants to call
itself /dev/sdb1. And is it fast!

That happens to be the "handle" of the digital camera,
however. After unplugging the hard drive, even
properly, I can't mount the camera with the same
device name without rebooting.

Or can I? It might be nice to know how to use both in
the same session, but it's difficult to conceive of a
scenario in which this would be necessary.

I'm sure glad that on my Pavilion 7950, the
receptacles for hot-plug devices are mounted on the front!

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

"SAMBA--opening Windows to a wider world."

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Feb 12 19:58:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Feb 12 19:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Programming in Common Lisp
In-Reply-To: <1045106971.1557.32.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302121948350.16592-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 13 Feb 2003, Bill Spears wrote:

> Weren't you just doing something like CLIPS, ie a rule based system
> based on a simple application of fuzzy logic?  FWIW, I'd use Python:
> very easy to learn and a reasonably big community.

Bill,

  Yes, and no. The models are rule-based, but they are fuzzy rules, not
explicit-case rules. One example frequently used by my mentor is a pricing
model for a British manufacturer done in the early 1980s. The four rules for
pricing a new product are:

	1. Our price must be high.
	2. Our price must be low.
	3. Our price must be near twice the manufacturing cost.
	4. If the competition price is not very high
		Then our price should be near the competition price.

  I understand that no one's been able to do this with a quantitative,
rule-based expert system.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard at appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/

> model for a British manufacturer done in the early 1980s. The four rules for
> pricing a new product are:

> 	1. Our price must be high.
> 	2. Our price must be low.
> 	3. Our price must be near twice the manufacturing cost.
> 	4. If the competition price is not very high
> 		Then our price should be near the competition price.
> 
>   I understand that no one's been able to do this with a quantitative,
> rule-based expert system.
> 
> Rich
> 
> Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
> 
>                        Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
>             2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
>  + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard at appl-ecosys.com
>                          http://www.appl-ecosys.com/
> 
> 
Right, clips is expert systems. No, what I meant is called a fuzzy
system: the sendai train system, somebody's kiln, a model helicopter
controller, etc.  I had a simple prototype running in Python about 5
years ago, but, ironically, my recent crash took my last remaining
Windows partition with it, and the Python code with it.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Feb 12 23:06:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)

Subject: [PLUG] Programming in Common Lisp
In-Reply-To: <20030213035926.GB19174@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302121531470.15799-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
	<1045106971.1557.32.camel@apollo.spears.org>
	<20030213035926.GB19174@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <86n0l0irsm.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rogan" == Rogan Creswick <creswick at cs.orst.edu> writes:

Rogan> On Thu, Feb 13, 2003 at 11:29:31AM +0800, Bill Spears wrote:
>> Weren't you just doing something like CLIPS, ie a rule based system
>> based on a simple application of fuzzy logic?  FWIW, I'd use
>> Python:


Rogan> Rule based stuff screams for Prolog.. but I don't know of much
Rogan> "real" software written in a logic-based language.

Interestingly, you can implement a Prolog in Common Lisp in under 400
lines (including comments).  

   $ wc -l *.lisp
       180 patmatch.lisp
       139 prolog.lisp
        59 unify.lisp
       378 total

See:

  <http://www.norvig.com/paip/README.html>

                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!''

From sean at fork.com  Thu Feb 13 00:47:01 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Thu Feb 13 00:47:01 2003
Subject: Fwd: [PLUG] rackspace.com
Message-ID: <20030213064242.33F84C5CD@max.seansdomain.org>

There was actually a very similar comment in the latest LJ.


Sean

----------  Forwarded Message  ----------

Subject: [PLUG] rackspace.com
Date: 12 Feb 2003 10:37:13 -0800
From: Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org

For those of you maintaining your own email black lists
or RBLs, my customers and I have been getting a lot of
spam from IP addresses allocated to rackspace.com in Texas.
I recall discussion here of using rackspace as a
co-location facility. rackspace has no database available
to the outside world to identify the IP blocks of their
individual customers (the spammers) and they don't return
phone calls about the matter.

As a result, we just blocked their 65.61.128.0/18
allocation entirely. They have other allocations and we'll
block them as well as we receive spam from them. If you use
IP addresses from their allocation, let me know what they
are and I'll white list them.

Ed



_______________________________________________
PLUG mailing list
PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From robby at planetargon.com  Thu Feb 13 07:36:02 2003
From: robby at planetargon.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Thu Feb 13 07:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: strange logs.....
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCCEOFCFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCCEOFCFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: 
     <2569.208.151.243.124.1045150156.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>

Never seen those before... however if you don't want your logs to be
bloated with codered/ nimida stuff...
add something like this this to your httpd.conf file

# Ignore IIS problems and script kiddies
SetEnvIf Request_URI "/cmd.exe" attacks dontlog
SetEnvIf Request_URI "/root.exe" attacks dontlog
SetEnvIf Request_URI "/cgi-local/formail.pl" attacks dontlog
SetEnvIf Request_URI "/default.ida" attacks dontlog
SetEnvIf Request_URI "/default.ida?" attacks dontlog
SetEnvIf Request_URI "default.ida" attacks dontlog
SetEnvIf Request_URI "default.ida?" attacks dontlog


having mentioned this, does anyone else have methods of keeping their logs
clean? Care to share?

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Feb 13 08:21:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Feb 13 08:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Programming in Common Lisp
In-Reply-To: <1045118505.1073.3.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302130807380.18547-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 13 Feb 2003, Bill Spears wrote:

> Right, clips is expert systems. No, what I meant is called a fuzzy system:
> the sendai train system, somebody's kiln, a model helicopter controller,
> etc.  I had a simple prototype running in Python about 5 years ago, but,
> ironically, my recent crash took my last remaining Windows partition with
> it, and the Python code with it.

Bill,

  Most of the work dune with fuzzy logic and models has been with
controllers. Your autofocus camera and image-stabilized videocam are other
examples.

  There are _very_ few folks who have been applying fuzzy logic to business
problems. One's been making his living at it -- as an independent consultant
-- since 1972. There's one other of whom I'm aware who's been trained by
this one fellow, and this other one is in Minnesota.

  There are quite a few companies applying neural nets and genetic
algorithms to many of the same problems (e.g. insurance ratings, fraud
detection) but there are problem classes that can be addressed by one and
not the others.

  I'm learning the nuts and bolts of fuzzy system modeling which includes GA
and neural net components in some models. I _can_ do it all in C (or C++ or
python or prolog or lisp or scheme or java or ...). The language really
doesn't matter. For the use I want to make of these models I'm considering
if learning and using CNU/Lisp (an implementation of Common Lisp) might make
model development much quicker than using C. Each project and situation
where this would be the most rational and pragmatic approach is different.
Therefore, each project/situation needs to have a new model built from
scratch. The fuzzy manipulation functions remain the same, and the UI will
probably be constant, but the derivation of fuzzy rules and the way the
model is structured will vary each time. That's where prototyping and
development speed can make a difference in time to a working model and cost
to my client.

Thanks,

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard at appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/

From plug at laynesoftware.com  Thu Feb 13 09:09:01 2003
From: plug at laynesoftware.com (Terry Layne)
Date: Thu Feb 13 09:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: strange logs.....
In-Reply-To: <2569.208.151.243.124.1045150156.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCCEOFCFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph> <2569.208.151.243.124.1045150156.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>
Message-ID: <20030213170659.M61305@laynesoftware.com>

On Thu, 13 Feb 2003 07:29:16 -0800 (PST), Robby Russell wrote
> Never seen those before... however if you don't want your logs to be
> bloated with codered/ nimida stuff...
> add something like this this to your httpd.conf file
> 
> # Ignore IIS problems and script kiddies
> SetEnvIf Request_URI "/cmd.exe" attacks dontlog
> SetEnvIf Request_URI "/root.exe" attacks dontlog
> SetEnvIf Request_URI "/cgi-local/formail.pl" attacks dontlog
> SetEnvIf Request_URI "/default.ida" attacks dontlog
> SetEnvIf Request_URI "/default.ida?" attacks dontlog
> SetEnvIf Request_URI "default.ida" attacks dontlog
> SetEnvIf Request_URI "default.ida?" attacks dontlog
> 
> having mentioned this, does anyone else have methods of keeping 
> their logs clean? Care to share?
> 

I just implemented the following:  Enable name based virtual hosts in apache
for all ip addresses.  Then setup as the first listed virtual host something
that doesn't match anything.  When someone reaches my site using an ip address
only, they go to the first VirtualHost because their ServerName doesn't match
anything.  That way all the logs go to their own file.  I have all my other
VirtualHosts logging to standard error_log and access_log.  I suppose you
could direct the junk_logs to /dev/null as well.


NameVirtualHost *

<VirtualHost *>
ServerName "codered.stopper"
ServerAdmin "webmaster at mydomain"
ErrorLog /var/log/apache/junk_error_log
CustomLog /var/log/apache/junk_access_log combined
</VirtualHost>

Regards,
Terry Layne



From buchholz at easystreet.com  Thu Feb 13 09:13:01 2003
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Thu Feb 13 09:13:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RHN subscription warning!
Message-ID: <3E4BD075.5020403@easystreet.com>

FWIW, anyone who is subscribing to the RedHat network should
be aware of the following clause in the current RHN "Use and
Subscription Agreement":

  ANNUAL SUBSCRIPTIONS. For annual subscriptions to the Service,
  the initial term of this Agreement shall commence on the Effective
  Date and shall continue for one (1) year. Thereafter, the term
  shall renew for successive terms of one (1) year each unless either
  party gives written notice to the other of its intention not to
  renew at least sixty (60) days prior to the commencement of the
  next term. Customer may provide notice of non-renewal in writing
  to Red Hat by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested,
  to the following address: Red Hat, Inc., Customer Service, 1801
  Varsity Drive, Raleigh, North Carolina 27606. You may not terminate
  the Service or this Agreement by email.

Best current practice for dealing with this kind of clause (if you
need the service) is to enclose a notice of non-renewal with the
original purchase.

I do find this type of agreement (especially the requirement for
registered/certified USPS mail) to be extremely objectional.  
RedHat's use of this *scam* has certainly lowered my respect for
them at least a couple of notches.

- Don Buchholz
- <buchholz at easystreet.com>






From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Thu Feb 13 09:53:02 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Thu Feb 13 09:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Strange CD-RW problem
Message-ID: <20030213175253.13382.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>

My HP desktop computer has two CD drives: a CD-RW and
a DVD-ROM. This is a rather common arrangement.

Yesterday evening, upon bringing up my disk-mounting
GUI tool, I noted that the CD-RW was no longer there.
Since /dev/cdrom1 is no doubt a nickname, perhaps the
symbolic link had disappeared. So I attempted to mount
the drive by its likely actual name: /dev/scd0,
/dev/sr0, etc. None of these attempts was successful.

I inserted a blank CD into the drive, brought up
xcdroast, and this DID work.This application does not
use the same device names as the other ones do.

It also boots from a CD, not then under the control of
the installed operating system. 

Provided that I use the DVD drive for all CD reading
functions, I am apparently not inconvenienced by this
strange occurrence. But I am still wondering what
causes a device to "disappear."   

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

"SAMBA--opening Windows to a wider world."



From kevinc at doink.com  Thu Feb 13 10:27:01 2003
From: kevinc at doink.com (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Thu Feb 13 10:27:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Partial SOLUTION to Auto Install and "other.img" ANY WORKAROUNDS?
Message-ID: <20030213182313.9B3FE56DE@joseph.doink.com>

Quite a while ago I posted this on alt.os.linux.mandrake:

    At the end of my MDK9 installations I create an auto install
    floppies.  Then I can boot from them and reinstall the whole
    system with less (of my choosing) interaction than the first
    installation.  So far, so good.  If I do this on my machine
    with an IDE CDROM drive, then everything works just fine.  If
    I do this on my machine with only a SCSI CDROM drive, for
    which I'm required to originally boot using the "other.img",
    then my CDROM drive is not detected and I can't install.

    How can I get around this problem?

    Can I somehow create an auto install floppy with the kernel
    from the "other.img"?

    At the end of an Expert install I'm offered a chance to
    create a package list floppy.  I didn't do this at the
    time, and I can't figure out how to create one, short of
    reinstalling.  Anyone know how to do this?

    I've tried setting my BIOS to boot from SCSI, rather than "C"
    drive (which is my only IDE drive in the box) or floppy, but
    that didn't seem to work.  I've got two SCSI hard disks, a
    SCSI tape drive, and two SCSI CDROM drives (one's a writer)
    in this system.  What might be required to boot from the
    CDROM?


SOLUTION:

    The Mandrake installation instructions say to boot in
    whatever normal manner you do, then at the Help Screen
    press <F1> and boot up with the boot options 'linux
    defcfg="floppy"' without the single quotes, but with the
    double quotes.


This will let me boot from other.img, so that I can get the right
SCSI drivers for my Buslogic card, and it advertises to let me
use the package list from the floppy disk I created during the
initial install.  I haven't tried this yet.

I still don't know how to make a "package list floppy" short of
reinstalling.  Any ideas there folks?

Thanks....

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Feb 13 10:47:11 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Feb 13 10:47:11 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Programming in Common Lisp
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302130807380.18547-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302130807380.18547-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <8665roggsv.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   I'm learning the nuts and bolts of fuzzy system modeling which
Rich> includes GA and neural net components in some models. I _can_ do
Rich> it all in C (or C++ or python or prolog or lisp or scheme or
Rich> java or ...). The language really doesn't matter. For the use I
Rich> want to make of these models I'm considering if learning and
Rich> using CNU/Lisp (an implementation of Common Lisp) might make
Rich> model development much quicker than using C. 

Do you mean CMUCL?  That's not a bad choice, but you might want to
keep in mind that since Common Lisp is an ANSI standard, it has
multiple implementations (both free-as-in-freedom and commercial), so
it doesn't matter that much which implementation you choose, and you
needn't limit yourself to one.  Learn the language, and then leave
yourself a choice of implementations.

I use CLISP quite a bit, because it is a little more light-weight for
exploration.  And even though CLISP compiles to byte-codes and uses a
matching byte-code interpretter, it is surprisingly quick.  CLISP also
has a nice 'readline' (command history, completion, editing, like
Bash) CLI for quick experimentation.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I've seen every kind of critter God ever made,
seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower, more
                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
                                        -- Burl Ives as Rufus Hennessy



From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Thu Feb 13 10:51:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Thu Feb 13 10:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Strange CD-RW problem
In-Reply-To: <20030213175253.13382.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030213175253.13382.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030213185055.GA19610@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

This probably isn't it, but worth checking. If you can mount it as
root that would be a good indication this is the problem:

Check that your user has permissions to the generic scsi device
(/dev/sg*) If you use the devfs, you can change the perms in your
/etc/devfs/devfsd or perms file (depending on teh distro). I have the
following line:

REGISTER ^sg[^/]*$ PERMISSIONS root.scsi 0660

and my normal user is a member of the scsi group.

From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Feb 13 11:15:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Thu Feb 13 11:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Grab the most recent file in perl?
Message-ID: <20030213191445.GB26108@rauhaus.org>

What would be the nicest way in Perl to grab the name of the most recent (by
modfication time) file in a directory with a bunch of files?

I could do something gross like:
@files = `/bin/ls -tr /var/local/flows/ft*`;

But no, I shouldn't have to shell out for pretty much anything these
days.

Would it be more like:

for (</var/local/flows/ft*>) {
	$file_hash{$_} = (stat $_)[9];
}

and then sort by the hash by value? I'm betting there's a better way,
and am happy to hear suggestions.

--Stafford

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Thu Feb 13 11:39:01 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Thu Feb 13 11:39:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ntpd
In-Reply-To: <1045106483.1073.7.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1045161970.1073.2.camel@apollo.spears.org>
	 <1045162426.1984.4.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
	 <1045106483.1073.7.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1045165068.1969.8.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Wed, 2003-02-12 at 19:21, Bill Spears wrote:
> On Fri, 2003-02-14 at 02:53, AthlonRob wrote:
> > Is your timezone set up properly?
> Probably not. BTW, what is the default for how often ntpd checks the
> time?

That is probably your problem.  RH should have some fancy tool for
setting it properly... if not, you just make a symlink from
/etc/timezone to the correct timezone file, if I remember correctly.

ntpd checks the time constantly... constantly fixing it.  My ntpd server
checks against six other servers, and then I use it for my LAN.  You
should read the documents at ntp.org... they're quite informative.  :-)

If you wanted something that just periodically fixes your clock (once an
hour?  once a day?) use cron and ntpdate (Which is actually being
depreciated, but I don't remember the ntpd switch to work like ntpdate
off the top of my head).

Rob




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Feb 13 12:25:02 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu Feb 13 12:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ntpd
In-Reply-To: <1045106483.1073.7.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1045161970.1073.2.camel@apollo.spears.org> <1045162426.1984.4.camel@duron.stpaultel.com> <1045106483.1073.7.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <200302131224.12561.aschlemm@attbi.com>

With NTP 4.x I think an NTP server will initially start polling about 
every 64 seconds and as things stabilize it starts increasing the 
number of seconds between polls until it gets to a maximum of polling a 
server ever 1024 seconds. 

Before you startup an NTP server make sure you system time is set 
reasonable well. This is normally done using "ntpdate -b <ntp-server>" 
to force the system time to be set rather than slewing it. You might 
also want to be sure that you write the contents of the system clock to 
the hardware clock as part of the shutdown process so the system time 
will be set fairly reasonably when the system is booted. 

If you don't update the hardware clock on shutdown you can also do this 
via a cron job at some reasonable interval. I noticed the hardware 
clock on my workstation was way off after I went many months without a 
reboot as NTP was only keeping the kernel's system time updated and did 
nothing with the hardware clock.

Tony
 
On Wednesday 12 February 2003 19:21 pm, Bill Spears wrote:
> On Fri, 2003-02-14 at 02:53, AthlonRob wrote:

From bspears at easystreet.com  Thu Feb 13 13:20:03 2003
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Thu Feb 13 13:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ntpd
In-Reply-To: <200302131224.12561.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <1045161970.1073.2.camel@apollo.spears.org>
	<1045162426.1984.4.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
	<1045106483.1073.7.camel@apollo.spears.org> 
	<200302131224.12561.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1045113590.1058.5.camel@apollo.spears.org>

On Fri, 2003-02-14 at 04:24, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> With NTP 4.x I think an NTP server will initially start polling about 
> every 64 seconds and as things stabilize it starts increasing the 
> number of seconds between polls until it gets to a maximum of polling a 
> server ever 1024 seconds. 
> 
> Before you startup an NTP server make sure you system time is set 
> reasonable well. This is normally done using "ntpdate -b <ntp-server>" 
> to force the system time to be set rather than slewing it. You might 
> also want to be sure that you write the contents of the system clock to 
> the hardware clock as part of the shutdown process so the system time 
> will be set fairly reasonably when the system is booted. 
> 
> If you don't update the hardware clock on shutdown you can also do this 
> via a cron job at some reasonable interval. I noticed the hardware 
> clock on my workstation was way off after I went many months without a 
> reboot as NTP was only keeping the kernel's system time updated and did 
> nothing with the hardware clock.
> 
> Tony
>  
> On Wednesday 12 February 2003 19:21 pm, Bill Spears wrote:
> > On Fri, 2003-02-14 at 02:53, AthlonRob wrote:
> > > On Thu, 2003-02-13 at 10:46, Bill Spears wrote:
> > > > I've got some sort of conflict between ntpd and my local
> > > > time/clock setup. ntpd is setting my local time to about 16 hours
> > > > ahead. FYI: RH 8.0.
> > >
> > > Is your timezone set up properly?
> > >
> > > Rob
> >
> > Probably not. BTW, what is the default for how often ntpd checks the
> > time?
> >

Well, I don't know what to say, but it's been _interesting_.  My problem
had something to do with rebooting. Everytime I did I would get a 16
hour (note we're in GMT-8) difference between hwclock -r and date. I
could then use date --set "-16 hours" to correct date, but the moment I
rebooted, the same 16 hour difference occurred. Finally chkconfig'ed
ntpd out and rebooted and it solved the problem, at least this time.






From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Feb 13 13:39:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Feb 13 13:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Programming in Common Lisp
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302131103350.18578-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302131103350.18578-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <8665rn97z4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich> On 13 Feb 2003, Russell Senior wrote: using CNU/Lisp (an
Rich> implementation of Common Lisp) might make

Rich>   Eeep! Typo. I meant GNU/Lisp, not the Carnegie Mellon
Rich> University implementation.

In that case, historically, GNU Lisp has been not such a hot choice.
I haven't looked recently, but in the past it hasn't lived up to the
usual reputation for quality that we associate with the GNU label.
Here's what the gcl man page says about its history:

   The GCL system contains C and Lisp source files to build a Common
   Lisp sytem.  CGL is derived from Kyoto Common LISP (kcl), which was
   written in 1984 by T. Yuasa and M. Hagiya (working under Professor
   R. Nakajima at the Research Institute for Mathematical Sciences,
   Kyoto Uni- versity).  The AKCL system work was begun in 1987 by
   William Schelter at the University of Texas, Austin, and continued
   through 1994.  In 1994 AKCL was released as GCL (GNU Common Lisp)
   under the GNU public library license.

More recently, GCL has principally been used as a vehicle for the
free-as-in-freedom version of Maxima, the symbolic math package
developed at MIT.  For a long time, it wasn't very conformant to the
ANSI standard.  CLISP (aka GNU CLISP) is probably a better choice.  It
is also GPL'd and distributed by the FSF.

For a more complete listing of implementations, see:

  <http://www.lisp.org/table/systems.htm>


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I've seen every kind of critter God ever made,
seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower, more
                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
                                        -- Burl Ives as Rufus Hennessy



From chgenly at alum.mit.edu  Thu Feb 13 13:48:01 2003
From: chgenly at alum.mit.edu (Chris Genly)
Date: Thu Feb 13 13:48:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ntpd
In-Reply-To: <1045113590.1058.5.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1045161970.1073.2.camel@apollo.spears.org>
	<1045162426.1984.4.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
	<1045106483.1073.7.camel@apollo.spears.org> 
	<200302131224.12561.aschlemm@attbi.com> 
	<1045113590.1058.5.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1045172830.20908.9.camel@gimli.genly.us>

I had a problem with time on my system when rebooting.  It turned out
that a time config file in /etc was symbolically linked to a file in
another partition.  The problem was that at bootup, the partition was
not yet mounted when hwclock was run.  So it didn't know the correct
time zone and assumed GMT.  I dual boot with windows, so my hwclock is
set to local time, not GMT.  I solved the problem by copying the
appropriate timezone file to /etc.

I don't remember the file names exactly.  But something like

 /etc/localtime   -> /usr/share/zoneinfo/America/Los_Angeles


It's interesting that your off by 16 hours and you are in a -8 timezone.
16 = 2*8.  Confusing GMT and localtime twice could cause the 16 hour
difference.

Chris

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Thu Feb 13 13:51:01 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Thu Feb 13 13:51:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Kudzu?  Was: Strange CD-RW problem
In-Reply-To: <20030213185055.GA19610@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20030213215006.7571.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>

> On Thu, Feb 13, 2003 at 09:52:53AM -0800, Robert
> Kopp wrote:
> > My HP desktop computer has two CD drives: a CD-RW
> and
> > a DVD-ROM. This is a rather common arrangement.
> > 
> > Yesterday evening, upon bringing up my
> disk-mounting
> > GUI tool, I noted that the CD-RW was no longer
> there.
According to the docs, I'm not the first to have this
problem after adding a digital camera as /dev/sda1. In
that case, the solution was to take the kudzu entries
out of fstab. I know next to nothing about kudzu, so
as long as I can still burn CD's, I might leave it
alone until I am more knowledgeable on the subject.
Any kudzu fans, or detractors, on this list?

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

"SAMBA--opening Windows to a wider world."



From alan at clueserver.org  Thu Feb 13 14:02:01 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Thu Feb 13 14:02:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Kudzu?  Was: Strange CD-RW problem
In-Reply-To: <20030213215006.7571.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302130520020.29827-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Thu, 13 Feb 2003, Robert Kopp wrote:

> > On Thu, Feb 13, 2003 at 09:52:53AM -0800, Robert
> > Kopp wrote:
> > > My HP desktop computer has two CD drives: a CD-RW
> > and
> > > a DVD-ROM. This is a rather common arrangement.
> > > 
> > > Yesterday evening, upon bringing up my
> > disk-mounting
> > > GUI tool, I noted that the CD-RW was no longer
> > there.
> According to the docs, I'm not the first to have this
> problem after adding a digital camera as /dev/sda1. In
> that case, the solution was to take the kudzu entries
> out of fstab. I know next to nothing about kudzu, so
> as long as I can still burn CD's, I might leave it
> alone until I am more knowledgeable on the subject.
> Any kudzu fans, or detractors, on this list?

The problem is not one of Kudzu, per se, but of how cd burners work.

To use a cd burner currently, you need to use ide->scsi emulation.  Adding 
the digital camera as a scsi device (probably usb storage) has moved the 
pointer for /dev/cdrom to something that does not exist. Kudzu is just 
trying to figure out what happened.

Try "ls -l /dev/cdrom" and see where it was pointed. Look through "dmesg" 
and figure out where it really is.  Modify simlinks as needed.

On Fri, 2003-02-14 at 05:47, Chris Genly wrote:
> I had a problem with time on my system when rebooting.  It turned out
> that a time config file in /etc was symbolically linked to a file in
> another partition.  The problem was that at bootup, the partition was
> not yet mounted when hwclock was run.  So it didn't know the correct
> time zone and assumed GMT.  I dual boot with windows, so my hwclock is
> set to local time, not GMT.  I solved the problem by copying the
> appropriate timezone file to /etc.
> 
> I don't remember the file names exactly.  But something like
> 
>  /etc/localtime   -> /usr/share/zoneinfo/America/Los_Angeles

Other way. In my case /usr/share/zoneinfo/Etc/GMT-8 -> /etc/localtime

> 
> 
> It's interesting that your off by 16 hours and you are in a -8 timezone.
> 16 = 2*8.  Confusing GMT and localtime twice could cause the 16 hour
> difference.
Yeah, thats what I thought, too.

One other thing: date --utc ==> Thu Feb 13 06:00:59 UTC 2003
date ==> Thu Feb 13 14:01:37 GMT-8 2003.  This is not the way I
understand UTC; I think UTC should be (GMT-8)+8, not (GMT-8)-8.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Feb 13 15:01:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Feb 13 15:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Grab the most recent file in perl?
In-Reply-To: <20030213191445.GB26108@rauhaus.org>
References: <20030213191445.GB26108@rauhaus.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302131457010.20253@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 13 Feb 2003, Stafford A. Rau wrote:
> What would be the nicest way in Perl to grab the name of the most recent (by
> modfication time) file in a directory with a bunch of files?
>
> I could do something gross like:
> @files = `/bin/ls -tr /var/local/flows/ft*`;
>
> But no, I shouldn't have to shell out for pretty much anything these
> days.
>
> Would it be more like:
>
> for (</var/local/flows/ft*>) {
> 	$file_hash{$_} = (stat $_)[9];
> }
>
> and then sort by the hash by value? I'm betting there's a better way,
> and am happy to hear suggestions.

Won't this do it?

$newest = (sort { -M $a <=> -M $b } <*> )[0]

J.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Feb 13 15:03:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Feb 13 15:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Programming in Common Lisp
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302131433230.19123-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302131433230.19123-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86ptpv7pi9.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich> That's interesting, Russell. Following the link to no-cost UNIX
Rich> implementations and clisp from Germany brings me to a ftp server
Rich> directory.  In the binary subdirectory I find the same rpm for
Rich> clisp-2.30 as I found on the GNU web page. Yet, they're supposed
Rich> to be different.

Rich>   T'wasn't the GNU Web page I found yesterday, it was the CLISP
Rich> home page.  Sigh. I'm back on the rails now.

GNU CLISP <ftp://ftp.gnu.org/pub/gnu/clisp/> and the german CLISP
ought to be the same thing, just different distribution points.  There
is a CLISP sourceforge site too.  GNU Common Lisp, or "gcl" can be
found at <ftp://ftp.gnu.org/pub/gnu/gcl/>.

Just to clarify, CLISP is a proper name, and not used here as a
contraction of Common Lisp, i.e.: GNU CLISP is not equal to GNU Common
Lisp (GCL).  I don't know if that is the source of your confusion, but
it certainly a possible one.

          *** Portland Linux User's Group (PLUG) Announcement ***
                                     
             The Linux Clinic - third saturday of every month
                                     
    Interested in Linux? Need help installing or configuring Linux? Be
           sure to attend the next session of the Linux Clinic.
                                     
                               Linux Clinic
                                     
                             February 15, 2003
                                     
                                1PM - 4PM
                                     
                             Riverdale School
                                     
                           11733 SW Breyman Ave.
                                     
                          Portland, Oregon 97219
                                     
   What to bring:
     * Your computer, monitor, keyboard and mouse.
     * Any relevant peripherals (printer, modem, etc).
     * Your Linux distribution (if you have already installed).
     * The manuals for your hardware - especially your monitor manual.
       
   Resources available:
     * Volunteers skilled in Linux installation and maintenance.
     * The PLUG CD library (including several recent Linux
       distributions).
     * T-1 Internet connection
     * phone jacks for testing modem and Internet setups.
     * Ethernet drops.
     * Infocus projector for demonstrations.
     * An extra Linux box for experimenting.
     * A number of reference materials

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Thu Feb 13 15:19:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Thu Feb 13 15:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Apache/PHP problem
In-Reply-To: <200302131224.12561.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20030213231755.44904.qmail@web40802.mail.yahoo.com>

I recently patched Apache on my Red Hat 7.1 machine to
Red Hat's latest release:
  apache-1.3.27-1.7.1
  php-4.1.2-7.1.6

Since the upgrade, I've had problems with it. I have a
couple of PHP-based upload pages, so people can upload
files to my page. It worked flawlessly before, with
files up to 100 MB, but now when I upload a time or
two, Apache goes weird. For example, this morning, the
page seemed to work fine for my Mozilla/Linux box, but
I would get errors like "the page contains no data" on
a WinNT or Win98 machine. Also, pages would sometimes
fail to refresh correctly about 25% of the time on
some Windows machines, while again them seemed to work
on my Linux box. At other times, the server would stop
working for all browsers. Restarting Apache would fix
it, but it would usually take two tries to stop Apache
(service httpd stop).

Any ideas or suggestions?

-Scott

From felix.1 at canids.net  Thu Feb 13 15:21:01 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Thu Feb 13 15:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Grab the most recent file in perl?
In-Reply-To: <20030213191445.GB26108@rauhaus.org> on Thu, 13 Feb 2003 11:14:46 PST.
Message-ID: <200302132319.h1DNJLu22845@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau):
> But no, I shouldn't have to shell out for pretty much
> anything these days.

this is the wrong philosophy.  the point of shell
programming is to let you solve common problems quickly by
giving you simple and powerful ways of combining existing
tools.

'ls -t' is the tool that answers the question you want.  why
spend the time and effort re-inventing the wheel?  don't you
have more important things to do?

one possible answer is performance.  in general, until
something gets executed a million times or so, performance
is not very interesting, it's not worth your time to
optimize.

another possible answer is reliability.  'ls -t' runs into
problems if you have filenames with newlines in them.

> for (</var/local/flows/ft*>) {
> 	$file_hash{$_} = (stat $_)[9];
> }
> and then sort by the hash by value? I'm betting there's a
> better way, and am happy to hear suggestions.

yes, that's ok.  what do you mean by "better"?  faster
execution, less memory use, more reliable, easier to read,
easier to write, more impressive, or something else?
--



From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Feb 13 15:36:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Feb 13 15:36:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] can't send mail, what's this entry
In-Reply-To: <FCYWHCSNVR737132OI2U2XKGKIB6LFUO.3e4c25fc@mike>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302131532410.1114-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 13 Feb 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> I've installed squirrelmail on a local RH 8.0 server, it 
> seems to work fine, but the mail isn't actually sent.

The interactions between SquirrelMail and PHP are many and subtle. In 
the [PHP] section, set

file_uploads = On
upload_max_filesize = 2M

(Season the '2M' to taste.)

I think that should do it.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Feb 13 17:50:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Feb 13 17:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to resolve RH upgrade conflict?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302131745490.19574-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  A couple of days ago I received notice from Red Hat that python and
tkinter have been patched to fix potential vulnerabilities. So I just
downloaded all the applicable packages and tried to upgrade what I have
installed. Unfortunately, I'm once again caught in the infinite loop of
self-referential, circular dependency quagmire and I don't know how to get
out of it. Here's the problem:

[root at salmo /home/rshepard]# rpm -Uvh python*
error: failed dependencies:
        tkinter < 1.5.2-43.73 conflicts with python-1.5.2-43.73
        python = 1.5.2-38 is needed by tkinter-1.5.2-38
        python2 = 2.2 is needed by tkinter2-2.2-16
[root at salmo /home/rshepard]# rpm -Uvh tkinter*
error: failed dependencies:
        python = 1.5.2-43.73 is needed by tkinter-1.5.2-43.73
        python2 = 2.2.2 is needed by tkinter2-2.2.2-11.7.3

  So, I cannot upgrade python because it requires tkinter to be upgraded
first. However, I cannot upgrade tkinter first because python's dependent on
it. Sigh.

  It seems to me that the only way to "upgrade" is to remove both python and
tkinter, then install the new versions.

  Without any intention of generating another long, virulent thread on
distributions, I'd like to ask if the idea of packages is to avoid just the
circular dependencies that keep me from easily maintaining my systems.

Oh, well,

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard at appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/

> tkinter, then install the new versions.



I've just done this and putting them bothon the same line doesn't help 
either.  What I usually do is use --nodeps on one then install the other 
normally.

$ rpm -Fvh --nodeps tkinter*
$ rpm -Fvh python*


--
Kyle Accardi

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Feb 13 18:21:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Feb 13 18:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Grab the most recent file in perl?
In-Reply-To: <200302132319.h1DNJLu22845@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
References: <200302132319.h1DNJLu22845@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302131819040.21316@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 13 Feb 2003, Felix Lee wrote:
> srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau):
> > But no, I shouldn't have to shell out for pretty much
> > anything these days.
>
> this is the wrong philosophy.  the point of shell programming is to let
> you solve common problems quickly by giving you simple and powerful ways
> of combining existing tools.
>
> 'ls -t' is the tool that answers the question you want.  why spend the
> time and effort re-inventing the wheel?  don't you have more important
> things to do?

Have you considered that perhaps finding the file with the most recent
mtime is perhaps just part of a larger program whose greater task is very
much suited to perl?

He's right that you shouldn't have to shell out for simple filesystem
operations from a robust scripting language.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Feb 13 18:58:01 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Thu Feb 13 18:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to resolve RH upgrade conflict?
References: <ENEFIFGGPEDGDJMEMKECEEMIGJAA.cb@onsitetech.com>
Message-ID: <3E4C5B2C.7070401@pacifier.com>

Christian Brink wrote:
> Won't this work
> 
> rpm -Uvh python* tkinter*


Apparently, the ftp method is a little wonky.

When I do
# rpm -Fvh ftp://philo:/pub/RedHat/Updates/i386/python* tkinter*

it just grabs the python packages and ignores the rest of the line.  Since 
this is the way I usually do it, explains why I never had luck.

Another solution is to copy all the inter-dependant packages into one dir 
and do rpm -Fvh *.rpm


--
Kyle Accardi




From felix.1 at canids.net  Thu Feb 13 19:02:01 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Thu Feb 13 19:02:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Grab the most recent file in perl?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0302131457010.20253@shaft.bitmine.net> on Thu, 13 Feb 2003 15:01:28 PST.
Message-ID: <200302140300.h1E30KO23724@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>:
> $newest = (sort { -M $a <=> -M $b } <*> )[0]

that does O(N log N) I/O operations.
calling 'ls -t' does O(N).
the difference is probably unimportant, unless you have
a million files or a slow filesystem.
--



From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Thu Feb 13 19:11:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Thu Feb 13 19:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to resolve RH upgrade conflict?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302131745490.19574-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030214031018.82458.qmail@web40811.mail.yahoo.com>

Rich,

To get out of this loop, just put all the RPMs in a
single directory, then do this:

  rpm -Uvh *rpm

That should do it.

-Scott
