From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Feb 13 20:43:06 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Feb 13 20:43:06 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PASA Meeting Tuesday, 18 Feb 2003
Message-ID: <1045197752.26039.20.camel@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

PASA, the Portland Area Sys Admins, invites you to our next meeting to
be held next Tuesday, the 18th of February with Tripwire Security. 
Please visit our meetings page at and RSVP so we can have an estimate of
attendance.  The RSVP is NOT mandatory!

http://pasa.portland.or.us/meetings (The RSVP code is new, so if it
breaks, please send a message to rsvp at pasa.portland.or.us.)


      * 7:00 - 7:30 Pizza / Welcome / Tripwire background
      * 7:30 - 8:00 Product overview
                Tripwire for Servers / Manager
                Managing change in a chaotic environment
                Presented by Joseph Wheeler - Sr. Systems Engineer
      * 8:00 - 8:30 Product overview
                Tripwire for Network Devices
                The solution for managing diverse network devices
                Presented by The Bender - Sr. Mixologist
                
About Tripwire

Joseph Wheeler spent four years with Symantec Corporation providing
technical support for products such as pcANYWHERE and developing
innovative ways to get customers to use online technical resources. In
the past four years with Tripwire he moved from the initial support team
to a systems engineering role. His current duties take him on flights
around the globe supporting Tripwire's numerous parners and customer
base, all the while searching for the most elusive of exotic beverages.

Tripwire(tm) Integrity Assurance solutions ensure the security and
availability of servers and network devices, while enabling increased
efficiencies and control over IT infrastructure across enterprises and
government agencies worldwide. The software establishes a baseline of
data in its desired state, detects and reports any changes to the
baseline, enabling rapid discovery and recovery when an undesired change
occurs. Tripwire identifies change, whether accidental or malicious,
from outside or within, and is the only way to know for certain that
your data is safe and remains uncompromised. Tripwire establishes the
foundation for data security and ensures a safe, productive, stable IT
environment.

Tripwire software is one of the most widely deployed and trusted
integrity assurance solutions in the world. Dr. Eugene Spafford and Gene
Kim created the initial release of Tripwire software in 1992 at Purdue
University. That academic source release received widespread support and
quickly became an essential part of best practices for corporate,
education, and government security professionals. Since 1992, more than
1 million copies of Tripwire have been downloaded and over a 1/4 million
are in active use.

Based in Portland, Oregon, Tripwire was founded by Gene Kim and W. Wyatt
Starnes. A fast-growing, global technology company, Tripwire has been
named to The Oregon Technology Fast 50 list and currently has operations
in 15 countries around the world.

Directions can be found on the Tripwire website.
http://www.tripwire.com/company/contacts/directions.cfm

About PASA

PASA is an informal support group for Portland Area Systems
Administrators. We currently have members from the East and West Side,
Vancouver, and Portland proper. Members are UNIX, NT, and Network
administrators -- sometimes a combination of the three. Someday we may
get around to building some structure into the group, but that hasn't
happened yet. (Of course, there are no membership dues either.)

We are also an official USENIX SAGE local group.


Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Thu Feb 13 21:01:02 2003
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Thu Feb 13 21:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: EM-Damaged Display
In-Reply-To: <20030213232101.27050.48937.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20030213202154.020b7910@www.dylanreinhardt.com>

Hi all,

This is a bit off-topic, being a hardware / physics question... but it's 
something I thought y'all might enjoy chewing on anyway.

About 18 months ago, some friends of mine got a new PC from a local vendor 
I recommended.  The display was a good quality 17" CRT (AOC Spectrum 7GLR).

After 8-9 months of unblemished operation, the display started showing huge 
amounts of distortion in large, wavy, occasionally-changing horizontal 
bands.  It looked for all the world like some kind of electromagnetic 
interference.

I poked my head out the window and sure enough, their satellite dish was 
mounted on the outside of the house, maybe 2-3' from the back of the 
display.  I had taken a different display over for testing purposes and 
when I plugged that one in, everything worked fine.  I decided I was wrong 
to suspect the satellite dish.  The problem -- whatever it was -- must have 
been the display.  That opinion was supported by the fact that the problem 
persisted when I plugged the first display into a PC back at my office.  I 
sent it back to the manufacturer and received a replacement, but no 
explanation.

Fast forward another 8-9 months and now the replacement display (also a 
CRT, but different model) is showing very similar problems and I'm thinking 
I might have been right about the satellite dish in the first place.  I 
have installed dozens of these displays around Portland and have never seen 
anything like this anywhere else.

At this point I have to admit I'm way out of my league.  Some questions 
come to mind:

1. Can there possibly be any such thing as cumulative damage from EM 
interference?
2. Could the satellite dish be a red herring?
3. Will a gaussmeter help me diagnose the problem or find a better spot for 
the computer?
4. Might an LCD display survive any better than a CRT?
5. Is there any kind of low-cost shielding I could be using here?

Since I never got that EE degree, I'm at a bit of a loss... any thoughts or 
help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance for anything offered,

Dylan

From plug at laynesoftware.com  Thu Feb 13 21:22:02 2003

On Thu, 13 Feb 2003 19:00:19 -0800, Felix Lee wrote
> Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>:
> > $newest = (sort { -M $a <=> -M $b } <*> )[0]
> 
> that does O(N log N) I/O operations.
> calling 'ls -t' does O(N).
> the difference is probably unimportant, unless you have
> a million files or a slow filesystem.

That sounds unlikely.  I just bet the sort that ls does with the -t flag is
not completely free of charge.  If it is, maybe we could use that to build a
perpetual motion machine or something.

You may be right that ls -t is the best solution, but the best way to find out
is to look for other solutions.  You may be prefectly happy driving in screws
with that hammer, but you might find a better way if you're curious enough to
look around.  If not, keep hammering away, after all, TMTOWTDI.


Regards,
Terry Layne



From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Thu Feb 13 21:29:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Thu Feb 13 21:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] text search/replace
In-Reply-To: <20030214051935.7396.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302132035471.20020-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <20030214051935.7396.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030214052850.GC20024@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

If you need to do this in only one file, then most text editors worth
their name can do it for you. in vi:

:1,$s/oldexpr/newexpr/g 

will do it. emacs has the ability also, but the keystrokes to do so
escape me at the moment.

If you need to do so on many files there are any multitude of ways to
do this in perl alone (not to mention awk, etc..).

this should work:

perl -pi -e "s/oldexpr/newexpr/g" file1 file2 file3

or use find to locate the files..

find . -name "*.lisp" -print | xargs perl -pi -e "s/oldexpr/newexpr/g"

to apply the reg.exp to all lisp files in this directory and it's sub
dirs (the -print is optional with many versions of find).

hth.
Rogan

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Feb 13 22:36:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Feb 13 22:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] text search/replace
In-Reply-To: <20030214051935.7396.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302132231480.20965-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 13 Feb 2003, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:

> I'm interested in finding a simple, text-based utility to search for
> text recursively (like grep) then replace that text with new text.
> I've had my eye out for something like this for a long time, and I'm
> sure it exists, but I just haven't come across it.

sed!

  for f in $(find . -name \*.txt); do
    cp $f $f.bak
    sed -e 's!oldtext!newtext!g' < $f.bak > $f
  done

  # then, when satisified you didn't mess things up :-)
  find . -name \*.txt.bak -exec /bin/rm -f {} \;

'course, Perl or a gazillion other scripting languages will get you 
there too. I just like sed. Seems, I dunno, Unixy or something :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

2/13/03 9:01:45 PM, Dylan Reinhardt <plug at dylanreinhardt.com> wrote:

>Hi all,

>This is a bit off-topic, being a hardware / physics question... but it's 
>something I thought y'all might enjoy chewing on anyway.
>
>About 18 months ago, some friends of mine got a new PC from a local vendor 
>I recommended.  The display was a good quality 17" CRT (AOC Spectrum 7GLR).
>
>After 8-9 months of unblemished operation, the display started showing huge 
>amounts of distortion in large, wavy, occasionally-changing horizontal 
>bands.  It looked for all the world like some kind of electromagnetic 
>interference.
>
>I poked my head out the window and sure enough, their satellite dish was 
>mounted on the outside of the house, maybe 2-3' from the back of the 
>display.  I had taken a different display over for testing purposes and 
>when I plugged that one in, everything worked fine.  I decided I was wrong 
>to suspect the satellite dish.  The problem -- whatever it was -- must have 
>been the display.  That opinion was supported by the fact that the problem 
>persisted when I plugged the first display into a PC back at my office.  I 
>sent it back to the manufacturer and received a replacement, but no 
>explanation.
>
>Fast forward another 8-9 months and now the replacement display (also a 
>CRT, but different model) is showing very similar problems and I'm thinking 
>I might have been right about the satellite dish in the first place.  I 
>have installed dozens of these displays around Portland and have never seen 
>anything like this anywhere else.
>
>At this point I have to admit I'm way out of my league.  Some questions 
>come to mind:
>
>1. Can there possibly be any such thing as cumulative damage from EM 
>interference?
>2. Could the satellite dish be a red herring?
>3. Will a gaussmeter help me diagnose the problem or find a better spot for 
>the computer?
>4. Might an LCD display survive any better than a CRT?
>5. Is there any kind of low-cost shielding I could be using here?
>

Here's my current (unchanged) section of /etc/php.ini:

;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
; File Uploads ;
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

; Whether to allow HTTP file uploads.
file_uploads = On

; Temporary directory for HTTP uploaded files (will use system default if not
; specified).
;upload_tmp_dir =

; Maximum allowed size for uploaded files.
upload_max_filesize = 2M

It looks like that's already there. Darn, that would have been easy to do.

From felix.1 at canids.net  Fri Feb 14 02:29:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Fri Feb 14 02:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Grab the most recent file in perl?
In-Reply-To: <20030214052029.M65053@laynesoftware.com> on Thu, 13 Feb 2003 21:20:29 PST.
Message-ID: <200302141027.h1EARh425416@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

"Terry Layne" <plug at laynesoftware.com>:
> That sounds unlikely.  I just bet the sort that ls does
> with the -t flag is not completely free of charge.

it's not free of charge, but it's done in memory, which is
much much much much faster than I/O.  step 1 in speeding up
a typical system program is to minimize the I/O calls.

'ls -t' will call stat() on each file just once, so for a
million files that's a million I/O operations.  in contrast,
'sort {-T $a <=> -T $b} <*>' for a million files will call
stat(), umm, I think it's somewhere over 4 million times.
I'd have to go looking for the exact formula.  so if your
directory is NFS-mounted from geosynchronous orbit, then
that perl sort will take about 2 months longer to run.

step 2 is to look at memory usage, since filling up RAM
means the OS will page out to disk, which is I/O again.  if
the 'ls -t' sort doesn't fit in memory, then the perl sort
won't fit in memory either.  in that case it's going to be
better to run the system 'sort' program, since 'sort' will
use an efficient algorithm for large datasets, and it's
nontrivial to duplicate this in perl.  Or you can use
File::Sort from CPAN, but that's not as good.

> You may be right that ls -t is the best solution, but the
> best way to find out is to look for other solutions.

sure, go looking if you're curious, but this is not an
interesting problem.  'ls -t' in this case might take about
.1 seconds to run.  if you spend half an hour to optimize
it, you might reduce it to .08 seconds.  big deal.  there
are many more useful problems to solve.
--



From hedlunch at yahoo.com  Fri Feb 14 06:21:01 2003
From: hedlunch at yahoo.com (mark hedlund)
Date: Fri Feb 14 06:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Intel compiler is great vs. Maybe I don't know how to use gcc
In-Reply-To: <200302141027.h1EARh425416@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <20030214142009.3847.qmail@web20509.mail.yahoo.com>

hey
I've been doing a lot of totaly pointless coding lately in C. I'm basicly writing
music. I'm using a lot of math heavy fuctions that I wrote, repeatedly called in
tight loops. I've been using gcc and had been having lots of weird problems. It's
all pretty much C but I've been using g++ in my makefiles because I like bool,
type checking, etc. Often, after a fuction has been called a few(hundred?) times,
it's data/variables get trashed. Some of those being ones that are being passed to
the function as paramaters. Also lots of strange math (rounding?) errors that were
causing weird random tones. I wasn't really understanding why. I'd heard that
Intel's compiler was great at math so I tried it. Suddenly all my problems are
gone. It's fast as hell, the error messeges are great. My code sounds so much
better now. I still don't understand what was going on. My usual way of debugging
led me to belive that the variables were as they should be but the output was all
wrong, you can hear it, not good. So I was wondering if there are any magic
switches that you can pass to gcc to make it suck less? I kind of liked some of
the data mangling that was happening. I'd like to compile some objects with the
screwed up gcc effects I was getting and some without. The intel linker wont have
anything to do with the gcc objects. This has been fun but confusing. I'd
apreciate anyone's thoughts on this sort of thing.
mark

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Fri Feb 14 06:26:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Fri Feb 14 06:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Grab the most recent file in perl?
References: <mailman.1045191730.4175.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86k7g3eyco.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Felix" == Felix Lee <felix.1 at canids.net> writes:

>> $newest = (sort { -M $a <=> -M $b } <*> )[0]

Felix> that does O(N log N) I/O operations.
Felix> calling 'ls -t' does O(N).

But still has to sort, so some part of it is O(N log N) (or worse :).

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Fri Feb 14 06:31:01 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Fri Feb 14 06:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Grab the most recent file in perl?
References: <mailman.1045218552.21075.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86fzqrey61.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Felix" == Felix Lee <felix.1 at canids.net> writes:

Felix> 'ls -t' will call stat() on each file just once, so for a
Felix> million files that's a million I/O operations.  in contrast,
Felix> 'sort {-T $a <=> -T $b} <*>' for a million files will call
Felix> stat(), umm, I think it's somewhere over 4 million times.
Felix> I'd have to go looking for the exact formula.  so if your
Felix> directory is NFS-mounted from geosynchronous orbit, then
Felix> that perl sort will take about 2 months longer to run.

So, you either use a Schwartzian Transform, effectively turning
Perl into a "fetch the mtime once" mode just like "ls -t", or
you use a high-water-mark algorithm:

    my @files = <some*glob*here>;
    my $oldest = shift @files;
    my $age_of_oldest = -M $oldest;
    for (@files) {
      my $age = -M $_;
      if ($age > $age_of_oldest) {
        $oldest = $_;
        $age_of_oldest = $age;
      }
    }

There.  Single O/S request per file.  Just like ls -t.  Faster
than ls -t for a large list, because it's O(n), not a sort.

It's not Perl's fault that there are bad Perl programmers.

Felix, I'm no longer sure whether you're malicious, or just a bad
programmer.  The jury remains out.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!

looks like the system that I know is getting backed up currently is
running the following:

/etc/bkupexec/agent.be -c /etc/bkupexec/agent.cfg

here is a sniplet from the agent.cfg file

# the hostname of this computer
name CLIENT1.FOO.ORG
# pasword
password F00123
# path to backup
export /var/www/html as var_www_html
# make sure this name is in your hosts file
tell backup_servername
tell_interval 30
follow_symdirs
# exclude these directories
exclude_dir /dev
exclude_dir /proc

-Robby

From plug at magnetinternet.com  Fri Feb 14 07:36:01 2003
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Fri Feb 14 07:36:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] BackupExec
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCOEPICFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCOEPICFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <49280.63.105.24.103.1045236935.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

Which version of Backup Exec?

I have tried to setup the backup agent on a Linux box with the newest
Windows version...unfortunately Backup Exec did not see it as a Unix Agent
in the backup selection.  I  ad it working before...it would see it as a
Unix Agent (in a previous version of Backup Exec).

I ended up making a Samba share of what I wanted to backup, and the
Windows box with Backup Exec saw it and backed it up.  :-P

Get the unix backup agent off of the Backup Exec CD, and install it on the
Linux box.  It's very simple to setup.  Just untar it and run the INSTALL
script.  It will walk you through the rest.  Then start the agent (the
INSTALL script places an agent.init in /etc/init.d I believe).  Try
finding the agent.init script.  Then try to browse to it from your Novell
box.

If you can't find the Unix Agent, look at veritas.com.  Last resort: 
contact me off the list and I'll get you a copy.

-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Fri Feb 14 09:30:03 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Fri Feb 14 09:30:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: EM-Damaged Display
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20030213202154.020b7910@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <3E4D2770.6050200@pacifier.com>

Dylan Reinhardt wrote:

> 1. Can there possibly be any such thing as cumulative damage from EM 
> interference?
> 2. Could the satellite dish be a red herring?
> 3. Will a gaussmeter help me diagnose the problem or find a better spot 
> for the computer?
> 4. Might an LCD display survive any better than a CRT?
> 5. Is there any kind of low-cost shielding I could be using here?


Sounds like magnetic fields, although the fact that they change may indicate 
RF interferance.  It's also strange that it takes so long to show up.

You say the crt retained the distortion even when you moved it to another 
location.  This is typical of a magnetized crt.  Most (all?) monitors 
degauss themselves when powered on, but it probably won't help yours.  A 
good repair shop may be able to bring it back.

Don't know much about dishes--don't think they have magnets, and if it is 
just a receiving, there wouldn't be much power flowing around there.

If it's transmitting, you may well pick up EM interfearance.  Perhaps 
there's some fat electrical runs behind the wall.

But it sounds like this is a residence.  Is there a cell phone tower nearby? 
   Ham/CB radio operator?  I wonder if constant RF bombardment could cause 
the kind of magnetic distortion you see.

Never used one, but a gaussmeter should be a big help here if you have one.

An lcd display should be immune from magnetic fields.  A crt uses magnets 
internally to steer the electrons while a lcd doesn't.

Doubt you'd find any kind of shielding that was cheaper then moving the crt 
to another wall.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi




From srau at rauhaus.org  Fri Feb 14 09:40:03 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Fri Feb 14 09:40:03 2003

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Fri Feb 14 09:41:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Fri Feb 14 09:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: EM-Damaged Display
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20030213202154.020b7910@www.dylanreinhardt.com> <3E4D2770.6050200@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <3E4D2A29.7050807@pacifier.com>

Easy troubleshooting techniques:

Run a compass across the wall and around the area to see if the needle moves.

Use a portable (running on battery) AM radio with a telescoping antenna. 
Tune it to an unused frequency so you hear static.  Then use the antenna as 
a probe and run it around the wall and the room to see if you can find 
places where the noise increases or buzzes.

Love to know what you find.

--
Kyle Accardi




From srau at rauhaus.org  Fri Feb 14 09:42:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Fri Feb 14 09:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Grab the most recent file in perl?
In-Reply-To: <86fzqrey61.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
References: <mailman.1045218552.21075.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <86fzqrey61.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <20030214174151.GB3185@rauhaus.org>

* Randal L. Schwartz <merlyn at stonehenge.com> [030214 06:31]:
> So, you either use a Schwartzian Transform, effectively turning
> Perl into a "fetch the mtime once" mode just like "ls -t", or
> you use a high-water-mark algorithm:
> 
>     my @files = <some*glob*here>;
>     my $oldest = shift @files;
>     my $age_of_oldest = -M $oldest;
>     for (@files) {
>       my $age = -M $_;
>       if ($age > $age_of_oldest) {
>         $oldest = $_;
>         $age_of_oldest = $age;
>       }
>     }

Exactly what I was hoping to find.

Thanks, I was hoping to get the Schwartzian perspective for this.

--Stafford

station will definitely do the trick finding RF.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Fri Feb 14 09:53:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Fri Feb 14 09:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: EM-Damaged Display
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20030213202154.020b7910@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
References: <20030213232101.27050.48937.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <5.1.1.6.0.20030213202154.020b7910@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <20030214175207.GA20389@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

I had a similar problem at work a year or so ago, every spring some of
the monitors would start to flicker, after a few months it would go away.

Half the people in the office had mini-fans mounted on their back cube
walls, which were only in use during the hotter months, everyone else
had flickering monitors. 

It may be worth asking your friends explicitly if there have ever been
any electric motors in that part of the house / lot.

-Rogan

On Thu, Feb 13, 2003 at 09:01:45PM -0800, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:
> Hi all,
> 
> This is a bit off-topic, being a hardware / physics question... but it's 
> something I thought y'all might enjoy chewing on anyway.
> 
> About 18 months ago, some friends of mine got a new PC from a local vendor 
> I recommended.  The display was a good quality 17" CRT (AOC Spectrum 7GLR).
> 
> After 8-9 months of unblemished operation, the display started showing huge 
> amounts of distortion in large, wavy, occasionally-changing horizontal 
> bands.  It looked for all the world like some kind of electromagnetic 
> interference.
> 
> I poked my head out the window and sure enough, their satellite dish was 
> mounted on the outside of the house, maybe 2-3' from the back of the 
> display.  I had taken a different display over for testing purposes and 
> when I plugged that one in, everything worked fine.  I decided I was wrong 
> to suspect the satellite dish.  The problem -- whatever it was -- must have 
> been the display.  That opinion was supported by the fact that the problem 
> persisted when I plugged the first display into a PC back at my office.  I 
> sent it back to the manufacturer and received a replacement, but no 
> explanation.
> 
> Fast forward another 8-9 months and now the replacement display (also a 
> CRT, but different model) is showing very similar problems and I'm thinking 
> I might have been right about the satellite dish in the first place.  I 
> have installed dozens of these displays around Portland and have never seen 
> anything like this anywhere else.
> 
> At this point I have to admit I'm way out of my league.  Some questions 
> come to mind:
> 
> 1. Can there possibly be any such thing as cumulative damage from EM 
> interference?
> 2. Could the satellite dish be a red herring?
> 3. Will a gaussmeter help me diagnose the problem or find a better spot for 
> the computer?
> 4. Might an LCD display survive any better than a CRT?
> 5. Is there any kind of low-cost shielding I could be using here?
> 
> Since I never got that EE degree, I'm at a bit of a loss... any thoughts or 
> help would be greatly appreciated.
> 
> Thanks in advance for anything offered,
> 
> Dylan
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug



From cb at onsitetech.com  Fri Feb 14 10:11:02 2003
From: cb at onsitetech.com (Christian Brink)
Date: Fri Feb 14 10:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: EM-Damaged Display
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20030213202154.020b7910@www.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <ENEFIFGGPEDGDJMEMKECGEPMGJAA.cb@onsitetech.com>

Actually I've fixed this sort of problem before.

If the degaussing buttons are not powerful enough, you can emulate what they
are doing with a more powerful magnet. Get a speaker(woofer) or powerful
magnet (hardrives are good sources else Radio Shack).  Then slowly bring the
magnet towards the center on the monitor until you see the magnet distorting
the screen. Then quickly make enlarging circles that gradually get bigger
until you are making circles about twice the size of the display. It should
be quick motion but it should take you a good minute to get the circles that
big.

You may have to do this several times, but I've never had a monitor that I
could not get into working shape with this.

HTH
Christian

From felixcatk at attbi.com  Fri Feb 14 11:43:01 2003
From: felixcatk at attbi.com (The Kerstings)
Date: Fri Feb 14 11:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] EM damaged monitor
Message-ID: <002201c2d461$35318830$a5aee00c@motherdivine>

Ah! something I have experience with!

Another source of EM is the ballasts of flourescent lamps.  Some people use them for desk lamps.  I had one years ago and it slowly twisted my old amber monitor about 10? CW.  I figured it out before I replaced the monitor.  Mine was 6 or 8" away from the top of the monitor.

Felix Kersting

From fmann at aracnet.com  Fri Feb 14 12:47:02 2003
From: fmann at aracnet.com (Floyd Mann)
Date: Fri Feb 14 12:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Apache/PHP problem
In-Reply-To: <20030213231755.44904.qmail@web40802.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302141241040.25426-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>

On Thu, 13 Feb 2003, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
> I recently patched Apache on my Red Hat 7.1 machine to
> Red Hat's latest release:
>   apache-1.3.27-1.7.1
>   php-4.1.2-7.1.6
> Since the upgrade, I've had problems with it.

...

> Any ideas or suggestions?

I don't know about your specific problem, but PHP 4.1.2 has some serious
problems.  We had problems with the session handling in it after we
upgraded (via Red Hat's RPM) and had to roll back to the php-4.0.6-14 RPM.

The good news is that most of the problems were fixed in 4.2 and 4.3.  We
have another machine where we built the 4.3 PHP by hand.  All of our code
is happy there or on the 4.0.6 box, but not under 4.1.2.

Good luck.

-F




From bspears at easystreet.com  Fri Feb 14 13:00:02 2003
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Fri Feb 14 13:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sound on the motherboard
In-Reply-To: <1045072231.1078.12.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1045072231.1078.12.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1045198792.3353.9.camel@apollo.spears.org>

To recapitulate:
On Thu, 2003-02-13 at 01:50, Bill Spears wrote:
> I have a motherboard with built in sound and finally decided to hook up
> some speakers and see if it works. It doesn't.
> 
> I used both sndconfig and the new version included with RH 8.0 and when
> it played a test sound nothing happened.
> 
> Context:
> 	motherboard: Ampton ddr 266
> 	sound stuff from boot up:
> 
> Intel 810 + AC97 Audio, version 0.22, 12:24:02 Sep  4 2002
> PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:02.7
> i810: SiS 7012 found at IO 0xd400 and 0xdc00, IRQ 11
> i810_audio: Audio Controller supports 2 channels.
> i810_audio: Defaulting to base 2 channel mode.
> ac97_codec: AC97 Audio codec, id: 0x414c:0x4326 (Unknown)
> i810_audio: only 48Khz playback available.
> i810_audio: AC'97 codec 0 supports AMAP, total channels = 2
> 
> 	speakers: plugged in to blue connector which I believe is line out.
> 
Derek Lee suggested I try the green output. It worked I can play a CD.
I used mixer, aumix, and found that only the volume and left/right had
an effect(still on green, which we believe to be the speaker out).
Today I tried cat something.au > /dev/audio which worked on green but
not blue.
I then tried Flash and got this:
Feb 14 12:42:29 apollo modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module
sound-slot-1
Feb 14 12:42:29 apollo modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module
sound-service-1-0
Feb 14 12:42:29 apollo modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module
sound-slot-1
Feb 14 12:42:29 apollo modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module
sound-service-1-0
My modules.conf looks like:
alias parport_lowlevel parport_pc
alias eth0 sis900
alias usb-controller usb-ohci
alias sound-slot-0 i810_audio
post-install sound-slot-0 /bin/aumix-minimal -f /etc/.aumixrc -L
>/dev/null 2>&1 || :
pre-remove sound-slot-0 /bin/aumix-minimal -f /etc/.aumixrc -S
>/dev/null 2>&1 || :



>

From atlanti at mailbox.hu  Fri Feb 14 14:07:02 2003
From: atlanti at mailbox.hu (atlanti at mailbox.hu)
Date: Fri Feb 14 14:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] 2 wireless cards in Linux
In-Reply-To: <20030213133349.B14337@csucsu.local.bekesnet.hu>; from atlanti@mailbox.hu on Thu, Feb 13, 2003 at 13:33:49 +0100
References: <20030213133349.B14337@csucsu.local.bekesnet.hu>
Message-ID: <20030213134215.C14337@csucsu.local.bekesnet.hu>


> To: plug at pdxlinux.org
> Subject: Re: [PLUG] Windows CE & Linux
> From: "Michael H. Collins" <mhtexcollins at austin.rr.com>
> Date: Thu, 05 Jul 2001 21:56:05 -0400

> I am using 2 wireless cards in Linux to send this mail
> One on this laptop and one in my DEC alpha Multia.  It is my wireless
> gateway.

> I find them easier to set up in Linux than Doze.  I don't need any
> stinkin cd to get it working.

> Lemme know what you need help with.

Hi!

I'd like to use 2 wireless cards in Linux.
I can use 1 card in:
Debian Woody
Avaya Wireless ISA  Adapter
Avaya PC CARD
with /etc/pcmcia/config.opts, and /etc/pcmcia/network.opts config files.

How can I modify the config files?
I can't find the answer.

cat /proc/interrupts
--
  0:   18273646          XT-PIC  timer
   1:         10          XT-PIC  keyboard
   2:          0          XT-PIC  cascade
   3:     983906          XT-PIC  wavelan2_cs
   8:          3          XT-PIC  rtc
  11:     808397          XT-PIC  eth0
  14:      67782          XT-PIC  ide0
  15:          4          XT-PIC  i82365
--


cat /etc/pcmcia/config.opts
--
# System resources available for PCMCIA devices

include port 0x100-0x4ff, port 0x800-0x8ff, port 0xc00-0xcff
include memory 0xc0000-0xfffff
include memory 0xa0000000-0xa0ffffff, memory 0x60000000-0x60ffffff

# High port numbers do not always work...
# include port 0x1000-0x17ff

# Extra port range for IBM Token Ring
include port 0xa00-0xaff

# Resources we should not use, even if they appear to be available

# First built-in serial port
exclude irq 4
# Second built-in serial port
#exclude irq 3
# First built-in parallel port
exclude irq 7
--

There is a jumper on the ISA Card. I can set the DMA 3E0 or 3E2  with 
it.
The Card  works in both.


Was I clean?

Thank You







From ed at escrubber.biz  Fri Feb 14 14:07:26 2003
From: ed at escrubber.biz (Ed)
Date: Fri Feb 14 14:07:26 2003
Subject: [PLUG] rackspace.com
Message-ID: <1045067137.16193.75.camel@red>

For those of you maintaining your own email black lists
or RBLs, my customers and I have been getting a lot of
spam from IP addresses allocated to rackspace.com in Texas.
I recall discussion here of using rackspace as a
co-location facility. rackspace has no database available
to the outside world to identify the IP blocks of their
individual customers (the spammers) and they don't return
phone calls about the matter.

As a result, we just blocked their 65.61.128.0/18
allocation entirely. They have other allocations and we'll
block them as well as we receive spam from them. If you use
IP addresses from their allocation, let me know what they
are and I'll white list them.

Ed

Subject: [PLUG] Sound on the motherboard
In-Reply-To: <1045198792.3353.9.camel@apollo.spears.org>

I was just reading the driver, i810_audio.c and it says:

The board has one output channel for PCM audio (supported) and  a stereo
line in and mono microphone input. Again these are normally locked to

From bspears at easystreet.com  Fri Feb 14 14:42:01 2003
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Fri Feb 14 14:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sound on the motherboard
In-Reply-To: <1045198792.3353.9.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1045072231.1078.12.camel@apollo.spears.org> 
	<1045198792.3353.9.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1045204895.3444.17.camel@apollo.spears.org>

On Fri, 2003-02-14 at 12:59, Bill Spears wrote:
> To recapitulate:
> On Thu, 2003-02-13 at 01:50, Bill Spears wrote:
> > I have a motherboard with built in sound and finally decided to hook up
> > some speakers and see if it works. It doesn't.
> > 
> > I used both sndconfig and the new version included with RH 8.0 and when
> > it played a test sound nothing happened.
> > 
> > Context:
> > 	motherboard: Ampton ddr 266
> > 	sound stuff from boot up:
> > 
> > Intel 810 + AC97 Audio, version 0.22, 12:24:02 Sep  4 2002
> > PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:02.7
> > i810: SiS 7012 found at IO 0xd400 and 0xdc00, IRQ 11
> > i810_audio: Audio Controller supports 2 channels.
> > i810_audio: Defaulting to base 2 channel mode.
> > ac97_codec: AC97 Audio codec, id: 0x414c:0x4326 (Unknown)
> > i810_audio: only 48Khz playback available.
> > i810_audio: AC'97 codec 0 supports AMAP, total channels = 2
> > 
> > 	speakers: plugged in to blue connector which I believe is line out.
> > 
> Derek Lee suggested I try the green output. It worked I can play a CD.
> I used mixer, aumix, and found that only the volume and left/right had
> an effect(still on green, which we believe to be the speaker out).
> Today I tried cat something.au > /dev/audio which worked on green but
> not blue.
> I then tried Flash and got this:
> Feb 14 12:42:29 apollo modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module
> sound-slot-1
> Feb 14 12:42:29 apollo modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module
> sound-service-1-0
> Feb 14 12:42:29 apollo modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module
> sound-slot-1
> Feb 14 12:42:29 apollo modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module
> sound-service-1-0
I fixed the above errors by adding the following to modules.conf
> My modules.conf looks like:
> alias parport_lowlevel parport_pc
> alias eth0 sis900
> alias usb-controller usb-ohci
> alias sound-slot-0 i810_audio
alias sound-slot-1 off
alias sound-service-1-0 off
Now Flash works.
> post-install sound-slot-0 /bin/aumix-minimal -f /etc/.aumixrc -L
> >/dev/null 2>&1 || :
> pre-remove sound-slot-0 /bin/aumix-minimal -f /etc/.aumixrc -S
> >/dev/null 2>&1 || :
> 
> 
> 
> > 
> 
> 
>

> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From alex at daniloff.com  Sun Feb 16 00:31:02 2003
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Sun Feb 16 00:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RocketRAID HPT372A --> HD devices names in Linux?
Message-ID: <03021600302800.03522@gate>

Hello Linux folkz,
I've gotten two RocketRAID HPT 372A IDE controllers and four hard drives.
Two hard drives per controller on separate channels.
When my system is booting it scans these two HPT controllers and sees all 
four drives.
However, Linux sees these controllers as RAID bus controllers Triones HPT372A 
rev 1, but it doesn't detect any drives connected to them.
I enabled the proper driver for this chipset in the kernel and still I can't 
figure out why I can't see these drives nether as separate drives hde, hdg, 
hdi, hdk, nether as raid devices. 

Could somebody please help me with this issue.
Many thanks in advance.
Alex 



From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Sun Feb 16 00:43:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Sun Feb 16 00:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RocketRAID HPT372A --> HD devices names in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <03021600302800.03522@gate>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0302160040130.27876-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

Check if you have them as scsi drives (cat /proc/scsi/scsi)
That's how my hpt372 shows up (and I had to install VIA's drivers, the
ones in the standard kernel don't support the recent revisions of this
controller yet).

On Sun, 16 Feb 2003, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> Date: Sun, 16 Feb 2003 00:30:28 -0800
> From: Alex Daniloff <alex at daniloff.com>

> four drives.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Sun Feb 16 10:55:03 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sun Feb 16 10:55:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] realplay
In-Reply-To: <1045374389.1062.3.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1045374389.1062.3.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1045421645.23754.4.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sat, 2003-02-15 at 21:46, Bill Spears wrote:
> When I execute realplay, the real audio window pops up and then I get
> this error message:
> Cannot open the audio device. Another application may be using it.
> 
> Anybody know what this is all about?

Are you in KDE or GNOME, by any chance?  If so, odds are you have a
sound server (Arts or ESD) taking control over your soundcard... so
things like RealPlayer that don't utilize the sound server are out of
luck when they try and access it.

Look through RP's settings to see if it can use ESD or ARTS by default -
I don't think it can, though..

If you're in GNOME with ESD, you can try running esddsp realplay, or if
you're in KDE with ARTS, you can run artsdsp realplay... the *dsp
programs load a library that forces everything the program tries to send
to /dev/dsp into the sound server, so things without sound server
support work with the sound server.

The reason the sound server is there is you cannot, most of the time,
play more than one audio stream out a soundcard at once.  The sound
servers mix different audio streams together, turning them into one
stream, so you can effectively play more than one stream at once. 
Problems with them, however, include trying to get them working with
apps that don't support them and the lag they introduce, which can be
seen if you watch the visualization in XMMS, or if you are one of those
audio master peoples.  :-)

Rob




From josh at barkingcorndog.homelinux.org  Sun Feb 16 11:09:03 2003

I use EasyTAG. It works not only on ogg vorbis but also flac, mp3, whatever.

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Sun Feb 16 12:50:03 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Sun Feb 16 12:50:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RocketRAID HPT372A --> HD devices names in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <03021608262300.03810@gate>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0302161245460.27876-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

Looks like now you get theom directly from Highpoint,
http://www.highpoint-tech.com/
Go to support, select HPT372 and there are linux drivers there. Follow
installation instructions to compile and install it (it's open-source
driver), then when you load the module you get some SCSI devices.
I load the module through dependency order in modules.conf:
pre-install hpt37x2 modprobe sd_mod  # Load sd-mod before hpt37x2
post-install ide-scsi modprobe hpt37x2 # Load Highpoint driver after ide-scsi

so it gets loaded automatically after ide-scsi driver (you don't need ide-scsi for Highpoint to work, I just use it for my CD)

scsi disks (real scsi or emulated). I have a small program which writes

I swear this stuff is going to drive me crazy.
Ok, esd is the right idea. I'm using gnome and I went into
RealPlayer:View:Preferences:Performance:audio drive options and selected
esd sound.  Whereupon my computer went progressively nuts, first
realplay locked up, and according to ps ax had 3 copies of itself
running. So, after much killing, I rpm -e'd RealPlayer and then rpm
-ivh'd it again, went thru the install which then locked the computer
again. Cycled this process again, made some progress, noticing that
realplay visually indicated that it was playing, but of course no sound.
Decided maybe my sound was fsck'ed, tried XMMS which was dead too. So I
killed X. Ominous quiet and black screen of mystery. But eventually X
came back and I tried: esddsp realplay which didn't work. Then tried
esddsp realplay & which produced sound. Thinking perhaps I was now
hallucinating from the pain and aggravation, I selected another
selection from the file menus and it worked. Not quite believing that &
had anything do with it I tried esddsp realplay, then realplay &, then
realplay and every **&^% one of them worked.

Not sure about the plugins yet. RealPlayer installs into netscape and I
use Mozilla, so I'll have to move some stuff around.

From eco2geek at attbi.com  Sun Feb 16 16:12:02 2003
From: eco2geek at attbi.com (Andrew Heil)
Date: Sun Feb 16 16:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [New to list] Please help - no fonts in Gnome apps on RedHat 8
Message-ID: <3E5028B7.3010600@attbi.com>

Hello,

I recently upgraded from RedHat 7.3 to 8.0 (Psyche). Now there's no text 
being displayed in Gnome apps and utilities, just GUI widgets - icons, 
buttons, (blank) tooltips, and windows, but no text. KDE works fine. I 
tried running Gnome instead of KDE once to see if that would fix it, but 
it didn't help.

Needless to say, this is a bit disconcerting, since RedHat is 
Gnome-centric and several basic configuration apps are Gnome ones.

One thing I was trying before upgrading - actually, my reason for 
upgrading - was trying to get the latest version of the Pan newsreader 
to run. It was an utter train wreck under RedHat 7.3 using RPMs, and 
compiling from source was also unsuccessful for both GTK+ and Pan. So my 
intuition tells me I'm having some sort of GTK+ problem.

Can anyone help?

Thanks -
- Andrew Heil

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Mon Feb 17 12:12:01 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon Feb 17 12:12:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] can you count on RBLs?
Message-ID: <200302171219.09059.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

Howdy gang,

What's the skinny on using RBLs? Anyone here use them? I'm concerned about 
blocking legitimate traffic. Some of my clients expect some legitimate mail 
from China, for example. It's not a relaying issue, so there's no potential 
of messing up a downstream server, just a question of possibly losing 
something important.

thanks!
-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~



From griffint at pobox.com  Mon Feb 17 12:58:01 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Mon Feb 17 12:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] can you count on RBLs?
In-Reply-To: <200302171219.09059.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200302171219.09059.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <200302171257.09300.griffint@pobox.com>

I finally had to disable use of RBLs as a means of rejecting mail during the
SMTP transaction. False postives were very rare but when they happened they
were a real pain to deal with. The sender would phone somebody in the office.
They'd call me. We'd run some tests at agreed times so I could watch the logs
and try to figure out which of the blacklisted servers was the problem. Was it
the sender's own server or some upstream server at some ISP? Then I'd have to
go through the whole mess of tracking down and explaining to some admin that
their mail server was an open relay, that it had been blacklisted, and that 
they needed to fix this. (And this of course is how you meet clueless and
defensive system admins.) In the mean time I'd have to whitelist the server at
my end so the mail would get through.

So I decided to ditch all that. I still use RBLs during delivery (via 
SpamAssassin).  Along with the other filters, if spam is detected then the
message goes to a quarantine folder instead of being rejected entirely. Once a
day each user gets an automated email reporting on new arrivials to their
quarantine folder. From there they can retrieve anything that looks legit.

Terry

On Monday 17 February 2003 12:19 pm, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Howdy gang,
>
> What's the skinny on using RBLs? Anyone here use them? I'm concerned about
> blocking legitimate traffic. Some of my clients expect some legitimate mail
> from China, for example. It's not a relaying issue, so there's no potential
> of messing up a downstream server, just a question of possibly losing
> something important.
>
> thanks!





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Feb 17 13:05:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Feb 17 13:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] can you count on RBLs?
In-Reply-To: <200302171219.09059.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302171259570.10906-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 17 Feb 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:

> What's the skinny on using RBLs? Anyone here use them? I'm concerned about 
> blocking legitimate traffic. Some of my clients expect some legitimate mail 
> from China, for example. It's not a relaying issue, so there's no potential 
> of messing up a downstream server, just a question of possibly losing 
> something important.

  I've not had any problems with the ones that I use. In a few cases -- a
very few cases -- _something_ that could not be identified was causing
rejections of legitimate incoming e-mails. I put those domains (and IP
addresses) in the postfix white list and the problem went away.

Rich

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Feb 17 19:41:04 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Feb 17 19:41:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PASA Meeting Tuesday, 18 Feb 2003 (2nd announcement)
Message-ID: <1045539611.591.183.camel@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

PASA, the Portland Area Sys Admins, invites you to our next meeting to
be held next Tuesday, the 18th of February with Tripwire Security. 
Please visit our meetings page at and RSVP so we can have an estimate of
attendance.  The RSVP is NOT mandatory!

http://pasa.portland.or.us/meetings (The RSVP code is new, so if it
breaks, please send a message to rsvp at pasa.portland.or.us.)


      * 7:00 - 7:30 Pizza / Welcome / Tripwire background
      * 7:30 - 8:00 Product overview
                Tripwire for Servers / Manager
                Managing change in a chaotic environment
                Presented by Joseph Wheeler - Sr. Systems Engineer
      * 8:00 - 8:30 Product overview
                Tripwire for Network Devices
                The solution for managing diverse network devices
                Presented by The Bender - Sr. Mixologist
                
About Tripwire

Joseph Wheeler spent four years with Symantec Corporation providing
technical support for products such as pcANYWHERE and developing
innovative ways to get customers to use online technical resources. In
the past four years with Tripwire he moved from the initial support team
to a systems engineering role. His current duties take him on flights
around the globe supporting Tripwire's numerous parners and customer
base, all the while searching for the most elusive of exotic beverages.

Tripwire(tm) Integrity Assurance solutions ensure the security and
availability of servers and network devices, while enabling increased
efficiencies and control over IT infrastructure across enterprises and
government agencies worldwide. The software establishes a baseline of
data in its desired state, detects and reports any changes to the
baseline, enabling rapid discovery and recovery when an undesired change
occurs. Tripwire identifies change, whether accidental or malicious,
from outside or within, and is the only way to know for certain that
your data is safe and remains uncompromised. Tripwire establishes the
foundation for data security and ensures a safe, productive, stable IT
environment.

Tripwire software is one of the most widely deployed and trusted
integrity assurance solutions in the world. Dr. Eugene Spafford and Gene
Kim created the initial release of Tripwire software in 1992 at Purdue
University. That academic source release received widespread support and
quickly became an essential part of best practices for corporate,
education, and government security professionals. Since 1992, more than
1 million copies of Tripwire have been downloaded and over a 1/4 million
are in active use.

Based in Portland, Oregon, Tripwire was founded by Gene Kim and W. Wyatt
Starnes. A fast-growing, global technology company, Tripwire has been
named to The Oregon Technology Fast 50 list and currently has operations
in 15 countries around the world.

Directions can be found on the Tripwire website.
http://www.tripwire.com/company/contacts/directions.cfm

About PASA

PASA is an informal support group for Portland Area Systems
Administrators. We currently have members from the East and West Side,
Vancouver, and Portland proper. Members are UNIX, NT, and Network
administrators -- sometimes a combination of the three. Someday we may
get around to building some structure into the group, but that hasn't
happened yet. (Of course, there are no membership dues either.)

We are also an official USENIX SAGE local group.


Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Feb 17 22:43:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Feb 17 22:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Spam
In-Reply-To: <3E51C2FA.4040807@attbi.com>
References: <3E51C2FA.4040807@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1045550571.4067.45.camel@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On Mon, 2003-02-17 at 21:22, Mark Morgan wrote:
> This was an interesting spam.  It had tons of these in the middle of the 
> words of an html mail. <!--RHBuW-->
> 
> Probably to defeat searches for particular words. Though I would think 
> that the bogus html comments would flag it.

Actually, the point is to defect check-sum anti-spam tools.  These spam
mailers generate random characters so every or most messages are
different, so when Razor and DCC makes check-sums of the messages,
they're different.

Wil

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Tue Feb 18 00:36:02 2003
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Tue Feb 18 00:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables logging
Message-ID: <3603.216.99.218.67.1045557278.squirrel@sautez.com>

Could someone tell me how I can get all messages from an iptables script
to log all request?  I'm trying to see where the machine thinks it is
sending a port forward request.  It appears to be wrong and I can't find
it.  I also can't find where iptables puts an logs.  I'm guessing it is
off by default but can't seem to get the LOG option to go on any new rule.

Thanks.

Josh



From plug at laynesoftware.com  Tue Feb 18 08:42:01 2003
From: plug at laynesoftware.com (Terry Layne)
Date: Tue Feb 18 08:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables logging
In-Reply-To: <3603.216.99.218.67.1045557278.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <3603.216.99.218.67.1045557278.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <20030218164049.M54111@laynesoftware.com>

On Tue, 18 Feb 2003 00:34:38 -0800 (PST), Josh Orchard wrote
> Could someone tell me how I can get all messages from an iptables script
> to log all request?  I'm trying to see where the machine thinks it is
> sending a port forward request.  It appears to be wrong and I can't find
> it.  I also can't find where iptables puts an logs.  I'm guessing it 
> is off by default but can't seem to get the LOG option to go on any 
> new rule.
> 

Do "man iptables" and look for the LOG target.  In a nutshell, for each rule
you want to log you create an identical rule except the target is LOG.  Put
that rule right before the one you want to watch.  When a packet matches it
first gets logged and then goes back to where it was and checks the next rule.  


--
Terry Layne
Portland, OR



From robbert at vafam.com  Tue Feb 18 09:43:01 2003
From: robbert at vafam.com (robbert at vafam.com)
Date: Tue Feb 18 09:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix Question
Message-ID: <104559012201@leo.hosting4u.net>

I've been setting up a Postfix mail server for my dad's home business and educational purposes and have been stumped with an error message I get when I send email to any valid email address.

554 <robbert at vafamsound.com>: Recipient address rejected: Relay access denied

The research I've done into the error message leads me to believe it's something to do with domains.  The server name is lserver.  I have it lserver aliased to localhost.localdomain.  The domain we have set up is vafamsound.com, but I have not set the server up with this (like I said localhost.localdomain is what I kept with the alias to lserver).

The Postfix documentation says that Postfix does not support Sendmail like virtual domains.  In the main.cf file, I've set myhostname to both lsever.vafamsound.com and lserver.localdomain in the hopes that this will be resolved.  I've also tried setting the mydomain variable equal to vafamsound.com.

What I'm confused about is what the FQDN is.  According to the book I have, "the myhostname parameter specifies the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the mail server.  This address will be used as the default address for all local users, unless specified otherwise by the mail administrator."

"The mydomain parameter uses the assigned DNS domain name of the mail server.  You can use this parameter instead of the myhostname parameter when a mail server is configured to receive messages for an entire domain."

Our ISP (dsl-only) has their dns servers set to point vafamsound.com to our IP.  Is my FQDN localhost.localdomain or vafamsound.com?  Is there anything else that I'm overlooking to stop getting this error.  Google has not been helpful, manily because I don't understand the relationship of the FQDN to my particular server.

I hope I've supplied enough information to get some useful help.  If not, let me know.

Robbert van Andel

_______________________________________________________




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Feb 18 09:58:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Feb 18 09:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix Question
In-Reply-To: <104559012201@leo.hosting4u.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302180947540.14598-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 18 Feb 2003 robbert at vafam.com wrote:

> 554 <robbert at vafamsound.com>: Recipient address rejected: Relay access
> denied

  This generally comes from one of the UCE filters.
 
> What I'm confused about is what the FQDN is.  According to the book I
> have, "the myhostname parameter specifies the fully qualified domain name
> (FQDN) of the mail server.  This address will be used as the default
> address for all local users, unless specified otherwise by the mail
> administrator."

  The fqdn is the host.domain.tld rather than just the host name. For
example, here the mail server's FQDN is salmo.appl-ecosys.com and not just
salmo. When I installed postfix as a replacement to sendmail this tripped me
up for a few minutes.

  Postfix wants the fqdn of the mail server when it's installed. Most of us
have the 'hostname' parameter set to only the host name. Check 'man
hostname' and you'll see how to set it to the fqdn for postfix installation
and set up. Once postfix is up and running, re-run hostname and set the
machine back to the host-only name.
 
> Our ISP (dsl-only) has their dns servers set to point vafamsound.com to
> our IP.  Is my FQDN localhost.localdomain or vafamsound.com?  Is there
> anything else that I'm overlooking to stop getting this error.  Google has
> not been helpful, manily because I don't understand the relationship of
> the FQDN to my particular server.

  See above.

  Type 'uname -n' on your mail server box and it will return the host name
of that machine. The FQDN that postfix seeks is <hostname>.vafamsound.com. 

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Feb 18 11:50:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] OT: Ion test equipment

On 18 Feb 2003, Russell Senior wrote:

> A van de Graaf and a thumbtack work pretty well too.

  The former I don't have; the latter I do.
 
> What is it that you want to check for?  In other words, define
> "working" for your purposes.

  Is it generating ions?

  The fan and heater work, but the ionoscope I have does not detect any
negative ions when the unit is on.

  According to the Desco folks (who distribute the CharlesWater line) this
unit is supposed to sense the ionic balance of the air around it and produce
both negative and positive ions in order to create a zone of no ionization
and, therefore, remove static charges from the electronic assembly/repair
workstation. My intent is to use this unit in the darkroom to eliminate dust
on negatives when I'm enlarging them. Desco says it's perfect for that
purpose.

  Ions, such as alpha and beta radiation, cannot be detected without a
suitable instrument. They have no color, taste, odor or flavor. I want to
know if I bought a non-functional unit.

Thanks,

Rich




From cb at onsitetech.com  Tue Feb 18 11:52:01 2003
From: cb at onsitetech.com (Christian Brink)
Date: Tue Feb 18 11:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] can you count on RBLs?
In-Reply-To: <200302171219.09059.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <ENEFIFGGPEDGDJMEMKECIEPAGKAA.cb@onsitetech.com>

I found the only good solution for RBL's was to use one that only blocked
Open Relays. When there is a problem (which there has not been for 6 months)
I can easily explain that their server is an open relay, and I can usually
point them in the right direction to closing it.

The downside is: it doesn't block a lot of spam. Most spammers are either
moving to their own servers, grabbing dialup accounts till they're shut off,
or finding a spam friendly off shore account.

Other RBL's just give too many false positives and if the blockee is not an
open relay it can make it difficult to find the real cause, and then explain
that to the parties envolved.

BTW I use relays.ordb.org

Christian Brink

>
> Howdy gang,
>
> What's the skinny on using RBLs? Anyone here use them? I'm
> concerned about
> blocking legitimate traffic. Some of my clients expect some
> legitimate mail
> from China, for example. It's not a relaying issue, so there's no
> potential
> of messing up a downstream server, just a question of possibly losing
> something important.
>
> thanks!
> --
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> Carla Schroder
> www.tuxcomputing.com
> this message brought to you
> by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org

From plug at laynesoftware.com  Tue Feb 18 12:43:01 2003
From: plug at laynesoftware.com (Terry Layne)
Date: Tue Feb 18 12:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] LVM on Redhat 8.0
In-Reply-To: <200302181905.h1IJ5pg17608@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <200302181905.h1IJ5pg17608@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <20030218204157.M88497@laynesoftware.com>

On Tue, 18 Feb 2003 11:05:51 -0800, Galen Seitz wrote
> I'm about to install Redhat 8.0, using LVM for all filesystems except
> / and /boot.  I would appreciate hearing any comments, both positive 
> and negative, regarding such a setup.  This will be my first attempt 
> at using LVM, and I'd like it to be a positive one.
> 

I've used LVM on Slackware and RH 7.3 for the past year with no serious
problems.  On Redhat 7.3 there was a bit of a problem with trying to mount a
filesystem before the lvm module was loaded at boot time.  I got around it by
modifying rc.sysinit to modprobe lvm-mod (or is it mod-lvm?)  Later I had a
need to switch to a custom kernel for other reasons so I built lvm into the
kernel so that I could go back to an unmodified rc.sysinit.

The commands for configuring volumes are very easy to use.  Just follow the
LVM-HOWTO and you'll be up and running in no time.

On my 4 RH 7.3 servers I have mirrored SCSI disks and I'm using LVM for a
/data filesystem so that future expansion will be easy.  These are running in
a production system.

On my Slackware box at home I have 5 SCSI drives (in an old AT case with no
motherboard) combined to create one big logical volume.  Five drives for a
total of 17 GB and one of them is held in place by velcro. :-)

--
Terry Layne
Portland, OR

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Tue Feb 18 13:23:01 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Tue Feb 18 13:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] First bash script
Message-ID: <20030218212218.GA3562@dalsemi.com>

I'm not sure if any of you use Jabber, but the server is a little
flaky.  On startup, it looks for the presence of a file in it's
root directory that contains the PID of a Jabber daemon process,
and if that file exists it refuses to startup, even if the PID in
the file doesn't exist anymore.

So I thought I'd try my hand at bash scripting and modify the startup
script to do the checking.  This is what I have:


#!/bin/bash

PIDFILE="./pidfile.pid"

##Check to see if file exists
if [ ! -e $PIDFILE ]; then
  echo "$PIDFILE does not exist"
  exit 0
fi

PID=`/bin/cat $PIDFILE`

##Is the file empty?
if [ ! $PID ]; then
  echo "$PIDFILE is empty"
  exit 0
else
  echo "$PIDFILE is not empty"
fi

##Is the process still active?
PTEST=`/bin/ps $PID | tail -1`

echo $PTEST

if [ $PTEST ]; then
  echo "$PID exists"
else
  echo "$PID does not exist"
fi

--------------------------------------------------------------

To test this, just create some process that you can easily kill
or start (like an editor) and put the process in pidfile.pid.

The last test fails saying:

[ckuskie at nwdc_lab ~]$ ./test.sh
./pidfile.pid is not empty
29439 pts/3 S 0:00 vim somefile
./test.sh: [: too many arguments
29439 does not exist

Can someone please give me a pointer as to what's wrong? I'm sure
that it has to do with what bash expects in the conditional, but
I'm not sure how to massage it to make bash happy.

Thanks,
Colin



From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Tue Feb 18 13:47:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue Feb 18 13:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] First bash script
In-Reply-To: <20030218212218.GA3562@dalsemi.com>
References: <20030218212218.GA3562@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <20030218214627.GA5260@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

> if [ $PTEST ]; then                                                                       
>   echo "$PID exists"                                                                      
> else                                                                                      
>   echo "$PID does not exist"                                                              
> fi

I think you want "'s arround the $PTEST.

if [ "$PTEST" ]; then
	....

you are currently doing something like this:

if [ 7936 pts/1    S      0:00 -bash ]; then
	... 

This may be true of your other conditionals, I'm not certian.

-Rogan

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Tue Feb 18 14:10:02 2003
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Tue Feb 18 14:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] First bash script
References: <20030218212218.GA3562@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <3E52ADD9.3030606@easystreet.com>

Put double quotes around the "$PID" in your test.

The construct

   if [ ! $PID ]  
 
is expanding to:

   if [ ! 29439 pts/3 S 0:00 vim somefile ]


With the double quotes it will read:

   if [ ! "29439 pts/3 S 0:00 vim somefile" ]

and the string with whitespace will be considered a single string.


If you want just the PID as the $PID variable contents,
then you might want to do

    PID=`awk 'NR==1 {print $1;}' $PIDFILE`

to get just the first token on the first line.

- Don

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Tue Feb 18 17:50:03 2003
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Tue Feb 18 17:50:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables logging
In-Reply-To: <20030218164049.M54111@laynesoftware.com>
References: <3603.216.99.218.67.1045557278.squirrel@sautez.com> 
     <20030218164049.M54111@laynesoftware.com>
Message-ID: <3890.216.99.218.67.1045619296.squirrel@sautez.com>

thank you.  I didn't get that from the man pages.  That is, that I should
put an additional entry for each thing I want to log.  I got that it was
an argument to iptables.  Not the case.


> On Tue, 18 Feb 2003 00:34:38 -0800 (PST), Josh Orchard wrote
>> Could someone tell me how I can get all messages from an iptables script
>> to log all request?  I'm trying to see where the machine thinks it is
>> sending a port forward request.  It appears to be wrong and I can't find
>> it.  I also can't find where iptables puts an logs.  I'm guessing it
>> is off by default but can't seem to get the LOG option to go on any
>> new rule.
>>
>
> Do "man iptables" and look for the LOG target.  In a nutshell, for each
> rule
> you want to log you create an identical rule except the target is LOG.
> Put
> that rule right before the one you want to watch.  When a packet matches
> it
> first gets logged and then goes back to where it was and checks the next
> rule.
>
>
> --
> Terry Layne
> Portland, OR
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

From keith at ahapala.net  Tue Feb 18 21:31:01 2003
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Tue Feb 18 21:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Network / NIC problems
Message-ID: <32810.10.0.0.100.1045632624.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>

I have the following setup:

laptop(10.0.0.35) <--> wireless AP <---> (10.0.0.10) firewall
(192.168.0.10) <---> (192.168.0.11)server

I have my firewall (and wireless AP) port forwarding the SSH connection to
my server. When I start and scp transfer from the laptop to xfer files
from the server to the laptop about 2Mb get transferred and the connection
dies. I can then ssh into the firewall down eth1 and bring it back up and
then I can make another connection to the server. When I bring up eth1 it
says no route to host, however the link is up and I can make another
connection. Any ideas on this one? Is my NIC failing? There is nothing in
the logs on either end.

TIA,
Keith





From stevea at nwtechops.com  Tue Feb 18 21:58:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Tue Feb 18 21:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Network / NIC problems
In-Reply-To: <32810.10.0.0.100.1045632624.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
References: <32810.10.0.0.100.1045632624.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <1045634207.1019.22.camel@main>

On Tue, 2003-02-18 at 21:30, Keith Nasman wrote:
> I have the following setup:
> 
> laptop(10.0.0.35) <--> wireless AP <---> (10.0.0.10) firewall
> (192.168.0.10) <---> (192.168.0.11)server
> 
> I have my firewall (and wireless AP) port forwarding the SSH connection to
> my server. When I start and scp transfer from the laptop to xfer files
> from the server to the laptop about 2Mb get transferred and the connection
> dies. I can then ssh into the firewall down eth1 and bring it back up and
> then I can make another connection to the server. When I bring up eth1 it
> says no route to host, however the link is up and I can make another
> connection. Any ideas on this one? Is my NIC failing? There is nothing in
> the logs on either end.

Check for drops in ifconfig, errors in ifconfig and netstat -s and
duplex mismatch in mii-tool or ethtool. That should give you an
indication of something failing at the physical or data-link layers.
Also, the OS should, in theory, throw a SIGURG in the event of an urgent
condition on a socket so if you have the ability to trap that signal you
should be able to verify the condition of the NIC (or even the state of
the OS) during the outtage period.




From tjg at craigelachie.org  Tue Feb 18 22:12:02 2003
From: tjg at craigelachie.org (Timothy Grant)

> connection. Any ideas on this one? Is my NIC failing? There is nothing in
> the logs on either end.

Keith is is an Orinoco/Prism card? if so, you may want to convert to the 
linux-wlan-ng with their prism drivers. I have had nothing but bad luck with 
the default Orinoco drivers, and the wlan-ng drivers have worked pretty well.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Feb 18 22:55:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue Feb 18 22:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] LVM on Redhat 8.0
In-Reply-To: <200302181905.h1IJ5pg17608@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <200302181905.h1IJ5pg17608@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <1045637645.4084.68.camel@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On Tue, 2003-02-18 at 11:05, Galen Seitz wrote:
> I'm about to install Redhat 8.0, using LVM for all filesystems except
> / and /boot.  I would appreciate hearing any comments, both positive and
> negative, regarding such a setup.  This will be my first attempt at
> using LVM, and I'd like it to be a positive one.

I've stayed away from it because I understand the LVM1 subsystem has
gone away from the 2.5 kernel altogether, to be replaced by parts from
LVM2 and EVMS.  I don't know if the disk formats are going to change or
not.  If not, I'd like to know because I'd like to use it myself.

If you've never used an LVM before, IBM has several Redbooks for AIX,
one in particular that covers concepts and terminology, which IIRC is
pretty much the same.  The other book(s), which cover the actual
commands, is very different.  www.redbooks.ibm.com

> BTW, do we currently have a way to search the mailing list archives?

Google with 'site:lists.pdxlinux.org' should work.  Hmm... Maybe not. 
The SSL redirection probably keeps Google from crawling it.  *sigh* I
told you-know-who that it was a bad idea.

Wil

          Interrupt:3 Base address:0xd400

checked 5 or 6 other machines and none of the interfaces show any errors

From ed at alcpress.com  Wed Feb 19 09:43:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Wed Feb 19 09:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] can you count on RBLs?
In-Reply-To: <ENEFIFGGPEDGDJMEMKECIEPAGKAA.cb@onsitetech.com>
References: <ENEFIFGGPEDGDJMEMKECIEPAGKAA.cb@onsitetech.com>
Message-ID: <1045676508.1859.91.camel@red>

Some of my customers get about 40,000 spam messages each
month and about 5,000 real messages - an 8:1 ratio. Without
RBLs and black lists, they'd be spending their time sifting
through their in-boxes. We solve the problem of white mail
being blocked by encouraging them to feed their white lists
in advance and not waiting for white mail to be blocked. We
make it easy for them to do so. Each customer has their own
white list.

One customer decided to block all of aol.com, yahoo.com,
etc. but spent time white listing all the company's customers.
It seems to work well and the occasional complaint is that
somebody isn't able to receive mail from a friend or family
member - not customers.

Any white mail that is blocked is referred to a web page
that apologizes for the inconvenience and allows the
customer to enter a message for the admin, who then
adds the customer to the white list.

Of course, this doesn't work well where the bulk of your
communications is with a constantly changing set of
customers. You'd use other technique for this scenario.

Ed



On Tue, 2003-02-18 at 11:51, Christian Brink wrote:
> I found the only good solution for RBL's was to use one that only blocked
> Open Relays. When there is a problem (which there has not been for 6 months)
> I can easily explain that their server is an open relay, and I can usually
> point them in the right direction to closing it.
> 
> The downside is: it doesn't block a lot of spam. Most spammers are either
> moving to their own servers, grabbing dialup accounts till they're shut off,
> or finding a spam friendly off shore account.
> 
> Other RBL's just give too many false positives and if the blockee is not an
> open relay it can make it difficult to find the real cause, and then explain
> that to the parties envolved.
> 
> BTW I use relays.ordb.org
> 
> Christian Brink
> 
> >
> > Howdy gang,
> >
> > What's the skinny on using RBLs? Anyone here use them? I'm
> > concerned about
> > blocking legitimate traffic. Some of my clients expect some
> > legitimate mail
> > from China, for example. It's not a relaying issue, so there's no
> > potential
> > of messing up a downstream server, just a question of possibly losing
> > something important.
> >
> > thanks!
> > --
> > ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> > Carla Schroder
> > www.tuxcomputing.com
> > this message brought to you
> > by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
> > ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

> > PLUG mailing list

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Wed Feb 19 10:48:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Feb 19 10:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix Question
In-Reply-To: <104559012201@leo.hosting4u.net>
References: <104559012201@leo.hosting4u.net>
Message-ID: <1045680402.20699.1.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Tue, 2003-02-18 at 09:42, robbert at vafam.com wrote:

> 554 <robbert at vafamsound.com>: Recipient address rejected: Relay access denied

Is vafamsound.com in your 'mydestination' line in the main.cf file?

If you want the mail server to accept email sent to a domain that has MX
records that resolve to your system, that domain must be set in
'mydestination' in your main.cf file - if it is not, you get a Relay
access denied error.

Rob




From srau at rauhaus.org  Wed Feb 19 10:55:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Wed Feb 19 10:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] BGP Router
In-Reply-To: <ENEFIFGGPEDGDJMEMKECCEEDGLAA.cb@onsitetech.com>
References: <ENEFIFGGPEDGDJMEMKECCEEDGLAA.cb@onsitetech.com>
Message-ID: <20030219185425.GA12880@rauhaus.org>

* Christian Brink <cb at onsitetech.com> [030219 10:19]:
> 
> Anyone ever setup a linux box to do BGP routing?? What is best scenario?
> 
> If so where is some documentation? I have searching through the howto's and
> I get referred to non-linux docs.
> 

GNU Zebra is probably your best bet (http://www.zebra.org/), though I
seem to recall that gated (http://www.gated.org/) does BGP now as well
as its OSPF support.

However, BGP can be wonky enough that I wouldn't want to use either of
those in a production environment. Used Cisco 7206VXRs are pretty dang
cheap now anyhow...

--Stafford



From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Feb 19 11:14:01 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Wed Feb 19 11:14:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] What caused damage to my /bin/ls file?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302191039020.2142-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

Something strange happened and I can not explain it.
Any ideas?

My system has a file /bin/ls
At 1:00 AM last night it ran the ls command as one would expect.
At 9:00 AM after a system reboot which probably isn't relevant it
gave me a "bash: /bin/ls: cannot execute binary file" error.

I got out of copy of ls, which I will call goodls and ran:

         goodls -l /bin/ls
which gave:
      -rwxr-xr-x    1 root     root        46784 Mar 23  2002 /bin/ls
just as I would expect.  However, /bin/ls would not run.
So, I ran diff goodls /bin/ls which indicated that the files differ.
(They shouldn't differ.  goodls was a backup I made of /bin/ls a week ago.)
So I ran
        file /bin/ls
which gave:
       /bin/ls: Sendmail frozen configuration  - version &&      &      &      &     &
This is certainly NOT correct.  It should be an ELF 32-bit LSB executable.

Next, I used od -bc to look for differences in ls and goodls.
The first 20k of the two files differ.  After that they are identical.

All of this made me wonder if a cracker had gotten me, so I started
looking at other files and my log files and and other systems on the
same network, and so on.  I haven't found abnormalities so far, other
than the /bin/ls file on that one machine.

Anyone have any guesses as to how that file got corupted?
It is really bugging me.


                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213
                                          (360) 260-2066 at work
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Feb 19 11:36:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Wed Feb 19 11:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] What caused damage to my /bin/ls file?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302191039020.2142-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302191119020.2829-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

I forgot to mention, that this system was not configured for security.
It has lots of services on it, but most of them are turned off.
I believe the only routinely open ports are:

         Port       State       Service
         22/tcp     open        ssh
         25/tcp     open        smtp
         515/tcp    open        printer

Others are opened when needed.

The system is also protected by an external firewall most of the
time and this firewall is moderately tight, altho I'm pretty free in
letting ssh traffic in.  Last night was an exception.  The firewall
was configured to stop all incoming traffic including ssh.

                                               Dave Mandel
