From miken at europa.com  Wed Feb 19 14:55:02 2003
From: miken at europa.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Wed Feb 19 14:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] mknod
Message-ID: <4.3.1.0.20030219143551.01475d80@mail.europa.com>

Hi,

What's the appropriate syntax for mknod to create a new entry in /dev for 
"/dev/hdc10" ?
On Tom's root boot diskette /dev/hdc8 is the highest partition.
The major and minor numbers for
hdc8 are 22,  8

Any tips appreciated
Mike




From griffint at pobox.com  Wed Feb 19 15:10:02 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Wed Feb 19 15:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] mknod
In-Reply-To: <4.3.1.0.20030219143551.01475d80@mail.europa.com>; from miken@europa.com on Wed, Feb 19, 2003 at 02:55:11PM -0800
References: <4.3.1.0.20030219143551.01475d80@mail.europa.com>
Message-ID: <20030219150927.A31270@aracnet.com>

mknod /dev/hdc10 b 22 10

Generally minor numbers increment with each partition. For
hda and hdc they start at 1. For hdb and hdd they start at 65
(to avoid minor number conficts with hda and hdc, with with
they share major numbers 3 and 22 respectively).

Terry

On Wed, Feb 19, 2003 at 02:55:11PM -0800, Mike Neal wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> What's the appropriate syntax for mknod to create a new entry in /dev for 
> "/dev/hdc10" ?
> On Tom's root boot diskette /dev/hdc8 is the highest partition.
> The major and minor numbers for
> hdc8 are 22,  8
> 
> Any tips appreciated
> Mike
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________

> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/

I'm a bit afraid I have been hacked, but I haven't found much else wrong.
No strange users.  Nothing strange in the log files.  No other programs
changed.  Altho, I can say any of this for sure until I get a bit more
time to examine things.  However, nothing obvious sticks out.
If it is a hacked system, it is either:

     -  Significantly better than the other hack jobs I've dealt
        with lately.
     -  Significantly worst than the other hack jobs I've dealt
        with lately.  The hackers didn't manage to accomplish much.

I wish I was running tripwire or something like that.
Tripwire would make it easier to find a hack.

On Wed, 19 Feb 2003, alan wrote:

>
> Run strings on it and see if it is a trojaned version.  (And the botched
> it.)

I didn't think of doing this.
The "trojaned" version of ls seems to have "2.05.0(1)-release" in the
beginning of the file.  Then it is missing a lot compared with the real
ls, and then it has lots of strings towards the end of the file, mostly

        lots of "GCC: (GNU) 2.95.3 20010315 (SuSE)"
        (Guess whose compiler this is.)
        lots of "01.01"
        followed by a few lines of symbols.

Does this ring any bells?
I don't follow security issues very closely.


>
> Are you using tripwire?  If so, what other binaries are effected.
>

Wish I was running tripwire, but I'm not.
I need to look around more, but I haven't found any other bad binaries
yet.

From kgoins at aracnet.com  Wed Feb 19 18:34:01 2003
From: kgoins at aracnet.com (Kirk Goins)
Date: Wed Feb 19 18:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Semi Dead system Need Help
References: <20030218212218.GA3562@dalsemi.com> <3E52ADD9.3030606@easystreet.com> <3E53077E.1090600@aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <3E543E91.7080803@aracnet.com>

If I boot from say CD (Mandrake 8.2) and goto to "rescue" mode, I have a /proc 
directory that has all sorts of cmds etc in it. I have the option to mount my 
existing partitions under /mnt which I do. Now I look at /mnt/proc and it is 
empty. Should it be?? The reason I ask is that when I boot from disk I get

/etc/rc.sysinit: mount command not found

which then causes all sorts of problems.

I need help getting this box working, how can I fix this problem short of 
reloading everything from CD and starting all over?

Thanks




From buchholz at easystreet.com  Wed Feb 19 18:40:03 2003
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed Feb 19 18:40:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] What caused damage to my /bin/ls file?
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302191747400.4482-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <3E543E76.7070201@easystreet.com>

If your system uses RPM's you can use the "-V" option in rpm(8) to
verify package integrity.  (Use "rpm -qf /bin/ls" to find the package
name.)

---

I was having intermittent (and then growing more frequent) problems
with commands failing to run, and reporting that they couldn't find
glibc symbols.  

 -- Grabbed a copy of "memtest86" from http://www.memtest86.com.
 -- Used the ISO image for a bootable CD.
 -- Let it run overnight.

In my case, there was an intermittent RAM error for a couple of bit change
patterns.  Very subtle .... very aggravating.  But over 4 hours it was able
to trigger about half-dozen errors in a consistent location.  Replaced 
the RAM.
Tested overnight, and everything was OK.

---

If the actual data on your disk is hosed, then it probably isn't a memory
problem.  Another recent headache involved a Dell laptop that would
*mostly* work .... until I tried to re-install the OS.  After running their
full system diags over a couple of days, I managed to log enough
consistent drive errors that Dell shipped a replacement drive.

---

screwed this file up.  I mean it was late and I was very sleepy.

so mistakes like this are hard to make.  Moreover, an accident
would surely have changed the date/time modified and/or the
file size or something.  Since these were changes it is more
like a hack or possibly a disk error.  I don't know at this
point.

> 2002 /bin/ls

> >> This is certainly NOT correct.  It should be an ELF 32-bit
> LSB executable.

> goodls.

These drops are probably caused by media errors. What's eth1 connected
to? What type of NIC is eth1?

From me at prestoncrawford.com  Thu Feb 20 09:41:01 2003

> 
> I just came across this new Linux mobile PC:
> 
>    http://info.lindows.com/mobilepc/mobilepc.htm
> 
> The price is quite attractive.  Anyone has experience
> or heard any comment about Lindows as a company
> and/or its Linux flavor?

All I know is that I don't like the Lindows distro, because you have to pay to download free software. Plus I think Michael Robertson is a smarmy, no-talent leach that latches on to a trend and tries to suck it dry. He's total 100% hyperbolic marketing. I mean, look at that page. He actually has the gall to compare a laptop to a PDA. He's a moron. Plus he compares the laptop to an iBook, but the price he lists is actually for the 12" Powerbook. The 12" iBook starts at $1000. Much cheaper.

I hate it when Microsoft lies and uses deceptive marketing to try to lure customers. I loathe it when a company does this using Linux.

Preston




From griffint at pobox.com  Thu Feb 20 09:42:01 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu Feb 20 09:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] can you count on RBLs?
In-Reply-To: <200302192344.31996.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>; from pluglist@bratgrrl.com on Wed, Feb 19, 2003 at 11:44:31PM -0800
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302171259570.10906-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <200302192344.31996.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <20030220094131.A7294@aracnet.com>

My postmaster address gets bombed, along with several other system
addresses (news, uucp, operator, games). I ended up disabling most of
these so that they bounce with an unknown-user error.

Every month or two I'll get a flood of mail to unknown users on my 
system. We're talking thousands of these messages over a day or two,
where the sender is just guessing at addresses. Anything that doesn't 
bounce goes in to their data base for their own future spamming and/or
for resale to other spammers. Somewhere along the way my system was
probed for the typical *nix system addresses, and these addresses have 
been getting spam  ever since. Sounds like they've just not got round to 
you yet.

I've been wanting to write a perl script or something that monitors the
mail log and watches for this sort of activity and then blocks it
through a firewall rule or /etc/mail/access entry, though it may be
too late for my system.

Terry

On Wed, Feb 19, 2003 at 11:44:31PM -0800, Carla Schroder wrote:

From jrosenbaum at ffadesign.com  Thu Feb 20 09:46:02 2003
From: jrosenbaum at ffadesign.com (josh rosenbaum)
Date: Thu Feb 20 09:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Lindows Mobile PC
In-Reply-To: <F75eSmc7Dc5Vp17dmog00024c77@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <004b01c2d907$3803d950$a501a8c0@Josh2>

I've been trying different revisions of Lindows for about a year now...  Its
decent for a newbie who doesn't know a thing about Linux, or someone who
really doesn't want to tinker with anything but still wants a computer.  The
"Lindows Warehouse" does have a lot of useful and "free" software that is
easily and quickly installable.  No RPMs or Library dependencies to figure
out.  I still prefer RedHat and a KDE interface because I feel it allows you
to do a little more with your machine, and it tends to be a little more
stable.

But, as a bundle, Lindows and their warehouse are kinda neat.  I would
particularly recommend it for people who don't want to buy into M$ but want
some of the ease of use in a GUI based OS.

As for mobilepc I haven't seen that before, I'll have to check it out.

Hope this helps.

Josh Rosenbaum
I.S. Manager
Fletcher Farr Ayotte PC
www.ffadesign.com
503-222-1661
503-222-1701 (FAX)

He's comparing it to a PDA, because a PDA isn't that much cheaper than

He might be a moron, but he's always getting a lot of attention from the
general public and advocating linux. If Lindows develops an easy way to
bridge linux and windows together for the general public that isn't ready
to use open office yet, all the more power to them.

To be fair, I haven't tried LindowsOS yet, but I'd like to take a look at
it someday just to see how easy it is to install Windows s/w on it. If I
could install all the windows apps that my mom needs for her business on
lindows, I'd seriously consider moving her from her windows environment.

LindowsOS might not be for me, but it might be good for someone else who
is ready to leave windows.

>> Mask:255.255.255.0 UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500
>> Metric:1
>>           RX packets:112104 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0 TX
>> packets:646377 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
>> collisions:0 txqueuelen:100
>>           RX bytes:23401595 (22.3 Mb)  TX bytes:870051437 (829.7 Mb)
>> Interrupt:3 Base address:0xd400
>>
>>
>> So the eth1 card on my firewall is showing the errors and drops. I
>> just checked 5 or 6 other machines and none of the interfaces show any
>> errors at all. Does this point decisively at a failing NIC or should I
>> install mii-tool or ethtool on my firewall and interpret that output?
>
> These drops are probably caused by media errors. What's eth1 connected
> to? What type of NIC is eth1?
>

I haven't opened the box up yet, but I just ran lsmod on the box and one
driver is the rtl8139 and the other is 3c509. The 3c509 card is 10mbit. I
changed my network around when I got my wireless to put my wireless
outside the firewall. Previous to that the 3c509 was plugged into the DSL
modem directly with a crossover.

I'll swap out that card tonight.

Thanks for the help.

Keith





From me at prestoncrawford.com  Thu Feb 20 10:07:01 2003
From: me at prestoncrawford.com (Preston Crawford)
Date: Thu Feb 20 10:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Lindows Mobile PC
Message-ID: <6bb2b0ef22a54f36880f49e023895041.me@prestoncrawford.com>

> He's comparing it to a PDA, because a PDA isn't that much cheaper than
> this machine.

I understand. It's still a stupid comparison, given that he itemizes all the things a PDA lacks. My wife's Dell laptop (on which I promptly loaded SuSE) only cost $700. I also own a Zaurus. When I bought my Zaurus I wasn't detered by the fact that it didn't have a full-size keyboard, didn't have hard disk, didn't have a USB or didn't have firewire. Not to mention a 12" monitor. It's a PDA. When I bought it I wanted a PDA. When I wanted a laptop I bought a laptop. I wouldn't pack a laptop with a 12" screen with me everywhere, nor would I spend much time typing on my Zaurus. It's a silly comparison.
 
> He might be a moron, but he's always getting a lot of attention from the
> general public and advocating linux. If Lindows develops an easy way to
> bridge linux and windows together for the general public that isn't ready
> to use open office yet, all the more power to them.

That's the problem I have. He's getting the attention of the public and making it look like Linux is the bastion of hucksters and shysters.
 
> To be fair, I haven't tried LindowsOS yet, but I'd like to take a look at
> it someday just to see how easy it is to install Windows s/w on it. If I
> could install all the windows apps that my mom needs for her business on
> lindows, I'd seriously consider moving her from her windows environment.

Actually, I don't think it does the Windows software thing anymore. That was the original premise, but I believe it either turned out to be too expensive or too difficult. Lycoris or Xandros would probably be better for a newbie looking for this kind of functionality.

> LindowsOS might not be for me, but it might be good for someone else who
> is ready to leave windows.

I agree. It might work for some newbies. I just think the good name of Linux is being sullied by Lindows. Just my opinion.

Preston

On Thursday 20 February 2003 09:46 am, Robby Russell wrote:
>.... but he's always getting a lot of attention from the
> general public and advocating linux.

It is possible that Microsoft will lose its Windows trademark because of 
Michael Robertson. http://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/30/technology/30LOGO.html
login: secretchimp password: matahairy

Microsoft sued Lindows, but already Lindows has scored some legal victories.
 "In his order last March, Judge Coughenour denied Microsoft's request for a 
preliminary injunction in a 29-page order indicating that the little-known 
defendant had scored some points.

"Although Lindows.com certainly made a conscious decision to play with fire by 
choosing a product and company name that differs by only one letter from the 
world's leading computer software program," the judge wrote, "one could just 
as easily conclude that in 1983 Microsoft made an equally risky decision to 
name its product after a term commonly used in the trade to indicate the 
windowing capability of a G.U.I.... Lindows.com was emboldened. It sued to 
invalidate Microsoft's trademark on Windows in October and asked for a 
summary judgment."

Lindows funded the XBox hacking contest, 
http://zdnet.com.com/2100-1104-978957.html. $200,000 prize! whee!

But then they pissed off everyone by taking over the Desktop Linux Summit:
http://www.desktoplinux.com/news/NS4417146902.html

Walmart PCs running Lindows are top-sellers. Whatever anyone may think of 
Michael Robertson, he's having an impact.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Thu Feb 20 11:24:01 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Thu Feb 20 11:24:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Lindows Mobile PC
In-Reply-To: <F75eSmc7Dc5Vp17dmog00024c77@hotmail.com>
References: <F75eSmc7Dc5Vp17dmog00024c77@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <1045768988.16628.7.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Thu, 2003-02-20 at 09:27, Vincent Yau wrote:

> I just came across this new Linux mobile PC:
> 
>    http://info.lindows.com/mobilepc/mobilepc.htm
> 
> The price is quite attractive.  Anyone has experience
> or heard any comment about Lindows as a company
> and/or its Linux flavor?

I think Lindows is evil, personally.

As for that mobilepc....

$799, huh?

It has a VIA chip in it.  Read:  Cut the MHz in half and that's your
actual amount of performance.  The chips have the suckiest FPUs on the
market... I'd be happier wtih a 933MHz 386 with the optional math
coprocessor than a 933MHz VIA C3.

As for the pricetag - it ain't that great.  Here I sit, typing on a
1.8GHz Pentium4 laptop with 256MB of RAM, a 14.1" display, a 20GB hard
drive, 24X CD-ROM drive, integrated LAN and modem, 16MB GeForce2Go
graphics chip, and a floppy drive (it plays BattleField 1942) I got on
sale for $706.  I dare say, this system could run twice as fast in any
benchmark as that Lindows machine.

Then the price comparisons.... they list an NEC with a 900MHz P3 for
$2200.  Ummmm... I don't think NEC, or anybody else for that matter,
sells laptop with 900Mhz Pentium 3 chips in them.  Those prices are
*way* outdated... so much so it ain't even funny.

As somebody else pretty much said... I loathe manipulative marketing
tactics from Microsoft.  To see it from a Linux company is sickening.

Rob

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Thu Feb 20 13:36:01 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Thu Feb 20 13:36:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] httpd performance
Message-ID: <20030220213553.46063.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>

I have httpd (2.0) installed in RH 8.0, Mandrake 9.0,
and Openoffice 3.1 on the same computer. I haven't put
it anywhere else yet.

I can bring it up on the computer on which it is
installed in any of these installations by pointing it
to "localhost." On OL3.1 and Mandrake, I can also see
it on a Windows computer connected to the network by
pointing it to 192.168.0.3.

But not Red Hat: "Connection refused." I find RH to be
a somewhat unsociable distribution, perhaps because of
firewall rules (which I don't fully understand). Does
anyone else get this impression?

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

"SAMBA--opening Windows to a wider world."



From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Feb 20 13:58:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu Feb 20 13:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] httpd performance
In-Reply-To: <20030220213553.46063.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <5.2.0.9.0.20030220135222.00bb19f0@localhost>

If you accepted the default firewall set, that refuses connection to any 
server on the box, unless you specifically enable it.

This is a good thing. Deny all, allow some is usually the most secure way 
to go about it.

Assuming you have the firewall running, you should boot up the fw config 
tool, and enable connections to port 80 (httpd).

Redhat as documentation here: 
http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/linux/RHL-8.0-Manual/custom-guide/ch-basic-firewall.html#S1-BASIC-FIREWALL-SECURITYLEVEL

At 01:35 PM 2/20/2003 -0800, you wrote:
>I have httpd (2.0) installed in RH 8.0, Mandrake 9.0,
>and Openoffice 3.1 on the same computer. I haven't put
>it anywhere else yet.
>
>I can bring it up on the computer on which it is
>installed in any of these installations by pointing it
>to "localhost." On OL3.1 and Mandrake, I can also see
>it on a Windows computer connected to the network by
>pointing it to 192.168.0.3.
>
>But not Red Hat: "Connection refused." I find RH to be
>a somewhat unsociable distribution, perhaps because of
>firewall rules (which I don't fully understand). Does
>anyone else get this impression?

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Thu Feb 20 20:27:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Thu Feb 20 20:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Certifications
In-Reply-To: <97650-22003242022314718@bctonline.com>
References: <97650-22003242022314718@bctonline.com>
Message-ID: <1045801597.2741.44.camel@main>

On Thu, 2003-02-20 at 14:03, Chaz wrote:
> Have any of you found certifications such as
> RHCE to be advantageous?
> -chaz
>

Only if your prospective employer requires it. One IS Manager read the
certification section of my resume and all she had to say was "Welcome
to the club". However, if your looking at a certificate that carries the
letters BS, MS or PhD then your looking at something that will likely
land a job with no top-out. An RHCE alone will max out eventually, and
possibly go down, as the market gets flooded with them (a good example
of this is MCSE and CNE). I think a good rule of thumb is that if a cert
gets you in the door then it is of value, it's just not a replacement
for a degree.

Steve




From stevea at nwtechops.com  Thu Feb 20 20:31:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Thu Feb 20 20:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Network / NIC problems
In-Reply-To: <32912.63.105.27.245.1045763665.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
References: <32810.10.0.0.100.1045632624.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
	<1045634207.1019.22.camel@main>
	<32837.63.105.27.245.1045672343.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
	<1045714167.1761.10.camel@main> 
	<32912.63.105.27.245.1045763665.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <1045801816.2741.48.camel@main>

On Thu, 2003-02-20 at 09:54, Keith Nasman wrote:
> I haven't opened the box up yet, but I just ran lsmod on the box and one
> driver is the rtl8139 and the other is 3c509. The 3c509 card is 10mbit. I
> changed my network around when I got my wireless to put my wireless
> outside the firewall. Previous to that the 3c509 was plugged into the DSL
> modem directly with a crossover.
> 
> I'll swap out that card tonight.

Media errors (normally in the form of CRC) are generally caused by flaky
switch/hub ports, crappy cables or interference. You might look at that
before going through the fun of swapping the NIC.




From judah at opusnet.com  Thu Feb 20 21:16:02 2003
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: Thu Feb 20 21:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] httpd performance
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030220135222.00bb19f0@localhost>
References: <5.2.0.9.0.20030220135222.00bb19f0@localhost>
Message-ID: <1045804573.4586.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I've found this to be a great tool for desktop firewall settings. Make
changes easily and immediately. Very good for quickly opening a port for
testing and then locking it back down after you're finished. And good
for the person who wants to run a desktop firewall with a lot of help
from this app..

http://firestarter.sourceforge.net/

A-

On Thu, 2003-02-20 at 13:57, Russ Johnson wrote:
> If you accepted the default firewall set, that refuses connection to any 
> server on the box, unless you specifically enable it.
> 
> This is a good thing. Deny all, allow some is usually the most secure way 
> to go about it.
> 
> Assuming you have the firewall running, you should boot up the fw config 
> tool, and enable connections to port 80 (httpd).
> 
> Redhat as documentation here: 
> http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/linux/RHL-8.0-Manual/custom-guide/ch-basic-firewall.html#S1-BASIC-FIREWALL-SECURITYLEVEL
> 
> At 01:35 PM 2/20/2003 -0800, you wrote:
> >I find RH to be
> >a somewhat unsociable distribution, perhaps because of
> >firewall rules (which I don't fully understand). Does
> >anyone else get this impression?
> 
> Russ Johnson

available, I want to learn how to fix mozilla.

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302210634500.25710-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

Perhaps try removing/moving the bookmark file and see if it adds a new one
when you relaunch Mozilla... or make a backup of your mozilla prefs folder
and move it and relaunch mozilla to reinit your mozilla folder. Then see
if your bookmarks have a problem anymore. (you can always copy your prefs
back over...)

#1 If I boot my original CDs and re-install, do I loose all my cfg setting or 
just end up replacing executables and the like?

#2 Let's say I have this system that can't complete booting because it gets to 
the point of wanting to mount /proc and it can't find the mount cmd. I can boot 
from CD, go to rescue, mount the partitions under /mnt and see the data. Can I 
install a new drive, install Linux on it, plug in the old drive as physical 
drive #2 and be able to recover files and such from it?

Thanks

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Fri Feb 21 09:33:01 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Fri Feb 21 09:33:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] What happens when...
In-Reply-To: <3E563CBB.4060603@aracnet.com>
References: <97650-22003242022314718@bctonline.com> <1045801597.2741.44.camel@main> <3E563CBB.4060603@aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <200302210940.34353.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Friday 21 February 2003 06:50 am, Kirk Goins wrote:
> #1 If I boot my original CDs and re-install, do I loose all my cfg setting
> or just end up replacing executables and the like?

Depends on how your system is partitioned, and what options your installer 
has. usually installs are partition-based, so if /home and /etc, for example, 
are in their own partitions, you can leave them alone and re-do everything 
else.

>
> #2 Let's say I have this system that can't complete booting because it gets
> to the point of wanting to mount /proc and it can't find the mount cmd. I
> can boot from CD, go to rescue, mount the partitions under /mnt and see the
> data. Can I install a new drive, install Linux on it, plug in the old drive
> as physical drive #2 and be able to recover files and such from it?
>

Yes indeedy! That's my fave method, over trying to repair a drive with boot 
problems, for me it goes faster. Doubtless our ancient wizened Linux wizards 
can surgically repair anything, this lowly grasshopper fumble and bumbles 
until things work right. ;-)

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~



From danh at fork.com  Fri Feb 21 10:07:02 2003
From: danh at fork.com (Dan Haskell)
Date: Fri Feb 21 10:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disappearing bookmarks in mozilla
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302210602540.25710-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0302210959001.11202-100000@cohiba.fork.com>

On Fri, 21 Feb 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I've no idea how to solve this problem with mozilla-1.2.1. I'll add a
> bookmark by pressing ctrl-d or shift-ctrl-d and it's gone the next time I
> invoke the application.

Seems like I had a similar problem with Netscape. The bookmarks, cookies,
and history data are held in memory until you exit - which is why several
of the files have the comment that says "do not edit". If I exited
abnormally the changes were lost. If I ran more than one copy of the
browser, one's bookmark cache over wrote the other's. That shouldn't
happen with Mozilla though, it's smart enough to offer to create a new set
of files for each instance.

Dan




From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Fri Feb 21 10:09:01 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Fri Feb 21 10:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] dpkg error- -subprocess paste killed by signal
Message-ID: <200302211016.56181.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

Okay Debian deities, here's your big chance to show off. what the heck is 
going on here? A Googling on "subprocess paste killed by signal (Broken 
pipe)" returns zillions of hits, on all different kinds of failed 
installations, but not much that is useful to me. I'm just an old country 
sysadmin, dammit, not a ace kernel hacker.

This all started with upgrading KDE 3.05 to 3.1 on Libranet Debian 2.7. 
Everything else went smoothly, these two packages are stubbornly resisting, 
libarts1 libartsc0. I tried moving /usr/bin/artscat and /usr/bin/artsdsp out 
of the way, what the heck it was worth a try. Made no difference. I started 
with

apt-get upgrade kdelibs4

which went fine. Then:

apt-get upgrade kdelibs-bin

That's when this dpkg error first appeared. I resorted to apt-get -f install, 
trusting in Debian's magical abilities to fix things. Well that didn't work. 
Then I tried deleting /usr/bin/artsdsp and /usr/bin/artscat from 
/var/lib/dpkg/info/libarts1-bin.list, which did not fix it. (Hint: leaving 
spaces between the filenames makes more errors.)

I won't bore you with ranting about how installing a single KDE app leads to 
this huge ugly winderz-type interdepency mess, especially on a fricken 
half-point release. I didn't want to upgrade every darn thing, I just wanted 
Quanta. 

So- any bright ideas?

Thanks!
Carla


# apt-get -f install
Reading Package Lists... Done
Building Dependency Tree... Done
Correcting dependencies... Done

The following NEW packages will be installed:

E: Sub-process /usr/bin/dpkg returned an error code (1)

From DVHoward at teleport.com  Fri Feb 21 11:00:02 2003
From: DVHoward at teleport.com (Douglas Howard)
Date: Fri Feb 21 11:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Ion test equipment
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302181112170.14820-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <006701c2d9db$70509670$c0061ad8@k61800DVH>

You can buy a professional tester like this
http://www.desco.com/catalog/19447.htm
(but who wants to spend that much) or 
make your own simple one as follows.

Build a simple Electroscope to detect the presence of a charge:
http://www.exploratorium.edu/snacks/electroscope.html
http://www.mos.org/sln/toe/simpleelectroscope.html

Charge it up and  put it in the path of the ionized air.
The "leaves" will start apart and slowly drop indicating less 
and less charge.

To store large charges use a simple Leyden Jar.
http://www.arcsandsparks.com/oneleydenjar.html
http://www.mos.org/learn_more/ed_res/cheapbook/leyden/ 
You could put the jar in the path of the ionized air and every 
few minutes, use the electroscope to see if any charge is left.

Have fun with physics!

Douglas Howard
Electrical Engineer, EMC Engineer, etc

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Feb 21 13:07:01 2003

>>>>> "Carla" == Carla Schroder <pluglist at bratgrrl.com> writes:

Carla> I won't bore you with ranting about how installing a single KDE
Carla> app leads to this huge ugly winderz-type interdepency mess,
Carla> especially on a fricken half-point release. I didn't want to
Carla> upgrade every darn thing, I just wanted Quanta.

Carla> So- any bright ideas?

Disclaimer: I don't have any experience with libranet, just
plain-old-debian-debian.  That said, here are a few suggestions.

What does your /etc/apt/sources.list look like?

You might try dpkg'ing the deb it is tripping over:

  dpkg -i /var/cache/apt/archives/libarts1_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb

and see what that says.  Maybe even try some of the --debug options.

I notice that these are kde.org packages.  You might check with
whoever is responsible for them to see if they have reported bugs.

The other suggestion is to do a full update/upgrade.  I notice you
have ~170 not upgraded packages.  Probably not related, but when
debugging it is often good to reduce variables.

killed by signal" is quite common, and not particular to any application. So 
far all I'm finding is mysterious kernel hacker communications, and 
bewildered users with no answers.

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Feb 21 15:04:01 2003

Hi Carla,

On Fri, 2003-02-21 at 14:32, Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Friday 21 February 2003 01:06 pm, Russell Senior wrote:
> > Disclaimer: I don't have any experience with libranet, just
> > plain-old-debian-debian.  That said, here are a few suggestions.
> 
> Libranet is Debian with nice extras. Underneath it's Real Debian.

Can you run dselect?
> 
> >
> > What does your /etc/apt/sources.list look like?
> 
> Libranet, Debian stable, and kde
> >
> > You might try dpkg'ing the deb it is tripping over:
> >
> >   dpkg -i /var/cache/apt/archives/libarts1_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb

You could try uninstalling anything to do with the "arts" package (I
believe it is the KDE sound server), using dselect would be easiest, let
it drag out anything it wants (you can get them back later), then don't
install anything else until you can run the install routine with no
errors; sometimes you have to run this several times to clear up any
cascaded dependancies.

Now go after Quanta, run the install routine until it doesn't do
anything.

Finally install any other packages (that you want) that were taken out
with the "arts" stuff.
> 
> Same error message.
> >
> > and see what that says.  Maybe even try some of the --debug options.
> >
> > I notice that these are kde.org packages.  You might check with
> > whoever is responsible for them to see if they have reported bugs.
> 
> That's a good idea. Libarts packages are related to sound drivers, I don't 
> thing they are KDE packages. But anything can happen when many chefs try to 
> fix the soup.
> 
> >
> > The other suggestion is to do a full update/upgrade.  I notice you
> > have ~170 not upgraded packages.  Probably not related, but when
> > debugging it is often good to reduce variables.
> 
> Well, this one is a showstopper- nothing wants to install until this 
> particular issue is resolved. This particular error, the "subprocess paste 
> killed by signal" is quite common, and not particular to any application. So 
> far all I'm finding is mysterious kernel hacker communications, and 
> bewildered users with no answers.

I think the (broken pipe) is a better clue, this is the reason for the
paste failure.  I saw this error a lot when working with a SOAP
developer, it usually meant the connection to the server was screwed up
somehow.  In this case, I think it is a command pipe created by the
install script.

Good Luck

Derek Loree





From stevea at nwtechops.com  Fri Feb 21 15:24:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Fri Feb 21 15:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] dpkg error- -subprocess paste killed by signal
In-Reply-To: <1045868611.20297.36.camel@toshi>
References: <200302211016.56181.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
	<86znoptkc1.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>  <200302211432.08720.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
	 <1045868611.20297.36.camel@toshi>
Message-ID: <1045869770.4238.9.camel@main>

On Fri, 2003-02-21 at 15:03, Derek Loree wrote:
> I think the (broken pipe) is a better clue, this is the reason for the
> paste failure.  I saw this error a lot when working with a SOAP
> developer, it usually meant the connection to the server was screwed up
> somehow.  In this case, I think it is a command pipe created by the
> install script.

I agree with Derek here Carla. The "Broken Pipe" is due to the signal
SIGPIPE being thrown by a process that is attempting to open a FIFO (or
unixsocket) when it is not open for read on the other side. Try doing 
/usr/sbin/lsof | egrep 'artscat|astsdsp' and see if there's a process
that has these files open.

Steve

From krisa at subtend.net  Fri Feb 21 15:28:16 2003
From: krisa at subtend.net (Kris)
Date: Fri Feb 21 15:28:16 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Blocking websites?
In-Reply-To: <38871.12.47.207.4.1045863079.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <38871.12.47.207.4.1045863079.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <20030221232724.GA12681@subtend.net>

On Fri, Feb 21, 2003 at 02:31:19PM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I need to restrict the websites that a couple users can access running. 
> They should be able to access 3 sites and no others.  If it makes any
> difference, the users are on a Linux Terminal Server.  Any suggestions on
> how to accomplish this?
> Thanks,
> ~M

Tweak local name resolution. :)  Only if they require access to these 3 sites _only_ (no
other local services).

Remove nameserver entries from /etc/resolv.conf and add the 3 hostnames
to /etc/hosts (with IP's).

They will be able to hit a website if they know the IP address, but they
won't be able to lookup the IP with no nameserver entries.  They could
do it with dig only if they knew an IP of a DNS server.

Quick-n-dirty if you don't want to mess with firewalling and your users
aren't technical.

From sean at fork.com  Fri Feb 21 21:10:02 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Fri Feb 21 21:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] dpkg error- -subprocess paste killed by signal
In-Reply-To: <200302211016.56181.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200302211016.56181.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <20030222050916.F184EC5CD@max.seansdomain.org>

> Unpacking replacement libarts1 ...
> dpkg: error processing
> /var/cache/apt/archives/libarts1_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb (--unpack):
>  trying to overwrite `/usr/bin/artscat', which is also in package

Right here it's telling you that /usr/bin/artscat is included in two 
packages.  Both libarts1_1.1.1.0 and libarts1-bin.  If you believe that the 
libarts1_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb contains a valid version or artscat you can

dpkg -i --force-overwrite 
/var/cache/apt/archives/libarts1_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb.  I've run into this 
many times and it hasn't seemed to be a problem yet.  Same with the other 
error.


Sean

> libarts1-bin dpkg-deb: subprocess paste killed by signal (Broken pipe)
> Unpacking libartsc0 (from .../libartsc0_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb) ...
> dpkg: error processing
> /var/cache/apt/archives/libartsc0_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb (--unpack):
>  trying to overwrite `/usr/bin/artsdsp', which is also in package
> libarts1-bin dpkg-deb: subprocess paste killed by signal (Broken pipe)
> Errors were encountered while processing:
>  /var/cache/apt/archives/libarts1_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb
>  /var/cache/apt/archives/libartsc0_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb
> E: Sub-process /usr/bin/dpkg returned an error code (1)



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Feb 21 21:16:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Fri Feb 21 21:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] busted AGP slot?
Message-ID: <86lm08uc9a.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

My father has an Intel P4 box, with an Intel 845 motherboard (Intel
845GBVL) with integrated video, LAN, sound, that I built for him.  For
reference, he runs w2k on it, but that isn't relevant.  More recently,
he became dissatisfied with the speed of the integrated video for 3D
graphics and wanted to upgrade, so we got him a Radeon 9500 Pro.

It worked great right of the bat.  Didn't even need to disable the
onboard video.  The motherboard seemed to detect that the AGP slot was
occupied and switched to using it.

It continued working fine for a few weeks, and then he started to
observe a weird shimmer on the monitor that seemed related to getting
warmed up.  I never saw it, so I can't describe it any better.  I told
him to call ATI, which he did.  Technical support said: "sounds like a
bad card, send it back".  My father (not a certified technician by any
stretch, certifiable, maybe, but let's not go there) removed the old
card.  He mentioned to me that he had some trouble getting it out.  A
week passes, and the new card shows up.  He plugs it in and gets no
video.  Hmm.  I come over last night and have a look.  I notice that
the little retention pin on the AGP slot is busted off (didn't find
the piece, but the remaining plastic tab is fractured).  We take the
card out and the onboard video works fine, plug the card back in and
get no video: zero, none.  Two possibilities: a) a DOA card; or b) a
busted motherboard.

So, I take the card home and plug it into my test box, and it works.
So, that seems to point to option b).  My hypothesis is that in
removing the card he managed to fracture something in the AGP slot
that prevents it from working.  

And so that brings me to my question: is there anything practical that
we can do about this short of buying a new motherboard?  Whatever the
problem, it seems limited to the AGP slot.  A replacement motherboard
is about $125-$135 or so. Any suggestions/recommendations?  I've
already thought of me keeping the card, but I don't think that'll fly
with Dad.

Thanks!

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I've seen every kind of critter God ever made,
seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower, more
                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
                                        -- Burl Ives as Rufus Hennessy



From kens at cad2cam.com  Fri Feb 21 21:32:02 2003
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Fri Feb 21 21:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] busted AGP slot?
In-Reply-To: <86lm08uc9a.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86lm08uc9a.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1045892284.3988.99.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>

On Fri, 2003-02-21 at 21:15, Russell Senior wrote:
> 
> My father has an Intel P4 box, with an Intel 845 motherboard (Intel
> 845GBVL) with integrated video, LAN, sound, that I built for him.  For
> card.  He mentioned to me that he had some trouble getting it out.  A
> week passes, and the new card shows up.  He plugs it in and gets no
> video.  Hmm.  I come over last night and have a look.  I notice that
> the little retention pin on the AGP slot is busted off (didn't find
> the piece, but the remaining plastic tab is fractured).  We take the
> card out and the onboard video works fine, plug the card back in and
> get no video: zero, none.  Two possibilities: a) a DOA card; or b) a
> busted motherboard.

You can try to fix the board, but these days it really is cheaper to
just buy a new motherboard.  Not worth the trouble to fix it.  Both of
you will be much happier with the finished product.  These motherboards
are multilayer boards and the force used in busting the old card out
probably delaminated at least a few layers.

Ask you Dad to wait for you next time to work on the systems.

Ken




From mikedela at ipns.com  Fri Feb 21 21:40:02 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Fri Feb 21 21:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] busted AGP slot?
In-Reply-To: <1045892284.3988.99.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
Message-ID: <XRPOGEEA625YPO84TPZ5YSPKFCAYV1.3e570cff@miked>

Be sure that the onboard video gets disabled before you try to boot to the new 
card in the slot.

It does sound like he busted the mobo, though. Hope not.

Mike

sites have a number of users. I am trying to figure out the best way
to handle groups for these users. each domain needs to have all its

it users a group name like group1,group2 ...etc or site1,site2 ..etc and then in the group
list I could just add all the user names after every group name.

> I have a lot of virtue domain on my server and each of those web
> sites have a number of users. I am trying to figure out the best way
> to handle groups for these users. each domain needs to have all its
> users plus all the web pages and emails listed under the same group so
> that I can control quotas. What I need to know is what is the best way
> to name the groups. I was thinking of giving every virtue domain and
> it users a group name like group1,group2 ...etc or site1,site2 ..etc and then in the group
> list I could just add all the user names after every group name.
> What do you think all ideas are welcome  
> 
> -- 
> Best regards,
>  Richard                          mailto:rkurth at starband.net

Sounds like a good scheme. Be sure to add the apache server user to the
groups.  That way the web server can serve the sites.

Ken

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Feb 21 22:42:02 2003
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Feb 21 22:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] busted AGP slot?
In-Reply-To: <86lm08uc9a.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86lm08uc9a.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1045896070.20294.74.camel@toshi>

On Fri, 2003-02-21 at 21:15, Russell Senior wrote:

[snip]

>  He plugs it in and gets no
> video.  Hmm.  I come over last night and have a look.  I notice that
> the little retention pin on the AGP slot is busted off (didn't find
> the piece, but the remaining plastic tab is fractured).  We take the
> card out and the onboard video works fine, plug the card back in and
> get no video: zero, none.  Two possibilities: a) a DOA card; or b) a
> busted motherboard.

Two possibilities: 1) He pulled on the card hard enough to bust it off,
bending the motherboard in the process, or 2) he pried it out of the
socket, making it much easier to bust it off.

If the motherboard was bent severely, then runs and solder joints will
break.  Tough to repair, and the quality of the motherboard will always
be in question.

If he pried it out, then the motherboard should be ok, unless he gouged
it or knocked something off.  By applying that much force in a less than
perpendicular direction, he may have dragged some of the connectors out
of socket.  These runs are delicate, but it may be possible to bend them
back.  To replace the entire socket, you would need access to a solder
pot (a device that continuously pumps molten solder into a pool that is
the shape of the connector).
> 
> So, I take the card home and plug it into my test box, and it works.
> So, that seems to point to option b).  My hypothesis is that in
> removing the card he managed to fracture something in the AGP slot
> that prevents it from working.  
> 
> And so that brings me to my question: is there anything practical that
> we can do about this short of buying a new motherboard?  Whatever the
> problem, it seems limited to the AGP slot.  A replacement motherboard
> is about $125-$135 or so. Any suggestions/recommendations?  I've
> already thought of me keeping the card, but I don't think that'll fly
> with Dad.

I'd like to see one in action, I've read pretty good things about them.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree





From scott_list at mischko.com  Fri Feb 21 23:27:02 2003

In-Reply-To: <1044983466.19365.101.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

>From his description, I think it was 1).  No obvious damage except for

Derek> If the motherboard was bent severely, then runs and solder
Derek> joints will break.  Tough to repair, and the quality of the
Derek> motherboard will always be in question.

Yeah.  Oddly, back on the onboard video, things are fine.  I would
have expected a "damaged" motherboard to be a little more squirrelly.
Evidently, there is enough continuity for the motherboard to detect
the card, but not enough for the card to generate comprehendable video
at the monitor.

Derek> I'd like to see one in action, I've read pretty good things
Derek> about them.

Just for reference, this is the 9500, not the top-of-the-line 9700.
It was about $190.  The 9700's were about another hundred.

What impressed me, really, was how well Intel's onboard video did on
3D graphics.  Not in the same class as the newer cards, but an order
of magnitude better than top-of-the-line from just a couple years ago,
and "for free".

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Feb 22 01:24:02 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat Feb 22 01:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] dpkg error- -subprocess paste killed by signal
In-Reply-To: <20030222050916.F184EC5CD@max.seansdomain.org>
References: <200302211016.56181.pluglist@bratgrrl.com> <20030222050916.F184EC5CD@max.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <200302220131.33302.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Friday 21 February 2003 09:09 pm, Sean Whitney wrote:
> > Unpacking replacement libarts1 ...
> > dpkg: error processing
> > /var/cache/apt/archives/libarts1_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb (--unpack):
> >  trying to overwrite `/usr/bin/artscat', which is also in package
>
> Right here it's telling you that /usr/bin/artscat is included in two
> packages.  Both libarts1_1.1.1.0 and libarts1-bin.  If you believe that the
> libarts1_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb contains a valid version or artscat you can
>
> dpkg -i --force-overwrite
> /var/cache/apt/archives/libarts1_1.1.0-0woody4_i386.deb.  I've run into
> this many times and it hasn't seemed to be a problem yet.  Same with the
> other error.

Thanks Sean! I'll note that for next time. KDE was so messed up I manually 
hunted down every last app and deleted it. I also deleted /etc/kde2 and 
/etc/kde3, and /user/lib/kde3. Then used only deb 
http://download.kde.org/stable/3.1/Debian woody main for my KDE sources. 
Installed the pieces I wanted, and now everything works.

A nice crash course in Debian package management, and the joy of the --dry-run 
option.

--

Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com

by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail

From bsr at spek.org  Sat Feb 22 02:42:02 2003

On Thu, 2003-02-20 at 11:23, AthlonRob wrote:
> As for the pricetag - it ain't that great.  Here I sit, typing on a
> 1.8GHz Pentium4 laptop with 256MB of RAM, a 14.1" display, a 20GB hard
> drive, 24X CD-ROM drive, integrated LAN and modem, 16MB GeForce2Go
> graphics chip, and a floppy drive (it plays BattleField 1942) I got on
> sale for $706.  I dare say, this system could run twice as fast in any
> benchmark as that Lindows machine.

Not everybody wants to run BattleField 1942 on their laptop, in fact I
never have.  I think this laptop fits a nice niche for some people:
folks that don't want to lug around a 7 pound monstrosity, or even a 4
pound laptop.

I've got an old Sony z505 that I would NEVER trade for one of those
giant computers that happen to fold up and that people call laptops.  I
regularly carry mine around and I'm not bothered by its weight - I never
have to decide whether to take it with me or not, I just take it.  I had
to carry around a friend's 12" iBook for a day and that extra 1.5lbs
made a difference.

> Then the price comparisons.... they list an NEC with a 900MHz P3 for
> $2200.  Ummmm... I don't think NEC, or anybody else for that matter,
> sells laptop with 900Mhz Pentium 3 chips in them.  Those prices are
> *way* outdated... so much so it ain't even funny.

In the ultralight laptop realm it's _not_ uncommon to find sub GHz
CPUs.  I imagine it's because they don't have 2 pounds to waste on a
battery just to power Intel's latest and greatest.  Lindows is using the
VIA chip because of its low power characteristics too I'd imagine.  And
those prices are not outdated - $800 is an excellent price for an
ultralight laptop.  

> As somebody else pretty much said... I loathe manipulative marketing
> tactics from Microsoft.  To see it from a Linux company is sickening.

That I agree with, but I don't see anything particularly manipulative
about their marketing, hyperbole definitely though

--Brent

Yes.  In order for the server to serve the site, it needs access.  If
you don't add it to the groups you will need to add world read access. 
This sounds like you don't want none group members to see the site.

Ken

From plug at laynesoftware.com  Sat Feb 22 11:13:01 2003
From: plug at laynesoftware.com (Terry Layne)
Date: Sat Feb 22 11:13:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Netscape vs Mozilla
Message-ID: <20030222191218.M28389@laynesoftware.com>

I've been using Netscape 7.0 instead of Mozilla because of plugin support. 
The one thing I really liked better about Mozilla is that you could block
popups.  To my delight I just discovered that if Netscape and Mozilla are
using the same config directory (~/.mozilla) then you can turn off popups in
Mozilla (Edit->Preferences->Advanced->Scripts & Plugins->Open Unrequested
Windows) and the feature carries over to Netscape.  In the prefs.js file the
line is:

user_pref("dom.disable_open_during_load", true);

I wonder who forced Netscape to leave that feature off of the setup menu?

--
Terry Layne
Portland, OR



From athlonrob at axpr.net  Sat Feb 22 11:17:01 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Feb 22 11:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Netscape vs Mozilla
In-Reply-To: <20030222191218.M28389@laynesoftware.com>
References: <20030222191218.M28389@laynesoftware.com>
Message-ID: <1045941361.11746.14.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sat, 2003-02-22 at 11:12, Terry Layne wrote:
> I've been using Netscape 7.0 instead of Mozilla because of plugin support. 

I assume you're talking GCC 2.95 vs GCC 3.2 plugin problems...

If you're using an up-to-date Moz version (1.2 or up) all the plugins
except for Java work great.  For Java, you should be able to find a
script to rebuild java with GCC 3.2 that'll fix the java plugin
problems.

I have Moz 1.2.1 working with Java, RealPlayer, and Flash... Moz and
Java compiled under GCC 3.2.  Java actually seems a bit faster, but that
could be my imagination.

That's in Gentoo, though.

Rob

From plug at laynesoftware.com  Sat Feb 22 11:44:02 2003
From: plug at laynesoftware.com (Terry Layne)
Date: Sat Feb 22 11:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Netscape vs Mozilla
In-Reply-To: <1045941361.11746.14.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On 22 Feb 2003 11:16:01 -0800, AthlonRob wrote

> had no hands on working knowledge of the operating system and it's 
> tools I would probably have failed.

I believe that when discussing tests, terms like "practical" and "applied
skills" should be interpreted to mean "things I know" whereas terms
like "book knowledge" and "rote memorization" mean "things I don't know."
At least that's how I've always used them. :-)

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Feb 22 12:35:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Feb 22 12:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Netscape vs Mozilla
In-Reply-To: <20030222194301.M89188@laynesoftware.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302221228100.2856-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Sat, 22 Feb 2003, Terry Layne wrote:

> Actually, I was referring to the fact that I've got a bunch of
> plugins working with Netscape and none of them working with Mozilla.  
> I haven't taken the time to fiddle with Mozilla to figure out what
> the problem is. Basically, I do about:plugins in Mozilla and see
> nothing.

There must be some symlinks missing. As root, do

  # season these to taste
  nsplugindir="/usr/lib/netscape/plugins"
  mozplugindir="/usr/lib/mozilla/plugins"
  #
  killall mozilla-bin
  for f in ${nsplugindir}/*
  do
    ln -s $f $mozplugindir
  done

Then, as you:

  mozilla &

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Feb 22 13:59:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sat Feb 22 13:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] I am looking for some different opinions about
	setting up groups
In-Reply-To: <1045933395.3989.106.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
References: <11223721359.20030221213922@starband.net>
	 <1045893709.3988.102.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
	 <17225263496.20030221220504@starband.net>
	 <1045933395.3989.106.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
Message-ID: <1045951112.1923.25.camel@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On Sat, 2003-02-22 at 09:03, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:

> Yes.  In order for the server to serve the site, it needs access.  If
> you don't add it to the groups you will need to add world read access. 
> This sounds like you don't want none group members to see the site.

This is a very bad idea.  The problem with putting Apache in their group
is that any vulnerability in a process running as Apache (Apache itself,
mod_php, mod_perl, mod_python, Java, mod_ssl, any other CGIs or
modules...) immediately gets write access to every one of your
customers' web sites.

There are better ways around this.  Assuming they'll be getting in with
FTP, you can use PureFTPd, which will make a "virtual chroot" into their
home directories, but will follow symlinks out, and IIRC only if they're
owned by an appropriate user, such as root.  So, you chroot them into
their home directories and make symlinks out to their web directories.

Given the choice between letting people see each other's documents and
giving Apache write access, I'd definitely choose the former.  Besides,
Apache only needs world-execute on directories to get access to the
files, unless they're providing open directories.  This should work to
set most directories properly:

  find /path/to/virtual/host -type -d -exec chmod 771 {} \;

And I tend to prefer to name groups after the group, rather than
something generic, like 'group1'.  Unless you're mixing in much older
Linux systems or proprietary UNIX systems, the limit is 16 characters
(although that's only with names added with the 'useradd' utilities;
LDAP can serve much longer names, and I suspect vigr would allow you to
put in longer names too).  So if nothing else, use 'myverylongexam00'.

If you're really going to be hosting many sites, ISPMan
(http://www.ispman.org) is a pretty nice tool.  If you want to hire help
setting it up, call me :)

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *

From jason at vancleve.com  Sat Feb 22 19:37:02 2003
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Sat Feb 22 19:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] (Free?) Admin Work Needed In Barcelona
References: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0302030535210.11431-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <12FFA05C.5070709@vancleve.com>

This may not interest anyone with bills to pay, but I was recently in 
Barcelona, where there is a funky little laundromat/cybercafe in dire 
need of a little networking expertise.  To be blunt, this is a poor 
business in a relatively poor area, but they provide good services, and 
they run Linux (Mandrake, I believe), so I told one of the management I 
would try to help him out.

I'm not really an admin, and I don't know the extent of their woes, but 
their network, if you can call it that, is pretty unstable.  And there 
is a problem with their printer, which I think is because there is no 
print server and their one Wintel box is hogging the machine.  In fact, 
they have no dedicated servers at all, thought my Spanish fellow there 
informs me they "used to".  He speaks decent English, by the way.

I'm just thinking this would be a great opportunity for you 
underemployed admins to practice your skills, since I doubt there is any 
money in it.  These guys are hurting for expertise, and they are open to 
somebody working remotely with them.  Probably a proper firewall would 
be a good start, which may have to be the print server as well.

Just an idea, assuming it's even possible to get things going remotely. 
  (Barcelona is a wonderful city, by the way, if you actually have the 
means to go there.)  Email me if you're curious, and I'll put you in 
contact with this fellow.

--Jason Van Cleve

From sean at fork.com  Sun Feb 23 17:24:01 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Sun Feb 23 17:24:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GNOME2 Background
Message-ID: <20030224012110.C38D1C5CC@max.seansdomain.org>

This script seems to have made a lot of my MAC and Windows user friends 
envious of linux.


#!/bin/sh
rm /tmp/xplanet-*.jpg;
FNAME=xplanet-`date +%s`.jpg &&
 
find ~/.xplanet -name clouds_2000.jpg -cmin +180 -exec rm {} \;
cd ~/.xplanet
 
if  ! [ -f clouds_2000.jpg ]; then
        wget -t0 -c -np -nd http://xplanet.lightbearer.com/clouds_2000.jpg
        xplanet -image earth.jpg -cloud_image clouds_2000.jpg  -shade 100 
-output day-clouds.jpg -geometry 1600x1200
        xplanet -image night.jpg -cloud_image clouds_2000.jpg    -cloud_shade 
30 -output night-clouds.jpg -geometry 1600x1200
fi
nice -n19 xplanet -mapdir ~/.xplanet/ -image day-clouds.jpg -night_image 
night-clouds.jpg -blend -output /tmp/$FNAME -geometry 1600x1200 -proj 
rectangular  &&
gconftool-2 -t string -s /desktop/gnome/background/picture_filename 
/tmp/$FNAME


Combine this script with  

*/5     *       *       *       *       /home/sean/bin/xplanetbg-gnome > 
/dev/null 2>&1


Works great.  I'm sure this script could be cleaned up a little.

Sean

PLAIN')dn

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Sun Feb 23 21:16:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Sun Feb 23 21:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Beowulf
In-Reply-To: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0302232054490.12577-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

From m at pdxlug.org  Mon Feb 24 08:23:01 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon Feb 24 08:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Help! Too Many Files Open????
In-Reply-To: <20030223164143.P19169@defiant.ncplus.net>
References: <20030223164143.P19169@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <10917.12.47.207.4.1046103772.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

lsof | wc -l

cat /proc/sys/fs/file-max

If the lsof command has a number approaching file-max, then:

echo somebiggernumberhere > /proc/sys/fs/file-max


> My rh7.2 (latest updates installed) running on an 800MHz Athlon with
> 768MB ram and lotsa free drive space (~2GB) currently has a load

From fixin at peak.org  Mon Feb 24 09:01:01 2003
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Mon Feb 24 09:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] W2K or XP for dual-boot system?
Message-ID: <20030224090058.A31293@tpol.peak.org>

I'm in the market for a new desktop machine.  It'll run Debian 90% of
the time, but I do handheld software for fun and will need to run
windows occasionally to use the compilers for WinCE.  So it'll be a
dual-boot system.

I seem to have a choice between machines with W2K and XP installed,
and so am wondering if I should care.  My work-issued laptop
dual-boots with W2K and seems fine (and runs all the apps I need).  XP
is newer, and presumably will be current longer; but I worry about its
reputation as spyware and whether it'll be a good citizen on a
dual-boot disk.

Any suggestions or experience to share?  Any good articles on the
subject?

Thanks,

--Eric House
-- 
******************************************************************************
* From the desktop of: Eric House, fixin at peak.org                            *
*    Crosswords 4.0 for PalmOS is out!: <http://www.peak.org/~fixin/xwords>  *
******************************************************************************



From athlonrob at axpr.net  Mon Feb 24 09:44:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Feb 24 09:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] W2K or XP for dual-boot system?
In-Reply-To: <20030224090058.A31293@tpol.peak.org>
References: <20030224090058.A31293@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <1046108599.18092.1.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Mon, 2003-02-24 at 09:00, Eric House wrote:

> I seem to have a choice between machines with W2K and XP installed,
> and so am wondering if I should care.  My work-issued laptop
> dual-boots with W2K and seems fine (and runs all the apps I need).  XP
> is newer, and presumably will be current longer; but I worry about its
> reputation as spyware and whether it'll be a good citizen on a
> dual-boot disk.

Win2K is Windows NT 5.0, WinXP is Windows NT 5.1 - they are *very*
similar.

Neither should give you any problems whatsoever in a dual-boot system.

XP is a bit evil with it's WPA, but if you don't mind that, might as
well go for XP.

Rob




From mikedela at ipns.com  Mon Feb 24 10:16:01 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Mon Feb 24 10:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what generates these reports
Message-ID: <9862MJ9841RMTRSN2WWVXWQ5YMJDBED.3e5a614e@mike>

I get a daily report from a machine that was originally a 
RH7.0 install. I like this report, but I cannot remember or 
find which program generates it. The first lines of the 
report are:

Active System Attack Alerts
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Feb 23 05:50:52 www portsentry[630]: attackalert: Connect 
from host: 75-194.kiev.dialup.ukr.net/212.42.75.194 to TCP 
port: 1080

Then after it flags all of the portsentry and ssh version 
mapper scans, it gives:

Unusual System Events
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Feb 23 04:02:13 www modprobe: modprobe: Can't locate module 
net-pf-10
Feb 23 04:30:01 www kernel: hdd: ATAPI 40X CD-ROM drive, 
128kB Cache

I feel kind of stupid for having to ask, but I've looked for 
this package over and over, it never seems to default install 
anymore, and I don't know what else to do but ask...

From shahms at shahms.com  Mon Feb 24 10:19:01 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Mon Feb 24 10:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what generates these reports
In-Reply-To: <9862MJ9841RMTRSN2WWVXWQ5YMJDBED.3e5a614e@mike>

Message-ID: <1046110681.18074.0.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

I'm pretty sure these reports are generated by a program called
"LogWatch"

rpm -q logwatch to see if it's installed and at what version.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Mon Feb 24 18:44:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Mon Feb 24 18:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Security fix for RH mail spools
Message-ID: <3E5AD864.10202@pacifier.com>

Just noticed this,
http://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2003-057.html

..."When creating a user account, the version of useradd included in Red Hat
Linux 7.2, 7.3, and 8.0 creates a mailbox file with incorrectly-set
group ownership. Instead of setting the file's group ownership to the
'mail' group, it is set to the user's primary group.

On systems where other users share the same primary group, this would allow
those users to be able to read and write other user mailboxes."

Oops.

--
Kyle Accardi





From sean at fork.com  Mon Feb 24 19:10:02 2003

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon Feb 24 19:10:18 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Mon Feb 24 19:10:18 2003
Subject: [PLUG] W2K or XP for dual-boot system?
In-Reply-To: <20030224090058.A31293@tpol.peak.org>
References: <20030224090058.A31293@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <1046142571.17817.23.camel@main>

On Mon, 2003-02-24 at 09:00, Eric House wrote:
> I'm in the market for a new desktop machine.  It'll run Debian 90% of
> the time, but I do handheld software for fun and will need to run
> windows occasionally to use the compilers for WinCE.  So it'll be a
> dual-boot system.
> 
> I seem to have a choice between machines with W2K and XP installed,
> and so am wondering if I should care.  My work-issued laptop
> dual-boots with W2K and seems fine (and runs all the apps I need).  XP
> is newer, and presumably will be current longer; but I worry about its
> reputation as spyware and whether it'll be a good citizen on a
> dual-boot disk.
> 
> Any suggestions or experience to share?  Any good articles on the
> subject?

XP, from my experience, is a bit picky about hardware. Take a look at
the Microsoft compatibility library and make sure your covered before
you install. The install itself will/should print a report about the
hardware that might not be supported but if you know ahead of time you
can have the current specific drivers ready for the OS at install time.

From kens at cad2cam.com  Mon Feb 24 20:44:01 2003
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Mon Feb 24 20:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Help! Too Many Files Open????
In-Reply-To: <10917.12.47.207.4.1046103772.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <20030223164143.P19169@defiant.ncplus.net> 
	<10917.12.47.207.4.1046103772.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <1046148662.17811.9.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>

On Mon, 2003-02-24 at 08:22, Matt Alexander wrote:
> lsof | wc -l
> 
> cat /proc/sys/fs/file-max
> 
> If the lsof command has a number approaching file-max, then:
> 
> echo somebiggernumberhere > /proc/sys/fs/file-max
> 
> 
> > My rh7.2 (latest updates installed) running on an 800MHz Athlon with
> > 768MB ram and lotsa free drive space (~2GB) currently has a load
> > average around 690 and is complaining about having too many files
> > open. I dunno how the load average got so high, but it's taking hours
> > for various things to happen, and I don't really want to push the
> > reset button.
> >
> > Ny question is more on the order of "how can this happen?".
> >
> > -bk
> > --
> > Bruce Kingsland
Do you mount anything using NFS?  The load average tallies blocked tasks
also.  vmstat 2
The 
r b s should add up to your load.

The r is running tasks
The b is blocked tasks
The s is stopped tasks

We find at work that when an NFS server goes down, we get a lot of
blocked tasks.  Sometimes if we are very lucky we can unmount the NFS
mount and remount it.  Most of the time, though, we have to reboot.

Ken

> Linux 7.2, 7.3, and 8.0 creates a mailbox file with incorrectly-set
> group ownership. Instead of setting the file's group ownership to the

enough vitriol.  At the least, this behaviour is downright annoying and 
time comsuming.

possible repercussions -- aren't so funny.

From fixin at peak.org  Tue Feb 25 09:09:01 2003
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)

Subject: [PLUG] Re: W2K or XP for dual-boot system?
In-Reply-To: <20030225074902.32474.54219.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>; from plug-request@lists.pdxlinux.org on Mon, Feb 24, 2003 at 11:49:02PM -0800
References: <20030225074902.32474.54219.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20030225090855.B13806@tpol.peak.org>

> > I seem to have a choice between machines with W2K and XP installed,
> > and so am wondering if I should care.  My work-issued laptop
> > dual-boots with W2K and seems fine (and runs all the apps I need).  XP
> > is newer, and presumably will be current longer; but I worry about its
> > reputation as spyware and whether it'll be a good citizen on a
> > dual-boot disk.
> 
> Win2K is Windows NT 5.0, WinXP is Windows NT 5.1 - they are *very*
> similar.
> 
> Neither should give you any problems whatsoever in a dual-boot system.
> 
> XP is a bit evil with it's WPA, but if you don't mind that, might as
> well go for XP.

It looks as if the problems I've heard about have more to do with the
partition type than the Windoze version.  If XP will let me install it
onto a Fat23 partition, and will use the same swap partition as Linux,
I'll give it a shot.  The WPA stuff could make for some cheap
entertainment: firewall it so it can't talk to the mother ship and
watch it squirm. :-)

The machine I wound up getting, an IBM M41 P4 1800/256/40, comes with
XP.  It's the first machine I've bought in close to five years, and
will be a fun change from the castoff PII/200 systems I'm used to.

Thanks for the help.  I'll post results when I have 'em.

--Eric

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Tue Feb 25 09:30:02 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Tue Feb 25 09:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] official KDE3 debs
Message-ID: <200302250938.29730.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

Running KDE3 on Debian presents some interesting issues; it works fine, if you 
install it correctly. See here for how to:

KDE3 and Debian : Frequently Asked Questions
http://davidpashley.com/debian-kde/faq.html

" Any packages which you download that are not from the official distribution 
may result in you being unable to upgrade to KDE 3 when it does enter Debian. 
If this does occur then you will have to remove KDE completely and then 
reinstall it."

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Tue Feb 25 10:28:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue Feb 25 10:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: W2K or XP for dual-boot system?
In-Reply-To: <20030225090855.B13806@tpol.peak.org>
References: <20030225074902.32474.54219.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
	 <20030225090855.B13806@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <1046197615.6519.6.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Tue, 2003-02-25 at 09:08, Eric House wrote:

> It looks as if the problems I've heard about have more to do with the
> partition type than the Windoze version.  If XP will let me install it
> onto a Fat23 partition, and will use the same swap partition as Linux,
> I'll give it a shot.  The WPA stuff could make for some cheap
> entertainment: firewall it so it can't talk to the mother ship and
> watch it squirm. :-)

Yes you can install onto a FAT32 partition... but Windoze can't take
advantage of swap partitions.  Swapping is always done to a file in
Windoze... you can set up a dedicated FAT partiton to contain nothing
but a static swap file if you want... but it can't use a Linux swap
partition.

Rob

From ed at alcpress.com  Tue Feb 25 13:53:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Tue Feb 25 13:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Alternare TLDs demo
Message-ID: <1046209926.18930.77.camel@red>

At last week's PANUG meeting, I did a presentation on
the alternate DNS Top Level Domains. For those who
want to experience it firsthand, you can use one of
my name servers for a week or two that has been
configured to resolve many of the new TLDs. It, of
course, also resolves the ICANN TLDs like COM, BIZ,
NET, etc.

I don't want to open it up to the entire world so
you'll need to send me your IP address. If your IP
address is doled out by a DHCP server, give me the
first few numbers of your current IP address and
I'll open up that entire sub/supernet. I'll send you
instructions for accessing the name server by return
email.

Once you can resolve the new names, you'll have access
to the slides I used for the presentation.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC




From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Tue Feb 25 13:56:02 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Tue Feb 25 13:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Image conversion
Message-ID: <20030225215536.50259.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com>

There are few situations in which I would benefit from
the use of OCR, but I could imagine circumstances
under which I would want to use it occasionally. 

I was able to get my USB scanner working with SANE,
but the only mode that seems to be supported is 24-bit
color. Most OCR programs require 1-bit input, which
makes sense.

I'm wondering whether it would be feasible to convert
the scanned images containing text from 24-bit to
1-bit, and if so, what software would do it. The only
point in OCR is to save time, so unless the process is
reasonably convenient, it wouldn't be worth the
trouble. 

I may use a Windows OCR program, so if the
image-editing program is for Windows, it would be
acceptable if it works under WINE. 

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

"SAMBA--opening Windows to a wider world."

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Tue Feb 25 18:43:02 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Tue Feb 25 18:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Image conversion & OCR
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOMEPJNEAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <20030226024300.97593.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>

--- Michael Luevane <mikel at quantecllc.com> wrote:
> If you go the Windows route, check out IRFanView -
> http://www.irfanview.com.
> Nice.
>
I scanned the original document at 150 dpi and 24-bit
color depth, since my scanner will not work in black
or gray modes with SANE. The quality of the type used
by the writer was high but not superb.

I used Irfanview under WINE to reduce the color depth
to 1 bit. I then used a Windows OCR program under WINE
to obtain the results below (!!!). If you type like I
do, OCR is still worth doing this way.

COORDINATION, BALANCE, RHYTHM, TIMING.
Most movement activities involve coordination, balance
rhythm and timing. Our visual process directs the
movements of our action system Our action system
carries and moves our visual process. Improving either
ability, the visual process or
the action system, aids the other.

A five by seven developmental trampoline, used as a
tool, not as a toy, is necessary in developing these
abilities. There are routines and procedures to
develop these abilities and rapidly at ayoungage.

Developmental Vision is involved and concerned with
the total being.

CONCLUSION:
Why has the public not heard about Developmental
Vision ? There are factions who have great influence
on daily newspaper editors. When working with children
having learning problems is written about it usually
is, "There is no scientific proof for it." Nonsense !
The scientific evidence is all around us, but there is
a requirement: one must learn how to sec it.

For many years, Developmental Vision bas been
presented to administrators in education at county,
state and national levels without success. No
responses. Perhaps Developmental Vision may he too
difficult to understand. It does require more than
surface logic and it is not a memory course. It
demands abstract thinking, 


=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

"SAMBA--opening Windows to a wider world."



From raanders at acm.org  Tue Feb 25 19:32:01 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue Feb 25 19:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Alternare TLDs demo
In-Reply-To: <5.2.0.9.0.20030225140102.01aa77e8@localhost>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Feb 26 06:50:04 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Feb 26 06:50:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Getting dosemu running again
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302260645470.1972-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I know some of you are successfully running dosemu. Yesterday I spent a
little time trying to get it running again here and made some progress.
However, when invoking the emulator I now get continuous error messages
writing to the screen.

  Below is the response I sent to the linux-msdos mail list and an
individual who offered some thoughts last month. If anyone here has insight
into solving the current error, please let me know.

Thanks,

Rich
--------------------------------------------------------------------

On Sun, 12 Jan 2003, Bonz wrote:

> An alternative approach is to create a large dosimage as per the
> instructions & sit this atop a linux partition which has ext3 protection
> & nowhere near as many problems with geometry of drives.

  Progress, I think.

  I made soft links from /var/lib/dosemu/bootdir.first/ to all the
directories in /dos7/. Then I modifed /etc/dosemu.conf so $_hdimage points
to bootdir.first.

  In the QuickStart doc file, it suggests inoking dosemu with 'dos -O
2>/tmp/error.out'. I tried that and nothing happened. I was back at the bash
prompt once again. So I tried what worked before, 'dos -C' (for color). Once
again, I saw this:

> Linux DOS emulator 1.0.0.0 $Date: 2000/03/05 $
> Last configured at Sun Mar  5 21:50:56 MET 2000 on linux
> This is work in progress.
> Please test against a recent version before reporting bugs and problems.
> Bugs, Patches & New Code to linux-msdos at vger.rutgers.edu
> 
> DPMI-Server Version 0.9 installed

  Nothing after this, so I pressed [Enter] and a non-stop race of:

ERROR: HLT requested: lina=0x5fbc!

kept scrolling by until I killed the process.

  Can someone please explain this error to me, and suggest how to fix the
problem?

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Wed Feb 26 08:37:02 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Feb 26 08:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard for linux?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302260704080.2229-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302260704080.2229-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1046277367.15918.8.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Wed, 2003-02-26 at 07:04, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Anyone here know anything about the DFI AK75-EC KT133A motherboard for a
> linux box?

A KT133A board shouldn't have any problems at all.  If it uses
integrated audio, video, or LAN, you *could* run in to problems, but at
least audio and LAN are generally well supported.  If it's an SiS video
chip, I think you could have problems.

Rob

From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org

--- Michael Luevane <mikel at quantecllc.com> wrote:
> If you go the Windows route, check out IRFanView -
> http://www.irfanview.com.
> Nice.
>
I scanned the original document at 150 dpi and 24-bit
color depth, since my scanner will not work in black
or gray modes with SANE. The quality of the type used
by the writer was high but not superb.

I used Irfanview under WINE to reduce the color depth
to 1 bit. I then used a Windows OCR program under WINE
to obtain the results below (!!!). If you type like I
do, OCR is still worth doing this way.

COORDINATION, BALANCE, RHYTHM, TIMING.
Most movement activities involve coordination, balance
rhythm and timing. Our visual process directs the
movements of our action system Our action system
carries and moves our visual process. Improving either
ability, the visual process or
the action system, aids the other.

A five by seven developmental trampoline, used as a
tool, not as a toy, is necessary in developing these
abilities. There are routines and procedures to
develop these abilities and rapidly at ayoungage.

Developmental Vision is involved and concerned with
the total being.

CONCLUSION:
Why has the public not heard about Developmental
Vision ? There are factions who have great influence
on daily newspaper editors. When working with children
having learning problems is written about it usually
is, "There is no scientific proof for it." Nonsense !
The scientific evidence is all around us, but there is
a requirement: one must learn how to sec it.

For many years, Developmental Vision bas been
presented to administrators in education at county,
state and national levels without success. No
responses. Perhaps Developmental Vision may he too
difficult to understand. It does require more than
surface logic and it is not a memory course. It
demands abstract thinking, 


=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/
