> integrated audio, video, or LAN, you *could* run in to problems, but at
> least audio and LAN are generally well supported.  If it's an SiS video

non-functional by jumpers? I've always been leery of putting all my eggs in
one basket.

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Wed Feb 26 09:27:01 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Feb 26 09:27:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard for linux?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302260853160.2402-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302260853160.2402-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1046280317.15918.14.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Wed, 2003-02-26 at 08:54, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   If any of these functions are on the board, can't they be made
> non-functional by jumpers? I've always been leery of putting all my eggs in
> one basket.

Generally they can be jumpered off, turned off in the BIOS, or (in the
case of integrated video, anyway) automatically turn off when whatever
the component is is plugged in to the board.  ie; integrated video goes
off when you plug in an AGP card.

Rob




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Feb 26 09:47:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Feb 26 09:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard for linux?
In-Reply-To: <1046280317.15918.14.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302260944560.2402-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 26 Feb 2003, AthlonRob wrote:

> Generally they can be jumpered off, turned off in the BIOS, or (in the
> case of integrated video, anyway) automatically turn off when whatever
> the component is is plugged in to the board.  ie; integrated video goes
> off when you plug in an AGP card.
 
Rob,

  That's what I thought. My systems are several years old and I don't keep
up with hardware so it's good to read confirmation.

Rich

From cb at onsitetech.com  Wed Feb 26 10:57:01 2003
From: cb at onsitetech.com (Christian Brink)
Date: Wed Feb 26 10:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Most effective way to count tar files on tape
Message-ID: <ENEFIFGGPEDGDJMEMKECAEHDGNAA.cb@onsitetech.com>

Is there an easy way to count the number of tar files existing on a tape
with 'mt' or another utility. I have some thing in mind, but I don't like it
(it's fairly time consuming and inefficient).

Also is there an effective way to clear all the files on a tape.


My Situation:
I am writing a set of files to a SCSI multichanger tape drive on a daily
basis. I switch tapes on a weekly basis. Once I cycle through all the tapes
I would like to blank the previously written to tape since most likely the
new archive will over write the BOF marker for the second set which will
confuse who ever is restoring from that if they do so before the entire tape
is rewritten.

Also I would like to track the file number of a particular archive, but I
can not do that without a count (without ensuring that backup program always
runs everyday at the same time and the beginning of the cycle always happens
on a Sunday - which as you can understand is impossible :( ).

Thanks,

Christian




From ed at alcpress.com  Wed Feb 26 11:32:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Wed Feb 26 11:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS security survey
Message-ID: <1046287878.18930.141.camel@red>

I'm doing a survey of ISPs to see how many are using
DNS configurations that are prone to DNS security
problems like cache poisoning. You can help by letting
me know the IP addresses of the "name servers" your
ISP has asked you to use when you subscribed to their
service. Normally, they give you two addresses but more
is OK. I have Easystreet covered.

I'll share the results with you when I'm finished.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>

American Heritage:
rag?tag
adj.

    1. Shaggy or unkempt; ragged.
    2. Diverse and disorderly in appearance or composition: ?They're a 
small ragtag army of racketeers, bandits, and murderers? (Thomas P. 
O'Neill, Jr.).

Rich,

I'm pretty partial to the Athlon XP 1800+.  It runs at
1538MHz, but performs like an Intel 1800MHz processor,
if you believe the marketing.  

But the processor is fast, reliable, and I've had no
problems with compatibility.  And ENU Inc on the west
side sells it with a fan for $79.  Pretty cheap for
what you get, I think.

I have nothing but good things to say about the Athlon XP processors. I'm 
running a 2000+ in my desktop system, and an Athlon 1ghz in two of my servers.

and up. The ECS motherboard seems to be a decent board for a general 
purpose board. I've put a few of those in systems, although I do have a 
Soyo KT333 in my workstation.

From john at johntelford.com  Wed Feb 26 17:26:02 2003
From: john at johntelford.com (John Telford)
Date: Wed Feb 26 17:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Reading ITnews
Message-ID: <20030227012453.GA18871@lnx2.labnet>

Buried in the daily barrage of PR and FUD being spewed forth daily by
the Information Technology (IT) industry are what I considers a few
kernels of truth and gems.  

An easy way of keeping up to date is to regularly visit the ITnews
Weblog (http://itnews.johntelford.com).  This local ad-free site
provides daily coverage of Linux and many other technologies.

I've been busy building ITnews and publishing articles since creating it
2 months ago.  There are 600 published articles and commentary.  Each
article contains links to the original story and Web site.  Material for
articles is coming from hard copy industry publications and from 50 IT
news sources syndicating 6,000 stories.

Finding something of interest in the 600 published articles is a simple
matter when using the Article Search facility.  You can read articles
posted on any day or month.  The ITnews home page contains articles
posted during the last week.

I hope you enjoy reading ITnews.

-- 
John Telford - Owner
JohnTelford.com LLC
503-292-6865 - fax:503-292-3094
john at johntelford.com - www.johntelford.com
Weblog: ITnews.johntelford.com

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Wed Feb 26 20:59:02 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Wed Feb 26 20:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] long-term data storage
Message-ID: <200302262107.33412.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

Is there any medium besides paper that you trust for long-term data storage? 
Seems like looking beyond five years gets iffy. What about 10-30 years? Which 
still isn't that long, compared to books and magazines. 

Seems to me any magnetic media, such as tape and hard drives, are inherently 
risky. Optical disks might last longer, assuming the means to read them 
survives. I've heard more than one passionate rant about "CDROMs will 
spontaneously delaminate, mark my words, and then you'll be sorry!" I have 
five-year old CDROMs that still work, my precious Quake and DOOM cds.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Feb 26 21:16:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Wed Feb 26 21:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] long-term data storage
In-Reply-To: <200302262107.33412.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200302262107.33412.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <864r6qgv7z.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Carla" == Carla Schroder <pluglist at bratgrrl.com> writes:

Carla> Is there any medium besides paper that you trust for long-term
Carla> data storage?  Seems like looking beyond five years gets
Carla> iffy. What about 10-30 years? Which still isn't that long,
Carla> compared to books and magazines.

I recently went back to 10-14 year-old floppies (720k 3.5-inchers) and
could read all but 3 out of about 200 (I am not sure the failure rate
was any better at the time!).  I could read all of my 5.25-inch 360k
floppies from the mid-1980's, nearly 20 years old.

Probably a good strategy is to periodically flip the data onto new
media, and not rely on dusty backups whatever their media.  I am
inclined to make archive copies, but keep hot ones on a hard disk
too.  Write down md5sums (or whatever) in a log book for comparison. 

--

seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower, more
                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!''

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Feb 27 06:21:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Feb 27 06:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] long-term data storage
In-Reply-To: <200302262107.33412.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302270610190.5771-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 26 Feb 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Is there any medium besides paper that you trust for long-term data storage? 
> Seems like looking beyond five years gets iffy. What about 10-30 years? Which 
> still isn't that long, compared to books and magazines. 

Carla,

  I am not an expert on the subject of archival permanence of data and
records. But, everything I've read from those who are experts suggest that
the answer to your question is, "no". We all know what happened to the 8"
floppy disk (and the 5.25" one, too) and the early WORM drives. Not to
mention the Cauzen strip reader and the 1/2" mag tapes on large, open reels.

  More recently (within the past month) I have read that while
commercially-burned cdroms may last quite a few years (if the readers are
still available then), home-made ones don't. I don't think it's a
delamination problem but the shallowness of the pits from the low power
lasers used to burn them. And the re-writable disks are even worse.

  There was a detailed examination of this issue in the last Technology
Quarterly published by "The Eonomist". Among those who know there is great
concern that the Smithsonian, Library of Congress and other archival
institutions are making digital copies of irreplaceable documents then
destroying the originals.

  Paper, on the other hand, will last forever if kept dry and unburned. Go
to your local landfill and you can find newspapers from 50 or more years ago
that are still readable. And we have photographs from 150 years ago that
show no signs of deterioration.

  If it's _really_ important, print it on quality paper and file it away.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard at appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/

  It was reading this article that prompted my question. The article doesn't
answer it, but the box-builder used a Duron.

From kgoins at aracnet.com  Thu Feb 27 06:25:02 2003
From: kgoins at aracnet.com (Kirk Goins)
Date: Thu Feb 27 06:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] What happens when...
References: <97650-22003242022314718@bctonline.com> <1045801597.2741.44.camel@main> <3E563CBB.4060603@aracnet.com> <200302210940.34353.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <3E5E1F89.8080009@aracnet.com>

An expensive fix, but it worked

Thanks

Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Friday 21 February 2003 06:50 am, Kirk Goins wrote:
> 
>>#1 If I boot my original CDs and re-install, do I loose all my cfg setting
>>or just end up replacing executables and the like?
> 
> 
> Depends on how your system is partitioned, and what options your installer 
> has. usually installs are partition-based, so if /home and /etc, for example, 
> are in their own partitions, you can leave them alone and re-do everything 
> else.
> 
> 
>>#2 Let's say I have this system that can't complete booting because it gets
>>to the point of wanting to mount /proc and it can't find the mount cmd. I
>>can boot from CD, go to rescue, mount the partitions under /mnt and see the
>>data. Can I install a new drive, install Linux on it, plug in the old drive
>>as physical drive #2 and be able to recover files and such from it?
>>
> 
> 
> Yes indeedy! That's my fave method, over trying to repair a drive with boot 
> problems, for me it goes faster. Doubtless our ancient wizened Linux wizards 
> can surgically repair anything, this lowly grasshopper fumble and bumbles 
> until things work right. ;-)
> 





From alex at daniloff.com  Thu Feb 27 08:35:02 2003
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Thu Feb 27 08:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Random segmentation faults --> =?iso-8859-1?q?Software,hardware=3F=3F=3F?=
Message-ID: <200302271634.h1RGYH016441@gate.daniloff.com>

Hello Linux folkz,
I've noticed random seg fault problem when
I compiled some applications from its sources.
Sometimes the same application compiled without problems.
Sometimes it exits with seg fault error.
Sometimes when I'm changing directories with cd and looking files with
less.
I'm getting random segmentation fault error as well.
Could somebody please point me what could be source of this problem?
Filesystem? I'm using ReiserFS.
Hardware, memory, hard drives?
This computer built on Tyan Tiger S2460 mobo with 3GB SDRAM and dual
Athlom MP 1500+ CPU's.
Recently I've changed failed IBM Deskstar 40Gb on the same but newer
edition.
Or something else?

From plug at laynesoftware.com  Thu Feb 27 08:49:02 2003
From: plug at laynesoftware.com (Terry Layne)
Date: Thu Feb 27 08:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Random segmentation faults --> Software,hardware???
In-Reply-To: <200302271634.h1RGYH016441@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200302271634.h1RGYH016441@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <20030227164742.M46253@laynesoftware.com>

On Thu, 27 Feb 2003 08:34:17 -0800, Alex Daniloff wrote
> Hello Linux folkz,
> I've noticed random seg fault problem when
> I compiled some applications from its sources.
> Sometimes the same application compiled without problems.
> Sometimes it exits with seg fault error.
> Sometimes when I'm changing directories with cd and looking files 
> with less. I'm getting random segmentation fault error as well. 
> Could somebody please point me what could be source of this problem? 
> Filesystem? I'm using ReiserFS. Hardware, memory, hard drives? This 
> computer built on Tyan Tiger S2460 mobo with 3GB SDRAM and dual 
> Athlom MP 1500+ CPU's. Recently I've changed failed IBM Deskstar 
> 40Gb on the same but newer edition. Or something else? Many thanks 
> in advance for any thoughts or ideas.

Random seg faults are probably a memory problem.  They tend to show up during
compiles because you have lots of pointers and a bad bit in a pointer tends to
point to somewhere it shouldn't.  Have a look at this page:

http://www.bitwizard.nl/sig11/

Memtest86 is a decent tool for testing memory.  I had a system with bad memory
that I fixed with the BadRAM kernel module, but with the price of memory these
days, it's probably not worth the hassle.

--
Terry Layne
Portland, OR

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Thu Feb 27 09:09:02 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Thu Feb 27 09:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] AMD CPUs for a linux workstation
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302261415240.3055-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302261415240.3055-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200302271049.53775.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

Tom's Hardware benchmarked 65 processors and posted the results last week in 
this article

http://www.tomshardware.com/cpu/20030217/index.html

Each successive Athlon represents a reasonable gain over the previous model 
until the 3000+, which really isn't much better than the 2800+ and can't be 
overclocked much.  Tom's results and a price list from your favorite vendor 
should give you a quick assessment of bang-for-the-buck.

You might also want to look at their review of the 3000+, which is available 
at

http://www.tomshardware.com/cpu/20030210/index.html

Tom's is generally a fan of AMD but points out that the Athlon has had a 
longer lifespan than any other modern processor and it is past time to move 
to the 64-bit Opteron or Athlon 64, which are expected to hit the shelves 
before mid-year and in the fall, respectively.  See the AMD processor roadmap

http://www.amd.com/us-en/Processors/ProductInformation/0,,30_118_608,00.html

for more information.  So, no current Athlon is bleeding edge, unless you mean 
bleeding in a financial sense.

Enjoy!

Mark

On Wednesday 26 February 2003 16:17, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I've looked at AMD's Web site and learn nothing useful about their
> different processor lines: Athlon, Duron and Moron. Ignoring the marketing
> hype, what would be the best _value_ for a behind-the-bleeding-edge
> workstation/server?
>
>   Thanks.
>
> Rich

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Thu Feb 27 09:14:01 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Thu Feb 27 09:14:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] long-term data storage
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302270610190.5771-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302270610190.5771-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200302271055.06983.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

I second what Rich said and just wanted to point out that there is an 
interesting article on this topic in the October 2002 "Technology Review".

On Thursday 27 February 2003 08:19, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Wed, 26 Feb 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > Is there any medium besides paper that you trust for long-term data
> > storage? Seems like looking beyond five years gets iffy. What about 10-30
> > years? Which still isn't that long, compared to books and magazines.
>
> Carla,
>
>   I am not an expert on the subject of archival permanence of data and
> records. But, everything I've read from those who are experts suggest that
> the answer to your question is, "no". We all know what happened to the 8"
> floppy disk (and the 5.25" one, too) and the early WORM drives. Not to
> mention the Cauzen strip reader and the 1/2" mag tapes on large, open
> reels.
>
>   More recently (within the past month) I have read that while
> commercially-burned cdroms may last quite a few years (if the readers are
> still available then), home-made ones don't. I don't think it's a
> delamination problem but the shallowness of the pits from the low power
> lasers used to burn them. And the re-writable disks are even worse.
>
>   There was a detailed examination of this issue in the last Technology
> Quarterly published by "The Eonomist". Among those who know there is great
> concern that the Smithsonian, Library of Congress and other archival
> institutions are making digital copies of irreplaceable documents then
> destroying the originals.
>
>   Paper, on the other hand, will last forever if kept dry and unburned. Go
> to your local landfill and you can find newspapers from 50 or more years
> ago that are still readable. And we have photographs from 150 years ago
> that show no signs of deterioration.
>
>   If it's _really_ important, print it on quality paper and file it away.
>
> Rich
-- 
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Mark A. Martin, Ph.D.
Applied Mathematics -- Software Development -- Systems Administration
Currently available for employment.
See http://www.amath.washington.edu/~mmartin/resume/ for details.
---------------------------------------------------------------------




From ed at alcpress.com  Thu Feb 27 09:19:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Thu Feb 27 09:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] long-term data storage
In-Reply-To: <200302262107.33412.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200302262107.33412.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1046366300.18930.202.camel@red>

On Wed, 2003-02-26 at 21:07, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Is there any medium besides paper that you trust for long-term data storage? 
> Seems like looking beyond five years gets iffy. What about 10-30 years? Which 
> still isn't that long, compared to books and magazines. 
> 
> Seems to me any magnetic media, such as tape and hard drives, are inherently 
> risky. Optical disks might last longer, assuming the means to read them 
> survives. I've heard more than one passionate rant about "CDROMs will 
> spontaneously delaminate, mark my words, and then you'll be sorry!" I have 
> five-year old CDROMs that still work, my precious Quake and DOOM cds.

I studied this issue a while back for a customer. I did
some informal testing as well. I had an extensive library
of diskettes that was indexed with a database so I knew
when the diskette was placed in the library. I noticed
that errors started occurring in diskettes that were over
6 years old and by 10 years the failure rate was nearly
50 percent. At 15 years, the majority of the diskettes
were unreadable.

My old 9 track tapes were still readable after more than
10 years - just in time for them to become obsolete.
I have spools of punched paper tape whose holes haven't
yet grown in, so they're still readable but I sold my last
paper tape reader a few years ago.

I now archive to optical media and I've put two new CD-ROM
drives in storage for the future. My archives tend to be
cumulative - I'm backing up the same old data along with the
new data simultaneously, so the age of the media is not as
critical. If I were not able to do that, I'd make copies of
my archives every decade or so.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Feb 27 09:23:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Feb 27 09:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] AMD CPUs for a linux workstation
In-Reply-To: <200302271049.53775.mmartin@u.washington.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302270916200.6329-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 27 Feb 2003, Mark Martin wrote:

> Tom's Hardware benchmarked 65 processors and posted the results last week in 
> this article
> 
> http://www.tomshardware.com/cpu/20030217/index.html

  Thanks, Mark.
 
> Tom's is generally a fan of AMD but points out that the Athlon has had a 
> longer lifespan than any other modern processor and it is past time to move 
> to the 64-bit Opteron or Athlon 64, which are expected to hit the shelves 
> before mid-year and in the fall, respectively.  See the AMD processor roadmap

  The primary use of the system determines what processor is most
appropriate. For writing, accounting, spreadsheets, e-mail and other
user-bound work the cpu speed and bit size is not terribly important. For a
machine on which I would be running spatial and
hydrologic/hydraulic/sediment transport models or fuzzy decision support
models I could justify a fast, 64-bit, multiple-cpu configuration. Actually,
for the low-end stuff, the current (~5 year old) PII/333MHz system is plenty
fast.

Rich

From ed at alcpress.com  Thu Feb 27 09:40:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Thu Feb 27 09:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS security survey
In-Reply-To: <1046287878.18930.141.camel@red>
References: <1046287878.18930.141.camel@red>
Message-ID: <1046367508.18931.218.camel@red>

Thanks to everyone who responded to the survey. I've
analyzed about 20 ISPs. The results show that about
75% of them have their customers resolve names using
their authoritative name servers. The problem with
this is the risk of cache poisoning, which has been
a problem with BIND and some claim with Windows 2000
DNS as well.

It seems that it would be wise to run your own DNS
as long as you don't do the same thing the ISPs are
doing.

Ed

This sounds like a customer of mine who wants to update his systems
because they're "old". They still work great and there's no

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Feb 27 09:54:01 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu Feb 27 09:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] AMD CPUs for a linux workstation
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302270916200.6329-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

Message-ID: <20030227175230.GI20365@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, Feb 27, 2003 at 09:21:41AM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Thu, 27 Feb 2003, Mark Martin wrote:
> 
>   The primary use of the system determines what processor is most
> appropriate. For writing, accounting, spreadsheets, e-mail and other
> user-bound work the cpu speed and bit size is not terribly important. For a
> machine on which I would be running spatial and
> hydrologic/hydraulic/sediment transport models or fuzzy decision support
> models I could justify a fast, 64-bit, multiple-cpu configuration. Actually,
> for the low-end stuff, the current (~5 year old) PII/333MHz system is plenty
> fast.

Unless the application is threaded or otherwise takes advantage of SMP,
the multi-cpu route won't help much.  However, the good news is that
you can buy used rack mount hardware like the Compaq Proliant 1850L
(512 Mb memory, Raid, Dual PIII-700 MHz Xeon server processors) for
about $1K on ebay, and there are quad boxes every once in a while for
more.  If your PII/333 is okay for the slow stuff, then one of those
might be a good buy.

Colin



From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Thu Feb 27 10:18:01 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Thu Feb 27 10:18:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS security survey
In-Reply-To: <1046367508.18931.218.camel@red>
References: <1046287878.18930.141.camel@red> <1046367508.18931.218.camel@red>
Message-ID: <200302271026.37401.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Thursday 27 February 2003 09:38 am, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> Thanks to everyone who responded to the survey. I've
> analyzed about 20 ISPs. The results show that about
> 75% of them have their customers resolve names using
> their authoritative name servers. The problem with
> this is the risk of cache poisoning, which has been
> a problem with BIND and some claim with Windows 2000
> DNS as well.


But do not even the BIND docs say to do this? Why yes, they do:
http://www.isc.org/tn/isc-tn-2002-2.txt

"1.3. Security Considerations -- Although BIND can provide both functions
   (authoritative and non-authoritative) in single instance, ISC recommends
   always separating these two functions.  In other words, you should run
   one server for your authoritative zones, and another that caches non-
   authoritative data.  Reasons include:

   -  Authoritative and non-authoritative data are served to different sets
      of clients.  In order to serve authoritative data to the Internet,
      the nameserver must be outside any firewalls.  However, caching
      nameservers should generally be placed inside firewalls to protect
      them from outside abuse."

So if DNS admins are following instructions, what's the problem?

--

Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~



From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Thu Feb 27 10:37:01 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Thu Feb 27 10:37:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] long-term data storage
In-Reply-To: <200302262107.33412.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302270938220.18838-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

Carla,

    This is a topic that I could go on about for quite some time, but ...
I recommend clay or stone tablets.  We have and can read clay and stone
tablets that are thousands of years old.  Of course, you may prefer paper.
Paper is easier to use and works pretty well depending on how the paper
was created and how careful you are storing it.  The dead sea scrolls
from around the time of Christ are in pretty bad shape, but we can read
many of them.  In more practical terms, my family has books, letters,
and photographs dating back to 1870 or so.  In most cases, the paper has
lasted quite well but the book bindings have fallen apart and the images
on the letters and photographs have faded.  Moreover, the letters are a
bit difficult to read, because of the languages and hand writing styles
used.  The photographs have lost value due to lack of meta data.
In other words, no one is still alive who knows who was photographed.

    Modern digital media is very bad in terms of long term storage.
As libraries, historical societies, and other institutions become
more and more digital, we are storing more and more of our culture
on transient media that requires constant maintenance by highly skilled
people.  If something happens in our society (war, economic depression,
total social chaos, etc) and we have to mothball everything for a
generation or two, we risk losing a lot of information of cultural
importance.

    In practical terms, we have to use digital media for many many things
and I wouldn't trust any digital storage system for more than about five
years.  Media breaks down.  Formats change.  Software to read
the data change.  Interfaces change so old tape drives or card readers
or whatever become unusable.  I have seen a lot of data lost due to
factors of this sort.  One really has to maintain data constantly
(at least once every five years) or it goes away.

I'm currently looking at some old nine track tapes.  One of them is dated
June 19, 1979.  The tapes have not been stored in good facilities; but
surprisingly I have been able to read most of them without error.  On
the other hand, this doesn't do much good since many of them are in a
variety of proprietary CDC or Prime or DG formats.  However, it has
been fun.

                                                       Dave Mandel
On Wed, 26 Feb 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Is there any medium besides paper that you trust for long-term data storage?
> Seems like looking beyond five years gets iffy. What about 10-30 years? Which
> still isn't that long, compared to books and magazines.
>
> Seems to me any magnetic media, such as tape and hard drives, are inherently
> risky. Optical disks might last longer, assuming the means to read them
> survives. I've heard more than one passionate rant about "CDROMs will
> spontaneously delaminate, mark my words, and then you'll be sorry!" I have
> five-year old CDROMs that still work, my precious Quake and DOOM cds.
>
> --

From ed at alcpress.com  Thu Feb 27 10:39:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Thu Feb 27 10:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS security survey
In-Reply-To: <200302271026.37401.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <1046287878.18930.141.camel@red>
	 <1046367508.18931.218.camel@red> <200302271026.37401.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1046371064.18926.236.camel@red>

On Thu, 2003-02-27 at 10:26, Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Thursday 27 February 2003 09:38 am, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> > Thanks to everyone who responded to the survey. I've
> > analyzed about 20 ISPs. The results show that about
> > 75% of them have their customers resolve names using
> > their authoritative name servers. The problem with
> > this is the risk of cache poisoning, which has been
> > a problem with BIND and some claim with Windows 2000
> > DNS as well.
> 
> 
> But do not even the BIND docs say to do this? Why yes, they do:
> http://www.isc.org/tn/isc-tn-2002-2.txt
> 
> "1.3. Security Considerations -- Although BIND can provide both functions
>    (authoritative and non-authoritative) in single instance, ISC recommends
>    always separating these two functions.  In other words, you should run
>    one server for your authoritative zones, and another that caches non-
>    authoritative data.  Reasons include:
> 
>    -  Authoritative and non-authoritative data are served to different sets
>       of clients.  In order to serve authoritative data to the Internet,
>       the nameserver must be outside any firewalls.  However, caching
>       nameservers should generally be placed inside firewalls to protect
>       them from outside abuse."

This advice from ISC is recent. No such advice existed two years
ago even though cache poisoning was known to be a problem before
then. I don't think O'Reily's DNS and BIND book mentioned this in
it's first edition (Cricket added it to the second edition released
last year). Many DNS admins learned their craft from this book
(first edition). I haven't researched whether Microsoft mentions
this in their documents.

> So if DNS admins are following instructions, what's the problem?

A rhetorical question? :-)

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC




From ed at alcpress.com  Thu Feb 27 11:05:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Thu Feb 27 11:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS security survey
In-Reply-To: <200302271026.37401.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <1046287878.18930.141.camel@red>
	 <1046367508.18931.218.camel@red> <200302271026.37401.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1046372629.18926.262.camel@red>

On Thu, 2003-02-27 at 10:26, Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Thursday 27 February 2003 09:38 am, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> > Thanks to everyone who responded to the survey. I've
> > analyzed about 20 ISPs. The results show that about
> > 75% of them have their customers resolve names using
> > their authoritative name servers. The problem with
> > this is the risk of cache poisoning, which has been
> > a problem with BIND and some claim with Windows 2000
> > DNS as well.
> 
> 
> But do not even the BIND docs say to do this? Why yes, they do:
> http://www.isc.org/tn/isc-tn-2002-2.txt
> 
> "1.3. Security Considerations -- Although BIND can provide both functions
>    (authoritative and non-authoritative) in single instance, ISC recommends
>    always separating these two functions.  In other words, you should run
>    one server for your authoritative zones, and another that caches non-
>    authoritative data.  Reasons include:
> 
>    -  Authoritative and non-authoritative data are served to different sets
>       of clients.  In order to serve authoritative data to the Internet,
>       the nameserver must be outside any firewalls.  However, caching
>       nameservers should generally be placed inside firewalls to protect
>       them from outside abuse."

A few things to think about:

If ISC recommends that you ALWAYS separate these two functions,
why does BIND combine both functions in one program?
If your answer is that it's legacy - that early design didn't
consider cache poisoning, why then does BIND 9 - a recent total
rewrite of the code - continue to combine the functions?

Why is there only one UDP port for the DNS protocol, thus
preventing both functions to be running in their own daemons
on the same computer?

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC




From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Thu Feb 27 11:08:02 2003

Date: Thu Feb 27 11:08:02 2003

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Thu Feb 27 11:11:01 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Thu Feb 27 11:11:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] AMD CPUs for a linux workstation
In-Reply-To: <1046368057.18935.226.camel@red>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302270916200.6329-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <1046368057.18935.226.camel@red>
Message-ID: <200302271252.40500.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

I guess I wasn't clear when I said "it is past time to move to the 64-bit 
Opteron or Athlon 64".  What Tom's Hardware meant (and what I garbled in my 
message) was that they think that it is time for AMD to release their 64-bit 
processors.  Whether or not you purchase them is up to you.

I personally would like to "move to the 64-bit Opteron of Athlon 64", which 
for me wouldn't just be change for the sake of change.  I have calculations 
that I would very much like to do that would currently take more than a month 
using my current (6-year-old) hardware.  This is too long to be practical.  
But, in any case, I wasn't making a suggestion regarding what Rich should 
purchase, only supplying information to help him and others make their own 
decisions.

I could take full advantage of a system with as many 64-bit, high-clock-speed 
processors as I could muster and there are other people in this category as 
well.  But, even for someone with my processing requirements/ambitions, the 
typically nonlinear relationship between price and processing power means 
that investing in a larger number of older, lower cost, lower power 
processors generally makes more sense (assuming that you can parallelize your 
application in a reasonable way).  Of course, the requirements on the typical 
server or workstation are much, much lower and buying the latest and greatest 
for the typical server or workstation is completely superfluous.  Purchasing 
should always be done in light of current and future requirements, capacity 
planning, and budgeting.

Tom's point was that, as far as the cutting/bleeding edge goes, the Athlon has 
reached the end of it's lifespan.  The architecture is over 5 years old and 
has reached the point of diminishing returns with respect to performance 
gains.  The Athlon is a great architecture, which is why it has been so 
durable and extensible, but AMD has been delaying their next generation 
products so they can milk every last dime possible from the 32-bit Athlon.  
This has made business sense but is making less and less sense as Intel 
pushes the envelope further and further.  According to what I've read, it 
seems that the primary thing keeping the Athlons competitive (on the high 
end) right now are the shortcomings in the chipsets supporting the P4's, 
which prevent systems from taking advantage of the full capacities of the 
P4's.  Another attractive feature for some of us is AMD's continued support 
of multiprocessor architectures.  If AMD released their next generation 
processors, it would benefit people who purchase processors at all points 
along the cost spectrum since decreases in the prices of lower-end processors 
almost inevitably accompany the release of more powerful processors.

Sorry for the confusion,

Mark

On Thursday 27 February 2003 11:47, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> On Thu, 2003-02-27 at 09:21, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > On Thu, 27 Feb 2003, Mark Martin wrote:
> > > Tom's is generally a fan of AMD but points out that the Athlon has had
> > > a longer lifespan than any other modern processor and it is past time
> > > to move to the 64-bit Opteron or Athlon 64
>
> change for the sake of change?
>
> This sounds like a customer of mine who wants to update his systems
> because they're "old". They still work great and there's no
> indication there's a capacity or speed problem.
--

Mark A. Martin, Ph.D.

Currently available for employment.

From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Feb 27 13:51:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Thu Feb 27 13:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Hotsites/coldsites
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOIEKNNFAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOIEKNNFAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <20030227215014.GB19560@rauhaus.org>

* Michael Luevane <mikel at quantecllc.com> [030227 11:19]:
> 
> Does anyone out there on this fine list have information about
> hotsites/coldsites in the Portland area?  I'm in the process of developing
> disaster recovery/business continuity documentation and procedures and this
> is one option that I need to put down (not that we'll use it, most likely).

You might want to be careful about your definitions, as disaster
recovery can mean very different things to different people.
I've not be directly involved in the process, but for a medium to large
sized organization, auditors have specific requirements for the whole
disaster recovery thing that are along the lines of being able to continue
business operations within X number of hours of Portland being off the map.

So even a DR facility on the West Coast is too close for them.

--Stafford

From keith at ahapala.net  Thu Feb 27 14:22:01 2003
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Thu Feb 27 14:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail Network Options
Message-ID: <33205.63.105.27.245.1046384461.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>

A client of mine is putting in another office location and I am to put in
a server there. Right now they only have one office (we'll call it
office1) with a fixed IP and their mail and website are on the
server(server1) there. I will be installing server2 in office2 on it's own
fixed-IP DSL line. I'm exploring the different options for delivering mail
from server1 to server2.

1) First thought was to just put .forward for each user to send the mail
to user at new.ip and setup postfix to accept mail to the IP. For office2 to
add a new user, they would have to add the user into server1, add a
..forward, and add the user to server2. Of course, if server1 is
inaccessible office2 doesn't get their mail.

2) Don't do the .forward routine and just have all mail that doesn't have
a user on server1 forwarded to the server2 and then bounced if there is no
user. This is easier maintenance-wise but has the same fault of server1
going down.

3) Set up the upstream DNS MX records to point server1.domain.com to one
IP and server2.domain.com to the other IP. This avoids the server1 link
problem. My question is whether or not the users could still have
user at domain.com addresses at the office2 location or would they have to
have user at server2.domain.com as their addresses. I'm guessing that they
would have to be user at server2.domain.com.

This is my first dealing with multiple physical locations under the same
domain so I'd like to get more input on how this is normally done and
whether there are other (probably obvious) options out there that I need
to look at.

Thanks,
Keith

From mikel at quantecllc.com  Thu Feb 27 14:28:01 2003
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael Luevane)
Date: Thu Feb 27 14:28:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Hotsites/coldsites
In-Reply-To: <20030227215014.GB19560@rauhaus.org>
Message-ID: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOAEMANFAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

Our goal is to have procedures in place so that we can quickly recover from
some event that negatively impacts our ability to do business. It might be
downed phone lines. It might be that our Internet access has been
temporarily cut off. Or it might be that our building was kidnapped by
aliens over the weekend as a prank.

We need to be able to get business up and running in the shortest, most
cost-effective timeframe.

As far as DR facilities in Portland being "too close", if anything happened
to our building that also affected some hotsite in another part of the metro
area, then we'd probably be dead, and it wouldn't matter.

So, I'm looking for something in the Portland area :P

From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Feb 27 16:16:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Thu Feb 27 16:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Hotsites/coldsites
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOAEMANFAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <20030227215014.GB19560@rauhaus.org> <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOAEMANFAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <20030228001531.GC19560@rauhaus.org>

* Michael Luevane <mikel at quantecllc.com> [030227 14:28]:
> Our goal is to have procedures in place so that we can quickly recover from
> some event that negatively impacts our ability to do business. It might be
> downed phone lines. It might be that our Internet access has been
> temporarily cut off. Or it might be that our building was kidnapped by
> aliens over the weekend as a prank.
> 
> We need to be able to get business up and running in the shortest, most
> cost-effective timeframe.
> 
> As far as DR facilities in Portland being "too close", if anything happened
> to our building that also affected some hotsite in another part of the metro
> area, then we'd probably be dead, and it wouldn't matter.
> 
> So, I'm looking for something in the Portland area :P

And that's probably perfectly fine for your needs. I just wanted to point
that for anyone who is doing DR and may need to satisfy formal audit
requirements, it's a whole different story.

--Stafford

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Thu Feb 27 16:34:01 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Thu Feb 27 16:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] long-term data storage
In-Reply-To: <1046380450.18935.298.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302271616070.18838-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

>
> On Thu, 2003-02-27 at 13:04, Terry Layne wrote:
> > Cool.  I just happened to run across a box of old eight track tapes from the
> > late seventies.

Actually, I may have a couple seven track data tapes around someplace.

These were a lot like nine track data tapes, but predate them.  They
go back to the 1960s and 1970s when many computers used 6 bit bytes.

I do recall, someone approaching me in the mid 1980s with a set of
seven track tapes they wanted to read.  At that time, I had a lot of
trouble finding a seven track tape drive to read the tapes.  I finally
found one in Michigan and gave the potential client a quote.
This was more money than the client was able to spend on the project.
However, they said they did want to recover the data and would look
at the project again in a couple years when funding was better.
I never heard from again.  I suspect the data is still being stored
on those seven track tapes somewhere.

                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213
                                          (360) 260-2066 at work
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Feb 27 17:18:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Feb 27 17:18:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] long-term data storage
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302271616070.18838-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302271616070.18838-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <86heap2ogp.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "David" == David Mandel <dmandel at pdxLinux.org> writes:

David> I do recall, someone approaching me in the mid 1980s with a set
David> of seven track tapes they wanted to read.  At that time, I had
David> a lot of trouble finding a seven track tape drive to read the
David> tapes.  I finally found one in Michigan and gave the potential
David> client a quote.  This was more money than the client was able
David> to spend on the project.  However, they said they did want to
David> recover the data and would look at the project again in a
David> couple years when funding was better.  I never heard from
David> again.  I suspect the data is still being stored on those seven
David> track tapes somewhere.

In the early 1990s we had a set of data that originated on 360k
floppies primarily, but that had then been heavily processed by me and
because of their immense size (heh, on the order of 100 megabytes
compressed) and our limited 150 meg harddisk, I had to do a shuffle
to-from tape to do a run through it all.  We had a DC600-style
quarter-inch cartridge tape drive that we stored it on (back in the
archaic DOS days, before I'd found GNU).

Another research group wanted to look at our data, but they couldn't
read our QIC tapes.  All they knew about was 1/2-inch 9-track and
something they called "square tapes", and did all their analysis on
big-iron timesharing systems with SAS.  We shopped around for a
service to copy the data from one to the other, and eventually spent
about $1500 or so to make three copies of 5 9-track reels, and that
was a deal.  Most other outfits were charging multiples of that.  The
next time we needed to do this, we spent a little more, around $3k I
think and _bought_ the drive.  We still have it.  The pisser is the
damned Pertec interface card, which makes the drive almost useless to
us.

The other little anecdote about the data conversion, when the other
group got the data, they spent _hundreds of dollars_ of computer
center account money _just doing a frequency count_ of the data, one
pass through.  They were amazed I was doing this on a PC, probably a
crappy old 20MHz 80386 at the time.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I've seen every kind of critter God ever made,
seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower, more
                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
                                        -- Burl Ives as Rufus Hennessy



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Feb 27 18:40:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Feb 27 18:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mail Network Options
In-Reply-To: <33205.63.105.27.245.1046384461.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
References: <33205.63.105.27.245.1046384461.squirrel@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <1046399941.1839.8.camel@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On Thu, 2003-02-27 at 14:21, Keith Nasman wrote:
> A client of mine is putting in another office location and I am to put in
> a server there. Right now they only have one office (we'll call it
> office1) with a fixed IP and their mail and website are on the
> server(server1) there. I will be installing server2 in office2 on it's own
> fixed-IP DSL line. I'm exploring the different options for delivering mail
> from server1 to server2.
...
> This is my first dealing with multiple physical locations under the same
> domain so I'd like to get more input on how this is normally done and
> whether there are other (probably obvious) options out there that I need
> to look at.

It may be a bit more than you're prepared to do, but the best solution
is to set up an LDAP directory which contains the mailbox routing
information at one site and replicate it to the other site.  You put in
MXs for both servers and let the servers figure out where to deliver it
locally.

You could do a poor-man's version of this with a virtual or canonical
maps and rsync or scp the configuration between the servers.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *
*   My GPG key recently expired.  It's updated on the key    *
*   servers.  Please update if you're using GPG/PGP.         *

Dave Poirier and I talked to to the article's author for 20 minutes a 
couple weeks back about the K12LTSP lab we put in over the winter holiday.

Our middle school students are rapidly getting proficient w/ OpenOffice, 
Mozilla, et al.

great. Our other schools are interested in deploying K12LTSP labs also.

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Fri Feb 28 13:42:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Fri Feb 28 13:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] long-term data storage
In-Reply-To: <86heap2ogp.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302281325480.26589-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

Russell,

    Your posting brings back many fond memories of floppies and
tapes of all sorts - even paper tape.  And of projects where one
hoped to process a tape per day and the total number of data tapes
was in the hundreds.

    For the record, I still have a usable DC600 style tape drive.
As I recall, mine will handle tapes up to 250 mb, but I may be wrong.
It may be limited to 150 mb.  I don't recall for sure.

    By the way, did anyone ever use Everex software with these drives.
The software was pretty and very fast compared with Unix drivers for the
same tape drives. The Everex system looked good and a lot of people used
it.  Unfortunately, Everex obtained their speed by accepting errors.
These tapes were very reliable under most any Unix OS, but rather iffy
using Everex on DOS systems.

                                                   Dave Mandel

From jelque at feather.net  Fri Feb 28 14:24:01 2003
From: jelque at feather.net (Jeff Blain)
Date: Fri Feb 28 14:24:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GNOME2 Background
In-Reply-To: <20030224012110.C38D1C5CC@max.seansdomain.org>
References: <20030224012110.C38D1C5CC@max.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <20030228222341.GA8879@blain.org>

On Sun, Feb 23, 2003 at 05:21:10PM -0800, Sean Whitney wrote:
> This script seems to have made a lot of my MAC and Windows user friends 
> envious of linux.
 
Nice work. 

It took me a few minutes to debug my copy/paste line wrap problem, and
realize I didn't have xplanet installed. Even my feable brain made it
work, and my kids love it. Maybe you should put it on freshmeat, or send
it to SEUL to include with their educational work.

Thanks,

Jeff


> #!/bin/sh
> rm /tmp/xplanet-*.jpg;
> FNAME=xplanet-`date +%s`.jpg &&
>  
> find ~/.xplanet -name clouds_2000.jpg -cmin +180 -exec rm {} \;
> cd ~/.xplanet
>  
> if  ! [ -f clouds_2000.jpg ]; then
>         wget -t0 -c -np -nd http://xplanet.lightbearer.com/clouds_2000.jpg
>         xplanet -image earth.jpg -cloud_image clouds_2000.jpg  -shade 100 
> -output day-clouds.jpg -geometry 1600x1200
>         xplanet -image night.jpg -cloud_image clouds_2000.jpg    -cloud_shade 
> 30 -output night-clouds.jpg -geometry 1600x1200
> fi
> nice -n19 xplanet -mapdir ~/.xplanet/ -image day-clouds.jpg -night_image 
> night-clouds.jpg -blend -output /tmp/$FNAME -geometry 1600x1200 -proj 
> rectangular  &&
> gconftool-2 -t string -s /desktop/gnome/background/picture_filename 
> /tmp/$FNAME
> 
> 
> Combine this script with  
> 
> */5     *       *       *       *       /home/sean/bin/xplanetbg-gnome > 
> /dev/null 2>&1
> 
> 
> Works great.  I'm sure this script could be cleaned up a little.
> 
> Sean
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Feb 28 18:30:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Feb 28 18:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: hardware problem
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302281823090.10571-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  We tried to use the second host today (hostname = caddis), but could not
get a login prompt on the monitor. The monitor status light showed red
(sleeping) and moving the trackball or pressing a key did not turn the light
green and wake it up. I turned off the monitor, then turned it back on. The
status light flashed green, I heard a relay click, the light turned red
again.

  Before concluding that the monitor died I dug out the little monitor I use
on the firewall box when rebooting it and connected that to the system.
Turning on the monitor resulted in the status light coming on -- yellow, or
receiving no signal. Tried a couple of times.

  Seems to me that the video card died. Is this a reasonable conclusion?
It's an ATI Xpert2000 that I purchased Nov. 30th last year. Could the card
have died in only three months? I suppose that's not unusual, but it's never
happened to me. The failure of the card that replaced was the first video
card failure I've experienced in 19 years of owning microcomputers.

  What say you all?

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Feb 28 19:07:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Feb 28 19:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: hardware problem
In-Reply-To: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C03CCBD4D@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302281856120.10605-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 28 Feb 2003, Petcher, Danielx J wrote:

> ANY hardware can fail.

Daniel,

  This I know; at least with vacuum tubes it was easy to tell a dead one
(and I had a tube tester, too). From the time the transitor was first introduced
the mantra was that solid-state devices would fail quickly or last for
years. I guess I have been lucky to not experience the quick failure before
now.

  What I asked, poorly and in a round-about way, was if there was something
other than the video card that might be responsible for the lack of signal
to the monitor.

> I usually find that it fails under stress. (Not stress to the equipment;
> stress to the operators.) :-)

  That's why the equipment gives up on a Friday or a weekend. I had a power
supply quit on a Saturday afternoon. For better or worse, Fry's was the only
place open, they had one, and I made the trip there that evening.

  Just before a cross-country trip years ago (to go overseas for a job) I
had my vehicle completely serviced. The shop didn't tighten the drain plug
on the transmission. The plug fell out and cooked the gears in western
Nebraska -- just before 5 pm on a Friday evening. That was quite a painful
experience for me, my son and the dogs (with a car packed full for our
journey). Also, a very expensive experience. Yup. Always at the worst
possible time.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

On Fri, 2003-02-28 at 22:06, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 28 Feb 2003, Petcher, Danielx J wrote:
> 
> > ANY hardware can fail.
> 
> Daniel,
> 
>   This I know; at least with vacuum tubes it was easy to tell a dead one
> (and I had a tube tester, too). From the time the transitor was first introduced
> the mantra was that solid-state devices would fail quickly or last for
> years. I guess I have been lucky to not experience the quick failure before
> now.
> 
>   What I asked, poorly and in a round-about way, was if there was something
> other than the video card that might be responsible for the lack of signal
> to the monitor.

> > stress to the operators.) :-)

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Feb 28 21:26:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Feb 28 21:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: hardware problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302281823090.10571-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0302282120060.12507-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Fri, 28 Feb 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

> We tried to use the second host today (hostname = caddis), but could
> not get a login prompt on the monitor.

Does this mean that you were able to get a login prompt over the 
network?

If the machine is functional other than the video console, I'd say 
your assumption that the issue is the frame buffer is one of the 
things I'd troubleshoot. Here's the whole list:

* if the frame buffer isn't built in to the mainboard, remove and 
  reseat it, making an effort to blow dust out of its agp or pci
  socket and to clean the contacts on the card,

* try the card in another slot, if possible,

* try a known good card in the slot in question,

* try the "bad" card in another host.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
